Africa News


January 1, 1997


Cape Verde;
Cape Verde Makes Progress In Family Health


BYLINE: Mamadou Amath, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

PRAIA, Cape Verde (PANA) - In spite of its poverty, Cape Verde says that over two decades it has been able to halve its child mortality rate with the introduction of a Child and Maternal Health care program.

The director of social development in the archipelago's health ministry, Dr Frutuoso Carvalho, says poverty prompted the government to opt for a policy of protecting the society's "most vulnerable groups."

Official statistics show that 30 percent of Cape Verde's 433,000 population are poor, while 14 percent are considered to be very poor.

Of the total population, 52 percent live in Praia, the capital, which is located on the main island of Santiago. 

Even before 1995, when Cape Verde adopted its national population policy, the government had committed resources to protecting the family.

This support has taken the form of a maternal and infant protection program which was initiated in 1977 by a non-governmental organization. With government backing, the program have now been extended to all the islands in the archipelago with satisfactory results.

"At least all health centres offer child and maternal health services," says Djamila Cabral Afonso, the executive director of the Cape Verdian Family Protection Association, or Verdefam.

Consequently, the isles infant mortality has been slashed by 50 percent in 20 years.

Some 25 percent of women within the procreation age bracket use contraceptives. This has led to a reduction in female fertility from more than seven children per woman a few years ago to five.

As a result, Cape Verde's has been able to hold population growth to around 2 percent per annum.

The progress achieved, so far, may be attributed to the short distances Cape Verdians need to walk to receive adequate medical care. Eighty percent of the population is located within an hour's walk from a dispensary.

Notwithstanding these achievements and the fact that abortion has been legal since 1986, the problem of youth reproductive health continues to be a major worry for officials.

For a long time, the health of adolescents was neglected as more attention was directed at mothers and children. But that is changing now as officials concentrate on the youth.

One major problems, health officials say, is that people in their early teens are sexually active. The officials told visiting journalists in October that this phenomenon was unsurprising since 30 percent of the women head their families. This is so because at least half the population lives abroad.

A number of non-governmental organizations have joined with the government to combat the free sexual morality among teenagers. They have formulated radio sex education slogans which are aired several times a day.

"Your health, it is your responsibility, protect it," says one of the messages

Verdefam, now two years old, has created two youth information centers where teenagers can discuss their problems with qualified officials. However, neither many youths are visiting these centers nor frequently.

Despite the availability of legal abortions in virtually all hospitals and health centers, abortions are still performed secretly by unqualified medical personnel.

Legal abortion has attracted as sharp criticism from the church.

"Human life needs to be defended on all occasions because it is the most sacred thing we possess," says Roman Catholic Rev. Arlindo Gomes Furtado of Our Lady's Parish in Praia.

His preference is for love to be consummated "within a spirit of communion and particularly within the security of a home."

Furtado says he strongly opposes the use of condoms which he describes as " a mechanical instrument and a foreign body" in the sexual act, which is "very important, very intimate and total" to the couple.

He says the condom should only be employed if one of the partners is sick and could infect the other.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 1, 1997


Uganda;
Uganda Has Appalling Teenage Pregnancy Rates


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Uganda stands as the sub-Sahara African country with the highest teenage pregnancy levels, the government says.

The Statistics Department of the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning released this in a Demographic and Health Survey conducted in 1995.

The survey, whose results were officially released recently, shows that patterns of high fertility associated with "low contraceptive use are rooted to teenage years of Ugandan women." 

Supporting this finding, on Dec, 27 1996, the Center for Development and Population Activities in Washington D.C. said: "overall, 43 percent of teenagers have begun childbearing, a disturbing finding because of its association with high morbidity and mortality for both the mother and child."

The survey covered 7,070 women aged 15-49 years and 1,996 men aged 15-59 years and was financed by the United States Agency for International Development. Its objective was to obtain information on levels and trends of fertility, family planning knowledge and use, infant and child mortality and maternal and child health.

The survey establishes that the relatively high level of fertility is due, partly, to an early start in unprotected sexual activity.

"By age 15, almost one third (30 percent) of girls have already had their first sexual intercourse," it says.

By age 18 years, it says, 52 percent of girls and 64 percent by age 19 years have had sex.

In addition, 93 percent of teenagers (15-19 years) are not using any methods of contraception.

However, fertility in Uganda has declined slightly from 7.1 births per women over the last two decades to 6.9 births per woman for the period 1992- 94.

"If unwanted births could be avoided, the total fertility rate would be 5.6 children per woman," the survey says.

Among the women, 15 percent of those married do not use contraceptives. Of these, 8 percent using modern ones while 7 percent were using traditional birth control methods.

Among the men, 10 percent use modern contraceptives and 15 traditional ones.

The survey shows that periodic abstinence remains the most popular method of control for both men (11 percent) and women (4 percent).

On sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), 6 percent of the men and 4 percent of the women interviewed reported having had a STD in the year prior to the survey.

"One third of both men and women who declared having STD took no action at all, while two thirds if men and three quarters of women sought treatment," it says.

While the survey reveals that virtually all men and women in Uganda know of AIDS, "yet, over 3 percent of women and 11 percent of men had not changed their sexual behavior."

The most common change for both men (55 percent) and women (53 percent) is the restriction of sexual activity to one partner.

Uganda is one of the states in east and central Africa most affected by the AIDS pandemic. At least 15 percent of Uganda's population of about 20 million live with HIV, the virus that causes the incurable acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

However, a vigorous anti-AIDS educational campaign under the government of President Yoweri Museveni has stabilized the spread of the virus.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 1, 1997


Tunisia;
Two Opposition Leaders Released For Health Reasons


BYLINE: Ali Dellali, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Two leaders of the Movement of Democrats and Socialists (MDS), the main opposition party in Tunisia, were released from prison conditionally Tuesday for health reasons, reports say reaching Tripoli from Tunis.

Under the law this means that Mohamed Moada, a university lecturer and former chairman of the party, and Khmayis Chammari, a MDS member of parliament, cannot regain all their civic and political rights. 

Moada, 58, were sentenced to 11 years imprisonment 15 months ago for spying for Libya.

Khmayis Chammari, 53, was serving a five-year term after being sentenced eight months ago for revealing secrets on the legal investigation into the spy case.

Both men have been on hunger strike since September 1996 to protest the deterioration of their health.

Humanitarian organizations joined the call for the men's release, saying that their imprisonment was politically motivated.

Tunisia denied this. Authorities said that both men were sentenced under common law.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


4 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 1, 1997


South Africa;
Opposition Slams South African Government


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's opposition National Party (NP) has accused President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) Government of steadily losing its grip on the country.

In his new year's message to South Africans on Tuesday, NP leader Frederik de Klerk, claimed numerous government failures and warned South Africans that they would soon experience enormous disappointment with the Mandela government. 

"The impression of a ship drifting downstream, apparently rudderless, is constantly compounded," De Klerk Said.

He claimed that the government had failed to keep its promises on education, health, reconstruction and development, and privatization in 1996, and also highlighted the country's surging crime wave.

De Klerk, the country's last president, said local corporations had warned throughout the year that vehicle hijacking and armed robbery were spinning out of control, and were becoming a serious deterrent to foreign investment.

He also cited as ominous signs the plunge in the value of the South African rand, which dropped 30 percent against the United States dollar in 1996, and the continuing white brain drain.

"The ANC displays a lack of vision for the country and for itself, and is in the grip of an identity crisis which is harming the country," De Klerk said.

"The National Party is prepared to do its part through political cooperation," De Klerk added, "but also through fearless criticism."

The white-led National Party -- which for decades in power practiced stringent racially discriminatory policies against blacks and other peoples of color -- withdrew from South Africa's Government of National Unity earlier in 1996, citing irreconcilable differences over the country's new constitution as the main reason.

Africa News


January 1, 1997


Southern Africa;
COMESA Drops UAPTA Travellers Cheques


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Committee of the Common Market of the Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) Central Bank Governors has decided to end sale of Preferential Trade Area (PTA) travellers cheques in all member countries with immediate effect.

However, the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe said travellers who had bought these cheques before December 31, 1996, would still be able to cash them in 1997. 

The decision to cease use of the cheques was reached in November 1996 at the governor's annual meeting in Maputo, Mozambique, following careful consideration of an independent report carried out by the firm, Coopers and Lybrand.

"The study established that although PTA travellers cheques had been of great benefit in promoting travel and... trade in the COMESA region during the pre-liberilisation era, their usefulness and level of utilisation had continued to decline as a result of the liberilisation process now taking place in all member countries," the Central Bank said.

The governors also resolved that the PTA Bank, in consultation with commercial banks and other economic operators would, in the future, examine the possibility of transforming the nature and ownership of the travellers cheque instrument into a regional credit card.

A decision is still to be made on the proposal presented to the governors after a series of comprehensive consultations.

There are 20 states within COMESA but Mozambique announced Tuesday it was withdrawing from the grouping.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


6 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 1, 1997


Nigeria;
Commonwealth Chides Nigeria On Military Rule


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Commonwealth Secretary-General Emeka Anyaoku has said the organization had succeeded in forcing member countries to respect democracy and the rule of law, but expressed concern about the delay by Nigeria to end military rule and release all political prisoners.

In his new year message, Anyaoku also listed other achievements made by the Commonwealth during 1996. These included the successful transition in Sierra Leone from military to civilian rule. 

Others were the launching of a fund for private sector investment in Commonwealth member countries and joint support by the organization, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to alleviate the debt burden on developing countries.

On Nigeria, Anyaoku said the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group, set up to monitor human rights, would continue to follow closely, that country's efforts to achieve democracy and greater respect for human rights in the country.

"Nigeria, which was suspended from Commonwealth membership by heads of government in New Zealand in 1995, remained a source of concern for the group, " he said.

Nigeria was suspended from the body after the execution of nine rights activists from the minority Ogoni people, among them the author, Ken Saro- Wiwa.

The hangings sparked a storm of international protests and the Nigerian authorities were accused of holding an unfair trial on trumped-up murder charges.

However, the Commonwealth has been criticized for not taking tougher sanctions against the military leadership in Nigeria.

In December, the Nigerian opposition coalition accused a the Commonwealth's Action Group of failing in its mission to the country and propping up the military government.

The group's mission, which visited the country for 48 hours, met with Nigerian leader Gen. Sani Abacha, leaders of five registered political parties as well as representatives of transition agencies.

But there were no meetings with political detainees or the opposition.

Anyaoku, a Nigerian, welcomed democratic developments in various Commonwealth countries, such as Ghana, where free and fair presidential and parliamentary elections were held early December.

"There will, therefore, be no room for complacency; we must remain ever alert to the needs of our members and defend the values which we stand for and support," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

7 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 2, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Teenage Pregnancy Home Rescues Jilted Pregnant Girls in Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Dorcas Chirambwe PANA Corespondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Tsitsi, a 16-year-old Zimbabwean girl, is already expecting a baby.

But the child mother-to-be is not relishing the prospect of bringing a new life into a society she now feels has no mercy for its vulnerable members.

Tsitsi, which ironically means "mercy", was recently thrown out of the family home by her parents when they discovered she was pregnant. Her boyfriend denied responsibility for the pregnancy. 

At this tender and impressionable age, Tsitsi has suffered mental trauma. She has to cope with rejection from her parents, boyfriend and society at large.

"I feel so used and humiliated," she says, stifling tears. "The father of my unborn baby has refused responsibility and every one thinks I have loose morals, yet he forced me into it. This is very unfair and I do not even know where to start from."

Tsitsi has now been forced to lead a life of begging on the streets of Mutare, Zimbabwe's third city on the border with Mozambique.

At times the girl gets a small allowance and food rations from the government's department of social welfare, but this is very little to meet all her needs.

She really has no choice but to live on whatever she lays her hands on.

However, a helping hand is emerging for girls in Tsitsi's predicament, at least in Mutare.

An association of women from inter-denominational Christian groups, which include the Catholic, Anglican and Methodist churches, has come to the rescue of girls like Tsitsi by setting up the Hagar Girls Home which opened early in 1996.

The home, which accommodates jilted girls, also provides counselling services, skills training and tries to reconcile the girls with their families.

Services of a legal adviser are offered to try and have the responsible father pay maintenance.

Chairperson of the association, Margaret Machinga, says the establishment of the home was sparked by the alarming rate at which teenage pregnancies were rising in the city.

"Our association decided to temporarily shelter the girls for at least a year while efforts to reconcile them with their families are made, instead of having the victims loitering around helplessly," she says.

Machinga says the objective was to reduce baby dumping, abortion and other problems associated with teenage pregnancies.

"During the period that the girls will be at the home we hope to equip them with motherhood and self-sustaining skills in preparation for responsibility," she says.

"The problem of young pregnant girls exists especially among those of school-going age who are rejected by society and are left stranded and at times homeless. In most cases the male will still be of school-going age or married, in which case the girl resorts to baby dumping, suicide, backyard abortion or becoming a street kid."

The home, currently sheltering three expectant child mothers, relies on donations from members of the association, the social welfare department and other organizations.

Although it can accommodate a maximum of eight girls, the home currently has limited facilities and authorities are appealing to well-wishers and companies in Manicaland province to help by donating in cash or kind.

The child mothers-to-be are already partly self-sustaining. They grow vegetables for their own use and sale to the local community.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 2, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
World Bank Unveils Anti-Poverty Plan For Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The World Bank has unveiled a new plan aimed at helping the sub-Saharan Africa fight poverty.

The plan is contained in the bank's report entitled "Taking action to reduce poverty in sub-Saharan Africa", just published. 

The plan includes the need to increase focus on rural development, a concerted effort to organise macroeconomic policy and public expenditure, a systematic assessment of project investments to determine if they might be carried out by the private sector and continuing support of collaborative research.

The sub-Saharan region lags behind other regions because of political instability, weak state institutions, ineffective policies as well as low productivity in agriculture.

While East Asians increased their gross domestic product by 900 U.S. dollars and South Asians by 420 dollars between 1970 and 1992, Africans saw an increase of only 73 dollars.

And where South Asians could expect to see their 59th birthday and Latin Americans their 68th, life expectancy in Africa was about 51 years.

Sub-Saharan Africa had also the lowest primary school enrolment and the highest infant mortality rate of any other region in the developing world.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 2, 1997


Mozambique;
More Mozambicans Work In South African Mines


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The number of Mozambicans working in South African mines rose from 55,000 in 1995 to 57,000 in 1996, according to Mozambican Labor Minister Guilherme Mavila, cited in Thursday's issue of the daily paper "Noticias".

Mavila said this is a reversal of a trend over the past two decades and was "against all expectations".

The wages of migrant miners are an important source of foreign exchange for the Mozambican economy. For almost a century, southern Mozambique has been regarded as a labor reserve for South Africa, and prior to independence in 1975 more than 100,000 Mozambicans worked in South African gold and coal mines. 

One of the economic aspects of the apartheid regime's destabilization of Mozambique was the sharp reduction in the number of Mozambicans recruited to the mines in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

While Mavila was pleased at the 1996 increase in Mozambican miners, he criticized the South African authorities for their discriminatory attitude towards migrants infected with the HIV virus that causes AIDS.

He confirmed that there have been cases of Mozambican miners expelled from South Africa because they tested HIV-positive. This was against the norms of the International Labor Organization, Mavila pointed out, which stress there should be no discrimination at the workplace against people infected with HIV.

HIV/AIDS is not a danger to other workers, since it can only be transmitted sexually or through contaminated blood. Mavila noted that the South Africans had not taken similar measures in the case of outbreaks of genuinely infectious diseases on the mines, such as meningitis, in which deaths had occurred.

Mavila said the agreement on migrant labor between Mozambique and South Africa will shortly be revised. The agreement dates back to 1964 and was the work of the Portuguese colonial regime and the apartheid authorities.

One of the aspects that the South Africans want to scrap is the system of " deferred pay". Under this system, the miners only receive 45 per cent of their wages in South Africa: the rest is sent to Mozambique, where the miners can pick it up on their return. The money is sent to the Mozambican authorities in South African rands - a convertible currency - but the miners receive in the non-convertible local currency, the metical.

Mavila defended this system on the grounds that the forced transfer of wages to Mozambique was a way of helping miners save, and it ensured benefits for their families. If this system were abolished, all the money would be likely to remain in South Africa, he warned.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 2, 1997


Libya;
Eight Libyans Sentenced To Death For Treason


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Six Libyan soldiers and two civilians have been sentenced to death for treason and dealing secretly with agents of foreign governments, Libya's national television reported Wednesday. 

They were tried by a court-martial for being members of a banned organization that has relations with foreign governments and for divulging state secrets.

They were also charged of trying to overthrow the government of Col. Moammar Kadhafi and destabilize the country.

The court, however, released six other soldiers and two civilians, also involved in the same case.

All the 16, who were arrested in March 1994, belong to the Ourfalla tribe, based in Beni Oualid, some 200 km south-east of Tripoli.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

11 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa: Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - A old year is gone, a new year is born and with this transition African newspapers commented on the past and their hopes for the future.

The Senegalese daily, Sud Quotidien, viewed the new year with gloom because of Africa's wars in Angola, Central African Republic, the Great lakes, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Somalia.

"Just as with a woman in labor, it is difficult to predict what Africa's present hardships will lead to," it said. "But one can still hope that Africa might emerge from this situation and give brighter prospects for its children. " Africa's wars, it said, were the result of the bygone East-West ideological rivalry. However, it added: "It is up to men of goodwill to do their best so that the operation (for peace) succeeds. Africa has many such men. Herein lies its treasure, so does its future." Algerian papers confined their views to domestic concerns. La Liberte described the past year as one of "tragedies and disillusionment." For example it said, despite government's optimism, acts of terrorism still occur and recent attacks were a "glaring example" of this. 

Turning to the economy, the newspaper said that the year had been one in which the public's purchasing power had deteriorated to the point that working class families were living in misery.

In the political arena, La Liberte said the public was disillusioned because the presidential election failed to bring with it an end to the violence in the country.

Le Matin wrote in the same vein.

"Algerians were expecting improvement in their living conditions. They are disappointed. It is as well to ask ourselves what 1997 will bring," it said.

"Another electoral year, perhaps a year full of dangers, of fireworks -- in the literal sense," it said.

Al-Watan, another Algerian paper, was also critical of the government's censorship of the press. Government, it said, had resorted to censorship in the name of fighting Islamic militancy but behind government's action was that harsh reality of "strict management" of society.

"There is very little room left for optimism," it said.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

12 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ghana Stock Exchange Opens Year Quietly


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Shares on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) ended the first trading in the year Thursday on a quiet note as the holiday mood continued to weigh down the market.

The GSE All-Share Index shed 0.62 points to 360.14 points, down from its previous 360.76 points.

Three equities recorded price changes, two gainers and one decliner. 

Market capitalization also slipped to 2,596.29 billion cedis, down from Monday's 2,597.21 billion cedis close.

Total shares offered settled at 1,238,410 against bids of 552,410 with a moderate volume of 532,010 changing hands compared to the meager 28,910 traded on Monday.

On the broader market, Unilever (UNIL) went down by 20 cedis to 780 cedis. Social Security Bank (SSB) edged up three cedis to 1,060, while Pioneer Tobacco Company (PTC) gained two cedis to 135 cedis.

Market players say that "business as usual is slow to take off just after the Christmas and New Year holidays."

However, they said there was hope that the market would heat up in the coming weeks on clearer direction of the economy.

GSE Managing Director Yeboah Amoa predicted Thursday a buoyant stock market operation in 1997.

He said the development and installation of the latest technology of an automated central clearing system, new products such as the HFC Dollar Index Bonds and upgrading of the skills of market operators, were signs that the market would perform better.

"With this development, the GSE will soon become one of the best in Africa and the world at large," he told the Ghana News Agency in Accra.

The GSE sold 35.7 million shares in 1996 valued at 27.8 billion cedis as against 55.8 million shares valued at 27.08 billion cedis in 1995.

"This phenomenon is indicative of the fact that share values of listed equities are appreciating," he said. "With improvement in the fight against inflation, we have seen share prices appreciate."

He said even though the GSE All-Share Index registered a growth of 13.82 percent in 1996 as against 6.33 percent in 1995, there was a negative growth in real terms.

"This is still lower than the interest rate and it affects the market's operations," he said.

The market, he added, was now safer with the right legal environment and appropriate technology. He said a Security Regulation Commission (SRC) equipped with highly trained staff was being developed to enforce integrity on the market.

However, he said, even without the SRC the market had worked with controls.

He said companies listed on the stock market received additional premium and tax holidays as incentives. The listing of Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC), which holds about 90 percent of the GSE's capitalization, had added momentum and a reputation to the exchange.

"It has expanded the GSE's Market Capitalization. However, it must not be taken as being responsible for the total performance of the market as the market can still perform better without it," he said.

The following were the closing prices Thursday of listed equities quoted in cedis (1 U.S. dollar = 1,727.18 cedis): (ST) ABL 576 AGC 22,500 ALW 1,415 CFAO 20 EIC 430 FML 404 GCB 701 GGL 275 HFC 136 KBL 660 MGL 150 MLC 53 MOGL 5, 900 PAF 171 PTC 135 '2 PZ 370 SCB 5,000 SPPC 112 SSB 1,060 '3 UNIL 780 -20 UTC-E 50 (ET)

Africa News


January 3, 1997


Science and Health;
Cholera Killed 5,000 In Africa Last Year


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Cholera killed 5,000 of the 80,000 people infected in 26 African countries last year, the United Nations agency, the World Health Organization, said.

The agency's Africa office, in Brazzaville, said that Cholera was particularly severe in Sahelian countries of Africa and in several others in Central Africa. The most affected states were Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Niger and Benin.

The head of the agency's Epidemics Division, Dr Antoine Kabore, told a news conference in Brazzavile on Thursday that the infection rate of cholera was 6 percent.

"We should reduce the rate further," he said.

Kabore said the re-emergence of cholera aggravated the already deplorable health situation in sub-Sahara Africa, except South Africa. Besides cholera, meningitis and measles were the other epidemics which erupted in several African states.

However, the most fatal epidemic was the ebola virus-caused haemorrhagic fever in Gabon which killed 39 of the 52 cases diagnosed in 1996.

The disease also surfaced for the first time in Libreville, the Gabonese capital in December 1996, where it killed two people who had direct contact with ebola virus victims in northeastern Gabon.

However, Kabore said the disease was contained rapidly with assistance from the U.N. agency.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

14 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
OAU Examining Africa Peace Force


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim said Friday that the continental body was seriously considering creating a peacekeeping force.

In a news conference in Dar Es Salaam reviewing African events during 1996, he said the force could be created in a few months. 

He said the lack of resources had contributed to the delay in the force's creation. He would not disclose the projected strength of the proposed force nor the amount of money needed to support it.

If established, he said, each O.A.U. member country would be required to train a unit of its army in techniques of solving conflicts. The units would have to be ready for deployment on request.

A continental force, he said, would have helped solve numerous conflicts in Africa like the one currently unfolding in eastern Zaire.

Salim, who is on a six-day tour of Tanzania, said that political conflicts were among the most disturbing events which had occurred in Africa in 1996.

He described as positive, the United States idea of creating an African force, now under consideration by the O.A.U. The idea has been supported by France which has often intervened on the continent in support of governments in several of its former colonies.

However, Salim said the O.A.U. would only take the U.S idea's practical aspects, without allowing the force to become "a source of problems in the future."

The U.S. idea, which the outgoing U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher tried to sell to African leaders in 1996, was met with mixed reaction during his African tour.

South Africa, which would likely be a key player in such a body, was initially lukewarm to the idea.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

15 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Tunisia's Benrekhissa Dies In Friendly Game


BYLINE: Bouazza Ben Bouazza, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 725 words


 

TUNIS, Tunisia (PANA) - Tunisian international defender Hed Benrekhissa of Esperance Sportive Tunis died Saturday after colliding with an opponent in a friendly match against Olympique Lyonnais, a first division French soccer team.

Medical officials said that Benrekhissa, 26, died of a stroke despite frantic efforts to save him at a nearby clinic. 

The daily Tunis newspaper, Le Temps, said Benrekhissa "fell during injury time and remained unconscious until his transfer to the clinic where he died around 0820 gmt.

Benrekhissa, who was elected the Arab player of the year in 1993, was regarded as a center-piece of Esperance Tunis, the oldest and most crowned team in Tunisia.

Tunisian supporters will always remember Benrekhissa's splendid goal against Zamalek of Egypt in the African Champions' Cup final won by Esperance in 1994.

His sudden death has been felt severely in the Tunisian sporting world.

Tunisian President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali sent a message of condolences to the player's family, expressing his "deep shock" at the tragic death.

A seasoned international, the talented right back, Benrekhissa was part of the Tunisian team which finished runners-up in the 20th African Cup of Nations in 1996 behind hosts South Africa.

With Esperance, Benrekhissa won the African Champions' Cup, the African Super Cup, the Arab Super Cup and the Afro-Asian Club Cup.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 6, 1997


Ghana;
Ghana's Rawlings Takes Oath Tuesday


BYLINE: Frank Agyekum, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Jerry John Rawlings is to be inaugurated on Tuesday in Accra as the first incumbent Ghanaian head of state to be re-elected since the country became independent from Britain nearly three decades ago.

Ghana became the first black African country to become independent on March 6, 1957. 

For Rawlings and his political party, the National Democratic Congress (NDC) , the scene will be a familiar one, having undergone a similar process in 1992 when they won power as the first government of the Fourth Republic.

In 1992, the NDC swept into the House with 188 seats after some opposition parties boycotted the parliamentary elections. The significant opposition was National Convention Party, which obtained eight seats, while the Eagle Party got one seat. Three other seats went to independent candidates.

All that is set to change this time with a better showing of the opposition in the December 1996 parliamentary elections.

Although the NDC still has a majority with 133 seats, which is just about two-thirds of the House, it will face strong challenge from 60 parliamentarians who belong to the New Patriotic Party, five from the People's Convention Party and one from the People's National Convention.

For Rawlings, it will set him up as the longest reigning head of state since independence. By the time his next four-year term ends, he would have ruled for 19 years, 11 of them as military ruler.

Ghana's first president, Kwame Nkrumah, ruled for nine years, while Gen. J. A. Ankrah and Lt.- Gen. A.A. Afrifa ruled for less than three years between them. Kofi Abrefa Busia (two-and-a-half years), Gen. Ignatius Kutu Acheampong (seven years), and Hilla Limann, two-and-a- half years.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 6, 1997


Somalia;
Banana Revenue Fuelling War In Mogadishu


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Twenty six Somali political groups have accused the faction led by Hussein Aideed, the son of the late Gen. Mohamed Farah Aideed, of using funds secured from banana production and marketing to fuel the war in Mogadishu.

The groups, which concluded eight weeks of talks last Friday at a Sodere resort center in Ethiopia, 125 km south-east of Addis Ababa, accused Hussein and his late father of illegally levying taxes and service charges on local banana growers, to secure funds to prolong the civil war.

The accusation is contained in a resolution titled "The role of bananas in the war in Somalia" released in Addis Ababa on Monday, three days after the political groups signed a peace agreement. 

The groups identified the money earned from bananas as "the main cause for the prolongation of the war and the suffering of our people in Mogadishu and the adjacent areas."

The Aideed faction was not represented at the Nov. 22 to Jan. 3 talks.

The meeting's objective was to bring about an all-inclusive provisional government in Somalia, which has had no recognized authority since the fall of the late President Siad Barre's regime six years ago.

The resolution strongly condemned what it termed as the "outrageous conducts and abuse of banana funds for detrimental purposes against the interests of the Somali people."

It appealed to the European Union (EU) and other concerned parties, in particular the Italian government, to desist from supporting Somali individuals that had secured illegal banana concessions and their parent companies abroad.

These were identified as the "Sombana" which has ties with the Italian firm "Denadai" and the American company, Dole.

The resolution urged the EU, the Italian government and others to refrain from "serious breaches of the banana industry and business norms and procedures, and to review their concessions and financial backing."

The political groups asked those firms to "consult and negotiate in due course with the newly established National Salvation Council of Somalia, on the question of banana production and business."


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 6, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. & Senegal Discuss African Reaction Force


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The deputy commander of the United States forces in Europe, Gen. James Jamerson, arrived Dakar Sunday for talks with Senegal on her participation in the Washington-proposed African Rapid Reaction Force for settling conflicts on the continent.

"I am ready to talk and listen to all of Senegal's suggestions...on the configuration of the African Reaction Force," he said, as reported Monday by the government daily newspaper, Le Soleil.

Jamerson is in Dakar for a two-day official visit. He said Senegal would have to determine the strength and conditions under which her soldiers would serve in the proposed 10,000-strong force. 

The Senegalese news agency, APS, reported Monday that Ethiopia, Mali, Senegal, Tunisia and Uganda had confirmed, in writing, their willingness to provide troops for the force.

However, it did not say to whom this confirmation was made: whether it was to the Organization of African Unity, United Nations or the United States Government. The objective of the force would be to provide Africa with a short-term capability to tackle a massive humanitarian crisis. The force would be trained and equipped by the U.S. It would cost between 25 million and 40 million dollars.

In October 1996, the outgoing U.S. Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, made a week-long visit five African states, seeking support for the force.

Ethiopia, the headquarters of the Organization of African Unity, asked Christopher to consult with the continental body, Africa's foremost political grouping. South Africa said the proposal was best tabled before the United Nations.

In a news conference in Dar Es Salaam on Friday, O.A.U. Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, said the organization was seriously considering the creation of its own peacekeeping force.

This O.A.U. force, which would comprise military units of all member states and would come under the control and command of the body, appears different from the U.S. proposal.

Salim described as positive the U.S. proposal, but said that the O.A.U. would only adopt the practical aspects of the U.S. idea, without allowing the O.A.U. force to become "a source of problems in the future."


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 6, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Tunisia's Benrekhissa Dies In Friendly Game


BYLINE: Bouazza Ben Bouazza, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

TUNIS, Tunisia (PANA) - Tunisian international defender Hed Benrekhissa of Esperance Sportive Tunis died Saturday after colliding with an opponent in a friendly match against Olympique Lyonnais, a first division French soccer team.

Medical officials said that Benrekhissa, 26, died of a stroke despite frantic efforts to save him at a nearby clinic. 

The daily Tunis newspaper, Le Temps, said Benrekhissa "fell during injury time and remained unconscious until his transfer to the clinic where he died around 0820 gmt.

Benrekhissa, who was elected the Arab player of the year in 1993, was regarded as a center-piece of Esperance Tunis, the oldest and most crowned team in Tunisia.

Tunisian supporters will always remember Benrekhissa's splendid goal against Zamalek of Egypt in the African Champions' Cup final won by Esperance in 1994.

His sudden death has been felt severely in the Tunisian sporting world.

Tunisian President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali sent a message of condolences to the player's family, expressing his "deep shock" at the tragic death.

A seasoned international, the talented right back, Benrekhissa was part of the Tunisian team which finished runners-up in the 20th African Cup of Nations in 1996 behind hosts South Africa.

With Esperance, Benrekhissa won the African Champions' Cup, the African Super Cup, the Arab Super Cup and the Afro-Asian Club Cup.

LANGUAGE: English

January 6, 1997


Ghana;
Ghana's Rawlings Takes Oath Tuesday


BYLINE: Frank Agyekum, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Jerry John Rawlings is to be inaugurated on Tuesday in Accra as the first incumbent Ghanaian head of state to be re-elected since the country became independent from Britain nearly three decades ago.

Ghana became the first black African country to become independent on March 6, 1957. 

For Rawlings and his political party, the National Democratic Congress (NDC) , the scene will be a familiar one, having undergone a similar process in 1992 when they won power as the first government of the Fourth Republic.

In 1992, the NDC swept into the House with 188 seats after some opposition parties boycotted the parliamentary elections. The significant opposition was National Convention Party, which obtained eight seats, while the Eagle Party got one seat. Three other seats went to independent candidates.

All that is set to change this time with a better showing of the opposition in the December 1996 parliamentary elections.

Ghana's first president, Kwame Nkrumah, ruled for nine years, while Gen. J. A. Ankrah and Lt.- Gen. A.A. Afrifa ruled for less than three years between them. Kofi Abrefa Busia (two-and-a-half years), Gen. Ignatius Kutu Acheampong (seven years), and Hilla Limann, two-and-a- half years.

BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency

LENGTH: 454 words

United States and Africa;
U.S. & Senegal Discuss African Reaction Force

Africa News


January 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Currency: CFA Franc Looses Ground, Cedi Stable


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The CFA franc lost ground on the United States dollar after gaining against the greenback last week in Dakar.

At Dakar's Citibank, the CFA exchanged at 513 (buying) and 543 (selling) to the dollar on Tuesday, as against 509 on December 31 and 510 on December 24.

Meanwhile, the Ghanaian cedi remains stable despite a lack of consensus among Ghanaian dealers on the evaluation of their foreign exchange needs. 

Some were expecting a "stable market", dismissing the likelihood of higher foreign currency demand, the Ghana News Agency, GNA, reported.

The agency said that other dealers reported that rising revenues would allow them to renew their stocks and meet consumer needs.

On Monday in Accra, the cedi rose slightly to exchange at 1,760 (buying) and between 1,750 to 1,800 (selling) to the dollar.

The cedi remains near its level at Dec. 31, 1996, according to the interbank rate made public by the Ghanaian banking association.

The cedi exchanged at 1,726 at the end of 1996 before falling to 1,726.82 (buying) and 1,735.36 (selling) on Jan. 6, 1997 in the Ghanaian capital.

Following are the nominal exchange rates of African currencies against the dollar:

Country Currency Current rate (Previous)

LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


Zambia;
Opposition Criticizes Church Plans To Ordinate President


BYLINE: Modern Bweema, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's opposition alliance of political parties has accused the government of subverting the independence of the country's churches by planning to have President Frederick Chiluba ordained.

Reporting this Tuesday, the Zambian News Agency said that the National Lima Party publicity secretary, Stanfold Hlazo, described the decision by some church leaders as a mockery of the Christian community in Zambia.

Hlazo said that government had wasted a lot of money in donations to ailing churches while the agricultural sector had been hard hit by high prices for fertilizers. 

The chairman of the opposition alliance, Rodger Chongwe, termed some church leaders on Tuesday as hypocrites and accused them of being financially dependent on the state as their sole source of funds and recognition.

Chongwe said the call by some church leaders to ordain Chiluba was also a danger to the development of democracy in Zambia.

Chongwe said the stance by the divisive churches only confirmed the fears of those who opposed the declaration of Zambia as a Christian nation.

"The very fact that Reverend Chintala, a Christian from a born again sect, was appointed to head the church ministry makes us believe that the call to ordain President Chiluba as reverend was conceived inside state house," Chongwe said.

"This is a signal of intensification of religious fundamentalists," Chongwe added.

However, he said it was notable that orthodox churches, like the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of God had not supported calls for Chiluba's ordination.

"President Chiluba has never gone to theological school. How do you ordain him?" Chongwe said.

Chongwe claimed that the state made a priority of subverting the independence of the churches and had done so by providing "huge financial donations" concealed in the treasuries of the churches.

Archbishop John Mambo of the Church of God has dissociated his church from the move to ordain Chiluba. Bishop Mambo has appealed to other church leaders to distinguish between mere politicking and the role of the Church in society.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Judge Releases 53 Suspects, Berates Police


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Lusaka High Court Judge, Justice Kabazo Chanda, released 53 suspected criminals Tuesday, most of them facing charges of aggravated robbery, because they have not been brought for trial since their arrest in 1992.

Chanda freed the suspects and said more would follow if reports prove true that police have been holding many others for years without being brought to court.

The releases were ordered in a special court session to which representatives from the Prison Service, Police and the chambers of the Director of Public Prosecutions were summoned. 

On the occasion, Corporal Ernest Lombe of the Prisons Service said that the suspects were detained between December 15, 1992 and November 29, 1995.

The Lusaka Division Criminal Investigations Officer, Teddy Nondo, blamed magistrates and the suspects for the delays in trials.

Nondo said that there was a tendency for magistrates to sign detention warrants before police had a chance to complete investigations.

He said the Flying Squad of the police and other units just picked up and locked up suspects without first charging them.

Nondo said, also, that some suspects elluded trial by refusing to answer to their names when called for court sessions.

Notwithstanding this, Justice Chanda said there was need to uphold human rights in Zambia because every suspect was innocent until proven guilty.

The suspects clapped, ullulated and sang hymns to praise to God and Justice Chanda for their freedom.

"The state has no evidence before you and that is why they have kept you for five years in prison," he said, "but do me one favour; do not go back and commit other crimes." Chanda said.

However, he warned that suspects would be re-arrested if police establish that they committed a crime. At the same time, he told police not to defy his order by re-arresting the suspects immediately after their release.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


United States and Africa;
Africa Policy Outlook 1997


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

Washington - First the good news: For the decade beginning in 1996, the annual economic growth rate for Sub-Saharan Africa is projected at 3.8%, double that for the decade that ended in 1995.

This welcome increase reflects improved commodity prices, the return to peace in several countries on the continent, and increased investment and productivity in many. Statistics for 1995 show that it was the first year of positive per capita income growth since 1989, and 1996 is expected to turn out even better.

This new aggregate growth refutes the stereotype of a consistently gloomy outlook for the continent. There are, however, many sobering qualifiers. The World Bank estimates that growth rates less than 6% will not significantly reduce poverty in most countries. While 12 African countries achieved this target in 1995, 41 did not. Food intake per person in Sub-Saharan Africa was estimated last year at just 87% of daily requirements. 

Africa's share of foreign direct investment continued to fall, from 10% in 1987-1991 to 3.6% in 1995. Meanwhile, global concessional aid flows, on which Africa is particularly dependent, continued their decline. While 1996 saw the approval of a new scheme for greater debt reduction for heavily indebted countries, it was unclear how many countries would actually benefit from it in 1997.

In addition, as the World Bank now concedes--echoing the longtime view of critics--"economic growth is necessary but not sufficient for reducing poverty." Even in countries praised for their economic reforms and growth rates, most people continue to struggle for survival under precarious conditions. Funds for investment in infrastructure and human development, essential for long-term advance, are squeezed by "market-oriented" budget constraints throughout the continent.

Peace and Security Issues

Countries cannot progress economically in the absence of basic physical security. In many countries, security is threatened by open conflict, physical displacement or arbitrary abuses by repressive regimes.

The multifaceted crisis in the Great Lakes region and Zaire, which made headlines in 1996, remains deadly. Open war also continues in the Sudan, and peace settlements in both Liberia and Angola could easily give way to renewed violence. In Algeria there is no end in sight to the violent conflict pitting extremist Islamic rebels against repressive government forces, in which both sides have targeted civilians and the lives of journalists are particularly at risk.

In cases such as the Great Lakes, the scale of crisis simply overwhelms local capacity to respond. There is a growing consensus, contrary to the Organization of African Unity's general assumption in past decades, that internal conflicts are not just the concern of one country. Neighboring countries and indeed the continent at large are victimized by spillover effects. Genocidal violence is in theory--if not yet in practice--the concern of the entire human community.

Yet consensus on the need to "do something" is unlikely to lead easily to agreement on who should do what. The crises mentioned above, and perhaps new ones, are certain to confront Africa advocates this year with hard questions.

In African countries not suffering open warfare--i.e. the vast majority-- civil society continues to expand its role in demanding respect for human rights, democratic governance, and attention to a wide range of specific issues. But advocates typically work in a climate of domestic repression and international indifference. The most prominent case in 1997, as in 1996, is likely to be Nigeria, where the military regime shows no signs of responding to demands for democracy and respect for human rights.

In South Africa, the new democratic system is well established. The extension of the Truth Commission's amnesty deadline into this year makes it likely that revelations about past abuses will continue. The country faces formidable problems, however, as it seeks to reconcile demands for economic growth with the need for equity in a society still fundamentally defined by the class and race hierarchies of the apartheid era. South Africa has yet to define a clear foreign policy that includes constructive participation in African issues as well as relationships with global economic powers.

Issues This Year

In Washington the political climate will likely remain extremely difficult for advocacy on Africa. The reelected Republican majority in both houses of Congress will continue to press for cuts in international affairs budgets, ranging from development assistance to U.N. funding, the World Bank's International Development Association, peacekeeping operations, and other international agencies. The Clinton Administration, moreover, is likely to be inconsistent in its support for such budget commitments, despite its success in ousting U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

In Congress the retirement of Senators Nancy Kassebaum (R-Kan.) and Paul Simon (D-Ill.) removes two of Africa's most prominent allies on the legislative front. While there are sympathetic lawmakers in both the Senate and House, it will be an uphill battle to build even a modest core of members ready to speak out regularly on Africa issues.

Apart from regular budgetary issues, there will be discussion of the African Growth and Opportunity Act introduced by Representatives Crane, Rangel and McDermott last year. The bill is designed to promote US trade and investment in Africa, but there is debate about whether it takes a balanced approach to development and reciprocal economic ties or fosters a one-sided stress on market-led growth and free trade.

In short, African issues are unlikely to receive much more attention from Washington in 1997 than in 1996. In many cases, however, relatively small shifts in US policy can have substantial impact on African or multilateral initiatives. The following is a brief checklist of some specific areas and issues on which US involvement may make a difference this year.

Conflict (Great Lakes and the Horn): With the return of the majority of Rwandan refugees from Zaire and Tanzania, the interlocked crises in this region are for the moment focused primarily within rather than between borders. Rwanda faces the massive challenge of integrating the refugees and establishing functional legal procedures for coping with the aftermath of genocide. The future of Zaire and the refugees remaining there is unpredictable, except for the certainty that the conflict is not over. Burundi's minority military regime is still under sanctions from regional countries, and massacres of civilians continue.

War rages on in southern Sudan, and the repressive Sudanese government is under increasing challenge in the north as well. There is, nevertheless, little immediate prospect of decisive military shifts or revival of stalled mediation efforts. The conflict has spawned an ongoing humanitarian crisis, and Sudan's neighbors could yet be drawn into the war.

Peace agreements (Liberia and Angola): The peace process in Liberia is formally on track again after its violent collapse in April 1996. But key steps such as disarmament of faction forces are not yet implemented, and a new collapse is easily possible in 1997. In Angola the United Nations peacekeeping force is scheduled to withdraw by mid-year. On paper the demobilization of Unita forces is complete, but observers warn that as many as 20,000 Unita troops are still operational. Insecurity is pervasive in the countryside, and there is a real threat of renewed open warfare.

Democratization (Nigeria and other countries): The internal and international campaign for democracy in Nigeria will continue, given the failure of the Abacha regime to offer more than token promises of change. Neither Western nor African countries are likely soon to take additional steps to increase pressure on the military regime, however, unless there is a dramatically visible escalation of the crisis. Pro-democracy efforts in most other countries are even less likely to attract major international attention and support.

Landmines: The Clinton Administration will have to decide soon whether to join Canada and other countries in pressing rapidly for a total ban on anti- personnel landmines or continue deferring to the Pentagon's opposition to quick action on the issue.

International institutions: Like his predecessor, incoming U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan is a highly skilled diplomat from the African continent. But the spectacle of the transition, engineered unilaterally by the United States, was not encouraging. Substantive issues were absent from the debate, save for the code-word "reform," generally understood as a euphemism for downsizing. This will be a critical year for US relations with the U.N. and other multilateral institutions. Unless the pattern of the last few years changes, the negative consequences for Africa will be substantial.

ENDS

The Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), the educational affiliate of the Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, No. 509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 1 (1/3)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2734 words


 

Rome - This report includes: Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania; Ethiopia. January 3, 1997.

EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Zaire a) WFP airlift to Kisangani continues. A total of 332 metric tons airlifted to Kisangani since beginning of airlift on 18 December. Further airlift operation begun with Andover aircraft (6 metric tons capacity), between Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi, Amisi and Shabunda. b) A UN Joint Logistics Centre in Kisangani proposed by WFP, to operate along the lines of the UN Joint Logistics Centre in Entebbe. c) Some 6 metric tons of WFP provided food distributed to 2,000 internally displaced persons in Kisangani on 28 December. Total food distributed by WFP is 135 metric tons. Food assistance also provided to refugees in Tingi-Tingi area. 

2. Tanzania a) With departure of Rwanda refugees Rwanda in December, total registered refugees remaining in Tanzania currently 248,000 (80,000 Burundian refugees in Ngara region; 130,000 Burundian refugees in Kigoma region; 38,000 Zairean refugees in Kigoma region). Influx of Zairean and Burundian refugees into Kigoma region continues at the rate of 1,000 per day.

3. Rwanda a) Total number of refugees who returned to Rwanda in 1996: 617, 200 from Zaire; 475,000 from Tanzania; 88,000 from Burundi; 8,000 from Uganda (UNHCR figures). WFP food assistance has been provided to all returnees. b) FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment mission estimated food aid requirements for the first half of 1997 are 81,000 tons of cereals and 33,000 tons of pulses, to cover needs of 2.571 million people (one-third of the population).

4. Burundi a) Insecurity in northern Cibitoke province halts missions to the province. Shots fired in the direction of the WFP Twin Otter flight path along the Kiriba forest of Kayanza. Heavy fighting in some areas of southern Bujumbura Rural and the border area of Bururi province. b) Increasing number of mine explosion leads to ban by UN Security Cell on travel on non-asphalt roads of Bujumbura Rural, Cibitoke and Bubanza provinces. WFP assessment and distribution missions affected.

ETHIOPIA

1. Update a) Special Report on the FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment mission to Ethiopia issued on 16 December. Recent crop of 12 million metric tons of cereals and pulses is 20 percent higher than good harvest of last year. b) Cereal prices dropped with general anticipation of a bumper crop. c) Food deficient areas exist throughout the country, due to displacement, structural inadequacies and lack of access/entitlement to food supplies. Some 1.9 million people will still require food assistance, for total needs of 186, 000 metric tons, most of which is covered by carry-over stocks and pledges.

D. Afghanistan

1. Update a) WFP interim policy, as of 24 December 1996: in addition to continued but reduced levels of activity in the north, work of WFP in Southern and Eastern Afghanistan will be exclusively in the areas of: humanitarian relief (including bakery projects); institutional feeding; projects where women or girls comprise 50 percent or more of the direct beneficiaries; food-for-seeds in cooperation with FAO; and selected food-for- work (in health, water and sanitation projects, de-mining activity and certain other categories). WFP activities will be in areas where WFP/NGO female staff, international and national, are allowed to work.

PART II - DETAILS

EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. ZAIRE

1.1 Kisangani

a) WFP continues to fly in food and relief materials to Kisangani by a Zairean chartered 707, from where it is moved either by road or by a locally chartered aircraft to Lubutu/Tingi-Tingi. Since the inception of the flights on 18 December to 1 January, WFP flights have moved in a total of 332 metric tons.

b) WFP has begun another air operation, consisting initially of twenty flights with an Andover aircraft (capacity 6 metric tons), between Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi, Amisi or Shabunda. The destination will vary depending on the needs and security situation in each area. This aircraft will also be available to move relief materials.

c) WFP has proposed that logistical coordination and prioritisation for food and non-food cargo in this part of Zaire be achieved through a UN Joint Logistics Centre in Kisangani, along the lines of the successful UN Joint Logistics Centre in Entebbe.

d) On 28 December, WFP provided food for 2,000 internally displaced persons in Kisangani, making available 4 metric tons of maize meal, 1.68 metric tons of peas and 0.28 metric tons of oil. Distribution was carried out by the Norwegian NGO CEPZA, and CARITAS. Total food distributed by WFP is 135 metric tons.

1.2 Tingi-Tingi

a) On 27/28 December, WFP carried out a second distribution to refugees in Tingi-Tingi (49 metric tons of maize meal). Two trucks carrying a total of 16 metric tons of maize meal were sent by WFP from Kisangani to Lubutu/Tingi- Tingi on 2 January.

b) As of 31 December, the UNICEF Nutritional Centre had 100 children in a therapeutic feeding programme and 300 children in a supplementary feeding programme in Tingi-Tingi.

c) Estimated number in need in the area: Lubutu/Tingi-Tingi 160,000, Amisi 30,000.

1.3 Shabunda: Prior to the evacuation of international staff of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) from Shabunda, ICRC had counted 56,000 refugees in Shabunda from Rwanda and Burundi (no breakdown of figures available). To facilitate access to the refugee site from the airport, ICRC constructed an 80 metre long wooden roadway across the existing bridge. Since ICRC's departure, information on the Shabunda area has not been available.

1.4 Goma

a) Reports of refugees hiding in the thick forest near Tongo continue. The refugees are said to fear attacks from armed men roaming the area.

b) WFP continues its operation of distributing high-energy biscuits to refugees in the Goma area returning to Rwanda. From 25 December 1996 to 1 January 1997, some 6,343 persons received WFP biscuits, with the beneficiaries consisting of 789 refugees, 2,330 Zairean internally displaced persons and 3,224 recipients in hospitals and nutritional centres. Monitoring of the hospitals and nutritional centres is carried out on a daily basis by WFP in conjunction with the agencies involved in the health sector.

1.5 Bukavu: High-energy biscuit distributions continue, mostly on the northern axis from Bukavu, which is the area in greatest need.

2. TANZANIA

2.1 With the vast majority of the Rwandan refugees having returned to Rwanda from Tanzania by 30 December, Tanzania currently accommodates approximately 248,000 registered refugees. The breakdown is as follows: 80, 000 Burundian refugees in the Ngara region; 130,000 Burundian refugees in the Kigoma region; 38,000 Zairean refugees in the Kigoma region. The influx of Zairean and Burundian refugees into the Kigoma region continues with some 1, 000 arriving per day.

2.2 An estimated 475,000 Rwandan refugees repatriated from Tanzania to Rwanda in 1996. Some Rwandan refugees remain both scattered in Tanzania and at the holding centre for intimidators at Mwisa camp. The exact numbers are uncertain.

2.3 Following the repatriation of the Rwandan refugees, WFP retrieved its food commodities from the Rwandan camps in the Kagera region. This food, which consists of approximately 600 metric tons, will be distributed to the remaining Burundian and Zairean refugee caseloads in the Ngara and Kigoma regions.

2.4 WFP airlifted 40 metric tons of corn-soya blend (CSB) and high-energy biscuits from Entebbe to Kigoma for distribution to the new arrivals and targeted beneficiaries. A total of 1,000 metric tons of CSB procured in Nairobi is being despatched to Kigoma.

3. RWANDA

3.1 According to UNHCR, the total number of refugees who returned to Rwanda in 1996 is as follows: 617,230 from Zaire; 475,000 from Tanzania; 87,922 from Burundi; 7,998 from Uganda. WFP food assistance has been provided to all returnees.

3.2 Conclusions of the FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission (Special Report dated 23 December 1996): Food aid requirements for the first half of 1997 are estimated at 81,000 tons of cereals and 33,000 tons of pulses, to cover needs of 2.571 million people, or one-third of the projected population. The number of beneficiaries includes recent returnees who were not engaged in farming during the 1997 A season, previous returnees who will have to leave farm areas they are presently occupying, groups such as widows, elderly people living alone and orphans made vulnerable by civil strife, and population structurally vulnerable due to a poor resource base. WFP pledges for the first semester of 1997 are sufficient to cover the needs, however further pledges will be required for the second semester of 1997.

3.3 A useful summary of the food situation in Rwanda and other countries in the region, entitled "Overview Paper: Food Security in East and Central Africa", dated 23 December 1996, is available from DHA/IRIN Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org.

3.4 WFP is currently in the process of finalising a Workplan for 1997, in close consultation with other UN agencies and involved parties. A Consolidated UN appeal for the Great Lakes Region will be launched shortly.

4. BURUNDI

4.1 Although only partial information was available on the security situation of much of the country, many areas remain clearly unsafe. Missions to Cibitoke province have been halted owing to insecurity in the northern area of the province. Shots were fired in the direction of the WFP Twin Otter aircraft's flight path along the Kiriba forest of Kayanza. The southern part of Bujumbura Rural and the border area of Bururi province are reported unsafe and some areas have witnessed heavy fighting, with rebel attacks leaving a reported 70 dead in Rumonge commune.

4.2 In view of the escalation in mine explosion incidents, the UN Security Cell forbids travel on non-asphalt roads of Bujumbura Rural, Cibitoke and Bubanza provinces, affecting both assessment and distribution missions by WFP.

4.3 The WFP Burundi caseload totalled 133,150 from 23 to 29 December. Included in this total were 71,316 beneficiaries of emergency relief distributions and 32,611 returnees benefiting from the WFP returnee package. This returnee ration is provided to returnees (refugees who have returned to Burundi) and displaced persons who are returning to their homes or are resettling permanently elsewhere in Burundi.

4.4 WFP and other UN agencies are actively working together to render possible food transport on Lake Tanganyika from Kigoma to Bujumbura. Out of the some 2,500 metric tons import allowance to Burundi by the RSCC (Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee), 1,000 metric tons would then be routed from Isaka to Ngozi and the balance by Lake transport, to permit both good geographical pre-positioning of commodities within the country and limitation of overland transportation costs.

ETHIOPIA

1. UPDATE - Extracts from the recent FAO/WFP Mission report

1.1 A Special Report on the FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment mission to Ethiopia, issued on 16 December, describes the recent crop of cereals and pulses as 20 percent higher than last year's very good harvest. (Total production: some 12 million metric tons.) Early, plentiful and well distributed rains throughout the year not only encouraged planting and supported crop development in most zones, but also provided optimal conditions for draught animals.

1.2 Cereal prices, which have been declining steadily in most markets throughout the year, fell further with the onset of the harvest signalling the general anticipation of a bumper crop. The Mission stresses that given the fact that maize prices, in particular, were by November near or below production costs in the main production areas, efforts need to be made to improve marketing possibilities to avoid surpluses becoming a disincentive to producers.

1.3 In spite of the comfortable national production figure, there exist traditionally food deficient zones in various parts of the country (parts of Wollo, parts of Tigray, and North Omo) due to displacement, structural inadequacies and lack of access/entitlement to food supplies. Some 1.9 million people will still require food assistance. Overall food aid requirements are estimated at 186,000 metric tons, 64 percent of last year's requirements, but most of this total is covered by carry-over stocks and pledges, leaving a balance of 15,110 metric tons to be resourced.

1.4 The Mission recommended that all food aid should be met by local purchases and that no food aid should be imported. In addition, the Mission recommended that donors should seriously consider financial support for the purchase and export of Ethiopian grains (maize and sorghum) to neighbouring countries such as Kenya, Eritrea and Somalia, where similar FAO/WFP Missions have reported large deficits. Such action, as well as making logistical sense, will assist in establishing a floor in the Ethiopian grain market and reduce the possibility of the expected surpluses remaining unsaleable and becoming a disincentive to agricultural production next year.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


28 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 73 on the Great Lakes (01/07)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Nairobi - A statement issued by Zaire and Kenya yesterday after talks between Presidents Mobutu and Moi stressed that national sovereignty, territorial integrity, inviolability of national boundaries and citizenship issues were not negotiable.

The one-day meeting in Gbadolite, Zaire, was aimed at briefing Mobutu on the decisions taken by an African leaders' summit in Nairobi last month, which Zaire failed to attend. Kenyan radio reported that the Zairean side stressed its priorities were to "sustain the war effort to put an end to the major obstacle in the occupation of a portion of Zairean territory by the enemy". The joint statement said another priority was to "put the finishing touches to the democratisation process in respect of the electoral agenda". The two leaders deplored the international community's "indecisiveness" regarding the Great Lakes situation and its failure to implement UN Security Council resolutions on the deployment of a multinational force. 

* According to AFP, a former Zairean information minister and currently a member of parliament, Anicet Kashamura, has announced his decision to join the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire. AFP said he made the announcement during a visit to Paris where he called on foreign powers, especially the USA, France and Belgium, to support rebel leader Laurent Kabila.

* An investigation has opened into a German company suspected of exporting arms illegally to Burundi, after customs officers at Brussels airport last month seized engines from former Soviet armoured vehicles, gearboxes and other parts from the Fahrzeugwerke Neubrandenburg firm. A spokesman for the court in Neubrandenburg said the company was suspected of trying to export the goods illegally to Burundi through Belgium after a request for an export licence was turned down by the German authorities in October. However the firm has denied the accusations.

* Burundi's political parties are to take part in a national debate on January 27. The minister for institutional reforms Eugene Nindorera announced that the four-day debate would include about 60 people from across the political spectrum. However the main Hutu rebel group, National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), will not be invited to take part. The debate will cover five main themes: 1.the causes of the world's divisions and wars 2. the peace process and reconciliation in Africa 3.the nature of the Burundi conflict 4.past debates on national unity and the democratisation of Burundi 5.steps to resolve the Burundi conflict. Burundi radio said a special envoy of US President Bill Clinton arrived in Bujumbura yesterday but the reason for the visit was not yet known.

* Eight assailants died and one was captured after "infiltrators" exchanged fire with Rwandan soldiers in Ruhengeri prefecture over the weekend, Rwandan radio reported. It said one soldier and an unknown number of civilians were also killed. The gunmen apparently hid in someone's house and their intention was to free prisoners from a local jail and force local leaders to give them identity cards. Weapons were captured from the attackers. On Sunday night, a family of six and three children were killed by gunmen in Gitarama, the radio said. IRIN yesterday reported that similar incidents had occurred in the Gisenyi area last month, in which at least 10 people were killed.

* The UN International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) resumes in Arusha, Tanzania, on Thursday with the trial of Jean-Paul Akayesu. A Tribunal spokesman told AFP that Akayesu, who has already changed lawyers twice, would now be defended by Nicholas Tiangaye, a barrister from the Central Africa Republic who once represented CAR dictator Jean-Bedel Bokassa.

* The authorities in Arusha yesterday ordered the seizure of public transport buses operated by refugees, in a bid to step up efforts aimed at forcing illegal aliens out of the country. The regional administrator, quoted by AFP, accused the refugees of "masquerading" as businessmen to avoid repatriation. He said most foreigners were engaged in the transport business. Local officials were given a month to impound all buses owned by refugees.

* UNHCR repatriation figures for 1996 showed that a total of 1,300,582 refugees returned home last year. Of these, 719,307 returned from Zaire, 483, 445 from Tanzania, 88,309 from Burundi and 9,521 from Uganda.

Nairobi, 7 January 1997, 13:40 gmt (ENDS)
