Africa News


January 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Currency: CFA Franc Looses Ground, Cedi Stable


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 867 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The CFA franc lost ground on the United States dollar after gaining against the greenback last week in Dakar.

At Dakar's Citibank, the CFA exchanged at 513 (buying) and 543 (selling) to the dollar on Tuesday, as against 509 on December 31 and 510 on December 24.

Meanwhile, the Ghanaian cedi remains stable despite a lack of consensus among Ghanaian dealers on the evaluation of their foreign exchange needs. 

Some were expecting a "stable market", dismissing the likelihood of higher foreign currency demand, the Ghana News Agency, GNA, reported.

The agency said that other dealers reported that rising revenues would allow them to renew their stocks and meet consumer needs.

On Monday in Accra, the cedi rose slightly to exchange at 1,760 (buying) and between 1,750 to 1,800 (selling) to the dollar.

The cedi remains near its level at Dec. 31, 1996, according to the interbank rate made public by the Ghanaian banking association.

The cedi exchanged at 1,726 at the end of 1996 before falling to 1,726.82 (buying) and 1,735.36 (selling) on Jan. 6, 1997 in the Ghanaian capital.

Following are the nominal exchange rates of African currencies against the dollar:

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


Zambia;
Opposition Criticizes Church Plans To Ordinate President


BYLINE: Modern Bweema, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambia's opposition alliance of political parties has accused the government of subverting the independence of the country's churches by planning to have President Frederick Chiluba ordained.

Reporting this Tuesday, the Zambian News Agency said that the National Lima Party publicity secretary, Stanfold Hlazo, described the decision by some church leaders as a mockery of the Christian community in Zambia.

Hlazo said that government had wasted a lot of money in donations to ailing churches while the agricultural sector had been hard hit by high prices for fertilizers. 

The chairman of the opposition alliance, Rodger Chongwe, termed some church leaders on Tuesday as hypocrites and accused them of being financially dependent on the state as their sole source of funds and recognition.

Chongwe said the call by some church leaders to ordain Chiluba was also a danger to the development of democracy in Zambia.

Chongwe said the stance by the divisive churches only confirmed the fears of those who opposed the declaration of Zambia as a Christian nation.

"The very fact that Reverend Chintala, a Christian from a born again sect, was appointed to head the church ministry makes us believe that the call to ordain President Chiluba as reverend was conceived inside state house," Chongwe said.

"This is a signal of intensification of religious fundamentalists," Chongwe added.

However, he said it was notable that orthodox churches, like the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of God had not supported calls for Chiluba's ordination.

"President Chiluba has never gone to theological school. How do you ordain him?" Chongwe said.

Chongwe claimed that the state made a priority of subverting the independence of the churches and had done so by providing "huge financial donations" concealed in the treasuries of the churches.

Archbishop John Mambo of the Church of God has dissociated his church from the move to ordain Chiluba. Bishop Mambo has appealed to other church leaders to distinguish between mere politicking and the role of the Church in society.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 7, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Judge Releases 53 Suspects, Berates Police


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Lusaka High Court Judge, Justice Kabazo Chanda, released 53 suspected criminals Tuesday, most of them facing charges of aggravated robbery, because they have not been brought for trial since their arrest in 1992.

Chanda freed the suspects and said more would follow if reports prove true that police have been holding many others for years without being brought to court.

The releases were ordered in a special court session to which representatives from the Prison Service, Police and the chambers of the Director of Public Prosecutions were summoned. 

On the occasion, Corporal Ernest Lombe of the Prisons Service said that the suspects were detained between December 15, 1992 and November 29, 1995.

The Lusaka Division Criminal Investigations Officer, Teddy Nondo, blamed magistrates and the suspects for the delays in trials.

Nondo said that there was a tendency for magistrates to sign detention warrants before police had a chance to complete investigations.

He said the Flying Squad of the police and other units just picked up and locked up suspects without first charging them.

Nondo said, also, that some suspects elluded trial by refusing to answer to their names when called for court sessions.

Notwithstanding this, Justice Chanda said there was need to uphold human rights in Zambia because every suspect was innocent until proven guilty.

The suspects clapped, ullulated and sang hymns to praise to God and Justice Chanda for their freedom.

"The state has no evidence before you and that is why they have kept you for five years in prison," he said, "but do me one favour; do not go back and commit other crimes." Chanda said.

However, he warned that suspects would be re-arrested if police establish that they committed a crime. At the same time, he told police not to defy his order by re-arresting the suspects immediately after their release.


LOAD-DATE: January 7, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Southern Africa;
SADC States Preserve 5,000 Food Plant Species


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Southern African Development Community (SADC) member-states have collected over 5,000 samples of mainly traditional food crop seed species in the region for preservation at the sub-regional plant genetic resources center in Lusaka.

The center's director, Godwin Mkamanga, told PANA on Wednesday that the samples were just part of the 50,000 species the center intended to preserve for posterity.

The project is part of the SADC food security strategy and is aimed at saving traditional food crops which, he said, were threatened with extinction. 

"We have stored samples of seed for some 5,000 varieties of traditional food crops under scientific conditions. It is intended that these will remain alive for planting even after one hundred years from now," Mkamanga said.

Most of the preserved seeds are cereals, legumes and vegetables. They include maize, sorghum, millet, groundnut and their wild and weedy edible species.

The legumes include cassava, sweet potato, and yam varieties in addition to vegetable plants like okra, pumpkin, water melon, eggplant (aubergine) and cucumber varieties.

The center was established in 1989 by the Southern African Development Coordination Conference, the predecessor of the current 12-nation SADC.

Its objective was to coordinate the inventory, collection, characterization, evaluation and utilization of plant genetic resources in the sub-region.

It was also tasked with the establishment, over a 20-year period, of a network of local germplast programmes in member-countries and support plant research in the region.

The center is also responsible for conservation of other plant genetic resources, apart from food crops.

Mkamanga said the center was currently liaising with national plant genetic resources centers to establish national field gene banks for various indigenous fruit trees which could not be saved in seed form.

"We are encouraging the various affiliate centers in all the member- countries to plant useful local fruit trees as a matter of priority as part of the food crops preservation programme."

The seed samples are dried so that they retain only between five and seven percent moisture content. They are then sealed in specially designed bottles and placed in deep freezers at a temperature of minus 20 degrees centigrade.

Mkamanga said that almost all the SADC countries were losing some of the traditional food crops in the wake of modern hybrid seed being developed by commercial companies.

"The idea of preserving the traditional food crops is meant to act as insurance against possible failure of modern seeds in case of adverse weather conditions," he said, citing the 1990/91 drought which had caused widespread shortages of food in the region.

"With seed reserves like the one we are setting up, we could serve the situation by releasing the traditional seeds," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Politicians Condemn Bomb Blast


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

NEW YORK (PANA) - Four leaders of Nigeria's five authorized political parties, currently visiting the United States, have condemned the latest bomb explosions in Lagos, describing them as a terrorist acts.

Monday's bomb blast, which occurred near a bus filled with soldiers, killed two servicemen and injured several people. The explosion was the fourth in the city in the past two months.

Speaking Tuesday at a press conference in New York, the political leaders vowed that such acts would not stop the efforts to return the country to democratic rule.

"We will make sure this does not stop us from achieving our goals," said Gambo Lawan, chairman of the Grassroot Democratic Movement, one of the five political parties registered by Gen. Sani Abacha's military administration as part of a phased political transition programme.

Isa Mohamed, the chairman of the United Nigeria Congress Party, called on the international community to condemn the explosions.

The leaders urged the U.S. to support the transition programme and stop " financing" some people claiming to be fighting to bring democracy to Nigeria.

They are now in Atlanta, the next stop in an itinerary which will also take them to Miami, Houston, Kansas City, Chicago and Washington D.C.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Ghana;
Rawlings Takes Oath, Extends Olive Branch To Opposition


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana began his second four-year term Tuesday by extending an olive branch to his political opponents, saying his government would promote dialogue and reconciliation with the opposition.

"I hope the efforts that the executive or the ruling party for that matter will make will find an appropriate response from the minority parties in the supreme interest of our nation," he said in Accra after his inauguration.

Rawlings was sworn-in before an open air parliament and a large crowd at the seaside Independence Square in the Ghanaian capital, Accra. 

Dressed in rich Kente cloth with white jumper to match he took the oath of allegiance and the presidential oath which were administered by Chief Justice Isaac Kobina Abban.

Rawlings, "dialogue should not be a one-way affair, where the government is expected to bend over backwards to accommodate the opposition, while the opposition on its part surrounds itself with a barrier that prevents them from hearing any other views but their own."

The President urged the opposition to demonstrate that their public posturing on reconciliation are not just keeping with the political fashion of the moment but that they are ready to back their works with deeds.

"This must also apply to the media especially those newspapers with close affinity to the opposition. Without respect, humility, tolerance and restraint, reconciliation will be difficult to achieve," he said.

The President added: "We should not seek to endlessly provoke others and we must learn to be a little more positive in our approach to issues and more constructive in our criticisms."

He urged Ghanaians to find within themselves the spirit that allows them to break down the acrimony of the past.

Rawlings has become the longest serving head of state since Ghana gained its independence from Britain on March 6, 1957. He first came to power through a military coup d'etat on June 4, 1979. He handed over power to an elected government in September, 1979, but seized power again on December 31, 1981.

In 1992, he was elected for the first time in a popular vote.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Mozambique;
Controversial Environmental Project Abandoned in Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mosaflorestal, a joint venture between Mozambican and South African Companies, has agreed with the government in Maputo that its planned eucalyptus plantation will not be sited in the environmentally sensitive district of Matutuine, in the far south of the country.

The managing director of Socimo, Francisco Caravela, one of the Mozambican partners in Mosaflorestal, told the country's news agency, AIM, Wednesday that all of Mosaflorestal's shareholders have accepted the government position that, on environmental grounds, the project cannot go ahead in Matutuine.

"This was discussed with us and we have reached a position that is positive for all sides," Caravela said. 

The idea of the plantation is to provide raw material for the South African pulp and paper industry. Forty percent of Mosaflorestal is owned by Sappi forests, which is a subsidiary of the giant South African company, the Anglo- American Corporation.

The Mozambican government has said that it is not opposed to a eucalyptus plantation as such, and the Mosaflorestal project can go ahead elsewhere in the country.

"We have not found another area for the project yet but we're working on it with the government," Caravela said.

Mosaflorestal is liaising closely with the agriculture ministry and the planning and finance ministry and Caravela said a solution would be reached within a few months.

Environmentalists objected strongly to plans for a eucalyptus plantation in Matutuine, because this is one of the most important areas in southern Africa in terms of biodiversity.

Eucalyptus -- native to Australia, New Zealand and Tasmania -- demands large amounts of water. The plantation would, therefore, lower the water table and alter, radically, habitats in the region with a consequent loss of indigenous fauna and flora.

The government has decided that Matutuine should be the site for a major eco-tourism project, proposed by the right-wing American millionaire James Blanchard III.

Blanchard used to channel large amounts of money to the RENAMO anti- government forces, supported by apartheid South Africa, during its war against the government in Maputo.

The Blanchard project is to be developed over an area of 236,000 hectares. There has been much talk of an investment of 800 million U.S. dollars in this project but the Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, on Tuesday scaled this down to 20 million dollars of "direct investment." This is supposed to attract further capital up to a total of 800 million dollars.

Blanchard is promising to build casinos and luxury hotels for rich tourists, who will be able to stroll on Matutuine's unspoiled beaches and view its wildlife.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Why We Can Thump South Africa's Bafana Bafana


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, Commentary, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - TO the untrained eye, South Africa, or the Bafana Bafana, as they like to call themselves, are a very strong side-what with the Africa Cup of Nations resting in Nelson Mandela's residence and the world soccer governing body, FIFA, granting them the status of the highest -ranked African team.

Now, without any claim at expertise in soccer, I do not think the Bafana Bafana, in the present form-with a team full of aging players are that better than say-Nigeria, Ghana, Egypt and worse off, Zambia.

Take their 30-year-old goalie, Arendse. Those that watched him win his place during the Four Nations last year would admit that faced with lethal drives from goal-hungry strikers like Yekeni and our own Mwape Miti, Andrew Tembo and Jonson Bwalya, Andre Arendse would be taken in ill with impromptu whooping cough. He is not the sort of goalkeeper a serious team will depend on. 

Nor does the presence of Sizwe Motaung, their right-full back give any support to poor Andre. The Swiss-based Sizwe, to say the least, is only good in attack, and if he is given a hefty and aggressive winger like either Andrew Tembo and Jonson Bwalya, you would have clipped his wings.

But while he has a regular place at Leeds, Lucas Radebe, his biggest weakness is that he takes years to recover once beaten.

It is however, Mark Fish, who unfortunately spends half his time as a tourist at his new club at the competitive Italian Serie A, side, Lazio, who is a capable defender.

As their youngest player, Fish, is however, over-used because he is the only player with the energy to play as an attacking defender, -which sometimes makes him play to the gallery.

To check him Mwila should field a strong and tested midfield comprising of course Charles Musonda and someone like say, Jonson or Andrew at position six.

Bafana skipper, Neil Tovey, has great ability to read the game, and can be instrumental in various moves. He has a good fighting spirit but he too has little know how on managing a neat midfield.

he has nothing great left in him to stop the bullets from the Chipolopolo The Bafana Bafana midfield of Linda Buthelezi, Shaun Bartlet and Erick Tinkler, can at times be deadly.

But Buthlelezi's ball-controlling skills are a horror. He has earned more red and yellow cards than all Zambian players together in the last five years. Underpressure the panicky man in him lets loose and can earn Zambia clear free kicks and at the most a penalty.

Masinga, who last season was unceremoniously sidelined at English side, Leeds, is what some can confidently call a chancer, fights less for the ball and wait to be fed. Cutting the supply mid way will frustrate him through out the game.

The "new kid" on the Bafana Bafana bench, Skosana, is a right inclusion at the wrong time because if his performance against Mufulira Wanderers is anything to go by, he only needs the likes of Allan Kamwanga, to continue sizing him.

There isn't that much gold left in the Bafana mines anymore. If any, its the steam, stamina and running. We can use skill, experience and maturity to spank their infancy and whack their overgrown pride.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Great Kalu For Clear Win


BYLINE: Reuben Tonga, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - GOAL-scoring skipper, Kalusha Bwalya, whose arrival yesterday boosted confidence in the Zambian camp, declared he would lead Zambia to a clear victory against South Africa's Bafana Bafana in the World Cup qualifier slated for Independence Stadium this Saturday.

Speaking in an interview shortly after his arrival from his Mexican base, Kalusha, dressed in a blue suit, with a Chipolopolo scarf on his shoulders, however, warned that the match will not be easy as the South Africans have improved in the past few years.

"I am ready to lead the rest of the players to the World Cup and I feel that we have the players to win the match. I cannot make any predications as to the outcome of the match but I am ready to play," said the skipper. 

Asked how he felt about the presence of his longtime mate, Charles Musonda, Kalusha said he was glad that his friend was around to play against South Africa.

"I am willing to play with any players and since I played with Charles before, I do not see any problems, I only hope we can achieve something on Saturday," he said.

He also said he believed with the experience they have, Fred Mwila and Samuel 'Zoom' Ndhlovu are capable of leading the team to its first-ever World Cup appearance.

"We will be playing to win but one thing we have to know is that South Africa has improved and they are a good side," said Bwalya, who arrived on the same plane with his young brother Joel.

And Joel, speaking in an interview at the airport, insisted that the important thing on Saturday would be for Zambia to clinch even a 1-0 win so as to be at par with the rest of the teams in the Group.

"This game is important in that it will determine if we will still have chances of playing to qualify, and that is why as at now, I think the best we can do is force even a 1-0 win so that we work hard in the tougher match against Zaire," said Joel, dressed casually in a black jeans suit with some fancy black footwear and a piece of cloth on his head.

"Personally I feel I am ready for this match and I am only looking forward to join the rest of the players in training," he added.

Joel plays his club football in Belgium.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
CPJ Comdemns Arrest Of Journalist


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, the Committee To Protect Journalists (CPJ) to His Excellency President Frederick Chiluba President of the Republic of Zambia.

Your Excellency,

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to condemn in the strongest terms the arrest of George Jambwa, a journalist for the privately owned newspaper "Chronicle".

Jambwa was arrested and detained on December 26 for trespassing into the Army Barracks while attempting to verify reports that Zambia's Army Commander, Lieutenant General Nobby Simbeye, was under house arrest. On December 30, Jambwa appeared before the Lusaka Magistrate Court to answer to charges of " criminal trespass" under section 306 of the Penal Code where he pleaded not guilty. He was released later that day on bail of ZK 50,000 (US$ 38), with two sureties each of the same amount. The trial is set to begin on January 21, 1997. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the arrest of Jambwa as a grave attack on press freedom and a blatant violation of his right to hold and express opinions and ideas. We respectfully remind Your Excellency that Zambia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 19 of which guarantees the right to "seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kind." These rights are also guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights; Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights; and the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zambia is a signatory.

We strongly urge Your Excellency to do everything in your power to dismiss the charges against Jambwa and ensure an environment where journalists can work freely and safely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Anything In Red, Black And Green On Sale


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - AS soccer mad Zambians prepare to celebrate the annihilation of South Africa's Bafana Bafana this Saturday, enterprising Zambians are cashing- in by selling all manner of Chipolopolo paraphernalia.

Anything that has red, black and green is up for sale and, soccer fans are literary falling all over each other to buy them ahead of the make-or-break match.

In Lusaka, Cairo Road is festooned with youth's selling things ranging from calendars, plastic shopping bags through scarves to regalia such as T-shirts and robes in Zambian colours. 

The average price for most items is K3,000 with the most expensive being a Zambian flag get-up going for K45,000.

A tailor at the City Center Market, Eugene Kopa, says he has made over half a million Kwacha over the last two weeks selling Zambian flags which he is offering for K15,000 each while Agnes Kaira, a Chilenje compound resident claims to have made "a fortune" by knitting scarves in Zambian colours.

"I am selling the scarves for K3,000 each and people are buying them like hot cakes," Kaira said.

But the hottest selling item is a T-shirt going for K5,000 which has " Zambia for 1998 France World Cup" emblazoned on the front while "See You There!" adorns the rear.

"We are definitely qualifying for the world cup," remarked one confident fan, Charles Mulenga, as he purchased one of the T-shirts. "I want to wear this T-shirt when we teach South Africa a football lesson on Saturday."

Chipolopolo fan club chairman, Elijah Chisanga, has urged all soccer lovers to make a bee-line for Lusaka's Axis Center and Kafue Wholesalers or phone 247767 in Lusaka for Chipolopolo scarves.

"All Chipolopolo fan club members should be in Zambian colours on Saturday," Chisanga said. "We don't want South Africa to score a single goal."

Motorists meanwhile have also refused to be counted out. They have hung Chipolopolo scarves inside their cars and occasionally flash out four fingers to pedestrians, indicating a 4-0 win over South Africa.

LANGUAGE: English

January 8, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
A Rainy Saturday!


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - INITIAL weather forecasts indicate that it will rain on Saturday when Zambia meets South Africa's Bafana Bafana in a World Cup first leg encounter at Lusaka's Independence Stadium.

Officer-in-charge of the Central Forecast Office, Reidner Mumbi, disclosed in an interview yesterday that the heavens will definitely open up. 

"We have been looking at the weather pattern for Saturday and indications are that it is going to rain," Mumbi said.

He, however, said if it rains heavily on Friday night then there is a fair chance that the rains will be reduced to a drizzle by kick-off time at 15:00 hours.

"There is also a good chance that Independence Stadium will not be affected by the rains and even if it rains, the intensity will be reduced by the time the game kicks-off," added Mumbi.

But national team technical adviser, Samuel "Zoom" Ndhlovu said in a separate interview yesterday that "rain or no rain the boys are ready for battle".

"We have got the right boots to use if it rains," Ndhlovu said, adding: " The boys are ready for battle, rain or no rain."

And, according to Ndhlovu, the Zambia national team is accustomed to playing in rainy conditions.

"We did it in Mauritius, we repeated it in South Africa against Burkina Faso and we shall certainly do it against South Africa...unless the pitch is flooded," the highly reputed trainer bragged.

Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Two South African Pilots Plead Not Guilty


BYLINE: Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - TWO South African pilots yesterday pleaded not guilty to a charge of flouting Zambia's aviation regulations by failing to communicate with a Zambian air traffic controller as required by law.

The pilots, Robin Anderson, 67, of Sunnyside, Pretoria and Mark Julian Main- warring, 29, of Johannesburg both accepted the charge proffered upon them but explained why they failed to communicate with Zambia aircraft control. 

"We were flying too low because of bad weather and so were unable to communicate with Zambia's aircraft controller," Anderson told principal resident magistrate Francis Nsokolo.

Main-warring gave the same explanation.

But when Nsokolo told them to come for trial on February 24, Main-warring hurriedly said: "We accept the charge and would like to plead guilty."

However, Nsokolo declined to accept their changed plea.

"It is not your fault that the weather was bad so we will have to hear evidence on this. We cannot force you to plead guilty when it was not your fault," Nsokolo told the pilots upon which they agreed to come for trial as ordered.

The two are charged under section 57 (1) and (2) of the Aviation Act Cap 740 as read with section 5 (1).

The two were travelling from Lusaka International Airport to Botswana's Shokwe Airport on December 20 last year and were supposed to communicate with the Zambian authorities before take leaving.

Zambian authorities would then have communicated with their counterparts in Botswana to release the aircraft to their care.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Business;
Traders In Zambia Take Advantage Of Raging Fertilizer Shortage


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - TRADERS in Northwestern and Eastern provinces have taken advantage of the raging fertiliser shortage to maximise their earnings.

Members of the Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) in the two provinces have complained of being taken advantage of by traders, some of whom are now collecting K50,000 as down payment from helpless farmers in dire need of fertiliser.

"Is this what the government meant by liberalisation? Where have they taken the fertiliser they bought? The ZNFU should demand an explanation on how the government has distributed its fertiliser," said Dick Moyo from Chipata's Luangeni constituency. 

And United National Independence Party Special Assistant to the vice- president, George Zulu, confirmed that he had also witnessed fertiliser being sold in 1kg packs going at K2,000 to K3,000 each.

"The price of fertiliser is obscene and scandalous. Investrust Bank is doing a good job in the Eastern province but some crooks have come on the scene, taking advantage of the shortage and farmers' poverty. They are repacking fertiliser into smaller packs and making more money out of the 50kg fertiliser bags," Zulu said.

Samson Mbaku from Mufumbwe called on the President to intervene in the fertiliser crisis.

"This is a matter of national concern. We should be proud to feed ourselves as Zambians and not always rely on imports. It will not hurt the government to reduce on their profits. In the long run, it will benefit the country," he said in a telephone interview.

Mbaku said some crooks had managed to collect the little money a few farmers had with promises to deliver fertiliser from Lusaka in two weeks time.

"The fertiliser never came and now they do not even have money to buy this government fertiliser which is yet to be seen," he said.

Agriculture minister Edith Nawakwi however, emphasised in a statement on Monday that the government prices would remain the same because they were competitive.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Supreme Court Summons Post Editor


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - THE Supreme Court of Zambia has summoned The Post's special projects editor Masautso Phiri to appear before it for contempt of court.

Phiri has been charged for alleging in his column, "A Post Card from Masautso Phiri" of December 11, 1996 that seven Supreme Court judges were offered K14 billion to dismiss the opposition petition challenging President Chiluba's election.

According to the summons, Phiri is required to appear before the full Supreme Court bench to show why he should not be held in contempt of court over his article on the day the petition between the opposition and President Chiluba will first be heard. 

"Let Masautso Phiri attend before the Supreme Court Building on the day the above petition will first be heard before the full Supreme Court in 1997 at 09:00 hours to show why you should not be held in Contempt of Court on your article which appeared in The Post issue No. 619 Wednesday December, 11. 1996 under heading "Praising God Loudly", the summon signed by the Master of the Supreme Court M. Masilinda read in part.

This was the second summons to Phiri over the same article-the first being by Vice-President Brigadier General Godfrey Miyanda.

In his complaint before Senior Resident Magistrate Gertrude Chawatama, Miyanda alleged that Phiri who was the first respondent and The Post Newspapers as the second "published defamatory matter contrary to section 191 of the Penal Code, affecting the complainant." The Miyanda case comes up on Friday morning for plea.

And the criminal libel case involving President Chiluba's Zairean girlfriend failed to take place yesterday because defence lawyer Sakwiba Sikota was appearing in another matter before the High Court and one of the accused Fred M'membe was still out of the country because of flight problems.

Magistrate Betty Musonko adjourned the case to Friday afternoon for the start of cross- examination of prosecution star witness Clementine Mutshinga Mununga. The prosecution reluctantly agreed to the adjournment but insisted on the earliest date for the resumption of trial.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
NGO Watchdog Meeting On


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - THE Non-Governmental Organi-sations (NGO) consultative workshop to discuss the policy framework for regulation of NGOs in Zambia has been scheduled for tomorrow in Kafue George.

And several NGOs perceived to be critical of the MMD government have been omitted from the list of participants which was compiled by the Community Development ministry. 

The hosts and agenda of the three day seminar which was only announced by the community development ministry in the media are still not known to some who have been invited.

But a source disclosed that the meeting is expected to discuss the modalities of forming a Council to oversee the activities of all NGOs in Zambia.

Community development permanent secretary Helen Matanda who has been sending out invitation letters to participants refused to answer queries concerning the seminar.

And Zambia Civic Education Association (ZCEA) chairperson Lucy Sichone said that her organisation has been left out because of its critical position on national issues.

She also expressed concern over government's interference in the activities of NGOs.

"Why should the government discuss the policy framework on behalf of the NGOs," Sichone asked in an interview yesterday. "What they have done in this particular case is to leave all NGOs which they have perceived of being outspoken and critical."

Other NGOs which have been left out include Alfred Zulu's Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT).

Inter-Africa Network for Human Rights and Development (Afronet) only received its invitation a day before departure for Kafue George.

"We just received the letter today but it does not state the agenda and who other participants are," Afronet executive director Ngande Mwanajiti said in an interview on Monday.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Itezhi-tezhi By-Election Date Set


BYLINE: Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - THE Electoral Commission has set the date for the Itezhi-tezhi by- election following the death of MMD area member of parliament Luminzu Shimaponda.

Acting Executive director for the electoral commission Joel Sikazwe said in a statement released in Lusaka yesterday that the polls will be held on February 20, 1997. 

"Aspiring candidates should lodge nomination papers and statutory declaration on January 30, 1997 at the Itezhi-tezhi sub-council offices," Sikazwe said.

Opposition Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC) have already indicated that they are not participating in the by-election.

"Part of our application in the High Court is that we shall not participate in any election based on the NIKUV register. It therefore does not make sense for us to condemn the system and then contest the elections using the same system we have condemned," said Mung'omba in an interview on Monday.

UNIP boycotted the controversial November 18,1996 presidential and parliamentary elections insisting that the NIKUV register was fraudulent, designed to give an in-built majority for the ruling MMD.

Commission chairman Bobby Bwalya said the Nikuv registers would not be changed until the year 2001.

Sikazwe said aspiring candidates should take along with them nine supporters who must be registered voters in the Constituency.

"The supporters must have in their possession the Green National Registration Card and voters cards and the aspiring candidate will be required to pay K20,000 non-refundable nomination fee," Sikazwe said.

Africa News


January 8, 1997


Business;
Zambian Investors On Mandatory Environmental Studies


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - ALL investors will now have to carry out Environmental Impact Assessment studies before they are allowed to continue with their projects, said environment minister William Harrington in an interview yesterday.

Harrington said certain projects undertaken in the tourism, agriculture, and other sectors had disregarded the cost of the ventures on the environment. 

"Before the end of January, it will become mandatory for investors in all economic sectors to undertake environmental impact studies," he said.

The effect will be achieved through a statutory instrument which is currently being drafted by the Ministry of Legal Affairs, confirmed Harrington.

He said the Environmental Council of Zambia (ECZ) would be responsible for checking that investors had complied with the requirement.

The ECZ would also be the final authority regarding the approval of an assessment study.

"ECZ will make sure that projects do not have an adverse impact on the environment. There is a serious commitment on our part to implement our environmental policy," said Harrington.

The minister emphasised that this was an Environmental Impact Adjustment scheme which would now be set in motion to protect future generations' inheritance.

But Ben Mukusi, a local timber trader, wondered where investors would get qualified environmental damage assessors.

"Obviously this work will be done by the ECZ and is just another way of collecting revenue. To reduce the chances of corruption, the government should carry out the assessment free of charge," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
President Turns To Church Over Religious Desk He Set Up


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - PRESIDENT Chiluba has asked the church to define the functions and purpose of the religious desk he has set up at State House.

Chiluba opened the religious desk and named a deputy minister and reverend Peter Chintala to be in charge of it when he announced his cabinet last month. 

A group of church leaders calling itself the consultative committee continued to meet in Lusaka yesterday to draft a mission statement for the desk.

The consultative committee is being assisted by officials from Cabinet Office's management strategic planning unit.

The committee which begun its meetings on Monday was expected to come up with the final policy framework of the desk by late afternoon yesterday.

Members of the committee include Zambia Episcopal Conference (ZEC) secretary general Father Ignatius Mwebe, Pastor Reutter from Gospel Outreach and several pastors from Pentecostal churches.

Moderator of the Reformed Church, Reverend Foston Sakala who is also part of the committee meeting at Gospel Outreach (GO) Centre in Lusaka, hinted that the focus of the committee has been to ensure that the desk plays the role of a facilitator for dialogue between the church and the state.

Reverend Sakala said he was happy government had consulted the church over the matter.

"It was my own view that having established the desk, it was necessary to ask concerned people what they would want it to be so that the state does not impose anything on us," Sakala said in an interview at GO centre yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Dorothy Masuka Is In Zambia


BYLINE: Goodson Machona and Reuben Phiri, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - PIONEER of Kwela and Township Jive, Dorothy Masuka known to her millions of fans as "Auntie Dottie", has quietly slip-ped into the country from her base in South Africa.

In an exclusive interview with The Post yesterday, the 70-something diva said she was in the country to visit her family and friends. 

"I have my children here and a lot of friends I left behind at the time I left this country in 1986," Masuka said in that familiar Southern drawl.

Masuka hit fame in the 50's with her lilting girl-next-door songs which were later popularised by the woman refered to as "Mama Africa"-Mirriam Makeba.

In the 70's, her fame heightened through her militant songs such as Musango and Zimbabwe Chaitora at the height of the Zimbabwean independence struggle.

This, however, did not amuse the rebel government of Ian Smith who consequently ordered her out of that country. She lived mainly in Zambia.

Prior to her departure for South Africa, she worked briefly as a Public Relations Manager at Livingstone's Fairmount Hotel.

Former Zambia Broadcasting Services (forerunner to the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation) radio DJ, Matteo "Mattie P" Phiri, described Masuka's visit to Zambia as an honour.

"She was among people like Mirriam Makeba and Hugh Masekela who shaped the music of Africa. She is a queen of music," the eccentric Phiri said in a separate interview yesterday.

According Masuka, who was born Dorothy Manyando Simasiku, arrangements are underway for her to hold a series of shows in Zambia sometime in April this year.

Masuka last performed in Zambia in 1989 at the former Ridgeway hotel, now the Holiday Inn Garden Court hotel.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Denouncers Of UNIP Protesters Warned Of Courting Violence


BYLINE: Masautso Phiei, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP chairman Malimba Masheke has charged that people condemning women who bared their breasts during his party's demonstration are courting violence.

"Those women were expressing their anger. That was much better than violence. People saying that that behaviour was wrong are taking a great risk. They are courting violence," Masheke, who addressed the demonstrators said in an interview on Monday. 

He was reacting to the growing condemnation which he claimed to have been orchestrated by the MMD government with President Chiluba joining the fray on December 30, 1996.

Addressing the audience at a swearing -in ceremony at State House, President Chiluba condemned UNIP for allowing ordinary women to bare their breasts.

"I hope these are not signals that the first thing they will do, if at all they come to power, is to take pornography and nudity to Parliament. We have to protect our women," Chiluba said.

The President made his remarks during the swearing ceremony of deputy defence minister Mike Mlongoti and deputy finance minister Dan Pule, adding: " If they cannot allow their wives to undress why allow ordinary women to do so? We have to dress ordinary people and move forward to uphold our morality."

And agriculture minister Edith Nawakwi on the same day also strongly condemned UNIP telling the Times of Zambia: "One can only hope and pray that the striptease in UNIP is not a reflection of the party's vision for Zambia because most women certainly prefer to keep their clothes on and continue with meaningful dialogue as opposed to exposing naked ignorance."

She added sarcastically: "Such a grotesque display of worn out anatomy of elderly women certainly reflected UNIP's desire to remain in a time-warp back in the stone age."

But Masheke yesterday reminded Nawakwi that the "worn out anatomy of elderly women" is the reality of Zambia today.

"You don't have to go far. Even in information minister David Mpamba's village women move with bare breasts because that is the reality of today's economy. Besides, when people mourn whether in Namwala, Gwembe, Lundazi or even Isoka, they bare their breasts to show grief," Masheke said. "The UNIP demonstrators were showing anguish because of the suffering they are going through."


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Business;
Zambian Agribusiness To Help Determine Policy Change


BYLINE: Goodson Machona, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - Private agribusiness companies should helpdetermine the direction and pace of policy change in the current liberalized market, an agribusiness entrepreneur has said.

President of the Zambia Grain Growers' and Marketing Association, who is also the interim chairman of the Southern Africa Agribusiness Federation (SAAF), retired Captain George Lloyd, said this when he officiated at a SAAF Founders meeting held in Harare, Zimbabwe, recently. 

"As our economies continue to be liberalized, it is critical that the private agribusiness companies help determine the direction and pace of policy change, assist in operationalising new trade protocols and support the formation of new agribusiness ventures that will create employment, income and foreign exchange throughout the SADC region," Captain Lloyd said.

The SAAF was conceived last year after 35 representatives of well-known agribusiness enterprises and associations from Zimbabwe, South Africa, Zambia and Malawi decided to form a body that will promote agribusiness trade and investment in all of the Southern African Development Conference (SADC) countries by facilitating private sector initiatives while guiding public support to the sector.

"The initial areas of activity for SAAF will be limited to policy analysis and advocacy, information collection, analysis, distribution and facilitation of agribusiness finance," Captain Lloyd said.

According to the time-table worked out, SAAF will be legally constituted during the first quarter of 1997 and begin operating during the second quarter.

LANGUAGE: English

51 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
First Trade/Outreach Mission To Francophone Africa


BYLINE: Corporate Council On Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Beginning January 7, 1997, The Corporate Council on Africa will lead a delegation of 42 senior representatives from U.S. companies to the West African countries of Congo, Cote d'Ivoire and Equatorial Guinea. The Trade and Outreach Mission will feature talks with each countries' Head of State and local private sector business executives. The mission marks the first time that the Corporate Council on Africa has embarked on such a venture to Francophone Africa -- a region that has traditionally been dominated by the French business community. According to the Council's Executive Director, David H. Miller, "Africa has many thriving markets and the interest that this mission has generated definitely underscores the positive attitude that U.S. corporate executives have toward Africa. This mission is a statement that, despite the generally negative public image that Africa seems to possess in the American media, the continent is continuing to attract the American business community. 

While politically and geographically diverse, all three countries possess economic prospects. With an abundance of natural resources, Congo, Equatorial Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire offer many attractive business opportunities for U.S. companies in several key sectors including petroleum, mining, forestry, and manufacturing. Substantial new oil deposits were discovered in Equatorial Guinea in 1995, and Congo and Cote d'Ivoire are beginning to open deep water acreage for hydrocarbon exploration. The governments of The Congo and Cote d'Ivoire have recently developed strategic structural adjustment programs in conjunction with the World Bank and the IMF. Also included in these development plans are economic reforms targeted at the reorganization and liberalization of their trade and investment policies. These programs are designed to make attractive markets for international entities and their implementation demonstrates the commi0tment these governments have to attracting foreign investment.

The goal of the Corporate Council on African Trade and Outreach Mission to The Congo, Cote d'Ivoire & Equatorial Guinea is to introduce American business into this uncharted territory and to promote the virtues of free enterprise to these emerging markets. Trade and Outreach Missions promote the cross-cultural exchange of ideas and information between business and individuals and work towards forming the foundation for strong U.S.-African commercial ties. The Council believes that by fueling economic growth, new trade and investment in Africa has potential to contribute, ultimately, to the material well-being and prosperity of the African people, while improving U.S. commercial presence on this often overlooked continent.

Accompanying the mission will be Congressman William Archer, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Congressman E. Clay Shaw, and senior representative from the State Department Africa Bureau. The sponsors of the mission are Motorola, Atlantic Telenetwork, Central African Foundation, General Motors, Occidental Petroleum, CMS Nomeco Oil & Gas Company, United Meridian International Corporation, Equator Bank Limited, Mobil Africa and F. C. Schaffer & Associates. Other mission participants include: Citibank, West African Distributors, Inc., AT&T, Cohen & Woods International, Michael Baker Corporation, Anadarko Petroleum, IBM Africa, Navistar, Alexis International, ComsatRSI, Stewart & Stevenson, International Trade Development Corporation, Adeerma Enterprises, Inc., and the Universal Marketing Group.

The Corporate Council on Africa, established in 1992, is a non-partisan, tax-exempt membership organization of corporations and individuals dedicated to strengthening and facilitating relationships between African and American individuals and organizations by creating educational, cultural and commericial exchange opportunities. The Council believes that it can accomplish this goal by educating constituencies about the different social customs, traditions, and economic climates on both continents and by utilizing a network of business executives and government officials to promote U.S.-Africa relations.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia Gears Up For World Cup Soccer Clash With South Africa


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Lusaka - When Zambia clashes with South Africa January 11 in a World Cup soccer qualifying match, the key factor at stake will be regional supremacy.

Both teams believe they are the best side in the Southern African region, if not on the continent and the match in Lusaka is looked at as one that will put an end to the dispute. 

Until recently, FIFA, the world soccer governing body, ranked Zambia as the best team in Africa with South Africa a close second, but in the latest ratings, South Africa has taken the top slot with Zambia now in second place.

Zambians would like these positions to be reversed again and are confident that the South Africans will be beaten. Zambia, under a new coach (Fred Mwila, who recently replaced Rould Poulsen of Denmark) has called on all the professional players it can get. The South Africans have done the same. Both sides have also been promised handsome monetary rewards should they win.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Air Of Anxiety Over National Budget


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - Workers, the main target for taxes, are gripped by general anxiety about what the national budget has in store for them, given indications of increasing pressure on government's financial obligations.

It is feared that taxes directly affecting workers will be raised and the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions has told its members to brace themselves for hard times. 

Among the major concerns, is that the government could face difficulties in balancing the budget which should be announced at the end of this month. About 25 % of the budget revenue comes from donor aid but it is not clear yet on which or how many donors have committed themselves to assist this year. The Paris Club meeting at which donor pledges are expected to be made, was put off last month (December) and will now be held next month.

Finance deputy minister Dan Pule has, however, allayed the fears, saying that Zambia's programmes with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank were still on course and that relations with the multi-lateral organisations were still intact.

Meanwhile, the government has limited the number of students entering university to under 1,000 this year because it does not have the money to support all those who qualify. About 12,000 pupils qualified to enter university but government says it can only offer bursaries to about a 1,000 of these.

Recently, the government also announced the scrapping of mature-age entrants to the university, contending that only those with appropriate academic qualifications would be allowed to enter the institution. Government also announced that it would soon increase the number of students into colleges in order to accommodate the growing demand for more places.

It is, however, not clear yet if the costs of increased college intakes would be met by the government.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
UNIP Facing Financial Difficulties


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP, the former ruling party, is facing financial problems that have led to the sacking of about 25 workers who allegedly protested for not being paid their salaries for four months. 

The workers were fired for misconduct after they closed off the entrance to their headquarters, Freedom House, in Lusaka. The party's administrative secretary Basil Kabwe said this was bad behaviour because the workers also closed out clients who rent some rooms in the UNIP building.

Prior to the presidential and parliamentary elections last November, the party ran into another financial hitch when it failed to meet the costs of holding its general congress. The party president, Kenneth Kaunda, is said to have assisted in meeting the shortfall.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Election Defeat Severe Blow To ZDC


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Lusaka - The once dynamic Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) party has been reduced to near rubble following the November 18 election defeat. The party, which seemed good enough to give the ruling MMD a good run for the 150 parliamentary seats, could only manage two seats and this has dampened the spirits of many of its members, including its leaders. 

It took close to a month for the once vocal party founder and president Dean Mung'omba to accept defeat but he and virtually all members of his executive have kept out of the public lime-light since the defeat. The only news coming out of the party, is a quarrel about who should lead the party on to the next elections in 2001.

January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Protests Against Chiluba's Election Falter


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - The great nerve with which opposition parties sought to petition President Chiluba's election on the contention that he is not Zambian, has began to die down and interest seemingly being lost.

Although five opposition parties have so far petitioned President Chiluba's November 18 election, there has been little activity in the courts. 

The court action has been going on rather quietly with the most recent development being a refusal by lawyers of the petitioners to furnish the state with facts on their claims. The lawyers said the facts would come up at a later stage. The parties that have petitioned include UNIP, which boycotted the elections, the Agenda for Zambia, the National Congress Party and the Zambia Democratic Congress.

Africa News


January 8, 1997


Science and Health;
Zambian AIDS Scourge Worries Policy Experts


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - Zambian policy makers are concerned that an ever-growing number of people in the working group are contracting HIV and dying of Aids. There is concern that the nation is losing some of its best brains and that this could affect development of the country. 

The fear is that a lot of money that is going to the training of young people could go to waste because some of them would die of Aids before their knowledge is utilised.

According to demographic statistics recently released , the Aids pandemic by the year 2002 will reduce the life expectancy from the current 51 years to 45. The statistics also show that the younger generation is at the most risk of contracting the virus.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian Manufacturers Demand Fair Competition With Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) has demanded that government impose trade disadvantages on Zimbabwean companies tendering for Zambian government and parastatal business. The manufacturers say that this should be done in retaliation for the tender disadvantages that Zambian companies are subjected to by Zimbabwe. 

They note that any Zambian exporter attempting to supply their product to Zimbabwe would have to contend with the fact that:

1. Goods made in Zimbabwe will be given a 10% price advantage over the imported price

2. Goods made in Zimbabwe with their Bureau of Standards mark, will be given 11% preference in price

3. Imported products will attract 7.5% import duty

4. Imported products will attracted a further 3% surcharge.

The Zambian manufacturers demand that because of this unfair playing field, the Zambian government should immediately ensure that "all Zimbabwean companies tendering for Zambian government and parastatal business must be given the same tender disadvantage" They also demand that there should be no further talks on a proposed trade agreement between the two countries until there is an assurance that the Zimbabweans intend to remove all their tariff and non-tariff barriers as outlined above.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
High Fertiliser Prices Threaten Agriculture Production


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - This year's agriculture produce, especially maize which is the country's staple food, is expected to fall because many farmers cannot afford fertilisers needed for a good yield. Both the commercial farmers and the peasant farmers have complained that the prices of the fertiliser, imported through donor aid, were too high for them to afford and grow the desired amount of maize this year. 

Government has said it cannot reduce the prices pegged at between K30,000 and K50,000 (about $23 to $40) because a targeted amount has to be realised to cover the cost of the importation. Government has also advised farmers to pass on the cost to the price of their produce. Many farmers may want to do this, but they cannot get the required loans to cover the cost because lending institutions are skeptical about the farmers' ability to repay loans, as was experienced last farming season.

The Zambia National Farmers Union has called on government to review its agriculture policies if the sector is to survive. The problem is compounded by poor logistics on how to transport the input to all parts of the country.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia's Crime Rate Falls But Criminals Get More Brutal


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Lusaka - Early last year, a smartly dressed wanted criminal walked into the casualty ward of the University Teaching Hospital (UTH) in Lusaka. He walked up to a bed on which lay a colleague who was shot and wounded by police two days earlier and pulled out a gun. At point blank range, he shot his colleague dead. A policeman assigned to guard the wounded criminal dashed to the scene only to meet a hail of bullet. He too died instantly as the gunman made his exit and fled.

Towards the end of the year, a gang of bandits crept up to a police tent pitched by the roadside at a road-block and shot dead two policemen before they could reach for their weapons. 

In between these two incidents in 1996 the police have had numerous gun battles with armed robbers. Both sides have taken casualties but it is the daring attacks on police personnel that have stolen the limelight. This is also causing concern with the police who now have to contend with a much more brutal brand of bandits. The police have, however, been swift in countering direct attacks on their personnel. In the UTH shooting, the culprit was cornered within days in a rural town about 300kms east of Lusaka. He was brought to Lusaka but was not given a chance to appear in court as he died in police custody from injuries believed to have been received in the cells.

The killing of the two policemen in the Copperbelt Province was a couple of days later followed by an ambush by the police on an hideout of some bandits. The bandits escaped into the night and are believed to have crossed into neighbouring Zaire.

Early in the year, Chief of Police Francis Ndhlovu stated that the police were in a much better position than ever before to contend with an evidently more daring and brutal clique of criminals. He also declared "total war" against bandits in an effort to reduce the crime rate in the country.

The government has also constantly assured members of the public to remain calm in the wave of crime. Following the shooting of three policemen in two days on the Copperbelt last month, the region's deputy permanent secretary Thomas Chibanga, said members of the public should not worry because the law enforcement wings had the capacity to contain the crime scourge. According to police statistics, the war seems to be going in the favour of the police. Last year, about 4,000 crimes were recorded, indicating a considerable drop from previous years when figures went beyond 7,000.

Police public relations officer Francis Musonda notes that the decline in figures indicates that crime prevention is more effective now. In 1995, 5,867 crimes were recorded, in 1994 there were 7,013, in 1993 there were 7,148. Aggravated robberies have topped the list of crimes in all years with 1,037 recorded last year. Almost each day an armed robbery is recorded, with, on some occasions, victims shot dead and women raped. Most of the robberies are of cars, usually snatched from the owners in ambushes. Many of the stolen cars are sold in neighbouring countries, especially Zaire.

The sources of guns used in the robberies have been another major source of concern for the police. It is generally suspected that most of the weapons used in the crimes are brought in from neighbouring Zaire. The criminals' frequent use of guns and attire similar to that used by the Zambian paramilitary personnel is, however, raising suspicion that some police personnel could be involved in the supply of the weapons to criminals or that they themselves carry out the crimes.

But the police, however, are of the opinion that some members of the public are suppliers of guns to criminals. This is despite the fact that it is difficult to legally own a gun in Zambia because of the red-tape and high licence fees. Last year, in an effort to reduce the number of guns illegally in the hands of the members of the public, the police offered an amnesty to all those who would surrender their guns. The response was poor despite two extensions and the police have kept the result secret.

A recent incident, however, seems to confirm that some policemen could be might be involved in crime. Police gave chase to a suspected car thief who ignored warning shots for him to stop. Instead he shot back at the police. Eventually, he was shot dead and he turned out to be a son of a senior police officer. It is suspected that he got the weapon from a police sentry. And, in a twist of fate, the policemen involved in the shooting have been arrested and charged with murder.

There has also been an increase in crimes whose motives are either unknown or point to the victims being targeted for murder by hired killers. Occasionally houses are broken into the homes and people killed without the contents of the house being disturbed. One such bizarre case was recorded in Chanyanya about 100kms south of Lusaka, where an old woman and two of her grandchildren were murdered in their house. Nothing in the house was touched. In other incidents, motorists are shot at but the motive is evidently not to steal the vehicles. The latest outrage that is being committed by suspected hired killers is that of throwing strong acid onto the face and body of victims. Last month, two men were arrested after doing this. They claimed they had been hired for a fee of one million Chat (about 800 US dollars).

The decline in crime is also attributed to the vigilance among members of the public, some of whom are increasingly taking the law into their own hands to deal with criminals because of lack of confidence in the police. A major issue that came up last year in the dealing of criminals was the stoning and burning to death of any suspect caught stealing. A more civilised manner of dealing with crime has been the proliferation of neighbourhood watch schemes in which people in a community take turns in patrolling their area with the assistance of the police. Areas with effective neighbourhood watch schemes have had very low crime incidents.

The latest innovation has been the introduction of community policing in the commercial centre of Lusaka. The area had long been a haven for criminals ranging from pick pockets to armed robbers. Shop owners now operate together to repel the robbers and scheme is showing positive results as relative peace has returned to the commercial centre.

The new year has began on another bloody note with the brutal killing of four wildlife officers who were trying to arrest illegal fishermen. This could be an indicator of another tough year ahead for policemen who are now just as vulnerable to attacks as any other citizen or resident of the country.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 8, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 74 on the Great Lakes (01/08)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Nairobi - Following Monday's denial by Paris, of French troops in the eastern town of Kisangani, Le Monde reported that retired Colonel Alain Le Carro, the former head of the French GSPR presidential security cell, and Robert Montoya former gendarme from the anti-terrorist cell are allegedly linked to the recruitment of mercenaries for Zaire. Both men denied their involvement.

Le Monde reported that there were some 200-300 soldiers, dubbed the "White Legion", stationed in Kisangani to train Zairian forces. Ten of their numbers are saided to be former French soldiers while others are alleged to be recruits from Belgium, Britain, Angola, Mozambique and South Africa. Le Monde said that their numbers are expected to increase significantly in upcoming weeks with the expected arrival of new recruits from Europe.The mercenary forces are expect to buy time for General Mahele to clean-up and reorganize Zaire's armed Forces. 

Strongly denying any official involvement, a spokesperson from the French presidency told Reuters they had no knowledge of such a force. Another spokesperson from the French Defense Minister stated that the presence of former French soldiers "could in no way infer that there was a link with French policy in the region." Although France is known to support President Mobutu, it is prevented by the international arms embargo on Zaire from providing military aid.

The South African security firm Executive Outcomes denied all involvement in the recruitment of soldiers; however, Le Monde claimed that some of the soldiers were recruited from among their numbers. Former Angolan rebel chief Jonas Savimbi also denied that his forces were assisting Zairian troops in Kisangani.

On 7 January, rebel leader Laurent Desire Kabila told AFP that the Zairian army was carrying out "very deep reconnaissance" missions from Kisangani, some 500 km west of Goma, towards rebel held territory. In an interview with the Ugandan journal "The Sunday Vision" on 5 January Kabila also claimed that Zaire was using Hutu ex-FAR to fight ADFL forces.

According to a Reuters report the Zairian government continues to rule out negotiations with ADFL rebel leader Laurent Kabila despite the fact that many politicians in Zaire are increasingly in favour of a peaceful settlement.

While on a visit to Paris, the former Zairian Minister of Information in the 1960 government of Patrice Lumumba, and currently a member of the Zairian parliament, Anicet Kashamura, stated in a press communique that he has joined with rebel leader Kabila. Mr. Kashamura also called on the US, France and Belgium to support the ADFL against Mobutu's dictatorship.

In an address to soldiers the new army chief General Mahele claimed the army was waiting for a green light from President Mobutu to begin their counter-offensive. In stressing the point that the army would fight according to internationally accepted rules he stated, "We will not harm civilians, our target is known." Residents in the rebel occupied territory have expressed anxiety over how Kinshasa would view those who remained in the area, as collaborators or an occupied population. Despite the semblence of normalcy in Goma, an AFP report indicated that several residents had fled or had made arrangements to flee in the event of a successful counter-offensive by Zairian forces. Analysts believe that Kinshasa's view of the civilians in the rebel held territory could impact on civilian loyalty in the event of a counter-offensive.

* Reuters reported that Kabila's ADFL has set up a training camp for new recruits at Rumangabo, 60 km north of Goma. Despite the training of several thousand new recruits they have yet to be incorporated into the core of the ADFL forces which remain predominantly Tutsi.

In a further effort to reign in its former allies the ADFL ordered the arrest of key Mai-Mai leaders. Star Radio, the ADFL mouthpiece, said the orders followed recent fighting between the Mai-Mai and ADFL forces. The Mai- Mai are composed primarily of teenagers grouped into units from their home areas. They have a strong belief in magic fetishes which they believe makes then invincible in battle. The alliance between Kabila's disciplined Banyamulenge troops and local Zairian warrior groups was disrupted by the recent return of President Mobutu to Zaire and the announcement of a counter- offensive by Zaire forces. Since then, the Mai-Mai have been involved in attacks on civilians and more recently against the ADFL forces. Over the last few weeks Kabila has announced various unsuccessful initiatives, including disarmament and retraining, to control the Mai-Mai violence. Reuters reported that the Mai-Mai continue to mutiny. In Butembo some 33 people, including 20 Mai-Mai warriors, were killed in fighting over the past week with alliance forces. Similar skirmishes were also reported in Rwindi and Bunia, 100 km and 360 km north of Goma respectively. Analyst believe that the internal conflict between the Banyamulenge and local ethnic groups allied to ADFL brings into question the strength of the alliance in the face of a possible Zairian counter-offensive.

* Kabila told AFP that he has been in regular contact with four unidentified foreign companies who have concessions in the Kilo Milo gold fields near Bunia, which fell to ADFL forces over Christmas. Kabila had issued an ultimatum to companies with mining concessions to resume operations by 3 January or risk losing them. To date, Kabila claims no company has resumed its activities because of "warmongering in Europe". If they become operational they are expected to provide enough financing for the ADFL war effort and the payment of wages for civil servants in the occupied towns.

* Over the weekend, Kenya launched an operation to round up alleged Rwandan Hutu militants. However, a police source told AFP that no arrests had been made to date and that the operation had been halted until 9 January. Recent reports indicated that several Hutu refugees had arrived in Mombasa from Tanzania. Other Hutu refugees are reported to have been operating businesses in Kenya since fleeing Rwanda in 1994.

* According to the state-owned Ugandan "New Vision" on Monday, there was fierce fighting on Sunday between the UPDF and Ugandan ADF rebels in Kampasa, deep in the Rwenzori Mountains. The fighting is reported to have involved 1000 UPDF troops. Kampasa is about 40 kms from Bwera town, Kasese, high up in the mountains. The paper quoted a senior military commander as saying that Kampasa is 'the real ADF base'.

* Radio Burundi reported the arrival on 8 January of the US envoy to the Great Lakes Region in Burundi.

Nairobi, 8 January 1997, 13:35 gmt (ENDS)

62 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Little Progress Made In Controlling Malaria


BYLINE: Oumar Dieng, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Two decades of efforts to control malaria have yielded little progress in reducing the intensity of the disease, which affects between 300 million and 500 million people each year in the developing countries.

In Africa, the world's major parasitic disease kills more than one million children below the age of five years annually. Apart from tuberculosis, malaria is the leading transmittable disease that causes more deaths than any other. 

World Health Organization (WHO) statistics indicate that 90 percent of the world's malaria-related cases and deaths occur in Sub-Sahara Africa. According to experts, malaria mainly attacks children, pregnant women, non- immunized travellers, refugees, displaced persons and farm workers.

It is in view of the severity of the disease in Africa that health experts are in Dakar attending an international conference on malaria, which was opened Monday by the Senegalese president, Abdou Diouf.

A study by the WHO says that malaria is a public health problem in at least 90 countries representing about 2.4 billion people, or 40 percent of the world population.

Although the disease has been known since antiquity, it has remained as a serious public health problem.

Malaria is transmitted through bites by the anopheles mosquito, which inject into humans single celled parasites called falciparium plasmodium.

The WHO malaria eradication campaigns have failed due to lack of money and because of the emergence of insecticide-resistant anopheles mosquitoes.

As a result, instead of insisting on eradicating malaria, the focus is now to reduce the disease's mortality, morbidity as well as its negative economic and social impact. This change of strategy was recommended by an international conference on malaria held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, in October 1992.

Malaria experts concede that the presence of drug-resistant mosquitoes, first observed in the 1970s, have complicated the treatment of malaria cases.

The malaria vector has managed to adapt to the insecticides which now in use. Because of this development, almost all programmes which were initiated to combat the vector in Africa have failed, except in some islands located far from the mainland.

Even the optimism raised by the use of insecticide-treated mosquito nets has not proved to be the panacea. Consequently, experts say that more investments are required to fund malaria research.

There is much optimism that something new could emerge from the Dakar conference when it ends later today. The meeting was sponsored by the United States National Health Institute, European Union, the Pasteur Institute of Paris, France, and United Kingdom Medical Research Council.

The conference is expected to enable experts from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe to review the existing anti-malaria strategies.

LANGUAGE: English
