Africa News


January 9, 1997


South Africa;
Presence Of Mercenaries In Zaire Denied


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - A private South African security firm, Executive Outcomes, has denied allegations that it had deployed mercenaries in eastern Zaire and had, instead, called for a top-level investigation into charge.

In a statement released Wednesday in Pretoria, the company asked that the investigation be conducted personally by South Africa's National Police Commissioner, George Fivaz, and the director-generals of the South African Secret Service and the National Intelligence Agency. 

Recent media reports had claimed that several hundred European and African mercenaries were assembling in eastern Zaire to help counter the advancing anti-government forces, known as the Banyamulenge.

The reports claimed that more mercenaries were expected to leave Europe later in January to join Angolan, Belgian, British, French, Mozambican and South African mercenaries in Zaire. The reports also claimed that Executive Outcomes was involved in the operation.

Meanwhile, the leader of Angola's former Unita rebel movement, Jonas Savimbi, has denied Banyamulenge claims that his forces are fighting alongside Zairian Government troops. The leader of the Banyamulenge forces, Laurent Kabila, claimed earlier this week that an unknown number of South African mercenaries and 2,000 Unita troops had joined 3,000 to 4,000 government troops in the central Zairean town of Kisangani to prepare for an assault on the Banyamulenge.

Savimbi said that all 65,000 of his troops, the number verified by the United Nations, are in Angola and are either being integrated into the national army or waiting to be demobilized.

"I am specifying with all my heart that we do not have one single man in Zaire," Savimbi said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 9, 1997


Ghana;
Rawlings Worried By Flow Of Refugees Into Ghana


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry Rawlings has expressed displeasure at refugees flocking into his country, saying they are becoming a burden on Ghana.

He said Ghana welcomed people who contributed the country's economic development but was increasingly worried over immigrants who were a liability. 

Rawlings said this Wednesday in an audience with Tambari Sanoussi, a Minister of State in Niger, who called on the president at the Castle, Osu, the official residence.

Sanoussi led his country's delegation to Tuesday's inauguration of President Rawlings and Vice-President John E. Atta Mills. Leaders of delegations from Benin, Guinea, Liberia and Togo, who attended the inauguration, also called on the Rwalings.

Apart from Liberian refugees, who fled their country's civil war, Ghana is also saddled with economic refugees, mainly from neighbouring Sahelian countries.

Rawlings said the best way to curb the influx of refugees from the sub- region into Ghana was for the governments of those countries to improve their economies and thus discourage their nationals from leaving.

At another meeting, with Liberian Foreign Minister Monie Captan, Rawlings said that the sub-region was getting tired of its role in the war-torn country and might not go beyond the June time limit to withdraw peace- monitoring troops.

Under the Abuja Peace Accord, the West African Peace Monitoring Group, or ECOMOG, will on Jan. 31, complete disarming Liberia's warring factions.

Elections are scheduled for May and a President inaugurated in June to hopefully end the seven-year civil war.

Rawlings said that West African countries contributing troops to ECOMOG had pumped so much money into Liberia that they were getting exhausted.

"It's gone on for far too long, and we cannot go beyond the schedule. We are coming to the end of our tether," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


65 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 9, 1997


United States and Africa;
United Nations Chief To Meet Clinton


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan announced Thursday that he would travel to Washington D.C. on Jan. 23 to meet with United States President Bill Clinton.

Annan told correspondents at the U.N. that he would use the meeting, the first between him and any head of state since he took office Jan. 1, to discuss U.S.-U.N. relations, particularly the settlement of Washington's 1.3 billion U.S. dollar debt to the world body. 

"I will also try and explain to them the need to work with other member states of the organization," Annan said.

When the U.S. debt is added to those of other nations, the U.N. is owed 2.3 billion dollars. The U.S. pays a quarter of the U.N. yearly budget.

Annan will also meet with the chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms.

On Tuesday, outgoing U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher met Annan at the U.N. headquarters in New York and promised that President Clinton would make recommendations on the U.S. debt in the next U.S. budget.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 9, 1997


Ethiopia;
Trial Witnesses Relate Disappearances of Relatives


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The trial of former top officials of the Ethiopian military regime, called the Derg, resumed Thursday with five witnesses for the prosecution relating experiences of torture of fellow prisoners and the disappearances of close relatives.

The witnesses were testifying in Addis Ababa against 71 Derg members accused of genocide and crimes against humanity. 

Twenty-five of the defendants are being tried in absentia. Among them is the former leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, who fled Addis Ababa for exile in Harare, Zimbabwe, a few days before the collapse of his regime in May 1991.

Three of the witnesses spoke of the disappearances of close relatives who had been arrested at the height of the "Red Terror" campaign in Addis Ababa for anti-revolutionary activities. They were believed to have been executed, without trial, by the military regime.

The campaign was launched following an attempt to kill Mengistu in Addis Ababa in October 1976. He was then deputy chairman of the Derg.

So far, 114 prosecution witnesses have testified. The trial resumes Jan 16.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Little Progress Made In Controlling Malaria


BYLINE: Oumar Dieng, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1190 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Two decades of efforts to control malaria have yielded little progress in reducing the intensity of the disease, which affects between 300 million and 500 million people each year in the developing countries.

In Africa, the world's major parasitic disease kills more than one million children below the age of five years annually. Apart from tuberculosis, malaria is the leading transmittable disease that causes more deaths than any other. 

World Health Organization (WHO) statistics indicate that 90 percent of the world's malaria-related cases and deaths occur in Sub-Sahara Africa. According to experts, malaria mainly attacks children, pregnant women, non- immunized travellers, refugees, displaced persons and farm workers.

It is in view of the severity of the disease in Africa that health experts are in Dakar attending an international conference on malaria, which was opened Monday by the Senegalese president, Abdou Diouf.

A study by the WHO says that malaria is a public health problem in at least 90 countries representing about 2.4 billion people, or 40 percent of the world population.

Although the disease has been known since antiquity, it has remained as a serious public health problem.

Malaria is transmitted through bites by the anopheles mosquito, which inject into humans single celled parasites called falciparium plasmodium.

The WHO malaria eradication campaigns have failed due to lack of money and because of the emergence of insecticide-resistant anopheles mosquitoes.

As a result, instead of insisting on eradicating malaria, the focus is now to reduce the disease's mortality, morbidity as well as its negative economic and social impact. This change of strategy was recommended by an international conference on malaria held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, in October 1992.

Malaria experts concede that the presence of drug-resistant mosquitoes, first observed in the 1970s, have complicated the treatment of malaria cases.

The malaria vector has managed to adapt to the insecticides which now in use. Because of this development, almost all programmes which were initiated to combat the vector in Africa have failed, except in some islands located far from the mainland.

Even the optimism raised by the use of insecticide-treated mosquito nets has not proved to be the panacea. Consequently, experts say that more investments are required to fund malaria research.

There is much optimism that something new could emerge from the Dakar conference when it ends later today. The meeting was sponsored by the United States National Health Institute, European Union, the Pasteur Institute of Paris, France, and United Kingdom Medical Research Council.

The conference is expected to enable experts from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe to review the existing anti-malaria strategies.

South Africa;
Presence Of Mercenaries In Zaire Denied


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - A private South African security firm, Executive Outcomes, has denied allegations that it had deployed mercenaries in eastern Zaire and had, instead, called for a top-level investigation into charge.

In a statement released Wednesday in Pretoria, the company asked that the investigation be conducted personally by South Africa's National Police Commissioner, George Fivaz, and the director-generals of the South African Secret Service and the National Intelligence Agency. 

Recent media reports had claimed that several hundred European and African mercenaries were assembling in eastern Zaire to help counter the advancing anti-government forces, known as the Banyamulenge.

The reports claimed that more mercenaries were expected to leave Europe later in January to join Angolan, Belgian, British, French, Mozambican and South African mercenaries in Zaire. The reports also claimed that Executive Outcomes was involved in the operation.

Meanwhile, the leader of Angola's former Unita rebel movement, Jonas Savimbi, has denied Banyamulenge claims that his forces are fighting alongside Zairian Government troops. The leader of the Banyamulenge forces, Laurent Kabila, claimed earlier this week that an unknown number of South African mercenaries and 2,000 Unita troops had joined 3,000 to 4,000 government troops in the central Zairean town of Kisangani to prepare for an assault on the Banyamulenge.

Savimbi said that all 65,000 of his troops, the number verified by the United Nations, are in Angola and are either being integrated into the national army or waiting to be demobilized.

"I am specifying with all my heart that we do not have one single man in Zaire," Savimbi said.

Ghana;
Rawlings Worried By Flow Of Refugees Into Ghana


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry Rawlings has expressed displeasure at refugees flocking into his country, saying they are becoming a burden on Ghana.

He said Ghana welcomed people who contributed the country's economic development but was increasingly worried over immigrants who were a liability. 

Rawlings said this Wednesday in an audience with Tambari Sanoussi, a Minister of State in Niger, who called on the president at the Castle, Osu, the official residence.

Sanoussi led his country's delegation to Tuesday's inauguration of President Rawlings and Vice-President John E. Atta Mills. Leaders of delegations from Benin, Guinea, Liberia and Togo, who attended the inauguration, also called on the Rwalings.

Apart from Liberian refugees, who fled their country's civil war, Ghana is also saddled with economic refugees, mainly from neighbouring Sahelian countries.

United States and Africa;
United Nations Chief To Meet Clinton


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan announced Thursday that he would travel to Washington D.C. on Jan. 23 to meet with United States President Bill Clinton.

Annan told correspondents at the U.N. that he would use the meeting, the first between him and any head of state since he took office Jan. 1, to discuss U.S.-U.N. relations, particularly the settlement of Washington's 1.3 billion U.S. dollar debt to the world body. 

"I will also try and explain to them the need to work with other member states of the organization," Annan said.

When the U.S. debt is added to those of other nations, the U.N. is owed 2.3 billion dollars. The U.S. pays a quarter of the U.N. yearly budget.

Annan will also meet with the chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms.

On Tuesday, outgoing U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher met Annan at the U.N. headquarters in New York and promised that President Clinton would make recommendations on the U.S. debt in the next U.S. budget.

Ethiopia;
Trial Witnesses Relate Disappearances of Relatives


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency

LENGTH: 227 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The trial of former top officials of the Ethiopian military regime, called the Derg, resumed Thursday with five witnesses for the prosecution relating experiences of torture of fellow prisoners and the disappearances of close relatives.

The witnesses were testifying in Addis Ababa against 71 Derg members accused of genocide and crimes against humanity. 

Twenty-five of the defendants are being tried in absentia. Among them is the former leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, who fled Addis Ababa for exile in Harare, Zimbabwe, a few days before the collapse of his regime in May 1991.

Three of the witnesses spoke of the disappearances of close relatives who had been arrested at the height of the "Red Terror" campaign in Addis Ababa for anti-revolutionary activities. They were believed to have been executed, without trial, by the military regime.

The campaign was launched following an attempt to kill Mengistu in Addis Ababa in October 1976. He was then deputy chairman of the Derg.

So far, 114 prosecution witnesses have testified. The trial resumes Jan 16.

72 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa: Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The shootout between French troops and mutineers of the Central African Republic army, French President Jacques Chirac's call for intervention in eastern Zaire and the battle for privatization of Cote D'Ivoire's telecommunications service were the issues discussed in editorials in the African press.

Le Soleil commented on the reasons for the shooting to death of two French soldiers by the Mutineers in Bangui.

The shooting occurred, it said, because the mutineers were frustrated by the presence of French soldiers who frustrated the rebels' attempt to overthrow President Ange-Felix Patasse. 

It noted that the former Malian military leader, Amadou Toumani Toure, was the leading peace negotiator between the mutineers and the government but wondered whether, under the circumstances, he would succeed.

"Will the mutineers have the strength to overcome their resentment, after the shooting, and engage in dialogue?" it asked.

Kinshasa newspapers focused on the talks between Presidents Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya and Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, to find solution to the Banyamulenge revolt in eastern Zaire.

A Kinshasa bi-weekly, La Societe, said that Moi, with backing of France and the United States, had tried to convince Mobutu to negotiate with the Banyamulenge leader, Laurent Kabila, and his allies.

The Kenyan approach, it said, confirmed that Zaire's eastern neighbors, particularly Uganda and Rwanda, supported Kabila.

Another bi-weekly, L' Avenir, wondered whether after Zaire's "humiliating battle losses" at the hand of the Banyamulenge, Kinshasa would negotiate.

A Dakar newspaper, Sud Quotidien, noted that French President Jacques Chirac had called for an international force to end the rebellion. But, it noted, since the United States remained indifferent to this proposal, France was unable and would not try to intervene alone.

On economic matters, Ivorian newspapers commented on the plans to privatize the country's telecommunications sector. They also spoke of the battle between French and Malay interests for the Ivorian concern, CI-Telecom, which was the center of this privatization bid.

The Abidjan paper, Jour, said that the so-called privatization of CI- Telecom looked like "a masquerade" for selling it to France Telecom.

"If this masquerade has been confirmed by the authorities, businessmen should draw conclusions," it said, and that would be that "Cote D'Ivoire is well and truly the preserve of French business interests."

For its part, Republicain Ivoirien said that the French could not possibly lose out because Paris "considers Cote D'Ivoire as Africa's showcase."

For this reason, it said, it wondered whether bidding had been fair since France already controlled the Ivorian energy and water utilities.

"Overall, the (President Konan) Bedie government is the winner. With these gifts to France, it can expect to continue being the guarantor of French interest in Cote d'Ivoire," it said.

La Voie, another Abidjan paper, referred to an "underground war" between the U.S. and France (through Africa Bell and France Telecom), and said that the U.S. had been kept out of the deal to the advantage of the French.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Great Lakes;
Cholera Kills Over 100 In The Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - An outbreak of cholera has killed more than 100 people in the troubled Great Lakes region, currently teeming with refugees or displaced persons.

The death toll was revealed here Thursday by the head of epidemiological services at the Brazzaville-based African regional office of the World Health Organization (WHO), Dr Andre Ndikuyeze. 

Addressing a news conference to review the situation since fighting erupted in eastern Zaire last September, he said 8,000 cases of diarrhoea and 100 cases of cholera had been registered on the Rwanda-Zaire border.

The disease killed five of the cases diagnosed, the WHO official added.

Ndikuyeze said that 100 deaths were recorded from 3,500 cases which were diagnosed among refugees who crossed from Zaire to Tanzania.

Another cholera epidemic, he added, had killed 10 people in Burundi's Rumonge province. However, the epidemic had been controlled and the cholera- related mortality had also been reduced all over the region.

But, WHO had to spend nearly three million U.S. dollars, which it received from various donors, to deal with all the emergency health and humanitarian needs.

Ndikuyeze said WHO will organize a meeting in Nairobi in February to prepare a contingent plan for emergency humanitarian intervention in the region.

The meeting will be attended by countries neighbouring Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Blue Chips Tumble On GSE, But Volume Picks Up


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian local council elections will now take place March 15, officials have said.

The chairman of the National Electoral Commission, Sumner Dagogo-Jack, said Thursday that these polls would be preceded, on Feb. 24, by ward congresses to nominate candidates and select delegates for local council party congresses. 

Only candidates of the five political parties approved by the military government of Gen. Sani Abacha will be involved in the council elections.

Party congresses will be held Feb. 26, to nominate candidates for the councils' chairmanship. Elected councillors are to be inaugurated March 24.

The council polls, initially scheduled for the last quarter of 1996, were postponed following the creation of 183 new local council areas in the country.

The Electoral Commission has said that voters' registration for the local council polls will begin Feb. 10 throughout this country of some 100 million people.

Registration will last 10 days, after which voters' lists will be published from Feb. 21-25 for people who might have claims and objections.

The local council polls are expected to be a major step in the military government's plan to return Nigeria to civilian rule by October 1998.

Nigeria has been ruled by the military for 26 years since the nation became independent from Britain on Oct. 1, 1960.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


South Africa;
Buchner Linked To Inkatha Gun-running


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Johannesburg - GENERAL Jac Buchner, former police commissioner in the old KwaZulu homeland, has been implicated in running large supplies of war matG riel to Inkatha paramilitaries in the early 1990s by former members of the police special forces unit that operated out of the Vlakplaas base near Pretoria.

The evidence has been presented by former Vlakplaas agents to the truth commission. It indicates that Buchner was involved in supplying truckloads of weapons - assault rifles, rocket launchers, landmines, rockets and ammunition - to members of the Inkatha Freedom Party when he was the commissioner of police for the KwaZulu homeland. 

The information is also in the possession of the Transvaal attorney general and is being investigated by his officials. This is the first time Buchner has been linked to the gun-running operation and it is likely he will feature, either as an accused or as a witness, in a huge trial that is expected to come before the courts early this year.

Former Vlakplaas commander Eugene de Kock first exposed the clandestine gun- running operation during his murder trial when he named IFP senator Philip Powell, former homeland minister CJ Mtetwa and Transvaal Inkatha leaders Themba Koza and Humphrey Ndlovu as key middlemen in the weapons programme.

De Kock also claimed at least four other police generals at the time - including Basie Smit, Krappies Engelbrecht, Nick van Rensburg and a General Steyn - were aware of the fact that Vlakplaas was ordered to supply a batch of home-made shotguns to Inkatha's paramilitary units.

But the Vlakplaas commander never mentioned the name of the former KwaZulu police commissioner in his court testimony, probably because De Kock is known to have been fiercely loyal to Buchner since he fought with him during the Rhodesian bush war in the 1960s. De Kock was introduced to his wife in Rhodesia at the time by Buchner, and the two men have remained loyal friends.

It is also known that Buchner was a member of the Badger Unit, an association of police and military covert operatives set up by De Kock and his colleagues in the early 1990s. The Badger Unit has been implicated in various gun-running operations, including the project to supply Inkatha militias with weaponry.

Now other Vlakplaas officers - including De Kock's one-time confidant, Chappie Kloppers - have not only confirmed their commander's account of how Vlakplaas ferried weapons to Inkatha, but have also added the former homeland police commissioner's name to the list.

Buchner was highly decorated during the Rhodesian bush war when he fought with South African police forces there. He then acquired a reputation in the security police during the 1970s - when he was in charge of "debriefing" captured guerillas - for his uncanny ability to use a combination of torture and psychological pressure to turn captured African National Congress cadres into police agents, or askaris. He was the mastermind of the police's askari units that worked with Vlakplaas to infiltrate and assassinate ANC-aligned activists in the 1980s.

It was suspected Buchner used his office after he became police commissioner for KwaZulu to provide clandestine state support for the Zulu nationalist movement, but this is the first time strong evidence has emerged to show this.

Efforts to contact Buchner for comment were not successful at the time of going to press.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Last Decades Of Menilek's Reign


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Addis Ababa - The last decades of Menilek's (1889-1913) reign marked the beginning of Ethiopia's modernisation, which had been delayed, among other reasons by almost a century of internal or external warfare.

An unprecedented period of peace after the battle of Adwa, the opening up of foreign contacts in the aftermath of the Italian defeat, and the advent of increasing numbers of foreign craftsmen, created an entirely new climate for economic and technological developent. This owed much also to the Emperor's almost child-like interest in innovations of all kinds, and to the ability of his trusted Swiss engineer Alfred Ilg. 

All these factors contributed to the founding at this time of a modern state. The Founding of Addis Ababa One of the earliest developments in the field of modernisation had its origin in 1881, when Menilek, then only king of Shawa, abandoned the old Shawan capital, Ankobar, and established his headquarters further south, on the mountain of Entoto. Later, in 1886, his consort Queen Taytu, and her courtiers, moved down to the nearby plain, the site of thermal waters. There they set up a new place of abode. Taytu named it Addis Ababa, literally New Flower. Five yeras later it became the capital of the Ethiopian realm, The settlement, which rapidly acquired the character of a boon town, had by 1910 an estimated population of around 70,000 permanent and 30,000 to 50,000 temporary inhabitants. The town became the site of many of the country's principal innovations, and, because of its sizeable population, enabled a degree of specialisation of labour scarcely known elsewhere in the land.

Enter the Russians The growth of Addis Ababa, which was particularly rapid after the battle of Adwa, was accompanied by the construction of some of the country's earliest modern bridges. They were important in that the land in and around the capital was broken up by deep ravines, which were filled during the rainy season by unfordable torrents. One of the first Addis Ababa bridges was erected by a group of Russians after one of their number was drowned on the way to or from the then nearby Russian Legation. Other bridges were built over the Awash river on the trade route to the Gulf of Aden coast, and in Gojjam. Its local ruler, King Takla Haymanot, obtained the bridge- building services of an enterprising Italian, Count Salimbeni.

Where Tewodros had Failed Partly in view of the impending conflict with the Italians, Menilek subsequently reorganised the system of taxation. He instituted a tithe for the upkeep of the army, in 1892. This marked an important step, which Emperor Tewodros had attempted, but for lack of resources had failed to take, towards terminating the old, but iniquitous system, whereby the soldiers lived by looting from the peasantry.

New Money The need to assert Ethiopian sovereignty in the face of Italy's Protectorate claim may well also have helped to prompt Menilek to issue the country's first national currency in 1894. This, according to the Ethio- Italian Additional Convention of 1889 was to have been struck in Italy, but Menilek, after denuncing the Italo-Ethiopian Wechale treaty, of 1889, had it minted in Paris instead. The at least partially political motive for instituting the new currency was revealed in an official proclamation. It declared that this money was introduced "in order that our country may increase in honour and our commerce prosper". The new money bore the then politically relevant Biblical motto: "Ethiopia stretches forth her hands to God", as well as effigies of Menilek and the Lion of Judah. The currency was based on a silver dollar, of the same weight and value as the old Austrian Maria Theresa dollar, or thaler, which had circulated throughout Ethiopia, as well as much of the Middle East, since the mid-eighteenth century. Despite this equivalence Menilek's money failed to supplant the thaler, which for the next half century was to remain the country's principal coin. A mint was later established in the palace, with Austrian help. It was used to strike Menilek's smaller denomination coins, but not the thaler piece itself, which was imported from Paris.

A Postal Service The year 1894 also witnessed the issue of Ethiopia's first postage stamps. These too were produced in Paris, and bore representations of Menilek and the Lion of Judah. The stamps were at first little used in the country itself, but were well received by philatelists, and provided the basis for the subsequent development of an efficient postal system. This owed much to the assistance of French advisers, and enabled Ethiopia to join the International Postal Union in 1908. This was the first international organisation to which the country was admitted, but by no means the last.

The Jibuti Railway Another important step taken by Menilek at this time was the granting to Ilg, in 1894, of a concession for the construction of Ethiopia's first railway, to link Addis Ababa with the French Somaliland port of Jibuti. Ilg, whose work confined him the Ethiopian capital, obtained the support of the French trader Lon Chefneux, who became his partner. Implementation of the project could not, however, take place until after the battle of Adwa, on 1 March 1896, and the consequent elimination of Italy's Protectorate claim. The French Government almost immediately afterwards the gave permission, on 5 March, for the laying of an adjacent section of the line across French protectorate territory, between Jibuti port and the Ethiopian frontier.

The railway project, however, soon ran into numerous technical, financial and political difficulties. Building operations were so delayed that the railway line reached Dire Dawa, half way between Addis Ababa and the coast, only in 1902. The original railway company then went bankrupt. Menilek was obliged to grant a second concession, in 1906, to his personal phycisian, Dr Vitalien, who had the support of the French Banque de l'Indo-Chine. Railway construction work, backed by French finance, was then resumed, and the line duly arrived at Aqaqi, in the vicinity of the capital, in 1915. The coming of the railway, the country's greatest technological achievement of the period, contributed greatly to the expansion, and permanence of Addis Ababa. Of major commercial importance, the line also led to substantial expansion of the country's import-export trade.

Railway construction was accompanied by the installation of the country's first telephone and telegraph line, which followed the railway track from the capital to the coast. This line, which was erected by the technicians working on the railway, and led from Addis Ababa to Jibuti. The line was supplemented, after the battle of Adwa, by a second one, installed by Italian electricians. It ran from the Ethiopian capital to the frontier of Eritrea, as well as to a number of provincial capitals to the south and west of the country.

Next Week: The Coming of the Eucalyptus Tree, and the First Modern Schools and Hospitals.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Prostitution and Its Impact


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

Addis Ababa - Prostitution certainly has a number of negative effects both on the individuals and the society at large. Besides its contribution to moral degradation, it also greatly undermines the institution of family as marriages get broken apart as a result of it.

The promiscuous sex relationship practiced by both the prostitutes and their customers also lead for the spread of a number of sexually transmitted diseases (STD's) pausing great threat to public health. This is particularly true especially in Ethiopia where a number of studies over the years conducted indicate.

High rate of HIV infection among prostitutes:

The role prostitutes play in perpetuating the AIDS pandemic has been studied by many investigators. Sex workers have been viewed as major reservoirs for a variety of sexually transmitted diseases in various parts of the world. 

The AIDS pandemic which few years ago was known to be a problem of western societies where deviant sexual behaviors are practiced, is now recognized from a number of sero-surveys conducted since 1984, it is also prevalent in Ethiopia. For instance, sero-epidemiological surveys carried out in 23 towns since 1988 indicated that the prevalence rate of HIV infection was 16.9 % among prostitutes, 13.0 % among long distance truck drivers, 3.7 % among blood donors, and 2.4 % among scholarship winners.

A sero-survey conducted a year later among prostitutes and long distance truck drivers, this time in 8 towns (Adaitu, Asmara, Bahirdar, Diredawa, Metu, Nazareth, Nekemt, and Addis Ababa) has revealed that the prevalence rate in these towns increases by an average of over 60 % in year's time. Studies on STD's show that these too are also on the rise.

Even among the general population, reported AIDS cases have been on the increase since 1986. This is reaching such a frightening proportion and Multi- partner sexual contact females or prostitutes play significant roles both as victims and transmitters of HIV in Ethiopia as studies done elsewhere show similar results.

The Lack of use of protective methods:

In Addis Ababa, HIV infection is on the increase which can be attributed to the large population of prostitutes in the city. In 1974, it was reported that some 80,000 prostitutes were in Addis Ababa constituting over 25 percent of the adult female population of the city. This figure has significantly increased over the years much to the great influx of women from rural areas. Besides, most of the prostitutes never use protective methods regularly. For instance, a study conducted with 2663 prostitutes in Addis Ababa and 6564 prostitutes in 23 other towns of the country on pregnancy and STD protective means used by prostitutes indicated that outside the capital city, 42.2 % (n = 2771) of the women reported using oral contraceptives always or often and only 1.8 % of all women in the study always or often used condoms.

The results were similar in the capital city. This study in Addis Ababa which was carried out among four sub-groups of prostitutes: bar girls; tej (local wine) sellers, tella (local beer) sellers, and women in red-light houses, indicated that condoms and spermicide known to protect from sexually transmitted diseases (STD) and HIV infection were very rarely used by prostitutes in the city. Of all the respondents, only 1.8% used condoms often or regularly. The reason being that the popular STD's protective means among prostitutes in Addis Ababa are condoms which often depended on the choice of the customers. The overwhelming majority do not use condoms on regular basis because of the customer's refusal. One of the bar girls in Kasanchize state when asked about as to why she never use condoms regularly,

"I prefer to use condoms and I ask the men to use them. Some say yes and others say no. If they use them well and good, but if they refuse I accept to sleep with without them. What can I do, I have no choice, I need the money."

A study conducted among 282 randomly selected prostitutes in Addis Ababa indicate that among STD/pregnancy protective means widely used by women, oral pills are reported as the most widely used taken regularly by 41.7 % of the respondents, while intra-uterine device was negligible. The use of condoms are reported to be regular or frequent by 2.9 % of the females, occasional or very rare by 56 %. No use of condom are reported by 41.4 % of the respondents.

Numerous studies in Ethiopia as in the rest of Africa have shown that prostitutes are at a higher risk of HIV infection and transmission- playing significant role in its spread. For instance, a sero-epidemiological survey on HIV infection carried out among four categories of prostitutes randomly selected in Addis Ababa that of the total 4975 females registered in 40 Kebeles (the smallest administrative unites); 2617 were interviewed and tested for HIV. The result indicated that a quarter of the female sex workers have been infected by HIV.

The major risk factors associated with HIV and other STD's infections and transmissions among prostitutes in Addis Ababa and else where in the country are:

-high number of sexual partners,

-infection with other sexually transmitted diseases,

-lack of general education, and

-duration of involvement in prostitution.

For instance, the sero-epidemiological survey on HIV infection carried in Addis Ababa among the four categories of prostitutes indicated that the rate of infection for the entire group varied from 10.3% for those having one or less partner per week to 66.7% for those with 6-7 partners per week. Also according to this survey, the highest HIV prevalence rate was in the central zone of the city which includes Mercato, Arada and other business centers covering an area of 24.759 km. The prostitute population is concentrated in this central zone which also has a high density of population of the city. This indicates that prostitutes are at a higher risk of HIV infection and transmission in Addis Ababa.

From the on going discussions, one can clearly see the effect prostitution has both on the individuals and the country at large. As in the case of Addis Ababa and other urban areas of Ethiopia where the use of protective means aimed at both safer sex and contraception is rather very low in spite of the frequent sexual practice and turn over of partners reported by multi partner sexual contact women, prostitution acts as a major vehicle for the spread of STD's including HIV. Needless to say that most of the clients are Ethiopian citizens with the exception of few foreigners mainly claiming the economically active age group of the society.

Numerous studies on prostitution show that the age group between 15-24 years is the most frequently infected. For instance, according to the one sero-epidemiological survey on HIV infection among randomly selected prostitutes in Addis Ababa indicated that HIV prevalence rates was highest among the age groups between 15-24 and 25-34 years respectively. This is also true among the general population of the reported AIDS cases, it is highest among the age groups between 20-29, 30-39 and 40-49 respectively.

AIDS cases as of 30 November, 1994. Total 15565. Source: Adapted from AIDS update, epidemiology & AIDS control department, Ministry of Health.

Ethiopia in 1993 with great openness admitted having close to half a million AIDS patients. This figure is increasing greatly as the human immune deficiency virus epidemic is showing a tremendous progress. Again prostitutes are the most important reservoir of many sexually transmittable pathogens including HIV in Ethiopia and other developing countries. The 1993 World Bank report presented at a symposium on AIDS and development held by the Abidjan based African Development Bank (ADB) said, that the disease was cutting down millions of Africans in the prime of life draining family purses and state health budgets and depressing industrial and agricultural out put; making the world's poorest continent even poorer.

Although the World Bank report said that it was impossible to estimate accurately how far AIDS was hitting national income, but it was probably cutting the rate of growth of gross domestic product per capita. The problem is even made more serious, because many African countries are trying to recover from falling per capita incomes in the 1980's. World Bank foretells that the AIDS epidemic will continue to make recovery more difficult.

The AIDS epidemic is doing more economic damages than any common diseases such as malaria because it strikes mainly at the economically-active population both rich and poor. Today, in many African countries as is the case in Ethiopia, particularly in urban areas, AIDS has doubled or tripled the adult death rate becoming the biggest adult killer. For instance, the World Bank report quoted a 1988 study showing that 25 days of inpatient AIDS treatment at Zaire's biggest hospital, Mama Yemo, cost 90 dollars, three times the average monthly income. Businesses are suffering from the loss of workers and absenteeism due to AIDS-related illness. The report also said that up to 10 percent of the Uganda railway corporation's 5,600 employees have died of AIDS over the past few years.

In Ethiopia, the AIDS toll is claiming a considerable labor force both in the rural and urban parts of the country. How can we strive hard to rebuild and develop this country when AIDS is dealing a major blow to the struggle for economic recovery and development? And if it risks reversing all of the efforts, all of the hard-won achievements of the past few years that the government so passionately boast's of?

Is prostitution a national problem yet or do we have to sit and wait until it starts knocking at every door and further break apart the family system and destroy our ailing economy? Do we have means and can we effectively exploit them to contain its spread? Thus the harmful effects of prostitution are very serious indeed and something Tshould be done to contain its spread.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Proximate Effects of Economic Policies


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Addis Ababa - In January 1996, the maximum import tariff rate was cut from 80 percent to 60 percent as a result of which the average customs rate declined from 29.5 percent to 24.5 percent. (It has been reported that the rate is now down to 50 percent ).

It would be interesting to note that the maximum customs duty was as high as 209 percent as recently as 1993. However, government revenue from import duties increased substantially from some 700 million birr in 1992/93 to over 1.6 billion birr in 1995/96. This was partly due to the devaluation of the birr which inflated the nominal import tax base in birr terms.

Besides, the decline in the weighted average customs rate, which was not as high as that in the maximum rate, is more important in determining the outcome on government revenue that the cut in the maximum rate per se, which affects only a relatively few luxury items. While imports of especially items considered luxury would have been unaffordably expansive for most people without the progressive customs tariff reduction, the rate reduction on the other hand seems to have exposed domestic import-substituting industries to rather stiff import competition, particularly in the textiles and food sectors. 

In March 1996, domestic fertilizer prices were reduced from an average of 245 birr per quintal to 195 birr per quintal. Although the measure afforded some relief to peasant farmers across the country, it is believed to have inflated the government's expenditure on subsidies. Since even at this subsidized average price, fertilizer is still expensive vis a vis average farm incomes, it is doubtful whether the peasant's perception of the high costs of farm inputs has changed in any significant way.

In July 1996, the controversial measure of banning franco valuta imports was taken by the government (franco valuta imports required no foreign exchange from the domestic banking system). Arguments for and against the measure have been entertained both in the government-owned mass media and in the private press.

As for the effects of the ban, three major questions may be raised: has the flow of imports been affected? Have domestic prices of imports gone up as a result of the narrowing of the scope for importation to only licensed importers? Has anything been lost in terms of efficiency in the import mechanism? It is difficult to ascertain the facts related to these queries on a nation-wide basis, but indications so far are that some imports (for example, used cars) are not as readily available as before and this has tended to raise domestic prices. For instance, the prices of second-hand cars have tended upward in recent months. In terms of efficiently, it a well-known fact that the franco valuta system was at least twice more efficiency than the letter-of-credit(L/C) mechanism in terms of time cost.

Also in July 1996, four measures related to foreign exchange operations were announced to have become effective. These were a) the formal institution of export retention schemes, b) the establishment of foreign exchange bureaus within commercial banks, c) the change from fortnightly to weekly foreign exchange auctions, and d) the lifting of the ban on foreign exchange access for imports of used goods with the exception of clothing. Ten percent of export earnings may now be retained in exporters' own retention accounts. The scheme has generally been received favorably by exporters. Foreign exchange bureaus have still not started actual operation at the time of writing, but when they do they are expected to at least help in decentralizing the exchange control operations of the National Bank of Ethiopia. On the other hand, the fact that foreign exchange auctions are now held every week instead of every fifteen days has improved the availability of foreign exchange. The removal of the ban on foreign exchange bidding for imports of used goods has lessened the negative impact of the abolition of the franco valuta mechanism through which such imports were allowed. Even then, the still-in-effect ban on used clothing, which now accounts for a very significant part of the purchases of clothes by the vast majority of consumers, has continued to exert its negative consequences.

It was in August 1996 that the Administration of Region 14 put into effect its unconscionable rent increases on government -owned houses used for commercial purposes. The reverberations of this drastic measure are far from dead, and its effects have in many cases become unbearably burdensome. Attempts at passing at least part of the extra costs on to consumers have so far been timid and modest at best. There is hardly any doubt that the measure has caused an enormous amount of financial distress in the business community.

By contrast, there was a bit of cheerful news in September 1996 (effective as of September 11, to be exact) when increases of no mean relative magnitude were announced in favour of low-income pensioners. The raises are by no means anywhere near the equivalent of an offset to years of cumulated inflation, but the gesture towards this nearly forgotten section of our society never failed to gladden many a heart.

But soon afterwards the bad news was upon once again. On 22 September 1996, fuel price increases were announced by the government, true to official commitments entered into with the IMF and World Bank. Strangely, there have been no offsetting increases in day-time taxi fares in Addis Ababa, for example. Sheer low purchasing power of the public and quite possibly fear of government retaliation appear to have been the reason behind tax operators' obvious error on the side of mercy.

Also in September there was another piece of news of significant economic import. The National Bank of Ethiopia, never a laggard in policy innovation, announced drastic cuts in interest rates. The minimum interest rate on bank deposits was slashed from 10 to 7 percent while the maximum lending rate was chopped from 15 to 10.5 percent. The news was received with mixed feelings. Some thought the lowering of the lending rate was a relief while some bit their lips with obvious displeasure as they quickly reckoned the prospect of dwindling interest income on their deposits. Further, the implicit narrowing down of the margin between the deposit and lending rates was not exactly the best of news for commercial banks, some of which have still not managed to get rid of their long faces on the decisions!

In July 1996, the proclamation (Proc. No. 40/1996) on so-called micro- financing institutions (or really mini-banks) was issued. The idea did initially succeed in creating some excitement among a few prospective financial investors, but it appears the enthusiasm has since evaporated as not a single new financial investor has been licensed to date on the basis of the proclamation. it is believed that some of the conditions laid down in the proclamation are not particularly attractive, which means revisions may be called for.

Mid-September witnessed a historic economic event and decision. The consultative Group Meeting for Ethiopia was held here in Addis Ababa, the first time ever the meeting took place not only in Ethiopia but also on African soil.

The outcome of the deliberations of the meeting was an unmitigated success for the ERPDF government, producing a pledge of 2.5 billion US dollars in outright grants and concessional loans from participating donor governments and international organizations, when in fact the amount requested by the Ethiopian government was only 2 billion US dollars.

The Christmas holiday mood may have been a factor in the generous extra gesture, but the whole outcome must have taken the government by surprise.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

79 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Medical Veteran Says Care Deteriorating


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

Addis Ababa - Medical care in Ethiopia has been going down hill for the past eight years, according to Dr. Pawlos Quana'a. At 62, Dr. Pawlos Quana'a, an Ophthalmic Surgeon, is as opinionated and headstrong as ever.

His recent retirement as head of the Eye Department at the Addis Ababa University far from spells out an end to one of the most illustrious medical careers in the country. He will try to re-activate his private clinic which has been sealed by the region 14 health bureau for the past year. 

By his calculation, he is most probably one of the first ten Ethiopian doctor to graduate and return to this country. "Some stupid fellow " in Wingate -- where Dr. Pawlos went to school -- told the class that the World Health Organization was giving out scholarships and those who wanted to be doctors should put up their hands. "We did not know what being a doctor meant" he explained but the whole class followed the hand of one classmate, he said. That "stupid fellow" may not have been so stupid after all, for some of the best doctors of the country came from that class.

The scholarship was for the American University of Beirut, where his London Matriculation results enabled him to go straight to the second year. Though there was a somewhat large Ethiopian community in Beirut--with four fifths of the country's senior medical staff graduating from there--the new culture took some getting used to, remembers Dr. Pawlos. When a teacher entered the class the Ethiopian students who, out of habit stood, could not help noticing the others lounging in their desks. The climate was another bone of contention. When the Ethiopians complained about the heat and humidity, the people around were quick to respond, "How did you get to be so dark then?". But it was not all discomfort and misunderstandings. They took part in special cultural shows and also had fun on the sports field. Dr. Pawlos still proudly remembers coming first in the 800 meters and taking part in soccer and the pole vault.

In 1958, he graduated and came back to Ethiopia to work at what was then known as the Princess Tsehai Memorial Hospital. Though the government was doing all it can to get more Ethiopian doctors, it was more than obvious that it still had a long way to go before it achieved its goal. "It was unbelievable" Dr. Pawlos exclaimed as he recalled that there were around five hundred foreign doctors here in Addis Ababa alone. "When it was the king's birthday the Ministry of Health would hold a cocktail, where we would be invited. we would stand by the wall with our coke in our hands" he added, " because the foreigners would have filled the room."

Patients, used to the mostly Bulgarian and Yugoslav Doctors, could not come to terms with their Ethiopian counterparts. "The patients would always complain," said Dr. Pawlos, "that the doctor had not seen them. When we went to them and said 'but I saw you this morning', they would reply 'I do not mean you, I meant the foreigner.' Of course rather capable people help change this attitude, now, it is an entirely different story. "Of the expatriate doctors, Dr. Pawlos said, "there were some good one, and of course there were some terrible ones.

Luckily, there was a General Medical Advisory Board (GMAB) that screened anybody who was not capable." In trying to illustrate clearly just how useful the GMAB was, he tells of an instance where someone with a B.A. in Education was caught in Arussi trying to pass himself for a doctor. "The nurses were complaining that the man, who came from Sudan, did not seem to be a doctor. So we went to check him out and true enough he did not know the slightest thing." Two years later, Dr. Pawlos went back to Lebanon to specialize in Eye, Ear, Nose, Throat (EENT), but found out he could only do one--so he chose the eye. When he came back to Ethiopia this time, he joined Menelik Hospital eye department. In 1970 he became head of the eye department at the Addis Ababa University. "Luckily," he explained, "eye doctors from the ministry of health would help out. But for many years, I could claim I was the only one in the university who had only one staff in his departmen." The one-man department soon expanded in 1983, when three of the first batch of eye doctors joined the department. It still remains understaffed, but Dr. Pawlos is hopeful that this might change soon. The department has now graduated around thirty-two eye doctors.

Apart from his duties at the university and Menelik Hospital, Dr. Pawlos is involved in various activities. He is the chairman of the National PolioPlus Committee, and the district coordinator of Janipur Foot for Kenya, Ethiopia, Uganda, and Eritrea. Both selfless Rotary activities, he notes. He was also the outgoing president for the Ophthalmic Society of Ethiopia in 1996, and past president of Rotary Club of Addis Ababa. Till 1994, he was International Vitamin A Consultative Group (IVAGC) regional representative for Africa. Dr. Pawlos is also country representative for the Afro Arab Society of Ophthalmology.

Ethiopia started training its own doctors in 1963, and medical care in the country was rising steadily. That is until recently. According to Dr. Pawlos, Ethiopia does not lack manpower, yet. Discouraged with the state of things, the country's young doctors are leaving for other countries. "Saudi Arabia has no manpower but it does have enough cash" Dr. Pawlos noted to hire expatriated--some of them Ethiopians. Ethiopia on the other hand, he said, had the manpower but artificial scarcity of medical supplies by the health authorities, he said, were making things bad.

Long waiting lists, inadequate service, lack of essential equipment as gloves and syringes, are a clear indication that what had started out full of promise four decades ago, looks highly disheartening now. Dr. Pawlos Quana'a, a bachelor, has one daughter from his previous marriage. His hobbies include swimming, and reading historical and classical novels. Surprising for someone whose year book shows inscribed under his photo, 'resistance to tyranny is obedience to God' and 'Stubbornness is a virtue not a vice,' Dr. Pawlos' motto in life is 'Fair play'.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

January 10, 1997


Eritrea;
Mysterious Deaths of Tourists and Driver


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

Addis Ababa - Six people--one Eritrean driver and five Belgian tourists-- were recently shot dead in Eritrea.

According to Mr. Alain Hanssen, Charge d'Affair of the Belgium Embassy to Ethiopia, the victims had multiple bullet impacts on their bodies. Mr. Hanssen explained that as there were no survivors, there are no witnesses to clarify the question of who committed the crime. It could be, he added, bandits or terrorists--like the Eritrean Jihad--who had murdered the six.

Africa News


January 10, 1997


Somalia;
Formation of National Council Welcome News (Editorial)


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - The formation of the National Salvation Council (NSC) by 26 Somali political movements recently is good news. NSC is highly structured and it has the support of the Ethiopian Government. It has also a strong regional support. All this is positive. But is has not met with the support of Mr. Hussien Aideed.

Mr. Aideed has accused Mr. Ali Mahadi of receiving arms from Ethiopia and has denounced SNC. This is bad news. The SNC on its part has not given up hope on Mr. Aideed. They believe he will join. A reconciliation conference is schedule to take place in the town of Bussasso over the next six months.

The 26 Somali leaders who have taken the initiative to bring peace and stability for Somalia and also to the Horn need to be supported. For the sake of the Somali people and for the sake of peace and stability in the Horn of Africa, we hope Mr. Hussien Aideed will join the coalition. The people of Somalia genuinely need peace.

LANGUAGE: English

82 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Weekly Suspends Publication to Protest Editors' Arrests


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa - AKPAC, the firm publishing Tobia, independent Amharic weekly newspaper and monthly magazine, announced yesterday that it will suspend publication of its weekly paper indefinitely in protest against the arrest of four of its top editors. The monthly Tobia magazine, however, will continue to come out every month. 

The fourth arrest occurred Monday afternoon, when the editor-in-chief for the last four issues of the newspaper, Ato Arega Woldekirkos was taken from his office and placed in the Central Investigation Prison . According to Tobia sources, the charges against Ato Arega are not yet known, but he might appear in court today.

Ato Arega took over the post of Editor-In-Chief from Ato Goshu Moges, when the latter was arrested on 12 December, in connection with an article on the November 23 hijacking of Ethiopian flight 961. Ato Goshu, acting manager of AKPAC, was filling in for Ato Taye Belachew and Ato Anteneh Merid, editor-in- chief, and deputy editor-in-chief of Tobia, who had been arrested on 22 and 25 November respectively. The two have been in prison for 49 and 46 days in prison, without having their cases heard in court, noted Tobia.

AKPAC has explained that it was ceasing publication of Tobia weekly newspaper not because of manpower or financial constraints, but because it did not want to continue putting forward more people as 'sacrifice'.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
