145 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Malawi;
Malawian Group Seeks Abolition of Death Penalty


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Blantyre - The Balaka-based (south Malawi) Allelluya Band has put its weight behind concerned citizens and other human rights bodies to woo public support against capital punishment.

For the first time in the history of the country's prisons, the band performed at Zomba Central Prison on December 30, in response to a public outcry against the death sentence. 

Band leader and founder, Paul Banda said the decision to perform at the prison comes in the wake of findings by the Catholic magazine, Together, which sought people's views on death penalty. Banda said that through the magazine readers unanimously expressed a strong desire for the government to abolish capital punishment.

He said music has the power to transform society from bad to good. The move to hold the show in the prison premises was initiated by Rev Father Peter Gamba of the Montfort Press. Zomba was chosen as the first venue of the show because it has the most prisoners on death row.

"We want people of Malawi, including chiefs and parents, to rally against the death penalty." During a constitutional conference in 1994, chiefs voiced strong sentiments against abolishing the death penalty as punishment for convicted murderers. They argued that the move would pose a great threat to society by 'encouraging people to murder each other at will knowing they would not be hanged'.

Malawi has come under strong pressure from human rights organisations within and without to abolish capital punishment.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Malawi;
Government Pushes For Increased Maize Productivity


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Blantyre - Smallholder farmer, Chitenje Mwamadi, is one person who has been converted to and is practicing the government's gospel propagating the growing of hybrid maize varieties.

She has seen the benefit of planting her small piece of land, as recommended by the government, with hybrid maize varieties which are believed to be higher yielding than local varieties. "It took a lot of conviction for me to change from planting the old maize variety to hybrid. I am very happy now," said Mwamadi, comparing the 9 bags she used to harvest before to the 28 bags she now reaps from the same 0.2 hectare piece of land. 

Malawi - suffering chronic food shortages - is pushing for increased maize production. Last year the government launched the Maize Productivity Programme. This seeks to develop technologies that should improve efficiency in the use of fertilisers and promote crop diversification through the provision of a wide range of seeds. The programme aims to carry out extension campaigns targeted at poor farmers and train extension staff on new technologies.

Maize, largely grown by smallholder farmers in small pieces of land is the country's staple food. "Over the past years, there has been a decline in the maize productivity of smallholder farmers, a trend that poses a threat to household food security," Deputy Minister of Agriculture, Lizzie Lossa said last October at World Food Day Celebrations in the capital Lilongwe.

She listed factors that had contributed to the decline in maize production as poor uptake of improved seed, problems in managing soil fertility, poor resource base by smallholder farmers to enable them to purchase inputs and recurrent droughts. Between 1991 and 1994, Malawi witnessed three droughts which reduced food production by half. The decline in maize production has resulted in low per capita calorie consumption by most households. Half of Malawi's children suffer from chronic malnutrition.

A report by the Food and Agriculture Organisation showed that maize occupied 58.1% of the areas cultivated by smallholder farmers in 1994, a major percentage reduction when compared to 1978/88 when it occupied about 70% of the areas cropped. FAO said in 1994/95, 70% of maize planted were local low yielding varieties, whilst 29.7% were hybrid. Throughout the 1980s, 90% of maize planted by smallholders were low yielding local varieties.

"With the introduction of the semi-flint hybrids in 1990, there has been a gradual increase in the percentage of the areas planted with hybrids," said the FAO report. In 1992/93 - which was a good rainfall year - hybrids represented 24.5% of the maize planted, which fell back to 18.3% in 1993/94 which had poor rainfall.

With free fertiliser and hybrid seed distribution in 1994/95, hybrids plantings increased to 29.7%.

Estimates show that there was growth of 1.3337% per annum in the growth rate in smallholder maize production over the period 1983/84 to 1995/96. However, the introduction of semi-flint hybrids in 1990 saw positive growth of hybrids with an annual growth rate of 10.088%.

But the report cites a number of constraints which negatively affected the country's agriculture. Although the constraints have been documented, they are yet to be removed, which will continue to impact negatively on Malawi's food security.

Some of the constraints, according to the report, were land tenure and access to land, limited access to and the nature of agricultural extension messages, poor rural feeder roads, poor pricing of farm inputs and high prices of farm inputs.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


147 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe's "Riders For Health"


BYLINE: Tim Chigodo, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

HARARE - In 1993, a group of motor cycle riders entered Zimbabwe's Mashonaland Central Province and discovered that living conditions in the commercial farms were poor. There were no pre-schools, no toilets and hundreds of children were malnourished.

>From a humble beginning established three years ago on 25 motor cycles, the "Riders for Health" in Zimbabwe have today improved nutrition levels among labourers in some commercial farms and there are plans to expand the programme.

Since their arrival in this Southern African country with a population of 11 million people, the Riders for Health group has assisted about 250,000 Zimbabweans, mainly children of farm workers whose standard of living is not so good owing to high illiteracy levels. 

Due to the encouraging response from the farmers, their labourers and the co-operation of the government, the riders have been able to work with ministries of Health, Education and the former National Affairs to train farm workers to maintain good hygiene, build toilets and participate in literacy classes.

Mr. Mike Gatton of Save the Children Fund (UK) told APS of the setting up of Farm Community Trust of Zimbabwe to give the health programme a national outlook.

The trust which comprises nine people from SCF, farm workers, farmers, the government and some donors, requires 200 motor cycles to enable officials reach every corner of the country in a bid to improve poor people's lives all over the country, said Mr.Gatton.

"Now the Farm Community Trust of Zimbabwe has been set up and that is a good indication of the government's positiveness. What we are doing is to make it more effective for officials of the government. They are able to reach the people than sitting in an office," he said.

The co-ordinator for the farm Community Trust of Zimbabwe, Mrs. Lynette Mudekunye believes the programme will be a resounding success in the next two to three years as many people will have been trained to ride the motor cycles and to show their fellow country men how the scheme works.

On why the SCF insists on motor cycles instead of cars, she said cars were more expensive and they can easily tempt users to engage themselves in personal business. "Motor cycles can't be diverted to those things other than that which they are assigned. We want to be cost effective", she said.

The SCF is spending US$100,000 a year in the training of literacy tutors, women's clubs and construction of buildings.

To demonstrate that the government was happy with the Riders for Health plan, it has acquire 110 motor cycles for its department of Social Welfare thanks to assistance from the World Bank.

The fleet coordinator, Mr. Alfred Gonga said several environmental health technicians have been deployed in all the country's provinces since the riders were accepted by the government.

"They asked us to train their people since 1994. We visit every quarter of the country and we agreed nobody must ride those motor cycles before we train them," said Mr. Gonga.

However, the Riders for Health programme, if allowed to continue should see Zimbabwe improve some aspects of its health sector which have been neglected since the more than one billion dollar budget was subsequently reduced by one third due to a shortage of government funds.

Finance Minister Mr. Herbert Murerwa allocated $1,810,157 for the 1996-97 period. This was a 17 per cent increase over the previous year when the Health Minister Dr. Timothy Stamps had to ask for supplementary budgets to meet the ministry's requirements. In 1995- 96 the allocation was $1,545,481, 838 and because of the high cost of living, more money had to be poured into the coffers of the sector only to be cut later, causing national outcry from churches and human rights organizations.

The Riders for Health group provides what will, given support, turn out to be something of a breakthrough in the delivery of health and other outreach services in Africa. The way in which motor cycles have been wasted and their potential destroyed in the great motorcycle disaster should not be ignored or underestimated.

Since the programme began in 1989, there has only been one fleet in Malawi that has been well managed. But that was a small fleet - it costs a great deal to run it and it suffered a very high number of accidents. Riders for Health fleets are run in the most cost efficient manner possible and suffer very low accident rates.

People using motorcycles in outreach programmes or feel that it would be appropriate to do so, should talk to Riders for Health, who have shown in countries where they have programmes that future development of health and other services using motorcycles save a great deal of money.

The programme was begun by motor-cyclists and was nurtured by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and friends and colleagues of Save the Children Fund (UK). It is now an independent organisation with its roots in the motorcycle community and it is supported by manufacturers, dealers, competitors (including world champions) and by helpful and enthusiastic motor- cyclists in Europe, Australia and North America. This is a powerful resource on which to draw and it is the organisation's guarantee of its ability to provide a successful and predictable service to clients in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


148 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Rwanda;
First Verdicts For Genocide Trials


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

KIGALI - A nurse and a former local government official were sentenced to death on January 3 in the first verdicts handed down for the 1994 ethnic massacres in Rwanda.

The process has finally begun. Rwanda's overloaded justice system is trying to come to grips with the killings of more than 500,000 Tutsis and Hutu moderates by Hutu extremists in four terrifying months of civil war, triggered by the death of Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana and his Hutu counterpart in Burundi Cyprien Ntaryamira in a plane crash near the capital Kigali on April 6, 1994.

Nurse Deogratias Bizimana and former local official Egide Gatanazi, whose trials opened on December 27, have two weeks to appeal against the sentences handed down by the court in Kibungo in south-east Rwanda.

Despite numerous witnesses' statements, they pleaded innocent in their trial on December 27, which lasted just a few hours before being rescheduled for sentencing, and during which they had no legal representation. 

Bizimana faced 11 counts of taking part in massacres and leading death squads, as well as possessing arms, pillaging and refusing to help those in danger. He confessed after being arrested, but during the trial said the confession was extracted under torture. The father of two told Radio Rwanda that he was "sure of getting out of" his sentence.

Gatanazi, 43, was charged with murder, rape and theft. He said the case was a plot against him and insisted he was innocent, even though his own sister testified against him.

The death sentence has never been abolished in Rwanda, but no one has faced the firing squad since the end of the 1970s.

More than 90,000 people are crammed into Rwandan jails and living in horrific conditions as they await trial for the 1994 bloodshed.

A United nations court also due to hold war crime trials has been set up in Arusha, Tanzania, but it will only deal with the suspected ringleaders, leaving lesser officials to the domestic Rwandan judiciary. About 20 people have been indicted, many of them now living in exile abroad, but so far none of the trials has opened. Unlike the Rwandan courts, it will not hand down death sentences.

The civil war ended when the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) rebels seized power in Kigali in July 1994, ousting the Hutu-led government and sending several millions of Hutu refugees fleeing into neighbouring countries like Zaire and Tanzania.

Judicial sources said on December 31 that suspected ringleader of the killing Froduald Karamira who was arrested in June at Addis Ababa airport, Ethiopia, will go on trial on January 14 in Kigali.

A businessman before all the killings started, Karamira led a Hutu group called "Power", which opposed any accommodation with the minority Tutsis. He tried to flee the country, but was arrested last June in Adis Ababa.

On December 31, a former Rwandan school teacher became the fifth suspect to stand trial in Rwanda in connection with the 1994 genocide of half a million people, Rwanda national radio reported.

Francois Bizimutima, accused of leading an extremist Hutu organisation heavily implicated in the four-month bloodbath, stood in the dock in the northern town of Byumba, but the trial was put back until January 9 after the defendant asked for more time to prepare his case. Accused of allegedly planning and carrying out massacres during the ethnic bloodletting from April to July 1994, he requested in particular time to find a lawyer and witnesses.

The current Tutsi-led government in Rwanda says Karamira organized massacres and went on radio and television to incite Hutus to kill Tutsis.

Three other trials have also been started and adjourned, one indefinitely, the others until January and February. According to Radio Rwanda, two other trials would open on January 14 in Nyamata, south of Kigali.

But opposition groups, including the Resistance Forces for Democracy (RFD) and the main organisation supporting the millions who fled Rwanda after the genocide, the Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy to Rwanda (RPD), remain extremely concerned by the legal proceedings.

In a statement received in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, the RFD said the Rwandan judicial system was "incapable of meeting the fair and conciliatory justice that the country needs," while the RFP, for its part, appealed to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda to "get more involved" in the genocide trials.

"It would have been like asking a Muslim court in former Yugoslavia to try a Serbian genocide suspect," said Chris Nzabandora of the exiled RFD opposition party.

Exiled opposition leader Seth Sendashonga said in the RFD statement that the Rwandan government had published a list of more than 1,900 people thought to be responsible for the genocide of more than half a million minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus. Those found guilty of organizing, planning and carrying out massacres and rapes face death by firing squad.

While acknowledging that "many" of the people named had in fact been involved in "preparing and executing the massacres," he said the list contained many errors, and noted that "not a single soldier, official, militant or sympathiser" of the Tutsi-led authorities, which put an end to the Hutu bloodbath by sweeping to power in July 1994, was on the list.

Other Hutu groups have also expressed grave concern at the legal process insisting that the minority Tutsi-dominated authorities cannot guarantee fair, impartial trials for their erstwhile Hutu adversaries. With the large numbers awaiting trial in Rwanda's overcrowded jails, the process looks set to last several years.

The figure has been swelled by the arrest of some 5,4600 other new suspects who recently returned to Rwanda among more than one million refugees who had fled the country in 1994 into exile in eastern

Zaire and Tanzania. Most of the detainees had returned from Tanzania, due to the fact that "genocide organizers who were based in Zairean camps escaped, while those sheltering in Tanzania were obliged to go back to Rwanda."

By December 31, more than 480,000 Rwandan refugees had returned home from Tanzania, leaving some 50,000 still in the country, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) confirmed.

Refugees in Tanzania, numbering about 530,000, began a mass exodus towards their homeland after Tanzanian authorities ordered the camps, which they had occupied for two and a half years, to be closed before December 31.

The decision to send back the refugees followed the massive return to Rwanda of close to 500,000 refugees in eastern Zaire, after fighting broke out there between local Tutsi rebels, known as the Banyamulenge, and Zairean forces.

In one and a half months, Rwanda, whose population totalled 7 million before the 1994 genocide, has 'recovered' more than one million Hutus.

The refugees fled Rwanda fearing reprisals after the genocide, which only ended with the seizure of power in Kigali by the RPF. But after Tanzania announced its decision to close the camps, tens of thousands of refugees fled in the opposite direction from Rwanda in an effort to escape forced repatriation.

However Tanzanian military forces blocked routes and the Rwandan refugees slowly began leaving their hiding places in the forests. With swollen feet and fear in their bellies, they began the long trek back to the frontier post of Rusumo, which they had passed in the opposite direction back in 1994.

However, UNHCR officials still believe that hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees remained stranded in eastern Zaire.

Since November, some 1.3 million Rwandans had returned from exile after fleeing the 1994 civil war -- nearly 720,000 from eastern Zaire and more than 480,000 from Tanzania.

In a statement issued in Geneva on January 7, the UNHCR said that of those who remained in eastern Zaire, 150,000 were clustered at Shabunda, 120,000 at Tingi Tingi and 60,000 at Amisi, but many others are unaccounted for. " Yesterday (January 6), 4,500 emerged from a previously unknown location north- west of Bukavu, the capital of South Kivu province," UNHCR's spokeswoman Pamela O'Toole said.

The Tingi Tingi camp is thought to be under the control of Hutu Interahamwe extremists, complicating the task for refugees who want to return but are intimidated into remaining.

The UN agency said options to help ease their plight included creating humanitarian land corridors, moving refugees to more accessible areas and airlifting them home.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Nigeria;
Siege In Ogoniland Alarms Church Council


BYLINE: Sam Gonza, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

LAGOS - A year after worldwide publicity in the wake of the execution of the Ogoni author and environmental activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others in November 1995, the plight of the minority tribes of Nigeria's Delta region seems to have become obscure. But an incisive new report by the World Council of Churches (WCC) shows that repression characterised by torture, rapes and looting besides massive pollution of the environment with oil continues unabated in the Ogoni people's homeland.

More than a year after the military authorities in Nigeria executed author and environmentalist Ken Saro-Wiwa and nine others - all leaders of the Ogoni community Ken following a dubious judicial process, a quiet state of siege continues to exist in Ogoniland of River State Nigeria.

"Intimidation, rape, arrests, torture, shooting, looting by soldiers and mobile police (called 'kill-and-go') continue to occur," concludes a World Council of Churches (WCC) report entitled "Ogoni - The Struggle Continues."

Published by the WCC's Unit III - Justice Peace and Creation, it was authored by Dr. Deborah Robinson of the WCC Programme to Combat Racism who visited Ogoniland in early 1996. 

Dr. Robinson, who told APS her visit to Ogoni was neither as "part of a government sponsored fact-finding mission nor part of a Shell- sponsored fact- finding tour," carried out interviews with individuals in the actual line of fire of a highly repressive security and administrative apparatus. She was also able to witness the massive environmental pollution that resulted from Anglo-Dutch Shell Corporations bungled operations in the region over a period of 30 years. Officially, the petroleum giant pulled out of Ogoniland in 1993.

Nevertheless, asserts Dr. Robinson in the face of denials by Anglo- Dutch Shell, the company continues to pump oil from some wells in the region as evidenced by flares (excess gas being burnt). A Shell spokesman emphatically denied this specific charge by Dr. Robinson.

What is not in doubt is that a vast array of pipework criss-crosses the land and is the source of leakages that have dumped oil into waterways and destroyed millions of acres of arable land. Not only are food crops devastated but farmers are separated from their farms by leaky pipes which also cause large scale health problems.

Anglo-Dutch Shell Corporation which has pumped out of Ogoniland petroleum worth some $30,000 million since they began operations in the area in 1958, has never paid compensation for the 500,000 people of Ogoniland whose natural occupation-farming and fishing-has been devastated and millions rendered destitute.

The Director of WCC's Unit III Rev. Dr. Sam Kobia says the report is not mere propaganda but contains hard evidence of what is happening on the ground in Ogoniland. Rev. Kobia challenges the international community to show solidarity with the suffering people of Ogoniland by actually doing something to ameliorate their situation. "The time to do something is now," he adds.

Dr. Robinson's report makes a total of 28 recommendations to help ease the plight of the Ogonis. Among these the report calls on the Nigerian authorities to restore democracy, release the 19 Ogonis imprisoned as a result of the activities with the MOSOP (Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People) as well as other political detainees. It also calls for the release for proper burial of the bodies of the nine Ogonis - including that of the MOSOP leader Ken Saro-Wiwa, who were executed on November 9, 1995. The WCC report also reproduces the late Saro-Wiwa's closing statement to the military- appointed tribunal which sentenced him and eight others.

The report also urges Anglo-Dutch Shell to accept responsibility for the oil spillages and oil pollution that have occurred in the areas under its operations as well as allow inspection by independent agencies for clean up activities.

Furthermore, Shell is urged to pressurize the Nigerian government to release the imprisoned Ogonis and guarantee the democratic process in Ogoniland.

The WCC is urged to establish a fund for the defence and assistance of political detainees and to organise the collection of emergency medical supplies for political prisoners and two poorly equipped clinics in Ogoniland.

Like in 1995, the WCC in December 1996 announced a $13,000 to the MOSOP under the council's Special Fund to Combat Racism. The 1995 allocation to the Ogoni group represented the largest share of a US$100,000 fund targeting 12 groups worldwide. The only beneficiary from Africa then, MOSOP would use the money to handle the many humanitarian aspects of their smuggle. "This grant is another visible symbol of the WCC's commitment not only to the Ogoni but also to oppressed indigenous people everywhere," said a statement by the council then. Last December's grant is the third that the group has received from WCC.

The Robinson report will be discussed at a UNIT III Commission meeting in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi from January 13 to 19, 1997 and requests for WCC action will be passed to the annual Central Committee which convenes in September 1997. Former WCC General Secretary Philip Potter and incumbent Dr. Konrad Raisser are attending the Nairobi meeting.

Meanwhile a report of the International Struggle Meeting on Nigeria organised by the WCC from November 20 to 24, 1996, consolidated the recommendations made in Dr. Robinson's report.

At the outset the deliberations reflected on the centrality of the churches' role in achieving transformation in Nigeria, a nation with an estimated population of nearly 100 million people, about 45 per cent of whom are Christians.

The meeting noted that the repression of the Ogoni people has been used by the Nigerian government to intimidate others struggling for justice in Nigeria. "This terror needs to be countered by giving the Ogoni crisis special focus. The Ogoni Struggle is a non-violent people's movement against powerful forces of repression, marginalisation and injustice," participants stated.

Other recommendations made by the International Strategy Meeting were directed at specific church institutions. Among others, the Christian Council of Nigeria (CCN) and the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN) were urged to support the Ogoni Council of Churches and to strengthen its ministry.

The CAN/CNN are urged to make a public statement calling for the release of the Ogoni 19 and to use all available means to advance the cause of the Ogoni people. The CCN is also encouraged to revive its activities in the field of peace, justice and development and to work with existing human rights training

and civic education programmes including those initiated by the Catholic Church.

Both CCN and CAN and other Christian groups are further encouraged to convene a workshop in Nigeria on the Church's role in societies in crisis, drawing upon the experience of the South African Council of Churches (SACC), the Institute of Contextual Theology, and the WCC's Urban Rural Mission, among others.

The recommendations further request WCC to urge all member churches, regional ecumenical bodies and national councils of churches to exert pressure upon the government of Nigeria. Emphasis is on guaranteeing of basic human rights and the return to the rule of law in Nigeria.

And among other recommendations, the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) in Nairobi is asked to distribute information on Nigeria to its member churches. The AACC capacity towards that end will have to be strengthened.

An AACC delegation is encouraged to visit the churches and representatives of civil society in Nigeria, increasing the awareness of WCC member churches of the crisis in the country.

The strategy meeting recommended a follow-up meeting on Nigeria to include an expanded number of partners from Nigeria and the international community.

Reacting to the WCC report on Ogoniland, General Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda said AACC is committed to implementing the recommendations spelt out in line with its pastoral mandate.

Speaking to APS in an interview here on January 9, Rev. Chipenda said AACC's role in helping resolve the crisis in Ogoniland will also depend on the input from the Nigerian churches, particularly the member churches of the continental body, and financial commitment on the part of the ecumenical partners.

He told APS that AACC had already written to the General Secretary of the CCN, seeking to know how the continental organisation can collaborate with the Council of Churches in Nigeria to help end the crisis in Ogoniland.

Rev. Chipenda said he also looks forward to the participation of Nigerian churches in the AACC International Affairs Board meeting scheduled for February in Nairobi.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Somalia;
Somali Groups Sign Peace Accord


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

MOGADISHU - Somali's clan factions have signed a major peace accord after more than a month of tough negotiations in neighbouring Ethiopia, but two key groups have refused to join the peace bandwagon.

Under the peace accord, signed on January 3 in Sodere, a tourist complex 200 kilometres east of Addis Ababa, Somali clan factions set up a National Salvation Council aimed at paving the way for a transitional government in a bid to end years of bloodshed and violence.

But the Somali warlord Hussein Mohamed Aidid's United Somali Congress/Somali National Alliance (USC/SNA) faction was not among the 26 groups which took part in more than four weeks of tough negotiations.

In a "solemn declaration" the clan chiefs urged Aideed and another absent warlord Mohamed Ibrahim Egal, who heads a self-declared government in Somaliland, in northern Somalia, to join their peace efforts to end chaos which has crippled the country since the fall of the former dictator Mohammad Siad Barre in January 1991, with no form of government as rival factions battled it out for control. 

In the declaration, the clan chiefs appointed a 41-member council and a national executive committee in the presence of observers from the Organization of African Unity and the Inter-Government Authority on Development (IGAD).

The declaration acknowledged "our inability so far to arrest the conflict" as the "main obstacle to progress in Somalia is the lack of a central authority."

Aideed took over as clan chief after his father General Mohamed Farah Aideed died in August from wounds incurred in a battle for the Medina district of south Mogadishu.

He considers himself the president of Somalia after his father, who set up a government unrecognized by the other factions, was declared interim president for three years at a conference of his supporters in Mogadishu in June 1995.

Aideed's main rival for control of the USC/SNA faction, Osman Hassan Ali Atto, did join the talks in Addis Ababa launched on November 22, thanks to an Ethiopian mediation, and ended on January 3.

The council aims to hold a new "conference of national reconciliation" in Bossaso in the north-east before setting up a provisional government and a transitional authority. A five-strong co-chairmanship will head the national executive committee and will "act and speak" for the council and will be in charge of coordinating emergency aid and rehabilitation programmes.

The National Salvation Council's mandate included to restore peace and stability, to boost reconciliation efforts between the clans, to draw up a transition charter and to put in place a central transitional authority or provisional central government.

Also present at the talks was Ali Mahdi Mohamed, a long and bitter rival of General Aideed's, whose forces control north Mogadishu, and who with Osman Atto as well as clan heads Abdulkadir Mohamed Aden, Aboudlahi Yussuf and Aden Abdoulahi Nur will form the co- chairmanship.

But on January 8, Aideed's Interior Secretary Mohamed Kanyare Afrah, scoffed at the invitations to his faction to join the peace bandwagon and made it known that those who went to Ethiopia for the peace conference committed a crime against his government.

Kanyare Afrah warned that when they return to Somalia, they will be detained and prosecuted for their action.

"We have a national representative government supported by most Somali factions," Kanyare Afrah said, and characterised those who went to Ethiopia as "invented factions, splinter groups and elements who carry messages for foreigners."

Kanyare himself appealed to the factions which went to Ethiopia to abandon their ways and join the government of Hussein Aideed. The leader of the self- declared Republic of Somaliland was also not expected to heed the call, as the north and north-west Somali territory has long refused to consider itself part of Somalia and its ongoing clan warfare.

Mogadishu has been the scene of renewed fighting in past weeks, as Aideed and Osman Atto's rival forces battle for control of the southern part of the city. A green line already divides the capital in a bid to separate Aideed's forces from those of Ali Mahdi's Somali Salvation Alliance.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


151 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Kuchera Elected President Of Zimbabwean Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

HARARE - Thousands of Christians from various churches in Zimbabwe thronged the United Church of Christ in Zimbabwe (UCCZ) here on January 5, 1997 to witness the installation of Rev. Murombedzi Kuchera as President of the church, according to a press release from the Ecumenical Documentation and Information Centre for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA).

EDICESA says the ceremony which was punctuated by music from popular gospel singer Mechanic Manyeruke and various UCCZ choirs, was attended by among others, heads of denominations of the

Zimbabwe Council of Churches (ZCC) member churches, the general secretaries of South African Council of Churches (SACC) and Council of Swaziland Churches (CSC), lay Christians and ecumenical organisations.

At 48 years old, Rev. Kuchera becomes the youngest president of his church although he brings to the Church more than 20 years of ecumenical experience. He replaces the outgoing President Rev. Watson Makata Mkwakwami who leaves the office after serving for 16 years. 

Rev. Kuchera, a well known religious leader in Zimbabwe, in the region as well as internationally, leaves the Zimbabwe Council of Churches, an organisation that he has led as chief executive for the last 15 years.

In 1979, Rev. Kuchera was a member of the ZCC Executive Committee and the Reconciliation Committee. He attended the historic 1979 Lancaster House constitutional talks which led to Zimbabwe's independence in 1980.

He was appointed General Secretary of ZCC in August 1982 and his first task was familiarization with the work of ZCC, the ecumenical donor partners and the World Council of Churches (WCC).

With only nine members of staff when Rev. Kuchera assumed the leadership of ZCC in 1982, the council has expanded and now boasts of 70 members of staff. It currently has 15 immovable properties with a high potential of becoming a self-reliant organisation. UCCZ's new leader also worked hard and helped ZCC to purchase the Kentucky Airport Hotel in Harare.

Under the leadership of Rev. Kuchera, ZCC was able to start the Ecumenical Human Resources Development Programme, which is now the largest programme of ZCC and the Justice, Peace and Reconciliation Programme which is the most vibrant and progressive programme of the council.

Among other programmes, Rev. Kuchera also initiated the Mission and Evangelism Programme, the ZCC regional Office in Zimbabwe's second largest city, Bulawayo and the Endowment Fund for self-reliance of the churches and the council.

On the regional scene, Rev. Kuchera helped to establish FOCCESA, which is the 12-member Fellowship of Christian Councils in Eastern and Southern Africa and its communication body, the Ecumenical Documentation and Information Centre for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA). FOCCESA comprises national councils of churches in Angola, Botswana, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

"Rev. Kuchera is highly regarded in Zimbabwe and is one of the national opinion makers and a point of reference," said ZCC President Rev. Enos Chomutiri.

He said Rev. Kuchera will be missed by his fellow members of staff but added that he was grateful that ZCC could still benefit from Kuchera's wide experience through his participation in the work of the council as a member of the Executive Committee.

On his appointment as President of UCCZ, Rev. Kuchera noted that overwhelming support and prayers from the church people was a great source of inspiration and strength in his acceptance of the challenging ministry.

"I shall try my level best, God is my help, to maintain the confidence the people showed in me through listening to the voice of God as He speaks through and during my term of office. It is my fervent hope that through listening to God's people, we shall together come up with a common understanding and shared vision of the UCCZ," said Rev. Kuchera.

The new president said his main concern would be promoting human dignity and sustainable communities through propagation of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, sharing available resources, practical actions of solidarity, human resources development, capacity building and empowerment of the poor. He also promised to work towards uplifting the marginalised, women and youth.

Rev. Kuchera noted the need for a church that works towards elimination of poverty through entrepreneurship training as one of the means to ensure that every Zimbabwean has three meals a day.

He said his leadership envisages a community of believers which is gender sensitive and promotes the status of women in decision making.

"The women have to be on the driving seat and not participate simply as passengers. Therefore the church will commit itself to initiate activities which will help women to find their proper places and roles in their families, at their workplaces, in their churches, and in their communities," said Rev. Kuchera.

On youth, Rev. Kuchera said these are an integral part of today's society and tomorrow's community. He noted that the youth's role in mission and evangelism is very important for Church's growth.

"The Church will initiate participatory programmes where the youth will learn the strategies for self reliance. They should be handled with care and raised in our families and not in the streets of our cities," said the UCCZ leader.

He said the UCCZ will work with Government in the programmes of agriculture, health education, vocational skills training for survival and rural development.

He also noted that the UCCZ will keep its ecumenical spirit and participate in the ecumenical foram at the highest level and promote ecumenical programmes initiated by ZCC, All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), World Council of Churches (WCC), interdenominational organisations and other churches.

Rev. Kuchera is married to Betty and they have seven children.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

152 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Clergy Caution African Politicians On Ethnicity


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

NAIROBI - Catholic bishops meeting here have accused some African politicians of exploiting the rich African ethnicity for their individual needs.

The clergy, who met here from December 18 to 21, 1996 to deliberate on the crisis in the Great Lakes region, noted that "ethnicity becomes a worst menace when political or private interest transform it into an ideology and instrument of conquest and power basis."

This ideology, by means of internal and external alliances, along with the sordid arms trade, engenders conflicts and feeds a spiral of discrimination, exclusion and violence that leads to massacres and even genocide, the clergy stressed in their statement issued at the end of the meeting.

The meeting was organised by the Vatican, under Cardinal Roger Etchegaray, who heads the Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace. It brought together 27 delegates, drawn from Burundi, Zaire, Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania and the Vatican. They included both priests, bishops, archbishops and cardinals. 

The Catholic clergy said disastrous effects of ethnicity are quite evident. In a subtle way it penetrates individuals as well as cultures and institutions, they stressed in their statement, adding that "even members of the church are affected by this contamination."

But on a good note, many sons and daughters of the church have accepted to offer the supreme sacrifice of their life to defend and save individuals of another ethnic group, the clergy's statement further said.

Pointing out that ethnocentric ideology is contrary to the gospel, they noted; "That is why we are determined to step up our efforts to build up a church which is the family of God, characterised by "conviviality" and where all its sons and daughters are recognised as such and respected in their equal dignity.

They thus called on churches to get involved in programmes to educate the people of God to take up responsibilities in the society in accordance with the social doctrine of the church.

Their meeting discussed four themes namely; The gospel as facing up to the ethnocentric ideology; Church's mission of reconciliation; Church as a voice of those enduring hardships and Solidarity between the churches.

On the mission of reconciliation of the church, for example, the clergy said the church urgently needs agents of reconciliation.

In a certain sense every baptized person must consider himself (or herself) a 'minister of reconciliation', the clergymen said.

And on the church as the voice of those enduring hardships, the clergy appealed to the political decision-makers to urgently work at alleviating sufferings of all kinds, "which befall our populations."

However any lasting solution to these human dramatic situations must include the promotion of the rule of law, they stressed.

They suggested that a joint ecumenical effort will give the witness of the church a wider field for providing comfort and taking action.

The bishops also expressed concern on the hardships imposed on the people, both lay and clergy, citing the brutal death of bishops in Burundi and Rwanda. "We express our anguish about Bishop Phocas Nikwigize, the emeritus bishop of Ruhengeri (Rwanda), who was a refugee at Goma (Zaire) and who has disappeared nearly a month ago," the clergymen further said.

And on solidarity between churches, the Catholic bishops hailed Pope John Paul II, sister churches in Africa and the whole world and non- governmental agencies "for all the concrete activities through which they have expressed their sympathy and solidarity towards our churches and our peoples."

Meanwhile, the Pope in his Christmas message, expressed concern over the crisis in the Great Lakes region. "Can we forget Africa? At the heart of the continent, around the Great Lakes, one of the cruelest dramas in its history is being played out, while the international community looks on with indifference.

"Thousands upon thousands of persons, our brothers and sisters, are wandering about, a prey to fear, famine and disease," the Catholic pontiff stated in the message, adding that "the number of refugees and displaced persons no doubt runs into the hundreds of thousands."

And in his New Year message, coinciding with the World Day of Peace Communication celebrated by Catholics worldwide on January 1, the Pope challenged the church among other institutions to continue working for peace despite the many odds that plague such intentions.

According to sources within the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Kenya Office, an estimated 1,432 Rwandan refugees had returned from Zaire between January 1 and 6 this year through Gisenyi while another 1,325 had also returned to Rwanda between January 1 and 5 through Cyangugu.

"It is difficult to portray the actual situation within the Great Lakes region right now but definitely we are aware of quite a number of Rwandan refugees returning to their country," a spokesperson at the office, told APS.

The spokesperson also disclosed that an estimated 120,000 refugees are said to have fled the designated camps in Eastern Zaire, the battle field inside the country.

"Up to now, the information we have is that these people are on their own, somewhere inside Zaire, where we are told there could be a daily death rate of between 11 to 15 persons. The issue is being dealt by our Kisangani Office in Zaire," she told APS.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Anglican Bishop Dies


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

LAGOS - The Anglican bishop in charge of Nigeria's Delta region has died from his injuries after being shot and wounded in an attack on his official residence, the pro-government Daily Times reported on December 28.

Bishop Samuel Elenwo, who was shot several times in the back, and a female guest, who had several of her fingers blown off, were brought to a hospital at Port Harcourt, but died on December 28.

Police sources cited in the Nigerian press said six bandits attacked the bishop during a dinner with several guests at his home on the night of December 27. The bishop was shot while trying to flee the melee. 

The bandits left after pillaging the residence. Quoting family sources, the newspaper said the assassins fled the scene following the attack after pillaging the residence but without demanding any money or taking away anything.

The reason for the attack remained a mystery, but the newspaper quoted sources saying the bishop may have been assassinated for his family's support for one of the factions disputing the traditional title in the southern Rivers state municipality.

The announcement of the bishop's death came the same day as two Nigerian private newspapers voted violence in Nigeria as their "Man of the Year," an exceptional choice because the press usually nominates individuals who have taken major steps affecting humanity for the title.

This Day and Vanguard newspapers announced that their boards of editors had respectively, chosen "Mr. Assassin" and "Violence" as man of the year.

Many prominent, as well as ordinary Nigerians, have been brutally killed by "Mr. Assassin, that faceless, nameless, unidentifiable personality who leaves no clues" after striking, This Day wrote.

"This beast, this spirit, kills with bravado and daring and ruthlessness, in the process defying the agents of law and order, breaking every security cordon, and hitting his target noiselessly but with professional plan," added the daily, which carried a drawing of a masked assassin, gun to the ready, on its front page.

In its five-page report, the Vanguard listed a litany of violent events which ended in tragedy. One noted victim was Ibrahim, the first child of General Sani Abacha, who died with 13 others when a presidential plane crashed last January near Kano, northern Nigeria.

Another victim listed by the newspaper, which also carried a drawing of a masked assassin on its front page, holding a gun and a human skull, was Kudiratu Abiola, the wife of detained millionaire politician, Chief Moshood Abiola, who is widely believed to have won the June 1993 presidential election. She was killed after unknown gunmen opened fire on her car last June.

On December 18, the son of Nigeria's former Justice Minister Olu Onagoruwa was slain in a robbery at his home in the capital, the Guardian daily reported.

It said unidentified assailants broke into the home of Toyin Onagoruwa, demanded money, and then took him outside where they shot him twice.

The senior Onagoruwa was Justice Minister in military junta leader General Sani Abacha's first government, shortly after the latter assumed power in November 1993, but was sacked in September

1994 for expressing reservations about a wave of draconian decrees from Abacha limiting press and individual freedoms.

A score of prominent people have been gunned down by unknown assassins this year alone. Security agents are yet to solve any of these cases.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Media Urged To Publicize Landmines' Dangers


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

HARARE - Media, information and education personnel from various organisations meeting here on January 6 for a brainstorming session on the need to ban landmines in Zimbabwe and other countries in the region, have called on both print and electronic media to inform the public on the dangers of landmines.

The meeting convened by the Ecumenical Documentation and Information Center for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA) forms the publicity and education committee which is part of Zimbabwe's Campaign to Ban Landmines.

A press release by EDICESA here said participants who included print and electronic media journalists, librarians, teachers and trade union representatives, focused their debate on the need to clear areas infested with landmines, policies relating to the financing of clearance, compensation of victims of explosions and ways of involving affected populations in mine- clearing programmes.

It is also the aim of the campaign to influence policy about the use, production, stockpiling and trade in landmines as well as public awareness and education. 

The participants noted the need to launch educational campaigns, involving ordinary men, women and children, particularly in mine- infested areas in the country, said the EDICESA release.

The meeting suggested that for the campaign to be effective it would be necessary to involve the Zimbabwe National Army (ZNA) public relations office. According to ZNA statistics, there are 2.5 million landmines on Zimbabwean soil.

Noting that the victims of landmines are mostly children of school going- age, the publicity and education committee called for workshops with headmasters and teachers on the subject of landmines.

They also called on the Ministry of Education and Culture to disseminate information on landmines to schools and to the public at large through the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC)'s educational channel, Radio Four.

The meeting also felt that the whole country should be involved in the fight against landmines and suggested that pamphlets in English and vernacular languages should be produced and circulated to people living side by side with landmines.

"There is need to encourage the setting up of landmines' committees in affected zones so that people in those areas can meet regularly and exchange information. Whatever resolution they can come up with can be channeled to the right authorities," said a reporter with Horizon Magazine, George Mangwiro.

He added that people, particularly in the rural areas do not feel free to release information on landmines to strangers although some of them have "all the information" that could be useful to any demining programme.

Realizing the strategic position of the Church, the participants called on pastors particularly those serving in mine-infested areas to dedicate time to this critical area, so that together with the people, solutions could be found.

"Awareness programmes should be intensified in areas like Chipinge (in the south-east near the border with Mozambique), where anti- personnel landmines are indiscriminately planted. The growing populations in these areas need information on the danger of landmines to minimize death and injuries," said Gorden Simango, a documentalist at EDICESA.

But the participants felt the problem of landmines should not only be the responsibility of government and other structures in the country but the international community should also assist with financing demining activities.

"After all, it is the developed countries that manufacture most of these landmines that are killing people and livestock," said one participant. Thus the media were also challenged to sensitize the international community on the need to assist Zimbabwe and other countries in the region to get rid of the hidden killers.

It is estimated that out of the more than 110 million landmines planted in various parts of the world, 30 million are in Africa, most of them in Southern Africa.

The participants expressed concern that two countries in the region -- South Africa and Zimbabwe -- have produced landmines. They called for a total ban on manufacturing, use, selling, exporting and stockpiling of landmines.

Of the Southern African Development Community (SADC)'s 12-member countries, only two do not have a problem of landmines.

This is why individuals, governmental and non-governmental organisations in Angola, Mozambique, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe have set up national campaigns to ban landmines.

Their findings are expected to be shared in Maputo, Mozambique in February 1997 during an international conference which is expected to go along way towards achieving a landmines-free zone in Southern Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 13, 1997


Liberia;
Fears Over Slow Disarmament In Liberia


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

MONROVIA - Only 5,000 guns out of the expected 60,000 have so far been surrendered in the on-going disarmament process in Liberia, Major-General Victor Malu, the Nigerian commander of the West African peace keeping force, ECOMOG, has confirmed.

According to the Abuja-Accord signed in the Nigerian capital late last year by the warring factions in the Liberian conflict, the disarmament process which began on November 22 should be completed by January 31. General Malu was however still hopeful that the deadline would be met. "As a matter of fact the fighters have shown a lot of interest in disarming. 

"The problem is that there is no food in the vocation centres where the fighters are supposed to congregate following the disarmament exercise."

He conceded that the last two weeks of December had seen a drastic reduction in the flow of weapons in the disarmament exercise.

But on January 6, the factional leader of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) Charles Taylor disputed the prediction that 60,000 guns were expected to be reclaimed from the fighters, saying "not all fighters in Liberia carried guns."

But one of his rivals for the leadership of Liberia, George Bowen of the Liberian Peace Council (LPC) has suggested that dishonesty on the part of some factional leaders was the cause of the slow pace of the weapons reclamation exercise.

In late December 1996, the Catholic Bishop of Monrovia, Michael Francis issued a pastoral letter entitled "Free Fair and Democratic Elections" in which he expressed concern at the slow rate of recovery of weapons from the fighters. At the time only about 700 guns had been given up.

Bishop Francis says unless the fundamental process of disarmament is completed to the satisfaction of all concerned, there is real danger that the elections due in May this year will be constrained by intimidation.

"If there is intimidation, the elections will not be free, fair nor legitimate", says the Catholic leader.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 13, 1997


Nigeria;
Vandalisation Of Nigeria's Church Schools Decried


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LAGOS - Lagos' Roman Catholic Archbishop Anthony Olubunmi Okogie, has deplored what he described as the "vandalisation" by government of schools and other institutions with missionary roots.

In his Christmas message delivered on December 24, Okogie said that unless something was done to retrace lost values, the road to peace and happiness in Nigeria and the world might remain a long one.

The Roman Catholic Church in Nigeria has consistently demanded the return of schools, hospitals and other institutions taken over from missionary and voluntary agencies by the government 20 years ago. 

Okogie, a renowned critic of the military government that rules Nigeria, also deplored unemployment and the lack of basic amenities such as good water, roads and housing.

He also spoke of the need for government to bring about democracy through the establishment of justice, love and peace all over Nigeria, and called on public officials to resist corruption.

"If they resist such temptations, if they keep the good of the people they serve before them, history will tell of their heroism," he said.

A week later, Archbishop Okogie reiterated that Nigerian military ruler General Sani Abacha needed selfless advisers if he is to redress social ills plaguing Africa's most populous nation with population estimates put at more than 100 million people.

"If his advisers had come to his aid and offered him advice that will benefit the general populace and not their own selfish and sectional interests, some of the social ills that now plague the nation would have been arrested," Okogie said in his New Year message, released on December 31.

Okogie said that those who come to power unexpectedly but prefer to use their powers to either destroy, amass wealth or profound unworkable theories, make life difficult for many people.

The cleric also condemned those campaigning for the legalization of abortion, adding that the two main religions in the country -- Islam and Christianity -- "agree on the illicitness of legalizing abortion."

He urged the government to create employment for jobless school graduates as well as help bring down the prices of vital food items which, according to him, are currently beyond the reach of many people.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 13, 1997


Science and Health;
Zambian Legislators Adopt Resolutions To Protect Environment


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian legislators have recommended that a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Environment be established, as a way of protecting the environment.

The legislators resolved, at the country's fist workshop on Environmental Education for legislators, that parliament enact laws to regulate, monitor and implement the use of the natural resources. 

"Laws should be introduced to provide a price tag on industries who pollute the environment," they said. "By laws should also be introduced by councils to ensure that every village have pit latrines as part of clean environment programme."

In understanding the existing practices that compound environmental degradation, and the constraints in promoting environmental education in formal and informal ways, the legislators recommended that the Ministry of Environment be classified as a priority ministry, to ensure that more funds are allocated to it.

The workshop -- held last week, in Siavonga, south of Lusaka -- was attended by 28 parliamentarians from each of the country's nine provinces.

It was aimed at creating an in-depth understanding of environmental issues, as well as elaborating measures to mitigate the negative effects of environmental problems.

Zambia loses an estimated 200,000 to 300,000 hectares of forests each year. Because of this rate of exploitation, officials say, the country is likely to experience a shortage of forest resources in the near future.

Other environmental degradation cited at the workshop was lose of soil productivity which is causing extensive land abandonment because of current practices in agriculture and animal husbandry.

In some parts of Zambia, soil loss on cultivated land is estimated at between 12.5 and 20 tonnes per hectare annually.

Environmentalists observe that through deforestation, illegal hunting and over-fishing, a number of species in Zambia may soon be lost completely.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Southern Africa;
Toward a Mine-Free Southern Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - On December 5, 1995, in a village in Maputo Province, Mozambique, several children were collecting scrap metal to sell.

Among the bits they found was a land mine. When the metal was weighed on a scale in the market, the land mine exploded, instantly killing eight children. Three others died in hospital. 

This happened three years after the peace agreement ended the 16-year civil war. Since then, in Maputo Province alone, 98 people have stepped on land mines. Out of these, 68 were children.

Every Southern African country, except Lesotho and Mauritius, has had people wounded or killed by land mines. Officials estimate that at least 20 million of these devices have been laid in the region.

The weapons lie hidden and awaiting the footsteps of a woman gathering firewood or a child fetching water. Long after a conflict ends, land mines threaten villagers, render farmland unusable, and disrupt transport and market systems.

To end the carnage, the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines has tried to get an immediate and permanent end to their use, manufacture, export and stockpiling.

The organization's next conference, to making all of Southern Africa mine- free, will be held in Maputo from from Feb. 25 to 28.

Of the 17 countries most severely plagued by antipersonnel mines, seven are in Africa. Three of these -- Angola, Mozambique and Zimbabwe -- are in Southern Africa.

At least two nations in the sub-region, South Africa and Zimbabwe, have manufactured land mines. Angola has between eight million and 20 million mines in its soil -- more than one for each of its 10 million people. In Mozambique, about one million land mines remain.

The organizers of the forthcoming conference said Monday that the gathering would consist of speeches, panel discussions, workshops, papers as well as visits to demining sites and training centers, prosthetics and rehabilitation programmes.

Participants would review the scale of the regional land mine problem, its socio-economic consequences and how these weapons affect women, refugees, the internally displaced and returning populations.

They will also examine case studies of Angola and Mozambique and hear the experience of land mine survivors.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


159 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Business and Finance;
AGC, Ghana Government Agree On Assets Transfer


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Ghana government has agreed to transfer to Ashanti Goldfields Company Limited (AGC) government's interests, or rights to an interest, in the company's assets.

The Ghana News Agency, which reported the deal Monday, did not say when the agreement was signed.

However, it said that the interests were a 10-percent government share holding in the Ghanaian-Australian Goldfields (GAG), a 10-percent shareholding in Cluff Resources Ghana Limited and a right to acquire 10- percent interest in Ashanti Gold's Bibiani project. 

The total consideration of the transfers are valued at 15.9 million U.S. dollars. Of this, 13.9 million dollars will be settled by the issue of new AGC shares at a price of 13.81 dollars. This is equal to the average of AGC ordinary share price for five dealing days.

GAG is a 70-percent subsidiary of AGC, acquired through completion of the merger of AGC and Golden Shamrock Mines Limited. Cluff Resources Ghana Limited's principal asset is the Ayanfuri Mine in Ghana.

The government currently holds 18.6 percent of the issued share capital of AGC.

The government and AGC said "on completion of the transfers, the government will hold 19.4 percent of the issued ordinary share capital of Ashanti which will stand at 108,059,481 shares."

"Except in limited circumstances, or with the prior consent of Ashanti, the government has agreed not to dispose of the new Ashanti ordinary shares being issued as consideration for the Transfer for a period of 12 months," they said.

Government and AGC anticipate that the new AGC ordinary shares will be admitted to listing on the London Stock Exchange on January 20, at the same time as the transfers are completed.

Listings will be obtained on the Ghana, New York, Toronto, Zimbabwe and Australian Stock Exchanges shortly afterwards. AGC is already listed on all these exchanges.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 13, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa Urged To Invest In Human Resources


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Well trained personnel, rather than sufficient natural resources, hold the key to Africa's economic growth, a leading academic said Monday.

Professor George Benneh, who is president of the Association of African Universities, said this in Lusaka, Zambia, at the opening of the assocition's ninth general conference.

He cited Japan, Singapore and South Korea as some of the countries which had applied brain power to join the club of developed nations, even though they are endowed with scant natural resources. 

"This is the challenge that faces African universities and this is also the reason why African governments have to invest more in training and research," he said.

African universities, he said, needed to increase research and help society find solutions to problems like hunger, disease and poverty.

Failure to reach these types of goals, he said, could make African universities lose public confidence in the 21st century.

Addressing the same conference, the secretary-general of the Association of International Universities, Franz Eberhard, said that it was crucial for developing countries to break out of downward spiral of dependence and of underdevelopment.

He, too, said that governments had a crucial role of funding higher education and research, as well as creating the right atmosphere to enable African scholars to deliver what was expected of them.

Zambian President Frederick Chiluba, who officially opened the conference Monday, appealed to demographers, economists and other social scientists to examine, critically, some of the current theories which he said were alien to African conditions.

Chiluba said that academics should develop come up with theories that more correctly explained Africa's problems.

The week-long seminar has drawn participants from almost all African countries, including representatives from international organizations and donor community.

The association was created to encourage contacts between its 142 members and the international academic world.


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Burundi;
UN Coordinator: Sanctions Hamper Burundi Relief Effort


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Bujumbura - The following Press Statement is attributable to Martin Griffiths, UN Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes Region.

The regional embargo on Burundi declared on July 31, 1996 continues to impose severe restrictions on the ability of international humanitarian organizations to provide aid to the country's most vulnerable populations. 

On September 6, the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) authorized international humanitarian organizations to import fuel for emergency humanitarian relief. The fuel imported was sufficient for only one month of operations.

Since November 18, international humanitarian organizations have made several joint requests for a new allocation of fuel to the RSCC. To date, no authorization to import new supplies of fuel has been received.

Today, both UN and NGO fuel reserves are virtually depleted. Essential programs have already been reduced. Agencies are now being forced to consider reducing their emergency relief operations even further. If a favourable decision by the RSCC is not taken immediately, agencies will be unable to provide life-sustaining assistance to hundreds of thousands of extremely vulnerable people in Burundi.

For further information please contact Kerstin Holst, Policy Advisor, Office of the Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes Region on (Tel: 254-2-622166 or 622148, Fax: 254-2-622129).

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re- print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 14, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 77 on the Great Lakes (01/11-13)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Nairobi - Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army has admitted killing 126 Hutu refugees on Friday who returned to the country from Tanzania and tried to escape from a detention centre. Army spokesman Lt-Col Isaie Nibizi said seven soldiers had been arrested in connection with the shootings, in the northeast province of Muyingi, and would be charged in a court of law.

Presidential spokesman Jean-Luc Ndizeye also said the government was probing the incident and more details would be released in the course of the investigation.

A UN official in Burundi told Reuters that 120 Burundian Hutu refugees accused of fomenting trouble in the camps in Tanzania had been sent back to Burundi over the weekend. He said they were expelled from Tanzania's Kitale camp after in-fighting between Burundian extremist Hutus from the Palipehutu organisation and the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD). Reuters quoted eyewitnesses as saying the army massacred 83 Hutu civilians near Rutegama in Muramvya province last weekend, but presidential spokesman Ndizeye said he had heard nothing about the incident. 

A Burundian official said more than 200,000 civilians had been grouped into special camps in the troubled provinces of Cibitoke, Bubanza, Karuzi and Muramvya so that the army could differentiate between innocent civilians and Hutu rebels. Frederic Kazungu, chief of staff at the ministry for displaced people and refugee repatriation, admitted that conditions at the Karuzi camps in particular were not ideal, placing the blame on regional economic sanctions imposed by Burundi's neighbours last July. "Normally we should provide them with help by supplying them with food, medicine and plastic sheets, but we have had coordination problems with aid workers," he said. " Because of the embargo, aid from the main organisations has arrived only in dribs and drabs."

The UN today warned of serious impediments to relief operations in Burundi unless the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) authorises the importation of more fuel supplies. A statement released by the office of the Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes region said the ongoing regional economic embargo was severely hampering the ability of aid organisations to help needy people in Burundi. The fuel imports authorised by the RSCC in September lasted only one month and subsequent requests for new fuel allocations have not been met. The statement stressed that both UN and NGO fuel reserves were now virtually depleted.

The Tanzanian government has set a deadline of 18 January for all Burundian refugees living outside the camps to return to them. In a statement issued yesterday, the government also urged Burundians "who are ready to go home" to do so, because the situation in Burundi was "not as threatening as reported by certain quarters". Refugees from camps in the Kigoma, Tabora, Rukwa and Kagera regions had spread to local villages and towns, the statement said. It added that 30,000 people had already returned home voluntarily to Burundi.

The Tanzanian government also announced the closure of camps in the northwest areas of Karagwe, Milepa, Biharamulo and Ngara formerly inhabited by Rwandan refugees, most of whom had now returned home. Refugees who fled the camps and are still hiding out in forests or towns will be hunted down by the authorities and legal action taken against them. Zaireans entering the Kigoma region are not recognised as refugees and must register immediately in the camps so they can be assisted to return home, the government stated. Reuters quoted a UNHCR official as saying some 5,000 refugees had arrived in Tanzania last week, fleeing the war in eastern Zaire.

* The UN on Friday reported a total of 5,837 Burundian refugees currently in Rwanda, gathered in three groups. There were 707 refugees at the Musange Transit Centre in Butare prefecture who arrived with the mass influx of Rwandan returnees from Goma, Zaire, last November. The biggest group, 3,678 refugees, were at Kibangire camp in Cyangugu prefecture. They began arriving in June, fleeing the fighting in Burundi's Cibitoke province. Another 1,452 refugees were inhabiting the Kigeme camp in Gikongoro prefecture where they had fled in the aftermath of the assassination of Burundi president Melchior Ndadaye in October 1993. The Rwandan government believes there is no longer any need for refugee camps in Rwanda and the Burundians should now return home.

* The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR) today resumed the trial of the first defendant, former mayor of Taba, Jean-Paul Akayesu. The trial adjourned Friday after hearing testimony from the first prosecution witness, a Tutsi woman known simply as "K" to protect her identity. She narrated how Akayesu had ordered the killings of Tutsis in the commune of Taba, Gitarama prefecture, where she had worked as his accountant. The ICTR's witness protection measures include no photographing, filming or sketching of the witnesses. Akayesu today personally cross-examined the witness but requested an adjournment to prepare his questions. The court agreed to suspend work until tomorrow morning. Meanwhile, Akayesu has also requested a change of lawyer for the third time since his trial began in October last year. However the tribunal's registrar Adronico Adede refused to allow any further delays to the procedure. "We tried to make sure that everything was transparent, we gave him the benefit of the doubt hoping that he was really looking for good defence lawyers, (but) as soon as we saw he was playing games we stopped," Adede told reporters on Saturday. The tribunal provides defence counsel to suspects who say they cannot afford to hire their own lawyers. It will examine Akayesu's request later this week.

* In Rwanda, a former Hutu politician accused of being one of the architects of the 1994 genocide, goes on trial in Kigali tomorrow. Froduald Karamira was a vice-president of a faction of the MDR party and allegedly a leader of the Interahamwe militia. He is charged with inciting genocide and committing crimes against humanity which carries a mandatory death penalty. Every day, as the slaughter of Tutsis was underway, he allegedly made inflammatory broadcasts on extremist Hutu Radio Mille Collines (RTLM). Reuters reported Deputy Justice Minister Gerard Gahima as saying his ministry would receive funds from the UN to provide legal representation for genocide suspects, under an agreement to be formalised this week. The trial of two suspects, sentenced to death last week, came under criticism after it was learned that the accused had no defence counsel.

* The US ambassador in Kinshasa, Daniel Simpson, accused Rwanda and Uganda of aggression against Zaire, during an interview broadcast by state television. "We understand perfectly that Zaire has been attacked by Rwanda and Uganda," he said. "This poses problems both on the political and the humanitarian front." He added that the USA was "totally against" division or secession in Zaire.

Iran condemned the "savage aggression" against Zaire and offered its good offices for a peaceful resolution to the rebellion in eastern Zaire, Zairean radio reported last week. It quoted Iran's charge d'affaires in Kinshasa as saying the Zaire situation was "tragic". "Iran accepted...to mediate in the conflict between Zaire and its eastern neighbours," the radio said.

* Six senior Zairean army officers are to appear before military tribunals on various charges of desertion, rape and pillage in eastern Zaire. Government spokesman Koloni Longo, who made the announcement on state television last week, said "uncontrolled elements of the Zairean army have committed acts of vandalism and carried out exactions on the population". He added that the province of Upper Zaire, which has seen some of the worst looting by mutinous troops, had been declared a disaster zone.

* President Mobutu, who returned to France from Zaire on Thursday, underwent minor surgery on Friday at a Monaco hospital, Associated Press reported. He was admitted to the urology department and was expected to remain in hospital for several days. No further details were given. Mobutu underwent surgery for prostate cancer in August, finally returning to Zaire last month.

* Rebels in northern Uganda have killed more than 200 people in the Kitgum district in five days, the independent 'Monitor' newspaper reported today. It claimed some 400 members of the Lord's Resistance Army entered Uganda from Sudan on January 5 and went on the rampage, indiscriminately killing local people. However, Minister of State for Defence, Amama Mbabazi, quoted by the state-owned 'New Vision' newspaper, denied any knowledge of mass killings by LRA rebels, saying the only report he had received from the area was the killing of six rebels by government troops during fighting over the weekend.

Nairobi, 13 January 1997, 15:00gmt (ENDS)
