Africa News


January 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Currency: Kenyan Shilling On The Rise, CFA Franc Depreciates


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Kenyan shilling (ksh) continued to appreciate against the U.S. dollar and the British pound in the local market which remained favourable last week, market analysts said in Nairobi.

Reports reaching PANA Tuesday in Dakar, Senegal, say that the shilling gained 15 cents against the dollar and 17 cents against the pound sterling. 

The Ghanaian cedi remains relatively stable. On Monday in Accra, the interbank rate was 1,727 cedis to the dollar. On the previous Monday, the dollar exchanged for 1,726.82 cedis buying and 1,755.36 cedis selling.

Meanwhile, two currencies have recorded new losses against the dollar: The cfa franc exchanged at 521 (buying) and 551 (selling) to the usd Tuesday at Citibank in Dakar.

The losing trend started one week ago when the rate was 513 (buying) and 543 (selling) cfa to the greenback.

On New Year's eve, the rate was 509 cfa to the dollar, up from 510 cfa to the greenback on December 24.

The New Zaire (nz) was the same following the circulation of 100,000, 500, 000 denomination notes.

The measure, which cause massive price hikes to the delight of speculators, was described as a "source of inflation".


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Sudan;
Ethiopia Denies Bombing Sudanese Border Towns


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopian has described as a "baseless fabrication" Sudanese claims that its troops shelled two border towns Sunday before they were captured by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of Col. John Garang.

Addis Ababa's denial of involvement was aired Monday on Ethiopian Television. The station quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that the Sudanese accusation was "simply a tactic to redress and externalize the country's internal problems." 

Authorities in Khartoum have ordered a general mobilization to defend Sudan, after conceding that the two border towns in Blue Nile Province had fallen to the anti-government forces.

The government of Gen. Omar el Bashir alleged that the SPLA rebels were backed by Ethiopian troops which had shelled the two towns, enabling their seizure by the SPLA.

Sudan's parliament has accused Ethiopia of violating all international norms, charters and principles of good neighborliness.

Parliament said Monday that the attack was "only a part of the plot" led by countries spearheaded by the United States of America and "Zionist forces."

This plot, it added, started a long ago and involved an economic embargo, media campaigns aimed at tarnishing Sudan's image, and anti-Khartoum resolutions and sanctions passed and imposed by international organizations.

Sudan is under a limited embargo imposed by the United Nations for its failure to handover, for trial in neighboring Ethiopia, Egyptians who allegedly participated in a bid to assassinate Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa on 26 June, 1995.

The Sudanese parliament called on all Arab and Moslem states to condemned plots against Sudan.

Garang claimed Monday that the Unified Opposition Forces of North and Southern Sudan, now under his command, had captured the entire Nile Province, which borders Ethiopia.

The most prominent Sudanese opposition leader and former prime minister, Sadiq al Mahdi, recently fled into exile in neighboring Eritrea.

On his arrival in Asmara, the Eritrean capital, Mahdi announced that he was joining other externally-based opposition groups seeking to topple Bashir, who overthrew Mahdi's democratically elected government in June 1989.

Sudanese officials had minimized the impact of Mahdi's escape, saying this had only helped to cut him off from his supporters in Khartoum.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Tourism Tourism Earned Ghana 248 million dollars In 1996


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana attracted some 300,000 tourists in 1996, yielding an impressive total cash receipt of 248 million U.S dollars, the Ministry of Tourism said Tuesday.

Most arrivals were from Ghana's traditional tourism generating markets -- the United States, Britain, Germany and the Netherlands.

Ghana also became a destination for a significant number of tourists from Canada, Switzerland and other European and African countries.

In 1995, Ghana received 286,000 visitors and cash receipts of 237 million dollars, the Director of Research and Information at the ministry, Abraham Bekoe, told the Ghana News Agency on Tuesday in Accra. 

He said the sector expected an average tourist inflow of 399,000 annually from now till the year 2,000.

Foreign exchange receipts for tourist arrivals over the next three years, he said, would be an average of 386 million dollars each year.

Ministry officials say the heaviest influx of tourists into the country in 1997 is expected to occur in March, during the country's 40th independence anniversary celebration and later in August during the Pan-African Historical Theatre Festival, or PANAFEST '97.

However, Bekoe said that apart from these two major attractions, the sector was poised to enjoy a significant increase in tourist traffic, especially from the United States.

He expressed optimism at this "because of the impact of the ministry's promotional initiative there, the improvement in direct air links and Ghana's growing image as a tourist destination."

One major achievement of the industry in Ghana, he said, was that hotel beds had more than doubled during the past decade.

Ghana has about 10,783 hotel beds which the tourism ministry expects to increase significantly by the middle of the year.

"At present, more than half of this total -- that is 5,556 -- of our beds are in budget class hotels. But most of the new ones expected this year are all of international standard ranging between two-star and five-star," he said.

Out of these, he said, that Ghana expected an additional 2,750 beds all over the country by the year 2,010.

Most of the new hotels still under construction, such as Accra's Palm Beach Hotel at La, and the Golden Beach Resort at Elmina in the central region are expected to be ready for occupation by June.

The 168-bed Elmina Golden Beach Resort, owned by the Social Security and National Insurance Trust, is said to be of strategic importance to the August PANAFEST event, to be hosted exclusively in Cape Coast and Elmina.

Bekoe said the ministry expected 70 percent of all hotel projects and other receptive facilities within the festival zone to be completed before the start of the festival.

"The estimated shortfall of thirty percent in hospitality facilities is expected to be taken care of by other installations outside the immediate activity areas such as Takoradi and hostel facilities at the University of Cape Coast," he said.

Bekoe said airline operations in Ghana which previously constituted a major limitation to the growth of tourism, had now picked up impressively, increasing from only nine airlines a few years ago to 15 today.

"The good thing is that these increases are not just by mere local representation. They are increases reflected in terms of flight frequency," he said. "Chances are, that very soon, some of these airlines will start operating daily schedules in Ghana."

Bekoe said the ministry had a 15-year National Tourism Development Programme that will run until 2010.

The first phase of the programme, a five-year Tourism Action Plan, was set in motion in late 1996. It embraces various small programmes designed to unearth as well as boost the country's tourism potentials on a regional basis.

"These regional tourism programmes have been so fashioned to correspond with government's commitment to opening up the hinterlands, stimulating rural economies and eventually strengthening district authorities," he said.

Another important feature of the programme is a five-year marketing strategy and promotional programme. This initiative is intended to "sell Ghana as a more rewarding and preferable destination on the highly competitive international tourism market."


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Southern Africa;
External Forces Accused Of Promoting Split In Comesa


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The executive-secretary of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Bingu wa Mutharika, accused on Tuesday unnamed " external forces" of working to kill the organization by influencing some member states to withdraw.

"There are people out there who are not happy that Africans with black skins can sit down and get success. Unfortunately, we are victim of our own success," he said. 

Mutharika, a Malawian, was speaking at a news conference in Lusaka, the Zambian capital. He was reacting to announcements by Lesotho and Mozambique that they were withdrawing from the 20-nation common market.

He described the decision by the two countries as a matter of concern to the heads of state and government of the common market, and to himself. He appealed to both nations to re-consider their decision in the name of Pan- Africanism.

Mutharika noted that, unlike the much smaller Southern Africa Development Community, the common market -- also know by its acronym, Comesa -- was not an aid-coordinating agency. Rather, he said, it was a common market with the an objective of promoting regional integration by developing a larger market.

"Comesa is an organization established by Africans, executed by Africans, for Africans," he said. "I hope that both Mozambique and Lesotho will carefully take full account of medium and long-term development interests."

He expressed fear that the common market would experience the same fate as the East African Community that grouped Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda. This community, which created in 1967, was officially disbanded in 1983 because of political differences among heads of state.

"Mozambique and Lesotho will go around the circle like the East African nations went through and, later, after realizing their mistakes, will come back to cause problems," Mutharika said.

He dismissed rumors that Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania were also planning to withdraw from Comesa to concentrate on the newly-created East African Cooperation Arrangement.

In addition, he said he was unaware that Namibia was also likely to withdraw. The said that Namibia's withdrawal request had not been officially communicated to Comesa's headquarters in Lusaka.

Comesa's Council of Ministers will be meeting later this week in Lusaka. The council will discuss concrete measures to strengthen the body following the withdrawal of Lesotho and Mozambique.

The other 18 Comesa member countries are Angola, Burundi, Comoros, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Namibia, Rwanda, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Comesa was created under a treaty signed in Kampala, Uganda, in late 1994. It succeeded the Eastern and Southern African Preferential Trade Area.

Botswana and South africa are the only other Southern African states which have never joined Comesa.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Aviation ZEX Acquires Third Aircraft


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe Express Airlines (ZEX), a private operator, has acquired a third aircraft to service its Bulawayo to Harare route which was launched Tuesday.

At least 100 Bulawayo and Harare business executives flew on the inaugural flights on the Boeing 727-100 tri-jet. 

The airline's public relations manager, Peter Mukuna, said the carrier was leasing the 118-seat American-built jet from Million Air Charter. A second Boeing 727 is to be leased from the South African-based charter company.

Zex's second aircraft, a 44-seater Hawker, is also being leased from a South African-based company, Executive Aerospace.

Mukuna said the new business express service between Harare and Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's two leading cities, would be mainly to serve the business community.

He said ZEX would offer a free flight between the two cities whenever a plane was delayed for more than one hour.

"We are giving the most efficient service at an economy fare but most importantly we are saying time is money and the business concept is punctuality for an appointment," he said.

ZEX's normal two return flights between Bulawayo and Harare begin Wednesday.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


168 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 2 (1/10)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3107 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania.

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Zaire - most information as of 10 January

a) Health situation in Tingi Tingi and Amisi (location of estimated 160,000 refugees) deteriorating. Concern growing on condition of an estimated 25,000 refugees in Shabunda, cut off from humanitarian assistance since 24 December by insecurity.

b) Total 684 mt relief food flown into Kisangani by WFP from 18 December 1996 to 7 January 1997, including 149 mt UNIMIX transported on behalf of UNICEF. 

c) On-forwarding from Kisangani to Tingi Tingi and Amisi in small aircraft and by truck; poor road condition of roads and insecurity along the Kisangani- Lubutu road mean minimum two days to reach Tingi Tingi and Amisi.

d) WFP carried out two food distributions in Tingi-Tingi, one food distribution in Amisi and two food distributions in Kisangani. Total of 303 mt distributed: 260 mt in Tingi-Tingi and 24 mt in Amisi to refugees, and 19 mt to internally displaced persons in Kisangani. Distributions made by partner NGOs CEPZA and CARITAS. WFP food stock in Kisangani, 7 January: 350.6 mt.

e) Security situation in Kisangani currently calm; some international NGOs returning.

2. Burundi

a) Tension, rebel attacks and violence, in spite of announced cease-fire (24 December to 3 January) by CNDD. RN3 road remains closed to UN traffic; no access to southern part of Kayanza province by UN Agencies and NGOs. Fighting reported in Muramvya province.

b) Mine incidents, including reported anti-personnel mine incidents, continue to pose a serious threat to local population and WFP staff travelling to the interior.

c) Tanzanian National Sanctions Coordinating Committee gives WFP Burundi authorisation to use barges from Kigoma to Bujumbura on Lake Tanganyika for food deliveries.

d) Low fuel reserves for WFP operations in Burundi. Authorisation to import more fuel awaited from Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee. At 5 January, diesel stocks stood at 3,893 litres and petrol at 3,445 litres (one week's supply).

3. Rwanda

a) Repatriation from Tanzania largely completed; an estimated 480,000 refugees returned over the last three weeks.

b) Repatriation from Zaire continues, but at slower pace, with 1,440 returnees returning via Cyangugu and 840 via Gisenyi last week.

c) Total 16,256 mt food distributed in cooperation with NGO partners since the beginning of large-scale repatriation in mid-November (represents 972,752 people assisted with a monthly ration)

4. Tanzania

a) Government of Tanzania and UNHCR to move all Burundian refugees in Ngara to Lumasi camp; other camps in Ngara hosting Burundians (Kitali and Lukole) to be closed shortly.

b) Fighting between Burundian refugees in Kitali camp leads to the death of nine refugees.

c) Some 7,000 refugees cross from Burundi into Kigoma between 1 and 7 January.

d) Total refugee population as of 7 January is 270,607.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. ZAIRE - most information as of 10 January

1.1 WFP staff working in the area have reported that the health and nutrition situation in Tingi Tingi and Amisi, where an estimated 160,000 refugees have gathered, has been deteriorating. In Shabunda, where an estimated 25,000 refugees have gathered, the actual condition of the refugees is uncertain. Information on the area has not been available since an increase in insecurity led to the departure of the last humanitarian organisation working in the area, on 24 December. No humanitarian assistance has been possible to Shabunda since that time.

1.2 From 18 December to 7 January, WFP flew a total of 684 metric tons (mt) of mixed food commodities to Kisangani out of which 80 mt arrived directly from Kinshasa. 149 mt of UNIMIX (included in the total tonnage) were transported on behalf of UNICEF.

1.3 Most of the food that arrives in Kisangani is being on-forwarded by WFP to the refugees in Tingi Tingi and Amisi by both airlifting in smaller aircraft and over land. Due to the very poor condition of roads from Kisangani and insecurity along the Kisangani-Lubutu road, the journey by road takes a minumum of two days to reach Tingi Tingi and Amisi. Limited airstrips have allowed WFP to ferry in food by aircraft, however these smaller aircraft, capable of landing on the short runways, airlift a maximum of 6 metric tons at a time.

1.4 WFP's strategy is to use, and improve where possible, surface transport, both into Kisangani and onwards to the refugee locations, and in the meantime increase air transport capacity to cope with the immediate needs. WFP has been building up its delivery capacity and is at present able to deliver an estimated 64 metric tons a day to the estimated 160,000 refugees in the Tingi Tingi and Amisi areas which represents approximately 75 per cent of their current food requirements.

1.5 WFP has thus far carried out two food distributions in Tingi Tingi, one food distribution in Amisi and two food distributions in Kisangani. A total of 303 mt has been distributed: 260 mt in Tingi Tingi and 24 mt in Amisi to refugees, and 19 mt to internally displaced persons in Kisangani. The distributions have been carried out through two partner NGOs, CEPZA and CARITAS.

1.6 The WFP food stock in Kisangani as of 7 January amounted to a total of 350.6 mt, consisting of 70.2 mt CSB, 109.9 mt UNIMIX, 104 mt maize, 42.2 mt pulses, 19.4 mt high-energy biscuits, 3.9 mt oil, 0.95 mt salt.

1.7 The WFP Andover aircraft continues to make rotations between Kisangani and Amisi, supplemented by a DC-3 operating into Tingi Tingi. WFP is airlifting food commodities as well as needed supplies for other agencies. The Andover aircraft has not yet been able to land in Tingi Tingi due to the condition of the landing strip. Work on the airstrip is continuing.

1.8 The security situation in Kisangani is calm for the time being. Some international NGOs, including MSF-France and ICRC, are returning to the area.

1.9 Goma

a) The security situation is reported to be deteriorating in the Goma area. Fighting has been reported between 20 and 45 km to the north. Five people have been reportedly killed and several injured.

b) An estimated 2,350 persons returned to Rwanda from Goma from 30 December to 5 January. WFP continues to distribute high-energy biscuits to all returnees.

c) WFP continues to supplement hospitals and health centres with biscuits to feed the malnourished and the hospitalised. Monitoring of these centres is carried out on a daily basis and in conjunction with the agencies involved in the health sector.

d) WFP field staff visited three camps of Zairean internally displaced persons in the area west of Goma and reported an estimated 5,350 persons located there. Several cases of malnutrition particularly among children, have been noticed.

1.10 Bukavu: Rwandan refugees continue to come out of the forest near Bukavu and cross the Rwanda/Zaire border at Cyangugu. From 1 to 8 January, 4, 601 Rwandan refugees crossed the border. WFP provided 1.7 mt of high-energy biscuits along the road up to the border during this period. The security situation is reported calm.

2. BURUNDI

2.1 From 23 December to 5 January, tension remained high despite an announced cease-fire from 24 December to 3 January by CNDD. Rebel attacks and violence were reported across the country. The RN3 road remains closed to UN traffic. The southern part of Kayanza province remains troubled and of no access to UN Agencies and NGOs in the region. MSF-Holland has temporarily left Kayanza the province. Fighting has been reported in Muramvya province, where several people have been wounded by machetes. Muyinga city witnessed a tight military control of its population with identity papers being verified and houses searched during the reporting period. Burglary and theft of vehicles are on the increase with several attacks aimed at expatriates in Bujumbura.

2.2 Mine incidents continue to be reported in several parts of the country; these include unofficial reports of anti-personnel mines. An anti-tank mine was deactivated the morning of a WFP distribution in Mubimbi commune, on the road leading to the site, while several roads are reportedly mined in Kayanza province. This situation poses a serious threat to WFP staff travelling to the interior.

2.3 Local media reported that a cholera epidemic broke out in Rumonge commune of Bururi province, a region which remains highly unstable at the present time and of extremely difficult access for UN agencies and NGOs.

2.4 The WFP Burundi caseload totalled 143,274 between 23 December and 5 January. This includes the following: emergency relief for 75, 410 people in the provinces of Gitega Kayanza, Bujumbura, Karuzi, Cankuzo and Bururi; general distribution for 3,481 beneficiaries including new arrivals (869) at the Gatumba transit; returnee and refugee packages for 39,961, including returnees waiting to be transferred to their home provinces and refugees from Zaire (Banyamulenge) in Bubanza province; small-scale short-term food-for- work projects for 13,490; and 10,932 vulnerable people in Selective Feeding Programmes.

2.5 WFP Burundi has been authorised by the Tanzanian National Sanctions Coordinating Committee to use barges from Kigoma to Bujumbura on Lake Tanganyika for food deliveries. WFP will organise the first convoy as soon as possible.

2.6 WFP operations in Burundi are threatened by low fuel reserves. Authorisation to import more fuel is still awaited from the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee. At 5 January, diesel stocks stood at 3,893 litres and petrol at 3,445 litres which represents one week supply only.

3. RWANDA

3.1 The repatriation from Tanzania has been largely completed. An estimated 480,000 refugees are reported to have come back in the last three weeks. WFP is providing food-aid to all returnees.

3.2 Repatriation from Zaire continues, with the numbers of returnees dropping. Last week, 1,440 returnees came via Cyangugu and 840 via Gisenyi. 31 returnees also arrived from Uganda.

3.3 Nutritional problems have not been reported regarding returnees from Tanzania, however a number of malnutrition cases have been reported among returnees currently coming from Zaire. Reports of malnutrition have also been received from some areas hosting high numbers of "old caseload" returnees (in Kibungo and Umutara prefectures).

3.4 Emergency distributions of high-energy biscuits have been stopped in all parts of the country because almost all returnees have already reached their home communes. During the operation, WFP distributed some 350 mt of biscuits (1.4 million daily rations), mostly in Kibungo, Gisenyi and Ruhengeri prefectures.

3.5 Since the beginning of the repatriation, in mid-November, WFP provided, and distributed in cooperation with NGO partners, some 16,256 mt of food country-wide. This represents 972,752 people assisted with a monthly ration. Most distributions are carried out at the commune level, to heads of households.

3.6 All returnees from Zaire have received their first month food aid entitlement and the second month distributions are currently underway. Returnees from Tanzania are still receiving their first month ration (over 70 percent have already been assisted). First month ration consists of 417 g of maize, 120 g beans and 20 g oil per person, per day (2,038 kcal) and the second month of 250 g of maize, 50 g CSB, 120 g beans, 20 g oil (1,550 kcal).

3.7 The number of refugees coming to and residing in Rwanda has been dropping. Only 18 asylum seekers came from Burundi and five from Zaire last week. Following the repatriation of over 5,000 Zaireans from Mudende camp (Gisenyi), only 32 refugees remain and their departure is expected in the near future. The number of Burundian refugees in Kigeme camp (Gikongoro) decreased to 1,532 people following repatriation of some 800 persons. Currently, there are around 15,000 Zairean refugees and 5,000 Burundian refugees in refugee camps in Kibuye, Cyangugu and Gikongoro prefectures. WFP continues to provide food to all refugees in Rwanda.

3.8 The general security situation in Rwanda remained relatively stable from 1 to 6 January however a number of incidents were recorded: nine civilians were killed in Gitarama; at least four armed attacks occurred on local authority representatives in Gisenyi; and an RPA patrol was attacked in Ruhengeri. National security forces attributed all these attacks to the ex- FAR and Interahamwe elements.

3.9 UN HRFOR has reported that an estimated 2,600 of the returnees who came from Tanzania were arrested on allegations of taking part in the 1994 genocide. Some 700 more were arrested during November, among those coming from Zaire. Some returnees reportedly turned themselves in to the police, fearing reprisals from the local population.

3.10 Trials for genocide suspects started in several towns in Rwanda (Kibungo, Kigali, Byumba). Thus far, two defendants have been found guilty and sentenced to death in Kibungo. Currently, there are around 90,000 detainees awaiting trial. The Rwanda Government recently made public a list of 1,900 suspects who could face death sentence, considering the extent of their involvement in the genocide. The trials continue nation-wide.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 The Government of Tanzania and UNHCR have declared that all Burundian refugees in Ngara will be moved to Lumasi camp, and that other camps in Ngara hosting Burundians (Kitali and Lukole) will be closed shortly. The Kitali camp caseload is to be moved to Lumasi by 12 January. Meanwhile, hostilities which broke out between Burundian refugees in Kitali camp, led to the death of nine refugees.

4.2 The Tanzanian police is combing villages in Kagera region in search of Rwandan refugees. Those found are moved to Rusumo border point for repatriation.

4.3 The Tanzanians displaced in the Keza area due to conflicts with the refugees will return to their villages shortly. WFP will provide a two-week take-home ration for them.

4.4 Nearly 7,000 refugees crossed the border from Burundi into Kigoma between 1 and 7 January. New Burundian arrivals continue to be moved to Muyovosi camp.

4.5 Refugee population reported as of 7 January is as follows: Karagwe - 51; Ngara - 88,275; Kigoma - Kasulu 81,908, Kibondo 94,373, Kigoma 6,000, subtotal 182,281. Total 270,607.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 2 of 1997 - January 10, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


169 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 17


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3587 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 17 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, January 10, 1997. Note: The last situation report was dated January 2, 1997.

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted the Banyarwanda in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control. In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified.

On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, and south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma. 

As a result of shelling from Rwanda on October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps near Goma, fled to Mugunga camp. Both the ex-FAR and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)-financed Zairian Camp Security Contingent (CZSC) became involved in the fighting. After suffering defeat, the FAZ and CZSC retreated west and north, looting villages and displacing Zairians from Goma town and surrounding areas. After Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the ADFL counter-attacked from the east on November 14, forcing the ex- FAR and Interahamwe to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to flee. The ADFL has steadily continued its advance, seizing the gold-mining town of Bunia on December 24. The FAZ meanwhile have announced preparations for a counter-attack to reclaim lost territory.

U.S. Government (USG) Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date) - $93,529,153

Numbers Affected

Rwandan refugees: An estimated 555,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from the Eastern Zaire camps to Rwanda between November and the end of December. A total of 719,307 returned during 1996, the UNHCR reports. Of the 535,000 Rwandan refugees in Tanzania, almost all have repatriated to Rwanda: about 6, 500 returned between September 10 and December 12, and 473,082 returned from December 14-31. A total of 483,445 returned during 1996. The UNHCR claims there are more than 330,000 Rwandans stranded in Eastern Zaire, with 120,000 in Tingi-Tingi, just to the south of Lubutu, in North Kivu, and 150,000 in Shabunda, in South Kivu.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area, some 62,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania. The balance are unaccounted for. Newly Displaced: Fleeing continued fighting in Burundi, a new caseload of about 100,000 Burundian refugees has entered Tanzania. Approximately 35,000 Zairians have fled to Tanzania. Some 800 Rwandan and Zairian Tutsis remain in the Congo and 11,500 Zairians are reported in Uganda. The U.S. Embassy in Zaire estimates that 170,000 Zairians have been displaced by the conflict in eastern Zaire, including 20,000 from Uvira, 60,000 from Bukavu, 40,000 from Goma, and 50,000 from rural areas.

Current Situation

The UNHCR reported that as of December 31, 473,082 Rwandan refugees had returned from Tanzania since December 14, and that the mass return from Tanzania has ended. The UNHCR admits that its longstanding estimate of 540, 000 Rwandan refugees in Tanzania could have been an overestimate. It has declared that 52,300 Rwandans have fled into the Tanzanian countryside and south of Kigoma, where some could be posing as Burundian refugees. In Zaire, the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA) reported on December 30 that relief agencies had temporarily withdrawn expatriate staff from Shabunda and Lubutu because of security concerns. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) estimated there were 60,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees and 3,000 displaced Zairians in Shabunda at the time it evacuated its workers from there.

ICRC and Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) operations in Lubutu continue under the supervision of local staff. In the Lubutu area, 300 km northwest of Goma, MSF identified about 70,000 refugees and several thousand displaced Zairians in the area who need assistance. UNICEF and Action of Churches Together (ACT) are airlifting supplies from Nairobi to Kisangani, for overland transport to Lubutu.

Political/Military Situation

On December 18, President Mobutu Sese Seko returned to Zaire from France, where he was convalescing from cancer. He announced that he would take measures to recover the territory lost to the rebels. That day Zairian television announced the appointment of General Mahele Bokoungo Lieko as the new army chief.

On December 24, Bunia fell to the ADFL, and on January 2, the Alliance claimed to have captured Mangbwalu, 25 miles north of Bunia, and the Kilo- moto gold mining region, covering 83,000 square km. The ADFL also is believed to control the nearby towns of Boga, Geti, and Mambasa.

U.N. sources in Kinshasa report that the Zairian Special Presidential Division troops control Kisangani, which is under curfew. Uvira, Bukavu, and Goma remain under ADFL control. The GOZ last week repeated its refusal to negotiate with Kabila.

In response to U.N. Security Council Resolution 1080, approved November 15, a Canadian-led multinational force (MNF) was formed to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian assistance and the repatriation of refugees. On December 23 the UN Security Council accepted Canada's recommendation to end the MNF, effective December 31. The USG will continue to use diplomatic means to help humanitarian organizations gain full access in eastern Zaire.

Relief Efforts

The Government of Canada hosted a multi-donor meeting in Kigali on December 13 on the reintegration of Rwandan refugees. Representatives from 12 countries, the European Union, U.N. agencies, and the Government of Rwanda (GOR) met to discuss developments since the refugees began returning on November 15, to present GOR priorities, to review donor programs, and to discuss donor coordination efforts. The GOR reiterated its priorities of housing, security, justice and human resource development and called on donors to support whole communities, including returnees and existing residents alike. Shelter remains the highest priority, with the GOR reporting that populations have doubled or tripled in certain communes.

Zaire: Humanitarian agencies established a Coordination Committee in Kisangani to coordinate relief assistance in the area, including Lubutu. WFP airlifted 120 MT of food to Kisangani in late December. From there it has worked with La Procure, the logistics service branch of the Catholic Church, to take the food on to Lubutu and Tingi-Tingi. The ICRC delivered 10 metric tons (MT) of relief supplies to Kisangani for refugees and displaced persons and on December 17, it began distributing food rations to 4,400 Zairian displaced persons and 800 refugees in Kalemie. UNICEF is airlifting 10 MT of relief supplies daily to the Kisangani area.

UNHCR reports it has assisted in the repatriation of 35,000 refugees who have emerged from hiding in the Virunga National Park near Goma since November 19.

On January 9, the UNHCR announced the suspension of its activities north of Goma, due to insecurity.

Rwanda: Returnees from Tanzania are reportedly in good condition, as there was low malnutrition in the camps, most refugees have been vaccinated and they are carrying shelter materials with them. Registration is underway in the communes.

According to UNHCR figures released on December 12, local authorities in the communes registered over 470,000 Rwandans returning from eastern Zaire during the month of November. Food distribution is underway in all prefectures of Rwanda. WFP distributed 12,295 MT of food from December 16 to December 24, and had 7,107 MT of food available for immediate distribution as of December 24.

From November 15 to December 12, WFP and NGO partners distributed about 9, 700 MT of food commodities, representing over 580,000 people assisted with monthly rations. In addition, over one million high-protein biscuits were distributed.

On December 31, the GOR announced that all food was to be distributed through local authorities, and not NGOs, as previously practiced. The WFP was requested to transport food to the communes, from which the UNHCR would take it to points for distribution by local authorities.

Following the repatriation from Tanzania, the U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) reports that in Kibungo Prefecture, 2,243 returnees are in detention, and 676 are detained in Mutara Prefecture. Most of the returnees from Tanzania originally came from the two prefectures. Nationally, Rwandan authorities have detained 5,460 returnees between November 15 and December 31. GOR authorities have also registered 1,931 members of the ex-FAR in Gisenyi prefecture. Authorities are still compiling registrations in other prefectures.

The need for permanent shelter poses a major concern for the GOR. The GOR estimates that 200-250,000 will need new homes. An authoritative tally of new housing has not been undertaken, and shelter needs country-wide are not yet coordinated. WFP and UNHCR both report to have built about 6,000 new houses in 1996. The UNHCR also distributed 13,182 shelter kits as of November 30, 1996. Officially, the GOR has given squatters two weeks to vacate dwellings belonging to returnees but implementation of this policy appears varied at the commune level.

Trials of Rwandans suspected of involvement in the 1994 genocide began on December 27 in Kibungo. Two suspects were sentenced to death on January 3. Their lawyers have appealed the verdict. On December 30 in Kigali, the trial of two other genocide suspects was adjourned and moved to Gitarama. With the permission of the GOR, a French and two Belgian lawyers from Lawyers Without Borders are scheduled to arrive in Kigali on January 11 to assist Rwandan genocide suspects in their defense.

On December 31, the bourgmestre of Rukira commune, Kibungo prefecture, and his assistant were killed in a collision with a UNHCR water truck.

Burundi: Burundian Army officials claimed on Tanzanian radio that Hutu rebels launched an attack in southern Burundi on December 24, killing four Burundian Army soldiers, an undisclosed number of civilians, and losing thirteen of their own. U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso, reported on December 11 that more than 1,000 people were massacred in Burundi between late October and late November. WFP reports that Kayanza and Bujumbura Rural provinces are insecure and the situation has deteriorated in Bubanza province. Many parts of Bururi, Muramvya, Gitega, and Karuzi provinces remain unsafe. MSF Holland (MSF/H) announced on January 6 that it was suspending its operations in Kayanza province because of insecurity.

UNHCR reports that of the 62,000 Burundian refugees who have returned to Burundi from Zaire, about 45,000 spontaneously repatriated to Cibitoke province and 15,000 arrived through the Gatumba transit center outside Bujumbura. WFP is distributing returnee packages to both populations.

The U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Burundi, UNHCR, and NGOs are monitoring returns to insecure areas. UNHCR reports that about 38,000 of the returnees to Cibitoke have settled in 10 government sites.

Uganda: The Ugandan Government has agreed to the UNHCR's request to grant temporary refugee status to 3,081 Rwandan refugees who fled from the Karagwe area of Tanzania to Orutshinga camp, 260 km west of Kampala. On December 18, a local government official said the refugees who had registered in Orutshinga after leaving Karagwe would either have to go home or back to Tanzania.

The UNHCR reported 9,273 Rwandan refugees in Kisoro and 4,006 at Kihihi camp, in Matanda district, near Zaire. All arrived since in Uganda since the mass repatriation. In Nebbi, northwestern Uganda, 200 Zairian refugees arrived, having fled the advance of Alliance rebels in Eastern Zaire. Tanzania: UNHCR officials have expressed concern at reports of brutality by members of the Tanzanian security forces involved in the repatriation of Rwandan refugees. In late December, the GOT announced the arrest of a Tanzanian police officer suspected of involvement in the death of a Rwandan refugee.

A Tanzanian newspaper quoted the general in command of the refugee repatriation as saying that Tanzanian Defense Forces would begin house-to- house searches on January 1 in Ngara and Karagwe for escaped Rwandan refugees. Tanzanian forces reportedly detained 50 refugees from camps near Ngara and 100 from Karagwe. UNHCR reported that 49 refugees, 35 of whom confessed to being killers, turned themselves over to the agency in Tanzania.

To date about 20 Rwandan refugees chose to commit suicide rather than return, USAID officials reported.

About 52,300 refugees remain in Tanzania, the UNHCR reports. In the Ngara camps, 83,305 Burundians remain; in Kibondo district, there are 91,880 refugees, all Burundian but for 2,168 people of mixed marriages; in Kasulu, there are 77,106 Burundians and Zairians; in Kigoma town there are about 5, 000 people. UNHCR reported that 34,000 new refugees arrived in Tanzania from Zaire and Burundi in December.

About 30,000 Rwandan refugees from the Karagwe camps remain at large. The UNHCR reported that Tanzanian security forces identified about 100 Rwandan intimidators and have moved them to facilities in Mwiza, northern Tanzania.

USG Assistance On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, report on the situation, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist with repatriation efforts. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda Robert Gribbin, declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire posed a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda. On November 12, U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire, as a result of the violent break-up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire. On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region. On November 25, Ambassador Morris Hughes declared a disaster in Burundi, as a result of continuing civil strife.

USG FY 1997 Assistance (to date):

BHR/OFDA Assistance

To date, BHR/OFDA funding has been obligated as follows:

Grant to Action Aid for shelter in Kibuye - $648,500

Grant to AMREF for medical services - $212,129

Grant to ARC for water/sanitation/health - $2,795,893

Grant to CARE International for shelter/water/sanitation/food/non-food activities - $1,967,853

Grant to Christian Reformed World Relief Committee for seed distributionn - $650,189

Grant to CRS for food distribution - $328,846

Grant to Doctors of the World for medical services - $370,189

Grant to FHI for shelter and seeds - $1,941,054

Grant to ICRC for assistance to Rwandan refugees and displaced persons in eastern Zaire - $5,000,000

Grant to IRC for water/sanitation/health - $1,149,835

Grant to Medecins du Monde for medical services in Byumba, Gisenyi, and Ruhengeri - $652,760

Grant to Mercy Corps International for shelter in urban Kigali - $1,475,794

Grant to SCF/UK for unaccompanied children - $468,612

Grant to World Relief International for shelter in urban Kigali - $624,295

Grant to WVRD for medical and food distribution - $858,704

Grant to UNDHA for information coordination - $151,178

Plastic sheeting, blankets for UNHCR - $778,000

Emergency health kits for the GOR Ministry of Health - $205,013

Airlift of relief supplies to Rwanda for UNICEF - $90,000

Provision of health kits to GOR Ministry of Health $252,309

In addition, BHR/OFDA is procuring communications equipment for the GOR and is in the process of obligating additional funds.

BHR/OFDA Assistance - $20,621,153

BHR/OTI Assistance

BHR's Office of Transition Initiatives (BHR/OTI) has provided a total of $375,000 to the Women in Transition project and to fund visits by local reporters to the Tribunal in Arusha.

BHR/OTI also funded experts to travel to Rwanda to conduct an evaluation on the genocide trials.

BHR/OTI Assistance - $408,000

BHR/FFP Assistance

In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, Uganda, and Tanzania.

BHR/FFP Assistance - $72,500,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE (to date): $93,529,153


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997

170 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (1/6 - 1/12)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Geneva - 6-7.01.97 -- A seminar about transitions to democracy in the world took place in Rabat, organised by the Abderrahim Bouabid Foundation and presided by Prince Sidi Mohamed, heir of the Moroccan kingdom. In his opening speach the Prince declared the advance of democracy in his country is conditionned to the respect of "the holy values of our people", which means monarchy and the integrity of the Moroccan territory including Western Sahara. John Waterbury, author of the critical analysis of Morocco "Commander of the Faithfull" published in 1970 and still forbidden in Morocco, participated at this event. In an interview with the news agency EFE, the US specialist of political science said Morocco has changed, passing from a "culture of repression" to a "culture of administration". "Before, violence was used to govern. A violence which had to be shown. Now, administration is used to govern, violence is no more necessary. The monarchy is not questioned".

09.01.97 British declaration

The British Secretary of State at Foreign Office, on official visit in Tunisia, declared to be worried by the "lack of progress" in the question of Western Sahara. Mr. Jeremy Hanley commended the initiative of King Hassan II, starting talks with the Polisario Front and he underlined the negative effects of the W.S. conflict for the whole region.

NEW PUBLICATION

Hassan's heir prepares to take reins of power, Varadarajan Tunku, The Times, London, 28.12.96, p. 16.

NEW on INTERNET: Proyecto del Sahara de "Ingenierma Sin Fronteras" (ISF) del Pams Vasco ( Informatica ) URL: http://www.geocities. com/RainForest/5148/Sahara.html


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 8 (1/4-10)


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3080 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES GENERAL * Not surprisingly, Rwandan returns have been accompanied by an intensive focus on reintegration efforts in Rwanda. The ongoing conflicts in Burundi and eastern Zaire with spill-over into Uganda and Tanzania present continuing humanitarian challenges. As we adjust regional strategies to new circumstances, department would find it useful to hear from UNHCR's senior leadership on its proposed plan of action for the coming months in the great lakes. (STATE 5018, 1/9/97)

* United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan has recommended the appointment of a special representative for the Great Lakes region. ... Annan said that though the original idea was to send an envoy who would do another " exploratory round" in the region, he preferred the appointment of a special representative, who will be based in the area. (PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY, 1/9/97, courtesy of Relief Web)

* UNHCR assistant High Commissioner Vieira de Mello responded favorably to our request for a visit to Washington in the next two weeks. He welcomed the opportunity to discuss with the department coordination issues, regional strategies and UNHCR's plans for 1997. (GENEVA 108, 1/10/97) 

REPATRIATION TO RWANDA * On December 28, 13,414 refugees returned to Rwanda from Tanzania. UNHCR has declared that the mass refugee return from Tanzania is now finished. (KIGALI 49, USAID/DART Field Sitrep, 1/6/97)

* Around 473,082 returnees arrived in southeastern Rwanda from Tanzania between 14 and 31 December, while 555,000 have come back from Zaire since November. (UNHCR, 1/7/97)

* UNHCR repatriation figures for 1996 showed that a total of 1,300,582 refugees returned home last year. Of these, 719,307 returned from Zaire, 483, 445 from Tanzania, 88,309 from Burundi, and 9,521 from Uganda. (IRIN Emergency Update *73, 1/7/97)

* Small numbers of Rwandan stragglers continue to cross the border from Tanzania daily. Tanzanian forces are continuing to search for those in hiding, at least until next week when funding for the military operation runs out. (DAR ES SALAAM 232, 1/10)

* Repatriation from Zaire continues, but at slower pace, with 1,440 returnees returning via Cyangugu and 840 via Gisenyi last week. ... Rwandan refugees continue to come out of the forest near Bukavu and cross the Rwanda/Zaire border at Cyangugu. From 1 to 8 January, 4,601 Rwandan refugees crossed the border. (WFP EMERGENCY REPORT *2, 1/10/97)

SITUATION IN RWANDA: * Hutu hardliners, some infiltrating Rwanda among a million returning refugees, have carried out massacres inside the country as well as crossborder raids, Rwandan government and aid sources said Tuesday. Up to 50 people, including Rwandan soldiers, civilians and armed infiltrators from Zaire, have been killed since Christmas, a Rwandan defense spokesman and aid sources said. (Reuters, 1/7/97)

* Eight assailants dies and one was captured after "infiltrators" exchanged fire with Rwandan soldiers in Ruhengeri prefecture over the weekend, Rwandan radio reported. (IRIN Emergency Update No. 73, 1/7/97)

* The problem-plagued tribunal on Rwanda's 1994 genocide adjourned after a brief start on Thursday when the prosecution failed to present witnesses because they had not arrived from Rwanda, the court heard. (Reuters, 1/9/97)

* As for the treatment of returnees, the HRFOR continues to receive reports of ill-treatment in communal detention centres and during interrogations, as well as of illegal arrest procedures. HRFOR is particularly concerned with the level of tension between the local population and recently-arrived returnees in Kibungo. (UNHCR, 1/7/97)

* Some 5,460 recent Rwandan returnees were being held in detention throughout Rwanda as of 31 December 1996, according to a 6 January report from the Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. (UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1/7/97, courtesy of ReliefWeb)

Shelter * Estimates of the number of new shelters needed throughout Rwanda range from 200,000-250,000; yet the GOR, donors, and NGOs seem to lack a consistent strategy for meeting this need. While the GOR prefers to concentrate resources in resettlement sites as opposed to scattered settlement, many of the resettlement sites already constructed are unoccupied because they: 1) are located in areas where people do not want to live; 2) lack appropriate infrastructure; or 3) are designed in ways that are culturally unacceptable to returnees. (KIGALI 67, USAID/DART Field Sitrep, 1/7/97)

Food * Food distribution at the commune level is becoming problematic, because the government of Rwanda recently changed the original agreement under which the WFP and NGOs were operating. ... On December 29, the prefet of Kibungo notified WFP in writing that NGOs are no longer to be used in food distributions and food is to be distributed at the sectoral level rather than at the communes. (KIGALI 49, USAID/DART Field Sitrep, 1/6/97)

* Country-wide food distributions are going well generally speaking, and food is reaching those who need it. ... But the system put in place has led to unnecessary complications and confusion, particularly in the prefecture of Kibungo where the largest numbers of returnees were received and where the largest population of old caseload has resettled. The recent GOR decision to eliminate NGO participation in WFP distributions is a response to this confusion. (Currently 22 NGOs participate in the distributions.) The decision is also an effort by GOR to build the civil structures of the communes by strengthening local leadership and strengthening the confidence of newly returned citizens in local leadership. (KIGALI 48, 1/6/97)

* The agricultural season in Rwanda's northern prefectures has been relatively good. Production totals in the north should be above average and the region should have an overall food surplus in staple commodities. ... Famine early warning system (FEWS)/Rwanda estimates that Gitarama, Butare, and Gikongoro prefectures will face serious food shortages until the next harvest in June 1997. (KIGALI 146, USAID/DART Field Sitrep, 1/9/97)

* WFP/Rwanda Director hosted a meeting with the NGOs on January 6. ... WFP requested a readout from the NGOs on the communique of December 31 issued by Dr. Ephraim Kabajai, advisor to president of the republic of Rwanda and chairman of the joint commission for repatriation and reintegration of Rwandese refugees, and the emergency assistance coordination committee. ... NGOs felt that most Bourgemasters and sector counsellors were happy to have NGOs implementing food distributions. ... NGOs believe that local authorities have limited managerial capacity and limited time, and would have problems running the distributions. ... All NGOs thought the percentage of loss was likely to be higher with distributions through local authorities. ... NGOs and WFP agree that distribution operations continue in the current mode until WFP clarifies key points within the communique with the GOR. (KIGALI 166, 1/10/97)

SITUATION IN ZAIRE: * A former chief of security at the French presidency has denied that he is putting together a mercenary force to help the government of Zaire fight... (Reuters, 1/8/97)

* The UN refugee agency said Thursday it had suspended its activities north of Goma because of an ambush that left one person dead and six wounded. Craig Sanders of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees said the measure was in effect since Wednesday, the day of the attack, for security reasons and that no date had been set for resuming activities. (Paris AFP, 1/9/97, courtesy of FBIS)

* WFP continues to fly in food and relief materials to Kisangani by a Zairean chartered 707, from where it is moved either by road or by a locally chartered aircraft to Lubutu/Tingi-Tingi. Since the inception of the flights on 18 December to 1 January, WFP flights have moved in a total of 332 metric tons. WFP has begun another air operation, consisting initially of twenty flights with an Andover aircraft..., between Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi, Amisi or Shabunda. The destination will vary depending on the needs and security situation in each area. (WFP Emergency Report 1, 1/3/97)

* The U.N. refugee agency expressed concern on Tuesday about more than 330, 000 Rwandan refugees still stranded in eastern Zaire, especially 120,000 in a camp short of food and thought to be dominated by thugs. Eleven to 15 people were dying every day at the Tingi Tingi camp, where food shortages had prompted conflict between the refugees and local Zaireans, spokeswoman Pamela O'Toole said. (Reuters, 1/7/97)

* Desperately undernourished children are dying daily in makeshift refugee camps in eastern Zaire, the United Nations children's agency said Wednesday. The death toll is growing at a remote camp in Tingi Tingi near Lubutu, where 23 deaths were reported on Monday, UNICEF said. (Associated Press, 1/8/97)

* No one has yet done a count of the "refugees" at Tingi-Tingi, or interviewed them to determine their status and under what international mandate they may be entitled to assistance. ... The two stories, "refugees" and the value of the Zaire currency, shared the African news spotlight January 8. News stories pointed out that Zaire's currency value was backed by nothing, but failed to make the same disclaimer about the UN agencies' refugee numbers. (KIGALI 129, 1/9/97)

* Around Lubutu and Shabunda, where large numbers of Rwandan refugees and displaced Zairians have gathered, and throughout much of eastern Zaire military and militia activity proliferates, jeopardizing the security of international aid workers as well as refugees. Already ICRC and MSF were forced to withdraw from Shabunda after members of their respective staffs were threatened. On January 8, UNHCR suspended operations around Goma, Zaire after several cars were attacked, resulting in the death of one person and the wounding of six others. (Refugees International, 1/9/97, courtesy of ReliefWeb)

* UNICEF expressed deep concern, 8 January, at the deteriorating condition of the Rwandan refugees and internally displaced people sheltering in the Lubutu area, 170 kms southeast of Kisangani, in eastern Zaire. Recent reports reveal an alarming increase in the number of deaths among these people. (UNICEF, 1/8/97, courtesy of Relief Web)

* Despite its decision to withdraw from the area for the time being, the ICRC remains extremely concerned about the fate of the populations at Shabunda, who are stranded in the forest without any protection or assistance whatsoever. The ICRC will therefore be returning to Kindu as soon as possible to hold talks with the authorities and discuss its resumption of activities in the area once the security situation has stabilized. In addition, ways should be found for refugees in Shabunda to move to a location which poses fewer logistical obstacles to the provision of assistance, and from which refugees could return to Rwanda if they wished to do so. (ICRC, 1/8/97)

TANZANIA: * The Tanzanian authorities over the weekend arrested 75 more Burundian and Zairean refugees who left their camps in the Kigoma region. A total of 16 Tanzanians who were allegedly harboring refugees in Kigoma town have also been arrested, Kigoma police commander Christopher Shekiondo said. (IRIN Emergency Update *72, 1/6/97)

* With the vast majority of the Rwandan refugees having returned to Rwanda from Tanzania by 30 December, Tanzania currently accommodates approximately 248,000 registered refugees. The breakdown is as follows: 80,000 Burundian refugees in the Ngara region; 130,000 Burundian refugees in the kigoma region; 38,000 Zairean refugees in the kigoma region. The influx of Zairean and Burundian refugees into the Kigoma region continues with some 1,000 arriving per day. (WFP Emergency Report 1, 1/3/97)

* The former Rwandan camps in Ngara and Karagwe districts have not as yet been leveled. UNHCR and NGOs are continuing to sweep the sites, collecting belongings and preparing for the razing of the camps. (DAR ES SALAAM 232, 1/10)

APPENDIX

(Note: U.S. Government cables are denoted by a capital city name

followed by a number. Ex: KIGALI 4831)

* Note: The Consolidated Great Lakes report is a compliation of information from the following sources: USG cables; U.N., IO, and NGO situation reports; press clips; and USG departments, bureaus, and offices. The date and source of each entry are noted, but the information should be checked against source materials. Information is reported as of the date of the source; however, conflicting information may appear within the consolidated report due to rapidly changing events in the region.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 78 on the Great Lakes (01/14)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Nairobi - UNHCR in Burundi has confirmed the massacre by the army of some 120 refugees who had returned from Tanzania, AFP reported. UNHCR chief in Bujumbura Hitoshi Mise said 122 returnees had been killed.

"It's a special and particular case because (the refugees) were expelled by the Tanzanian authorities because of their involvement in violent clashes in which eight people were killed at the (Kitali) refugee camp," AFP quoted Mise as saying. In-fighting reportedly broke out earlier at the Kitali camp between Burundian Hutu extremists from the Palipehutu party and the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD). Burundian soldiers were said to have opened fire on Friday after panic broke out when 126 refugees were handed over by the Tanzanian authorities to the Kobero military post, near the northeast Burundian town of Muyinga, and then tried to escape. Mise said one of his colleagues who was on the spot described how a woman among the refugees had thrown a grenade towards the Burundian soldiers, although its pin was not pulled out. The matter, he added, was "very complex". 

Tanzania however today denied it had expelled the refugees. Deputy Minister for Home Affairs Emmanuel Mwambulukutu said as far as he knew Tanzania had never expelled Burundian refugees from its territory. "We don't have a policy of expelling refugees," he said, according to AFP. "The only refugees we have returned home are those who came from Rwanda. This we did after being assured of the restoration of peace and stability in that country." The number of Burundians entering Tanzania continued to rise, he said, and Tanzania had established two new camps to accommodate them.

UN Secretary General Kofi Annan yesterday expressed shock over the killings in Burundi and called for an end to the "cycle of violence" in the country. He urged the authorities "to ensure that the rule of law is scrupulously followed and to prevent further massacres by the army". There was a "pressing need" for an immediate ceasefire between the army and Hutu rebels, and for peace talks, he added.

Security remains a serious problem in northwest Rwanda. Employees of the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) were attacked in Gisenyi yesterday afternoon by an unidentified individual using hand grenades. As a result, UN security officials have suspended all travel by UN personnel to the prefecture as well as stopping UN human rights activities in Gisenyi.

In further security incidents, three people were killed and three more wounded when about 60 armed men attacked a hospital in the northwest Rwandan town of Kabaya over the weekend, aid workers said yesterday. According to local people, the assailants were Hutus who had infiltrated from Zaire or from nearby forests and looted the hospital's pharmacy. Two MSF surgeons who were at the hospital were threatened, AFP said. Unconfirmed reports stated that the attackers also tried to storm the local jail where a number of genocide suspects are imprisoned. Rwandan radio yesterday reported the deaths of three people who were murdered in Nyakabande sector of Kigali urban prefecture. Four suspects had been detained following the murders in which the victims were blindfolded and killed using blunt weapons. Violence in Cyangugu prefecture resulted in a security meeting over the weekend convened by the prefect Faustin Munyakabera at Nyakabuye. The meeting noted in particular that five "infiltrators" were killed nine days ago during clashes with the security forces in the area. Residents were warned against collaboration with infiltrators, one of whom was present at the meeting. According to Rwandan radio, he said his group of 23 men entered Rwanda from Bukavu last October but only 10 of them had escaped death or captivity.

Tension is particularly high in communes where genocide survivors are in the minority, such as Kigali Rural prefecture. UNHCR reports that in Kanzenze, the 10,713 registered returnees heavily outnumber the local population which has led to a reluctance by genocide survivors to denounce suspects for fear of reprisals. UN sources said local authorities believe virtually all the male returnees in Kanzenze took part to some extent in the genocide and most female returnees participated in looting properties. However, only 33 people have been arrested.

An alleged ringleader of the 1994 genocide, former politician Froduald Karamira, went on trial in Kigali today, but the hearing was immediately adjourned for two weeks to give the defence more time to prepare its case. The hearing began as Amnesty International again questioned the fairness of the trials in Rwanda. "In a climate of bitterness and suspicion, there is a risk that those accused of genocide will be considered guilty unless proven innocent," Amnesty said in a statement released today. It said the the trials "should conform to international standards of fairness including ensuring that the defendants have access to the court file and adequate time to prepare for their defence, are assisted by legal counsel, including foreign lawyers, and are allowed to call witnesses in their defence".

Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila claimed that the Bukavu-Shabunda-Kindu axis had recently been "infiltrated" by Zairean and former Rwandan (ex-FAR) soldiers, leading to "low-level fighting" with the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL). Rebel Radio of the People, which broadcasts from Bukavu, yesterday said the Zairean/ex-FAR troops were "silenced and defeated". The radio also pointed out that the " massive counter-offensive" awaited in eastern Zaire had not yet taken place, adding that Kabila had predicted that in the "post-Mobutu period", the ADFL would come to power "either via negotiations or through direct military action".

At least three people were killed by Interahamwe members who attacked a village in the Goma area under ADFL control last week, Reuters reported, quoting a rebel officer. "The village was attacked yesterday and again this morning (Friday) which was when the people were killed," said the officer who commands the checkpoint at Mushaki village. He added that the Interahamwe were located in nearby hills. AFP today cited local residents as saying hundreds of rebels had been combing the dense Virunga forests near Goma in a bid to flush out Zairean troops and Interahamwe. UN and NGO agencies reported an unusually high number of young men at the Tingi-Tingi camp near Lubutu and UN sources said they could be ex-FAR and Interahamwe who were using force to control the population. The sources said that since ADFL troops took Walikale on 25 December, refugees have been flowing out of the forest.

Concern has been expressed by humanitarian aid workers in the Lubutu area that food aid distributions in Tingi-Tingi and Amisi camps are not always reaching the intended beneficiaries. As in the Kivu camps in 1994, the most expedient way to distribute food, given staffing constraints, the large refugee population and security concerns, is to utilise existing camp structures, which parallel the Rwandan administrative structure. Concern has been raised that the distribution of food through the refugee leaders has led to inequitable food distributions with vulnerable groups being hardest hit. NGOs, aware of the problem, are trying to move away from prefect leaders to a distribution through commune and eventually cell leaders. According to UNHCR, food distribution monitoring has also been increased. WFP said it was increasing food movements to Tingi-Tingi and Amisi to 160 mt a week by road and 25 mt a day by air.

A report by UNICEF and MSF last week indicated elevated child mortality rates in refugee camps near Lubutu. Estimates from the cemetery and MSF feeding centres indicate a death rate of 20 people per day, most of them children under five. A recent UNICEF mission clarified that while the death rate among vulnerable groups was extremely high, the general refugee population was in relatively good health. They have been able to supplement their food needs by gathering wild plants.

The refugee population in Shabunda has not received food aid since the withdrawal of ICRC expatriate workers on 26 December. The UNHCR team in Kisangani has conducted two recent missions to the area and a third is planned for today. Because of time constraints and weather conditions, only the Burundian refugees closest to the airport have been visited to date. An intial assessment indicated that despite the lack of food aid the population visited seemed in relatively good condition. Some refugees in Shabunda have been able to find work in local gold mines. However, humanitarian sources caution that not all of the refugee encampments have been contacted and health conditions in the remaining camps may vary significantly.

A former Tanzanian cabinet minister was gunned down at his home outside Dar es Salaam over the weekend, police said yesterday. Nicas Mahinda, a member of parliament and former natural resources and tourism minister, was showered with bullets on Sunday by a gang of about 30 thugs who jumped over the fence of his compound. Twenty-five people have been arrested in connection with the incident.

Nairobi, 14 January 1997, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
