173 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Calls For Speedy Resolution To Conflict In C.A.R.


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Washington - Revised statement by Spokesman Nicholas Burns, January 10, on the situation in the Central African Republic.

The United States is concerned about the situation in the Central African Republic, and strongly supports a speedy resolution to the conflict between government and rebel factions. We call on all parties to respect the rule of law and the democratic process. The United States applauds the efforts of those Central Africans who are working to find a peaceful solution to their political differences and the important role being played by former Malian President Amadou Toumani Toure. We urge all parties to respect the cease-fire negotiated by African heads of state.

The United States notes that there have been numerous casualties during these weeks of conflict, most recently this past weekend in an unprovoked attack on cease-fire monitors which resulted in the death of two French soldiers and a number of Central Africans, including civilian bystanders. We express sympathy to the families of the dead.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Opposes South African Arm Sale to Syria


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Washington - Following are statements by the White House and State Department issued January 13, 1997.

Excerpt from daily White House Press Briefing by spokesman Mike Mccurry.

Q Mike, there were reports out of South Africa that the South African government is considering selling $640 million worth of arms to Syria, including tank firing systems. Apparently there are some concerns, however, in South Africa about the stance that the U.S. government might take on such a sale. Does the U.S. have a position on that? 

MR. MCCURRY: We have a strongly worded statement here that amounts to saying we think that's a very bad idea. We're aware of those reports. We have not independently confirmed that they may be trying to transfer tank firing missile systems to Syria, but we urge the government of South Africa not to go through with the sale and we have confidence that the government of South Africa understands the seriousness of this issue.

Comments at daily press briefing by State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns.

QUESTION: There were reports that the South African cabinet has approved, in principle, a large sale of electronic tank equipment to Syria. Do you think that this could have an influence on the Middle East peace process at all? What are your views on that? Are you against that? Would you try to persuade them not to do that, and could this have any influence as far as you are concerned on the negotiations on the ARMSCOR case that is still in the process.

MR. BURNS: Thank you. The United States is aware of the reports that South Africa is considering selling various weapons systems to Syria. We are deeply concerned about these reports. It would be extremely serious if these sales actually occurred. The United States hopes that the South African Government will not consummate arms sales to a country that supports terrorism. I think you know that both the Foreign Operations and the Foreign Assistance Act, the law of the United States, prohibits certain forms of U.S. assistance to governments which supply lethal equipment to Syria or to any of the other countries listed by the United States as a state sponsor of terrorism.

We would certainly analyze any potential sales in the context of our own laws. We would have to analyze any such sales and try to understand if in fact any violations of U.S. law took place. So it's a matter of very serious concern. We are now in touch with the South African Government. We'll remain in touch with them to try to ascertain if in fact these sales will go forward to Syria.

QUESTION: Do you have independent confirmation of what's going on? You eluded to reports. Are they press reports? Is that all?

MR. BURNS: Right. Among them. We have a variety of reports available to us and, as I said, we're trying on a first order of business to ascertain the plans of the South African Government. If in fact the sales go through, that would be a very serious matter indeed, and we'd then have to reflect upon the association of any acts or the relevance to our own laws, and I think you know the consequences of that, which are quite severe.

QUESTION: How much aid could it affect, potentially?

MR. BURNS: South Africa is one of our largest aid recipients.

QUESTION: Do you have a number, though?

MR. BURNS: Since I don't know what the outlines of any potential sale or actual sale would be, I think I want to demur there and say I can't anticipate what the effect would be, but in principle, any country that does sell military arms to a state sponsor of terrorism does expose itself to United States' law.

QUESTION: When did you find out about this?

MR. BURNS: I don't know when we found out about it. We have a lot of people in this government. When did the first person in the U.S. Government, either in our Embassy in Cape Town or Pretoria or in Bureau of Intelligence and Research find out about this, I don't know, but we've been aware of it for a little while, and we are in contact with the South Africans.

QUESTION: Can you say anything about the nature of the contacts -- how high they've gone?

MR. BURNS: They've certainly gone to a fairly high level in the South African Government, as represented by our Embassy.

QUESTION: Have you talked with Mbeki?

MR. BURNS: I don't know if Mr. Mbeki has been contacted personally.

QUESTION: Is it something that the Secretary talked to them about when he was out in Africa several months ago.

MR. BURNS: I'd have to check that. I don't know.

QUESTION: Could you get back? I'd be interested in that.

MR. BURNS: I'd be glad to take that question.

Yes, on this same subject?

QUESTION: Yes. Is Vice President Gore likely to raise this at the meeting of the Binational Commission?

MR. BURNS: That's an important meeting. All important issues will be raised. I don't want to commit the Vice President to raising any specific issue. Suffice it to say, this is on the top of our agenda with South Africa now.

QUESTION: These items have been described as tanks' firing systems. Are they actually weapons, or are they just components? And, if they're just components, would they violate --

MR. BURNS: That's a good a question. That's the kind of information that we need from the South African Government. I think, first, does the South African Government contemplate sales of military equipment to Syria. If that is so, what type of equipment. Are they components to the assembly of a larger product. Is it a product itself. Would any such potential sales then violate U.S. law -- the Foreign Assistance Act, for instance. Those are the kinds of questions that we've got to answer before we can decide on a course of action for the United States.

But in general, we believe that terrorism is a global battle. All countries are victims of terrorism. All of us have to bind together and act together to prevent terrorism, and we certainly ought not to put into the hands of state sponsors of terrorism -- in this case the Syrian Government -- lethal weaponry, and that's the core of the American concern as we look at this question.

QUESTION: So you know what these tank electronic systems would violate? For example, the Counter-Terrorism Act.

MR. BURNS: No, I don't know what systems specifically we're talking about. That's the line of inquiry here, so therefore I cannot answer that question.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


East Africa;
International Churches ACTions in Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: Action by Churches Together (ACT)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

Geneva - With 1,300,582 people (UNHCR figure) returning to Rwanda since mid- November, much of ACT International's attention is now focused on assisting returnees in their home Prefectures in Rwanda i.e. provision of temporary shelter or permanent housing, distribution of food and non-food items.

While ACT is busy through partners inside Rwanda, ACT members continue working with the remaining Burundian refugees in Tanzania as well as reaching out with assistance to some of the hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees and Zairian displaced in parts of Eastern Zaire.

Eastern Zaire - assisting refugees and displaced Major concentrations of refugees and displaced in government controlled parts of Eastern Zaire have been identified in three places: Shabunda (25.000), Lubutu/Tingi-Tingi and Amisi (together approximately 160.000). These figures are World Food Programme (WFP) estimates - note though that none of these figures are based on systematic counting but are estimates based on observations on the ground. And while some aid workers express concern over the unusually high percentages of young men amongst the refugees remaining in Eastern Zaire others point to the deteriorating health condition of some of refugees. At Tingi-Tingi for instance 810 malnourished children are in special feeding programmes. Shabunda was left by the ICRC on December 24, 1996 and information about the situation there has been scarce ever since. 

In cooperation with the WFP ACT members (Norwegian Church Aid and local partners) are flying, trucking and distributing food and non-food items (mainly medicine) to displaced in Lubutu and Kisangani as well as refugees at Tingi-Tingi and Masisi. Despite very difficult conditions on the ground ACT members have distributed more than 150 tons of food and medicine in these parts of Eastern Zaire. On top of this ACT is distributing relief items on behalf of WFP in Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi.

In both Bukavu and Goma areas, controlled by the Alliance for Democracy in Congo-Zaire (ADF), ACT member Christian Aid are working with local churches (among them the Eglise du Christ au Zaire) and NGO's to (re-)establish emergency and rehabilitation projects for the Zairian population affected by the war and turmoil in the region since September/October of 1996. For instance thousands of families fled Bukavu and Goma during the conflict in and around these and other major towns in Eastern Zaire. Many still remain in overcrowded villages living with families and friends. ACT plans to assist the displaced with badly needed food and non-food items in order for them to regain enough strength and confidence to return to their homes. In the Bukavu area local and international ACT members are working together to reestablish basic medical services to about 100.000 citizens. Another 4.000 families will be supported with agricultural seeds and tools. ACT members in Eastern Zaire are coordinating their activities at both the local level and in Nairobi, Kenya.

Rwanda - large scale shelter, housing and reconstruction ACT members are working towards assisting returning refugees and their receiving communities across Rwanda. Covered by ACT International appeals of late 1996 local and international ACT members are putting a high emphasis on shelter and housing programmes as this is seen as a priority area by the homeless families as well as a prerequisite for lessening the tension between Tutsis and Hutus, between those who fled and those who stayed after the genocide in 1994 and thus eventually a contribution to stability and reconciliation in the larger society.

Apart from providing plastic and blankets for thousands in need of temporary shelter ACT member Lutheran World Federation (LWF) is for instance in Eastern Rwanda (Kibungo & Umutara) planning to build or reconstruct 4,500 family houses benefitting an estimated 37.500 people. The construction cost of an average rural house in Rwanda is estimated to be between USD 1,000 to 1, 200. All building materials are purchased locally or regionally if possible and the construction of the houses relies heavily on people themselves taking part in the work serving a double purpose of both creating housing and providing some people with additional skills.

In Western Rwanda similar activities are going on in Kibuye and Gitarama Prefectures along with continued distribution of food and non-food items in 13 districts. All in all the programme in Western Rwanda aims at benefitting 120.000 people and are balanced between the needs of returnees from Zaire and the population who stayed in Rwanda after the 1994 genocide. To support these and other projects ACT/LWF is running nine warehouses across Rwanda in addition to a substantial transportation fleet. ACT/NCA in cooperation with the Conseil Protestant du Rwanda (CPR) have shipped 60 tons of blankets and plastic sheeting for immediate distribution to returnees as well as having started a shelter project with 200 houses in Kibungo- Mukarango with local NGO. ACT partner Eglise Episcopale au Rwanda (EER) in cooperation with Christian Aid are planning a shelter programme for 2,700 households in two communes in the Diocese of Byumba as well as distributing 4,000 kitchen sets in the communes.

ACT partners present in Rwanda co-ordinate their activities through a newly established ACT Forum, chaired by Karin Gezelius of ACT/Church of Sweden Aid. This co-ordination includes CPR (eight local church representatives), LWF, UMCOR, Church World Service, Christian Aid & the Salvation Army.

Tanzania - Burundian refugees still arriving In Tanzania ACT/TCRS is responsible for the camp management for approximately 70.000 Burundian refugees at Mtendeli camp. According to UNHCR there are currently 239.000 Burundian refugees in Ngara, Kibondo and Kasulu districts of Tanzania with about 600 new arrivals daily.

It is likely that close to 90.000 of the Burundian refugees will be moved in the near future from camps around Ngara to the camp at Lumasi left empty by Rwandan refugees in December, 1996. ACT/TCRS have been asked to assist UNHCR in transportation of these refugees.

Burundi - Relief items on hold at border With the civil conflict continuing in many parts of Burundi ACT/Christian Aid along with a number of local churches in Burundi are eagerly awaiting the arrival of seven truckloads of non-food relief items (blankets, plastic sheeting, jerry cans, soap etc). The relief goods are currently held up at the Tanzanian-Burundian border awaiting clearance from the local Tanzanian authorities that oversees the trade embargo on Burundi. Once in Burundi the relief items are to be distributed by local churches to displaced and other needy groups throughout 13 of Burundi's 16 regions.

Funding for Great Lakes Region appeals so far Since the latest escalation of the crisis in the Great Lakes Region began in September/October of 1996 ACT International has issued five appeals to fundraise for relief operations aimed at meeting the expanding and changing humanitarian needs in the region. The three first appeals (AFZR61-63) totaled USD 14,620,897 and they are so far covered up to USD 6,260,854 (43%) by ACT funding members and their back donors. The last two appeals (AFZR64 & AFRW61) totaling USD 4,828,328 were issued just before Christmas 1996 and have so far not been funded.

As the above described programmes and activities depend on funding responses, ACT International are asking all funding members and their back donors as soon as possible to pledge against these apparent needs. Crucial programmes are in danger of coming to a halt if funding is not found. This will have obvious and serious consequences for the beneficiaries through out the Great Lakes Region.

Action by Churches Together(ACT) is a worldwide network of Churches and their related agencies meeting human need through co-ordinated emergency response and common identity. Ecumenical Centre, 150, route de Ferney, P.O. Box 2100, 1211 Geneva 2, Switzerland. Phone: ++41-22-791.60.33 / Fax: ++41-22- 791.65.06 / E-mail: act@wcc-coe.org / Telex: 415 730 OIK CH.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Currency: Kenyan Shilling On The Rise, CFA Franc Depreciates


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Kenyan shilling (ksh) continued to appreciate against the U.S. dollar and the British pound in the local market which remained favourable last week, market analysts said in Nairobi.

Reports reaching PANA Tuesday in Dakar, Senegal, say that the shilling gained 15 cents against the dollar and 17 cents against the pound sterling. 

The Ghanaian cedi remains relatively stable. On Monday in Accra, the interbank rate was 1,727 cedis to the dollar. On the previous Monday, the dollar exchanged for 1,726.82 cedis buying and 1,755.36 cedis selling.

Meanwhile, two currencies have recorded new losses against the dollar: The cfa franc exchanged at 521 (buying) and 551 (selling) to the usd Tuesday at Citibank in Dakar.

The losing trend started one week ago when the rate was 513 (buying) and 543 (selling) cfa to the greenback.

On New Year's eve, the rate was 509 cfa to the dollar, up from 510 cfa to the greenback on December 24.

The New Zaire (nz) was the same following the circulation of 100,000, 500, 000 denomination notes.

The measure, which cause massive price hikes to the delight of speculators, was described as a "source of inflation".


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Sudan;
Ethiopia Denies Bombing Sudanese Border Towns


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopian has described as a "baseless fabrication" Sudanese claims that its troops shelled two border towns Sunday before they were captured by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of Col. John Garang.

Addis Ababa's denial of involvement was aired Monday on Ethiopian Television. The station quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that the Sudanese accusation was "simply a tactic to redress and externalize the country's internal problems." 

Authorities in Khartoum have ordered a general mobilization to defend Sudan, after conceding that the two border towns in Blue Nile Province had fallen to the anti-government forces.

The government of Gen. Omar el Bashir alleged that the SPLA rebels were backed by Ethiopian troops which had shelled the two towns, enabling their seizure by the SPLA.

Sudan's parliament has accused Ethiopia of violating all international norms, charters and principles of good neighborliness.

Parliament said Monday that the attack was "only a part of the plot" led by countries spearheaded by the United States of America and "Zionist forces."

This plot, it added, started a long ago and involved an economic embargo, media campaigns aimed at tarnishing Sudan's image, and anti-Khartoum resolutions and sanctions passed and imposed by international organizations.

Sudan is under a limited embargo imposed by the United Nations for its failure to handover, for trial in neighboring Ethiopia, Egyptians who allegedly participated in a bid to assassinate Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak in Addis Ababa on 26 June, 1995.

The Sudanese parliament called on all Arab and Moslem states to condemned plots against Sudan.

Garang claimed Monday that the Unified Opposition Forces of North and Southern Sudan, now under his command, had captured the entire Nile Province, which borders Ethiopia.

The most prominent Sudanese opposition leader and former prime minister, Sadiq al Mahdi, recently fled into exile in neighboring Eritrea.

On his arrival in Asmara, the Eritrean capital, Mahdi announced that he was joining other externally-based opposition groups seeking to topple Bashir, who overthrew Mahdi's democratically elected government in June 1989.

Sudanese officials had minimized the impact of Mahdi's escape, saying this had only helped to cut him off from his supporters in Khartoum.


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Tourism Tourism Earned Ghana 248 million dollars In 1996


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghana attracted some 300,000 tourists in 1996, yielding an impressive total cash receipt of 248 million U.S dollars, the Ministry of Tourism said Tuesday.

Most arrivals were from Ghana's traditional tourism generating markets -- the United States, Britain, Germany and the Netherlands.

Ghana also became a destination for a significant number of tourists from Canada, Switzerland and other European and African countries.

In 1995, Ghana received 286,000 visitors and cash receipts of 237 million dollars, the Director of Research and Information at the ministry, Abraham Bekoe, told the Ghana News Agency on Tuesday in Accra. 

He said the sector expected an average tourist inflow of 399,000 annually from now till the year 2,000.

Foreign exchange receipts for tourist arrivals over the next three years, he said, would be an average of 386 million dollars each year.

Ministry officials say the heaviest influx of tourists into the country in 1997 is expected to occur in March, during the country's 40th independence anniversary celebration and later in August during the Pan-African Historical Theatre Festival, or PANAFEST '97.

However, Bekoe said that apart from these two major attractions, the sector was poised to enjoy a significant increase in tourist traffic, especially from the United States.

He expressed optimism at this "because of the impact of the ministry's promotional initiative there, the improvement in direct air links and Ghana's growing image as a tourist destination."

One major achievement of the industry in Ghana, he said, was that hotel beds had more than doubled during the past decade.

Ghana has about 10,783 hotel beds which the tourism ministry expects to increase significantly by the middle of the year.

"At present, more than half of this total -- that is 5,556 -- of our beds are in budget class hotels. But most of the new ones expected this year are all of international standard ranging between two-star and five-star," he said.

Out of these, he said, that Ghana expected an additional 2,750 beds all over the country by the year 2,010.

Most of the new hotels still under construction, such as Accra's Palm Beach Hotel at La, and the Golden Beach Resort at Elmina in the central region are expected to be ready for occupation by June.

The 168-bed Elmina Golden Beach Resort, owned by the Social Security and National Insurance Trust, is said to be of strategic importance to the August PANAFEST event, to be hosted exclusively in Cape Coast and Elmina.

Bekoe said the ministry expected 70 percent of all hotel projects and other receptive facilities within the festival zone to be completed before the start of the festival.

"The estimated shortfall of thirty percent in hospitality facilities is expected to be taken care of by other installations outside the immediate activity areas such as Takoradi and hostel facilities at the University of Cape Coast," he said.

Bekoe said airline operations in Ghana which previously constituted a major limitation to the growth of tourism, had now picked up impressively, increasing from only nine airlines a few years ago to 15 today.

"The good thing is that these increases are not just by mere local representation. They are increases reflected in terms of flight frequency," he said. "Chances are, that very soon, some of these airlines will start operating daily schedules in Ghana."

Bekoe said the ministry had a 15-year National Tourism Development Programme that will run until 2010.

The first phase of the programme, a five-year Tourism Action Plan, was set in motion in late 1996. It embraces various small programmes designed to unearth as well as boost the country's tourism potentials on a regional basis.

"These regional tourism programmes have been so fashioned to correspond with government's commitment to opening up the hinterlands, stimulating rural economies and eventually strengthening district authorities," he said.

Another important feature of the programme is a five-year marketing strategy and promotional programme. This initiative is intended to "sell Ghana as a more rewarding and preferable destination on the highly competitive international tourism market."


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


179 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Southern Africa;
External Forces Accused Of Promoting Split In Comesa


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The executive-secretary of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Bingu wa Mutharika, accused on Tuesday unnamed " external forces" of working to kill the organization by influencing some member states to withdraw.

"There are people out there who are not happy that Africans with black skins can sit down and get success. Unfortunately, we are victim of our own success," he said. 

Mutharika, a Malawian, was speaking at a news conference in Lusaka, the Zambian capital. He was reacting to announcements by Lesotho and Mozambique that they were withdrawing from the 20-nation common market.

He described the decision by the two countries as a matter of concern to the heads of state and government of the common market, and to himself. He appealed to both nations to re-consider their decision in the name of Pan- Africanism.

Mutharika noted that, unlike the much smaller Southern Africa Development Community, the common market -- also know by its acronym, Comesa -- was not an aid-coordinating agency. Rather, he said, it was a common market with the an objective of promoting regional integration by developing a larger market.

"Comesa is an organization established by Africans, executed by Africans, for Africans," he said. "I hope that both Mozambique and Lesotho will carefully take full account of medium and long-term development interests."

He expressed fear that the common market would experience the same fate as the East African Community that grouped Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda. This community, which created in 1967, was officially disbanded in 1983 because of political differences among heads of state.

"Mozambique and Lesotho will go around the circle like the East African nations went through and, later, after realizing their mistakes, will come back to cause problems," Mutharika said.

He dismissed rumors that Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania were also planning to withdraw from Comesa to concentrate on the newly-created East African Cooperation Arrangement.

In addition, he said he was unaware that Namibia was also likely to withdraw. The said that Namibia's withdrawal request had not been officially communicated to Comesa's headquarters in Lusaka.

Comesa's Council of Ministers will be meeting later this week in Lusaka. The council will discuss concrete measures to strengthen the body following the withdrawal of Lesotho and Mozambique.

The other 18 Comesa member countries are Angola, Burundi, Comoros, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Namibia, Rwanda, Sudan, Swaziland, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Comesa was created under a treaty signed in Kampala, Uganda, in late 1994. It succeeded the Eastern and Southern African Preferential Trade Area.

Botswana and South africa are the only other Southern African states which have never joined Comesa.


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 14, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Aviation ZEX Acquires Third Aircraft


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe Express Airlines (ZEX), a private operator, has acquired a third aircraft to service its Bulawayo to Harare route which was launched Tuesday.

At least 100 Bulawayo and Harare business executives flew on the inaugural flights on the Boeing 727-100 tri-jet. 

The airline's public relations manager, Peter Mukuna, said the carrier was leasing the 118-seat American-built jet from Million Air Charter. A second Boeing 727 is to be leased from the South African-based charter company.

Zex's second aircraft, a 44-seater Hawker, is also being leased from a South African-based company, Executive Aerospace.

Mukuna said the new business express service between Harare and Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's two leading cities, would be mainly to serve the business community.

He said ZEX would offer a free flight between the two cities whenever a plane was delayed for more than one hour.

"We are giving the most efficient service at an economy fare but most importantly we are saying time is money and the business concept is punctuality for an appointment," he said.

ZEX's normal two return flights between Bulawayo and Harare begin Wednesday.

181 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 15, 1997


Science and Health;
Congo Releases Baby Gorillas Into The Wilds


BYLINE: Edwige Monguia, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Each day at 9 a.m. (0800 GMT), baby gorillas in Brazzaville's zoo are taught by their keepers to jump from one branch to another, and how to select the fruits and plants necessary for their survival in the wilds.

After five years of semi-captivity the animals will released into the wilds, a 44,000 hectare (108,724 acres) forested site 120 kilometres (74.56 miles) north to Brazzaville, provided by the government.

The rehabilitation of these primates is an initiative of the Congo's Gorillas Protection Unit. The unit was created in 1989 by a British non- governmental organization, Howitts and Port Lympe Foundation, in cooperation with Congolese authorities. The money for the project comes from the NGO. 

Congo's Wildlife Conservation Department puts the gorilla population at less than 100 in the north of the country and says that at least two gorillas are killed each month. This is because the animal is a local culinary delicacy, also hunted for its bones.

"According to custom, gorillas' skulls and hands bones are beneficial to man," The coordinator for the rehabilitation project, Marcel Nguimbi, says.

For instance, Congolese tie a gorilla's finger bone around the wrists of their infants and put these bones into bath water in the belief that it will make the child strong and courageous. In addition, gorilla bones are crushed into powder and consumed in the belief that it has aphrodisiac properties.

Baby gorillas are also threatened because they are hunted for sale to tourists at high prices.

"Under these circumstances, species preservation is vital to us forest wardens", Nguimbi says.

Congo's rehabilitation of baby gorillas is the first being undertaken, in this country, by its protection unit and 15 staff workers. The staff's task it to retrieve baby gorillas captured by poachers, return the animals to their orphanage and prepare them for their release into the wilds.

On of the unit's staff, Naobi Okayasu, form Japan, says: "Our role is to prevent baby gorillas traffic abroad. We receive and cure for them, return them to their natural environment, the forest."

After 4-6 years of rehabilitation at the Brazzaville zoo, the baby gorillas are released into Lessio Launa Forest Sanctuary. The site is named after the two rivers which run through the forest.

Officials say the site is the ideal halfway house for the release of the gorillas into the wilds.

"The area has no predators. There are only elephants, monkeys, pangolins; and reptiles harmless to gorillas," they say.

Three generations of gorillas have already been released into this facility. The first generation comprised six male and three female gorillas between five years and six years old. Three baby gorillas died soon after from natural causes.

The second group of three was released in September 15, 1996. The third, make up of two males and one female, was released eight days later.

"We did not have any health problem with the two last groups, as the first experience had taught us the precautions we needed to take," Nguimbi says.

While the unit is happy at returning the gorillas to their natural environment, some of the keepers have found it hard to part with their wards.

"It is true that their return to nature is beneficial to them, but we are sad to see the gorillas going forever, as we consider them as our children and gave a name to each of them," says Catherine Bibimbou, a keeper who has been with the unit since 1989.

In support of their return to the wild, the unit wants Congo to develop tourism in Lessio Louna where visitors could view the animals from the surrounding cliffs or their boats, far from direct contact with man.

"The area's natural beauty is appropriate for tourism," they said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 15, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
OAU To Hold Budget Session In Libya


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ranking African officials will use ships and cars to reach the Libyan capital, Tripoli, for this year's five-day annual budgetary session of the Organization of African Unity, an official said Wednesday.

The official, Momadou Bah, said these measures were necessary if the officials were to avoid violating a United Nations air embargo against Libya. 

Bah, the director of the organization's Political Department, told the Pan African News Agency that the O.A.U. had accepted Libya's invitation to meet in Tripoli beginning Feb. 24.

The session in Tripoli, he said, would not constitute a breach of the U.N. sanctions but high attendance would show solidarity with Libya, an O.A.U. member.

"There is no sanction on O.A.U. activities and on the relationships between the O.A.U. and member states," he said.

This will be the organization's first major meeting in Libya since the abortive summit of 1982, which failed to take place twice for lack of a quorum.

Libya is under sanctions imposed in April 1992 by the U.N. Security Council, after it failed to hand over for trial in the United States or Britain two of its citizens accused of planting the bomb that blew up a PanAm jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

Africa News


January 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Parties Ask for Assistance From American Group


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

WASHINGTON, D.C. (PANA) - The chairmen of Nigeria's five recently registered political parties in Nigeria have asked the National Endowment For Democracy, in Washington D.C., to spread the agency's aid evenly to all of the country's non-governmental organizations.

The chairman of Nigeria's Grassroots Democratic Movement, Alhaji Gambo Lawan, accused the endowment body of limiting its aid to anti-military government groups. 

He urged the agency to aid, also, registered parties which he called the major players in Nigeria's transition to democracy.

The agency's program officer for Africa, Dave Peterson, asked the parties to make proposals for the help they needed.

He denied that the agency's grants were intended for the opposition. However, he said that they were aimed at supporting the process of democracy and human rights through non-governmental efforts.

The National Endowment For Democracy, formed in 1983, is the principal source of funding for Nigeria's human rights and democracy movements. In 1995, it gave 303,313 U.S dollars to eight such organizations in Nigeria.

The Nigerian chairmen, who are visiting the United States to explain the three-year transition programme set by the Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, made their request Tuesday during a meeting with the endowment's officials in Washington D.C.

The U.S. capital was the last stop in the seven-city itinerary of the chairmen, who arrived here Jan. 4. They visited New York, Atlanta, Houston, Chicago, Miami and Kansas City.

The group held meetings with Nigerians and Americans to convince them of the genuiness of the transition process, announced by Abacha in October 1995. The process is expected to end in October 1998 with the installation of an elected head of state.

Africa News


January 15, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Stock Exchange Surges Wednesday


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

HARARE, (PANA) - Zimbabwe's watershed Industrial Index continued with its record performance, staging another major one-day gain Wednesday amid heavy buying, particularly of financial counters.

First Merchant Bank gained 400 Zimbabwe cents (10 zimbabwe dollars = 1 U.S. dollar) while Barclays Bank shares shot up 20 percent, putting on 600 cents on a day when several reasonable volume parcels exchanged hands. 

Among popular counters were Art, enjoying a new lease of life following its recent take-over by Trans Zambezi Industries, and Delta which saw over 5.8 million and 400,000 shares exchanging hands, respectively.

The index gained 226 points to close at a new high of 10,323.86 points.

In minings, gold counters continued to look soft following news of a glut on the world market after the Central Bank of the Netherlands sold 300 tones of gold recently, arousing fears of depressed prices.

Ashanti Goldfields dropped 1,500 cents to 8,500 and the index closed six points down at 1,141.54 points.

185 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 15, 1997


East Africa;
Nyerere Warns African Leaders On Great Lakes


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere said Wednesday African leaders needed to understand the realities of the continent's Great Lakes region before trying to solve its political and security crises.

"What happens in Burundi will also affect Rwanda and Zaire...Africa should understand that and help the region using this kind of understanding," he said.

He was speaking to reporters shortly after an hour-long meeting with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, in Harare. 

Nyerere said that Rwanda's crisis, which revolves around the arrest and trial of Hutu militants accused of the 1994 atrocities against the country's minority Tutsi, needed to be dealt with at the leadership level and with the help of the Arusha tribunal. The tribunal is holding in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha.

Nyerere said that Rwanda stood a much better chance of national reconciliation between its two warring communities than did Burundi, where the same ethnic mix and volatile problems exist.

With Burundi, he said, international sanctions had failed to force the country's military leaders to re-establish democracy.

"They (sanctions) didn't work that effectively but they at least helped in the sense that they had created an environment to open dialogue," he said.

The subregion, he said, was involved in ethnic turmoil. For example in Burundi, where Nyerere is the chief mediator, at least 150,000 people -- mainly civilians -- have been massacred in the past three years.

Nyerere also met Tuesday with Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano, wanting to learn from the country's experience in conflict resolution.

Between 1992 and 1994 Mozambique, with United Nations assistance, moved remarkably smoothly from a devastating war to multiparty elections whose results were accepted by all parties.

Details of Nyerere's talks with Chissano were not released. But Nyerere's visit came a few days after Burundian border police reportedly massacred refugees who had just been sent home from Tanzania.

The killing has been deplored by United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan. He called for a cease-fire in Burundi, which has been under turmoil since the October 1993 assassination of the democratically-elected President Melchior Ndadaye, a Hutu.

Ndadaye's brutal death touched-off Hutu revenge killings against the Tutsi, whose leader, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, returned to power July 25, 1996, in a coup.

Nyerere said while Rwanda was recovering, it could not do so fully without the help of the rest of Africa.

Mugabe is one of the four African leaders chosen at a summit in December 1996, to find lasting solutions to the political and ethnic problems of the Great Lakes.

The other members of the group, chaired by Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, are South African President Nelson Mandela and the chairman of the Organisation of African Unity, Cameroonian President Paul Biya.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


186 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Airways Fires 250 More Workers


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1031 words


 

ROME, Italy (PANA) - The heads of the African Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank are opposed to agricultural subsidies currently being applied by governments in Africa and elsewhere.

In plenary Thursday at the ongoing World Food Summit, the presidents of both institutions said subsidies had contributed to lower incomes.

"Apparently well-intentioned but misguided practices" aimed at cheap food prices for urban consumers through subsidies had only exacerbated the problem of lower farm incomes, ADB President Omar Kabbaj said. 

Subsidies, he added, "contributed to the marginalization of the rural economy and to declines in the income and welfare of rural dwellers."

And World Bank President James Wolfensohn told a news conference "no country, in the long term, can live with subsidies."

Earlier he told world leaders at the summit that governments "should reduce heavy intervention in the rural economy and concentrate on creating an economic and regulatory environment that fosters agricultural growth."

Both Kabbaj and Wolfensohn said that the reduction of subsidies tended to nudge farmers to areas which are more efficient.

To compliment this, both banks have adopted new approaches to rid the poor countries of the worst types of poverty, providing mocro-financing to allow for easy credit for farmers.

Kabbaj said ADB provides micro-credit to poor and vulnerable groups and has been giving credit to national and sub-regional development finance bodies so they could, in turn, lend to small and medium-scale enterprises.

Both banks have also been working with or have policies in place to collaborate with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), who have considerable experience in implementing poverty alleviation programmes.

"We will be making further strides in this area, with the finalization of a new micro-enterprise policy which will set the framework for extending appropriate credit to the poorest groups, using financial intermediaries such as NGOs and other grassroots organizations," Kabbaj said.

"We have initially set aside some 20 million dollars (U.S) for this type of support."


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Kenya-Coffee;
Low Prices At Kenya's Coffee Mart


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - Coffee sales at the Nairobi Stock Exchange this week reached 3.7 million U.S. dollars. 

However, the prices remained low with products in the first grade (AA) fetching 149 dollars.

In other categories such as AB, E, C and TT, products fetched average prices of between 120 and 140 dollars.

The lowest paid coffee in the ML grade managed only 10 dollars for an 80- kilogram bag, but average prices were pegged at 136.55 dollars.

The majority of clean coffee that fetched high prices was, however, sold in bulk during the auction conducted by the Coffee Board of Kenya.

January 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Lagos Anti-Crime Drive Gets A Boost


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The lagos state military administrator, Col. Mohammed Marwa, has donated 150 patrol vehicles, 12 motor-bikes and other communication equipment to the joint military and police team manning security in the Nigerian economic center.

Making the presentation Thursday, Marwa expressed concern at the rising rate of violent crime in the country, especially Lagos, where four people were reported killed in a car bomb bear the airport on Friday. 

The vehicles and gadgets are to facilitate the work of the team, known as " operation sweep," in response to increasing crime wave.

To complement operation sweep, Marwa recently launched a neighborhood vigilante watch group. He has also inaugurated members of four firearms and robbery tribunals to facilitate trial of suspects.

The federal government recently provided some 340 walkie-talkies, four broad-band air-base radio and other equipment to help fight crime in Lagos.

Africa News


January 15, 1997


Zaire;
Tshisekedi Wants Unity Government To Tackle Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - Zaire's hardline opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, has said that he would want to confer with President Mobutu Sese Seko, who is recuperating from an operation for cancer in France, on the possibility of setting up a unity government to tackle the serious crisis now facing the country.

He said at a news briefing in Kinshasa on Thursday that the crisis in eastern Zaire was partly caused by the non-respect of the decisions of a national conference held four years ago by the political class. 

The conference named Tshisekedi Prime Minister but the latter was relieved of the post months later by Mobutu.

"The crisis facing Zaire resulted from the mismanagement of the country by political leaders whose sole interest is to make money," said Tshisekedi.

Responding to a question on the suggestion that a separate territory to be known as Hutuland be carved out as a way of solving the ethnic problem in Burundi and Rwanda, he said "Zairians will never accept to surrender a square millimeter of their territory."

However, A local newspaper Friday accused Tshisekedi of being pro-Tutsi regarding the ongoing war in eastern Zaire, where Zairian Tutsi called the Banyamurenge have seized Zairian territory reportedly with support from the Tutsi government in Kigali.

"Soft", a privately-owned Kinshasa daily said "Tshisekedi granted to, and then withdrew Zairian citizenship from Rwandans" in 1967 when he was justice minister.


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 15, 1997


Nigeria;
Azikiwe Will Be Laid To Rest Saturday


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - All roads lead to Nigeria's eastern market city of Onitsha for the burial Saturday of the country's first president, Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe.

The event will mark the end of a week-long national funeral rites that involved several cities which were linked with the elder statesman, who died May 11. Saturday would be his 92nd birth day.

From Zungeru in the north to Lagos, Enugu and Onitsha, his ancestral home, it has been a feast of tributes to the late Nigerian nationalist, sportsman journalist and Pan-Africanist. 

A number of foreign leaders are expected at the burial.

The presidents of Guinea, Sierra Leone and Equatorial Guinea were among dignitaries that attended Zik's lying in state Tuesday in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.

Zik's body also laid in state in key cities in northern Nigeria where was born, in the west, where he grew up and worked, and in the east, his ancestral home.

As a demonstration of his firm believe in national unity, the three major tribes of multi-ethnic Nigeria -- the Hausas in the north, the Yorubas in the west, especially Lagos, and the Igbos in the east, have sought to outdo each other in paying glowing tributes to the former president.

The Nigerian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs in a tribute said "Zik was a detribalised Nigerian who got on very well with everyone, regardless of tribe, religion, age or social status."

Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha renamed the Abuja international airport after Azikiwe as a mark of honor.

Even in death, Zik continued to win admirers from high and low, at home and abroad.

In Enugu on Thursday, a mock parliamentary session was held in honor of Zik, the politician.

In a tribute titled "Zik, the ultimate philosopher, pathfinder," former military ruler Gen. Ibrahim Babangida said "we have to commit Zik to the earth with pride in us that our founding fathers had not lived in vain."

"They will continue to be remembered for their great attributes as motivators, disciplined visionaries and perfect examples that we can always be," he added.

In yet another, Kenyan Historian, Ali Mazrui, says of Zik: "when he combined certificate in law, a qualification in journalism, a masters in religion and philosophy, masters in anthropology, expertise in political science, Nnamdi Azikiwe was prophecy-incarnate signifying Africa's academic versatility when given half-a-chance."


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 15, 1997


Zambia;
Chiluba Says It Is Impossible To Postpone Elections


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba has told South African President Nelson Mandela that it is "impossible" to postpone Monday's elections since the 11 opposition parties participating in the elections have opposed postponement.

In his letter, dated 14 Nov. to Mandela which was made available to PANA Friday, he also said that the proposition to postpone the elections was totally impossible because of the "astronomical" costs incurred spent by the participating parties and in view of limited resources. 

"Postponement of the elections scheduled for next monday 18 November, 1996 is a totally impossible proposition which the principal opposition parties taking part in the elections have also said they will not accept," part of the letter said.

Chiluba maintained there is no threat to the internal security and stability to warrant a draconian move like a state of emergency, as suggested, to facilitate the postponement.

Mandela early this week held private consultations with Chiluba in Pretoria. He later sent South African constitutional court judge Richard Goldstone to explore possibilities of postponing the elections.

The opposition Zambia Democratic Congress, (ZDC) which is one of the political parties taking part in the elections, confirmed to PANA that it had refused to accept the suggestion of postponing the elections.

"We are not for the idea of extending the elections," said the party's general secretary, Derrick Chitala. "We had made it clear that we would only agree if we were compensated the money spent on elections."

Former President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party and seven other minor opposition parties are boycotting the elections.


LOAD-DATE: January 16, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 16, 1997


Ghana-Stocks Blue Chips Fall On Ghana Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Accra, GHana (PANA) - Blue chips on the Ghana Stock Market lost during trading Wednesday as total volume of shares traded hit another low.

Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC), Ghana Commercial Bank (GCB), Mobil Oil Ghana Limited (MOGL), Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) and Unilever lost, as major shares performed poorly during trading. 

The GSE All-Share Index dropped 3.67 points from 358.21 points to 354.54 points.

Total volume of shares sold was 148,040 shares, while bids stood at 6,424, 050 against offers of 4,645,660.

Market capitalization dropped to 2,647.23 billion cedis from Monday's close of 2,703.43 billion cedis out of a total of 930.95 million shares issued.

On the broader market, five equities lost, while four equities gained.

AGC's poor run continued with a loss of 490 cedis to settle at 20,510 cedis. GCB, which is reeling under a 70-billion cedi fraud by a super market owner, lost one cedi to close mid-week trading at 700 cedis.

MOGL lost 200 cedis to finish at 5,100 cedis, while SCB went down by 250 cedis to close at 4,750 cedis. UNIL lost 15 cedis to end at 760 cedis.

Accra Brewery Limited (ABL) and Social Security Bank (SSB) led gainers, appreciating by 15 cedis and 10 cedis to close at 591 cedis and 1,080 cedis, respectively.

SPPC and GGL gained five cedis each at 110 cedis 315 cedis, respectively.

The following were the closing prices of listed equities quoted in cedis: ABL 591 ' 15 AGC 20,510 - 490 ALW 1,415 CFAO 20 EIC 430 FML 404 GCB 700 - 1 GGL 315 ' 5 HFC 136 KBL 660 MGL 150 MLC 55 MOGL 5,100 - 200 PAF 171 PTC 135 PZ 368 SCB 4,750 - 250 SPPC 110 ' 5 SSB 1,080 ' 10 UNIL 760 - 15 UTC-E 50

Africa News


January 16, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria Terminates Steel Contract With Russian Firm


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian government has terminated its multibillion-dollar contract with the Russian firm, TPE, for the construction of a steel complex at Ajaokuta, in the center of the country, the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reported Thursday.

A 1983 completion date of the five-billion-dollar contract conceived in the 1960s to launch Nigeria into industrial age has not been met because of operational hitches. 

However, several units of the complex have been completed for the production of rods and other steel and foundry products in the country.

NAN said that work at the main gigantic project site had reached 98 percent completion before the termination of the contract with TPE.

The firm had already been paid some 50 billion naira (about 625 million U.S. dollars) for the work done but some bills are outstanding.

Inadequate working capital and shortage of raw materials were said to be delaying the remaining part of the construction.

The agency quoted the Russians as saying they could only resume work if a rail line was completed to ease the transportation of raw materials.

Officials of Nigeria's Federal Power and Steel Ministry, supervising the project, said there had been consultations between the Nigerian and Russian officials on how to settle the outstanding debts owed the Russian contractors.

In 1994, some 8,000 Nigerian junior employees of the firm, launched a violent strike, demanding the payment of their salaries. This caused substantial damage to property at the steel complex.

The riot led to a mass sacking of the strikers and re-organization of the management.

194 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 16, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Wants Continued Good Relations with Pretoria


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Washington - Remarks by State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns at the daily briefing on January 15 on the U.S. response to reports of a possible South African arms sale to Syria.

QUESTION: Just to ask a question for South African Broadcasting. What's your reaction to comments made by Nelson Mandela's spokesman today that he's disgusted - detests the kind of behavior the American government offered - the (South African) Government's reaction to your comments to what's happening in South Africa and is insulted by the American Government's attempt to hold a gun to South Africa's head.

MR. BURNS: My goodness, I haven't seen those remarks, but I can just say that we have a very good relationship with the Government of South Africa, and I'm sure that will continue, because our heads of state have a good personal relationship, and we've been able to do a lot of business with South Africa. We want to continue that. 

We said yesterday that in light of the allegations and reports that South Africa was considering a substantial arms sale to Syria, which is a terrorist state under U.S. law, that we were worried about that. We were concerned by it. We would raise this issue with the South African Government. We have done so in both Pretoria and in Washington. We'll continue to do so.

I also said yesterday that we didn't have all the facts on this, and that part of our effort right now was to seek the facts from the South African Government, and we will do that. We're working on it, and you can rest assured that we'll continue to take this issue very seriously, because we have to be concerned about the application of American law here.

But the United States Government is not going to make any decision and cannot make a decision on this issue until we get all the facts from the South African Government. I would suggest that we do that amicably and cooperatively in the tradition that we've established with the Mandela Government over the past couple of years, and that's how you'll see us talk about this issue.

QUESTION: I thought there had been deterioration in relations between America and South Africa, with those sort of comments saying, "What we find particularly insulting is for someone to hold a gun to our head and tell us what to do." Does the threat to withdraw the $82 million of aid still stand if this arms deal does go ahead?

MR. BURNS: I would encourage you to look very carefully at what I said yesterday. I will tell you, I was a little bit surprised to see the way that some news organizations covered my remarks and Mike McCurry's remarks yesterday. Both of us talked about the fact that we were aware of allegations; that we'd raised these allegations with the South African Government, and that we would continue to do that. It was a very serious issue, because it was a matter of law here, and it also is tied to the international fight against terrorism, Syria being a state sponsor of terrorism.

But we were very careful to say that we didn't have all the facts, and that obviously we're going to be talking to the South African Government before anything happens here. We hope very much that they would not go forward with any proposed sale. So I think that these were measured comments yesterday. No one's putting a gun to anyone's head, and we intend to work with the South African Government amicably and cooperatively on this.

QUESTION: Nick, can you explain the nature of the contact between the United States and Pretoria? I mean, did you call on the Ambassador here? When did that happen?

MR. BURNS: I don't know specifically at what level this issue was raised. I did check, and I know that it was raised both with the South African Embassy here in Washington, and also our Embassy went in to see the South African Foreign Ministry in Pretoria. I don't know if our Ambassador or their Ambassador were involved in these discussions in the two capitals.

QUESTION: Did that happen today or -

MR. BURNS: I think it's happened in recent days, and those contacts preceded the press reports. We've been aware of this for some time - not for a long time, but for some time.

QUESTION: But there were no contacts in the last 24 hours?

MR. BURNS: I suppose there were contacts in the past 24 hours. I don't know every time an American diplomat talks to a South African diplomat. I'm sure there were contacts in recent days because this is a prominent issue. It's in the news. We've said that we're seriously concerned by it and we are.

QUESTION: I just wondered, after your remarks yesterday whether there had been any contacts in which the South Africans may have said to you, "We don't understand the nature of our sale," or said anything -- provided you with any information that perhaps alleviated some of your concerns?

MR. BURNS: I don't believe we have yet received - I think we're in the process of receiving from the South African Government a full description of what may or may not be in the works. Until we receive a full description, we're not going to be able to determine the relevance of this issue to U.S. law and, frankly, the degree of seriousness of this issue. But I do want to repeat again today what we said yesterday. We don't believe that countries should provide military assistance to state sponsors of terrorism, Syria being clearly one of those states.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 16, 1997


South Africa;
Labor Welcomes Mine Health & Safety Law


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Johannesburg - COSATU welcomes the new Mine Health & Safety Act which was announced by Minister Maduna today. The Act heralds South Africa's commitment to international labour standards as it is in line with the ILO convention on this issue.

COSATU played a key role in the ILO convention, and last year put pressure on the government to ratify this convention. We believe they will be doing so this year. 

This Act is a great victory for South African mineworkers who have been struggling for decades to get reliable health and safety measures implemented on the mines. The RDP refers to this issue when it says: "The RDP envisages a new set of minimum standards for the mining industry that ensures fair wages and employment conditions for all workers and a health and safety system that recongnises the special hazards related to mining_4.5.1.10" .

Mineworkers have long been urging government to investigate the situation on the mines, and in 1991, under the leadership of the National Union of Mineworkers, they initiated the appointment of a commission on mine health and safety. The commission criticised the implementation of safety measures on mines in this country which have resulted in national tragedies such as the Vaal Reef mine disaster of 1995.

Mineworkers are faced daily with extremely difficult work situations, constantly threatened by the possibility of terrible deaths as a result of rock falls, mud-slides and other mining related horrors. It is estimated that nearly two miners die every day in South African mines - 80 percent of those being in the gold mines. The lack of training in the past has often meant that preventable accidents have recurred instead of being avoided.

COSATU believes this new law will introduce a more humane and caring attitude in the mining industry. It is crucial that a democratic country protects its workforce - particularly those workers who take great risks on a daily basis in order to sustain one of the key areas of our economy. Again the RDP is clear when it says: "Our principle objective is to transform mining and mineral-processing industries to serve all of our people."

COSATU therefore welcomes the introduction of this new Act. We urge all mines to take heed of the Act and to implement efficient and reliable health and safety measures with immediate effect!

Issued by COSATU Communications Department on behalf of the General Secretary. January 15, 1997.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 16, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Deplores Killing of Refugees in Burundi


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Washington - Following is the text of a statement by U.S. State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns issued January 14 deploring the killing of more than 120 Burundi Hutu refugees on January 10 in Burundi.

The United States deplores the recent violence in Burundi. The Burundian Army has confirmed the January 10 killing of over 120 Burundian Hutu returnees, who had reportedly been expelled from Tanzania the same day.

This massacre is only part of a pattern of violence in Burundi which must cease. Only the day before, witnesses implicated the army in the massacre of more than 80 civilians on January 5 in rural Muramvya Province. The army has also been involved in a practice of forced resettlement, by which Burundians in rural areas, mostly poor farmers, are forced to move into camps. Rebel groups have also been accused of human rights abuses. We understand that soldiers involved in the January 10 incident have been arrested.

The United States continues to call for a cease-fire and all-party talks to restore stability to Burundi. Special envoy Howard Wolpe has travelled extensively in the region working for a cease-fire, returning from Burundi, Tanzania and Kenya over the weekend.

LANGUAGE: English
