221 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria Terminates Steel Contract With Russian Firm


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian government has terminated its multibillion-dollar contract with the Russian firm, TPE, for the construction of a steel complex at Ajaokuta, in the center of the country, the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reported Thursday.

A 1983 completion date of the five-billion-dollar contract conceived in the 1960s to launch Nigeria into industrial age has not been met because of operational hitches. 

However, several units of the complex have been completed for the production of rods and other steel and foundry products in the country.

NAN said that work at the main gigantic project site had reached 98 percent completion before the termination of the contract with TPE.

The firm had already been paid some 50 billion naira (about 625 million U.S. dollars) for the work done but some bills are outstanding.

Inadequate working capital and shortage of raw materials were said to be delaying the remaining part of the construction.

The agency quoted the Russians as saying they could only resume work if a rail line was completed to ease the transportation of raw materials.

Officials of Nigeria's Federal Power and Steel Ministry, supervising the project, said there had been consultations between the Nigerian and Russian officials on how to settle the outstanding debts owed the Russian contractors.

In 1994, some 8,000 Nigerian junior employees of the firm, launched a violent strike, demanding the payment of their salaries. This caused substantial damage to property at the steel complex.

The riot led to a mass sacking of the strikers and re-organization of the management.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Nigeria;
Briton, Nigerians Jailed For Drug Trafficking


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - A Briton and three Nigerians were sentenced Thursday by a Lagos tribunal to a total of 24 and half years in prison for drug trafficking.

The Briton, John Nolan, 48, received the stiffest sentence of 10 years for exporting 22.9 kilograms of Indian hemp from the Murtala Mohammed International Airport, Lagos, on Sept. 5, 1994. 

The tribunal heard that his Nigerian accomplice, Akinbo Ohuona, 32, was arrested on the same flight with 10 kilograms of the substance. He received seven years in prison.

The third convict was Ugonna Anya, 32. She was sentenced to five years in prison for offering to sell 28.4 grams of heroin on Oct. 10, 1994.

Justice Abdullahi Tijani, the tribunal's chairman, ordered Sunday Olukayode, who is now in a Nigerian prison, to stay there for another two and a half years. He was deported from Finland in November 1995, after serving a two- year jail sentence for drug trafficking.

Nigeria has strict anti-drug trafficking laws, which prescribe double trial of its citizens already convicted for drug offences in foreign lands.

The chairman of the country's Federal Drug Law Enforcement Agency, Maj. Gen. Musa Bamaiyi, is advocating the reintroduction of the death penalty for convicted drug offenders in the country.

He said this would deter potential offenders in the trade, which had earned Nigeria a poor international image.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 17, 1997


United States and Africa;
African Executives To Attend Exhibition In Houston


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Some 70 business executives from West Africa will be attending the Property Building Exhibition to be held from Jan. 24 to 27, in Houston, Texas, The United States Cultural Center in Dakar announced Friday.

The exhibition is part of the U.S. Department of Commerce policy to increase business between American and West African constractors. 

The African participants, who will be split into seven groups, will come from Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Gabon, Guinea, Mali, Mauritania, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo.

An official of the United States Commercial Service in Abidjan, Frederic Gaynor, said that the exhibition, sponsored by the National Association of Housing Buildings Constructors, offered an opportunity to "draw West Africans to the United States and to facilitate regional cooperation between French and English-speaking Africans.

At least 2,000 participants will attend the event where articles such as tiles, fitted carpets, household and audiovisual equipment will be displayed.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Liberia;
Briefing Paper On Liberia


BYLINE: Justice And Peace Commission, National Catholic Secretariat


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Monrovia - NOVEMBER 20 - DECEMBER 4, 1996

The Latest Abuja II Accord signed by Liberia's warring factions in August this year provides a guideline for disarmament to begin on November 22 and conclude on January 31, 1996. The process commenced with jubilation and November 22nd was declared a Disarmament Holiday in Liberia. After about 11 days, it was reported that about 2,258 of the questionable 60,000 combatants have turned in their weapons. It is gradually losing momentum (and) a number of events and accusations among factional leaders have contributed to this:

a. On November 27, fighting was reported to continue in the Southeast around Grand Gedeh County between the Liberia Peace Council (LPC) and the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL). ECOMOG moved into Tappita to create a buffer zone. The NPFL agreed to withdraw from the town of Tuzon to Toe Town to enable ECOMOG's deployment. It is not clear which group provoked the fighting. 

b. On November 22 at about 4:00 P.M. fighting erupted between ULIMO-J and ULIMO-K in Bomi County. Several civilians were killed about 20 houses burnt in Borbor Town; 2 ULIMO-J fighters (Thomas and Kpor) were abducted along with several civilians.

c. There have been constant accusations made by the NPFL against the LPC and AFL. The (NPFL) claims that there are plans by both groups to eliminate their leader. Both groups are accusing the NPFL of hatching new plans to attack their positions and interrupt the schedule of disarmament.

d. The government as a collective has not made concrete efforts to contribute financially toward incentives to the combatants. In the face of this, widespread corruption has been institutionalized with reports of cash deposits in homes of ministers, purchase of 60 new vehicles and other acts of economic pillage.

e. The International community needs to re-assess its strategies regarding incentives for ex- combatants . Factional loyalists intend to use the issue of incentives to becloud the objectives of disarmament.

OTHERS

a A new ECOWAS Envoy has bee appointed. He is Alhaji Tefewa Belewa of Nigeria.

b. A military delegation arrived on the 27th of November (from) Niger. It is expected that this was an assessment visit intended to create the basis for the commitment of troops to ECOMOG.

Signed: Samuel K. Woods II, Director, JPC

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378; Washington, D.C. 20017 Tel. 202 832 3412; Fax 202 832 9051; email: afjn@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


January 17, 1997


Liberia;
LIBERIA: Human Rights Update


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3280 words


 

Washington, DC - JOINT PRESS STATEMENT BY THE LIBERIA HUMAN RIGHTS COMMUNITY ON THE LIBERIAN SITUATION, December 29, 1996

BACKGROUND/INTRODUCTION

Members of the Press, Seven years now, we have witnessed and continue to witness an unceasing trend of human rights violations, massive destruction of properties, unchecked corruption and mismanagement of public offices, unrestrained torture, rape, mayhem, massacre, etc. These acts of inhumane, cruel and degrading treatments are meted out by men who have arrogated to themselves a false monopoly over gangsterism and violence as a means of access to power and wealth.

Over the past years, human rights organizations have emerged with the aim of striving to re-establish and re-orientate respect of (the) rule of law, advocate, educate and sensitize the Liberian people to their basic human rights.

Numerous evidence abound regarding the woeful experience of our devastated nation. The war commenced on December 24, 1989. Since then, we have experienced killings in all parts of the country. We have been haunted by an unending nightmare of massacres and destruction. Inspite of attempts by unarmed civilians to address the spectre of violence, the carnage continues with its attending toll. 

MEMBERS OF THE PRESS, today we call you here in further pursuit of our commitment to sensitize and attempt to seek redress for individuals who have become constant victims of our civil strife. We do this not to supplant Government, neither to antagonize the powers that be, as others have referred to it, but to assist in creating the atmospherefor the inviolability of the human person. We also do not see ourselves as legally assuming the functions of Government in ensuring that the rights of citizens are guaranteed at all time; our mission is a moral pressure on the conscience of government, holding it to the dictates of the constitution and international laws. We also do so in the face of what appears to be a glaring abdication by government regarding its obligation to the citizens of Liberia as enshrined int he Liberian Constitution.

From the inception of agreements on the Liberian conflict we have seen the gradual erosion of civilians authority with the concomitant legitimization and institutionalization of acts of banditry and violence through the outright pawning of leadership of factions as a guarantee for disarmament and peace. We have in the past and today, continue to argue about the farcical nature of this conclusion.

The events of April 6, 1996 however, convinced both the local and international community to adopt constraints/measures to minimize the excesses of factions. The recent Abuja Accord vindicate this view in its attempts to identify specific sanctions against violators. We believe "law is nothing without the apparatus capapble of ensuring compliance or enforcement."

Inspite of these measures, the violations continue. What we attempt to do here is to allow local pressure to attract the conscience of the international community to insist on the application and enforcement of sanctions as mandated by the recent Abuja Accord of August (1996).

We believe that this Accord and its enforceability constitutes a major challenge to the local and international community and is a litmus test to the extent that our nightmares can be terminated. In the midst of inadequate logistics and the intentional, well orchestrated attack on our offices, we have all been left bare to operate on minimal facilities. Yet, we are commited to highlight and investigate some of the recent violations as evident that Liberians are concern about their plight and hence deserve attention. We call you here, first. to establish that the human rights record of this year is very disheartening. Events of April 6, 1996, characterized by the "Government forces" attack on citizens, followed by the univestigated murder of Hon. Seh Vincent, the two marketeers, two young ladies: Chrisitiana and Josephine among others represent the depth of insensitivity that have characterized our justice system.

Second, to look deeply into the Sinje Massacre which occured in September 1996. The Bloun Town Massacre of December 7, 1996, the abduction case involving employees of the Ministry of Education and a position regarding the shadow Congo Defense Force (CDF) operating in the western part of Liberia.

1. THE SINJE MASSACRE

On September 28, 1996, Liberians and the world were once more awakened to the brutality that have characterized our senseless civil war. Like the Carter Camp and Du Port Road massacres, spineless individuals, under the cover of darkness, attacked unarmed civilians in Sinje, Grand Cape Mount County. Outcries for conclusive investigation persist. Given our commitment, we commenced investigation into the massacre, undertook series of visits to the area and interviewed survivors. We are here to report to you our findings.

The detailed report is available but we will provide you a summary.

SUMMARY OF THE SINJE MASSACRE

The Senji Massacre occured on September 28, 1996 in Grand Cape Mount County barely a month following the signing of the recent Abuja Agreement. On September 27, 1996, a day before the massacre, the World Food Program (WFP), through its implementing partner in the region, the Liberia Islamic Union for Reconstruction and Development (LIURD) distributed Bulgur Whear and other food items to residents of Sinje. On September 28, 1996, at about 5:30 A.M. residents of Sinje were awakened by a volley of gunfire. Some ran from their homes while others were killed by the attackers. According to our investigations about 21 persons were killed in the massacre while about 21 others were abducted, some with their families.

THOSE KILLED INCLUDED:. 1. Miaata Barlo (wife of Fumba Barlo). 2. Lutee Barlo (son of Fumba Barlo). 3. Mama Barlo (relations of Fumba). 4. Garti Barlo (relations of Fumba). 5. Tata Barlo (relations of Fumba). 6. Jenneh Barlo (relations of Fumba). 7. Satta Barlo (relations of Fumba). 8. Sanda Barlo (relations of Fumba). 9. K. Varney Zodua (Father of Mohamed Zodua) 10. Bendu Zodua (Duaghter of Mohammed). 11. Siatta Zodua. 12. Mary Kennedy. 13. Emmanuel Jessey. 14, Morris Kiawu. 15. Varney Farma. 16. Lucinii Sumai. 17. Pop Joe (Town Crier). 18. Sando (Daughter of Mama Darwolo). 19. Momo Zodua. 20. Mary Boyah. 21. Sando (A lady from Gunn Town)

THOSE ABDUCTED INCLUDED.

1. Varney Sambola and Family. 2. Momo Fanbulleh and Family. 3. Amie Jallah (Wife of John Jallah). 4. Tenneh Zodua (Mother of Mohammed Zodua) 5. Kpadeh Baysah and wife. 6, Pater Zarwolo. 7. Tamba Kamara and Family. 8. Foday Kamara (Son of Tamba). 9. Sunday Kamara (son of John Jallah). 10. Watta Nuan and her four children. 11. Martu Jalaba and her son (she was wounded during the killing) 12. Varney Forboi (LIURD Volunteer worker) 13. Joseph Brown and Family. 14. Mammie Gargar. 15, James Gargar. 16. Lorpu Gargar. 17. Hajai Kamara. 18. Mammie Kamara. 19. Tenneh Kamara. 20. Maryea Koiwood (child under 10 years) 21. Musu Zodua (three years old child of late Miatta Barlo)

The attackers have been identified as ULIMO-K . The alleged perpetrators include: 1. Battle Front Commander, Jackson **. 2. Opa Sandi. 3. Mack Typson. 4. Jahanama. 5. Operations. 6. Jabateh. 7. Col Dardo. 8. Tarweh. 9. Col. Power. 10. Boakai Komah. 11. Sando Ragan. 12. Moluba Sombid. 13. Po-Boy Sheriff. 14. Mohammed Dambodambo. 15. Victor (known as "Bassa Boy"). 16. Varney Swaray. of the "Force Fire" and "PISO" Battalions respectively.

The Bloun Town Massacre:

On December 7, 1996, about 11 persons were bestially massacred in Bloun Town allegedly by ULIMO-J fighters while they went in pursuit of food. Bloun Town is across the Po River from Zwannah Town, a displaced and refugee center about 21 miles outside Monrovia and 6 miles from Hotel Africa.

Terrified by the news of the massacre, a team of 4 human rights investigators proceeded to the area on Friday, December 13, 1996, to investigate the massacre. Having interviewed an array of survivors, relatives and witnesses, which included the displaced refugees, relief workers in the camp and ECOMOG, in Zwannah Town, Bloun Town and Monrovia, the following conclusions, recommendations and observations were reached:

Observations:

1. It was observed that fighting has been going on in the area beyond Zwannah Town over the past two months between the Congo Defense Force (CDF) and ULlMO-J in complete violation of the ceasefire agreement;

2. It is observed that terror has haunted the various villages and towns around the Po River over the past six months;

3. It Was also observed that more civilians were reportedly tortured and/or killed in the last few weeks but because of the degree of terror across the Po River, civilians cannot determine the number of individuals killed or tortured. This suggest that the actual number of persons killed are more than eight;

4. There are constant threats of attack on the town by ULIMO-J because of the constant presence of the Congo Defense Force (CDF) in the area. The Congo Defense Force (CDF) carries out trade within the area with civilians and ECOMOG without being stopped. It was also observed that no degree of disarmament is presently being enforced in the vicinity as the Congo Defense Force appears to be a shady military arrangement. There is no disarmament for them. Concern is also being raised about the presence of ULIMO-J's Former Chief of Staff (D. Armah Youlo) in the area. Recommendations:

1. That ECOMOG take steps to inhibit the regular presence of known fighters in the displaced center (Zwannah Town);

2. That civilians must minimize the level of trade with the fighters. The trade has continued to encourage the looting and harassment;

3. The civilians have linked the issue of food distribution and security; they have therefore requested that food distribution be preceded by thorough security investigation of their environs; 4. The leadership of the camp needs to be encouraged to conduct a thorough research on the issue o security, freedom of movement, acts of torture and murder in the area.

CONCLUSION:

1. That the general security situation is highly unfavorable. What is today referred to as the Congo Defense Force (CDF) said to be operating in the area is being commanded by on Wilmot Charles, His advisor is his father Ezekiel Charles; Both men are alleged to be former members of the Armed Forces of Liberia. 2. It is clear from the preponderance of testimonies that the act was committed by ULIMO-J fighters:

3. The final lit of those killed (victims) was as follows: 1. Boima Cole. 2. Bala Cole. 3. Foray Cole aka Gboyo. 4. Jebbeh Cole. 5. Miatta Goba. 6, Charles Massaley. 7, Gbessay Gobah. 8. Jatou Armah. 9. Bendu Ngongho. 10. Zennie Sheriff.

Some of the alleged perpetrators:

1. Cape Mount Trouble. 2. Bush Devil. 4. It was reported that all of those killed were mutilated except for one person who was shot.

THE RECENT ABDUCTION CASE INVOLVING EMPLOYEES OF THE EDUCATION MINISTRY

On December 13, 1996, Minister Moses Barh of the Education Ministry informed us that some citizens were allegedly abducted from his vehicle on December 1, 1996 while returning from Paynesville. He named the victims as: (1) Mr. Charles B. Davis - Special Assistant to the Minister, (2) Mr. James B. Kerkulah Driver (3) Miss Julia Kuoh.

His letter also alleged that the incident occurred in Congo Town. Further investigations and interviews alleged that the incident occurred around the Zone 3 Police Station in Congo Town 10 yards from the home of Councilman Charles Taylor. The three abductees were taken from the vehicle mercilessly flogged and taken to the Watanga Base. The alleged Perpetrators mentioned in the National Newspaper of December 13, 1996 were listed as follows: l. Col, Chris Rogers. 2. Gen. Two for Five. 3. Gen. Banana. 4. Gen, Sebastain Boys

It was also alleged that the incident, occurred in the presence of Former Councilman Isaac Saye Musa. What is significant about this incident is that since such public accusation was made against the above listed individuals, almost two weeks now, no pubic rebuttal has been made neither has any legal avenue pursued to vindicate themselves. We think this incident attests to the growing acts of abduction and hostage-taking in our safe havens. We call on the Justice Ministry to act with a sense of urgency and restore the respect for law and order as we continue to live in the chains of constant fear, lawlessness and banditry. Finally, we call on the Justice Ministry and ECOMOG and the NPFL leadership to take steps to demolish the notorious WANTANGA BASE which has allegedly become a torture enclave or the point of no return for many.

CONGO DEFENSE FORCE (CDF)

The Liberian Human Rights Community (L.H.R.C.) is concerned about the emergence and constant mention of a group called the Congo Defense Force around the Po River, a disturbing phenomenon in the Liberian Peace Process. We are especially concern that some acts of bestiality and criminality have been associated with their presence.

While we do not want to grant credence to such on illegal and mischievous organization. It is imperative to draw attention to their existence as their involvement in the Liberian situation has accentuated the suffering and destruction of the Liberian people and their properties. They have been reportedly linked to the ambush of December 14, 1996 which occurred on the Bomi Highway in which 4 persons were killed. Since its emergence earlier this year, the so-called Congo Defense Force (CDF), this shadow group has undertaken a pattern of Human Rights abuses and ceasefire violations in the western region. This presents a disturbing feature both for the already horrible Human Rights situation and painstaking peace process. Our information, as received from interviewees in the western region as well as those connected to the Congo Defense Force (CDF) is that this group has affiliation or is in fact an offshoot of one or two of the factions. Our interaction with some elements of the Congo Defense Force (CDF) revealed that they refer to a leader of one of the recognized factions as (ULIMO-K) leader and to the NPFL as one of their suppliers of arms and ammunition.

While this group (may) not be strong enough to reverse or impact the chemistry of the Peace Process there is a likelihood and fear that some recognized faction, fearing dissolution, wanting to undermine or abdicate responsibility under the Abuja Accord and continue their military campaign could transform themselves into splinter groups of this nature.

As a group not recognized by the Abuja Peace Agreement, the actions of this so-called Congo Defense Force (CDF) are criminal in nature and must therefore not be condoned. Wrong precedence and impunity, we have repeatedly warned, are detrimental to the attainment of peace.

We therefore advise that ECOMOG, UNOMIL, LNTG and other groups must adopt a homogenous policy regarding dealings and interaction with the CDF. It is important to attribute criminal responsibility for violations and atrocities committed by this group. We would however advise against granting them undue legitimacy and formal recognition. MEMBERS OF THE PRESS, our position will be officially communicated to all concerned and ensure that the relevant pressure will be brought to bear. Another point of concern is the limited jurisdiction of our Justice System. ln a special Government announcement of December 3, 1996, the Justice Minister alluded to this fact in her advise to investors and/or their representatives not to proceed to any area of the country not yet declared "Safe Haven(s)" and where the presence of the Government of Liberia has not been reestablished.

We are concerned that inspite of the representation on the Council of State of all faction leaders, the country remains balkanized into mini spheres of control where the standards of justice are dictated by factions and not by the government of Liberia; where factions and their operatives are not answerable to the jurisdiction of our national justice system. We call on the LNTG to take steps in addressing the growing concern which continues to inhibit freedom of movement and subject our people to inhumane and degrading treatment.

1. Catholic Justice and Peace Commission. 2. Liberia Watch for Human Rights. 3. Fore-Runners of Children's Universal Rights for Survival Growth and Development. 4. National Human Rights Monitor. 5. Liberia Human Rights Chapter, Inc. (Signatures on file)

Distributed by Africa Faith and Justice Network; P.O.Box 29378; Washington, D.C. 20017; 202 832 3412 tel. 202 832 9051 fax; email: afjn@igc.apc.org

Africa News


January 17, 1997


Science and Health;
Forum Seeks Answers To Adolescent Health Crisis


BYLINE: Centre For Development and Population Activities


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Washington, DC - With a 23 percent increase in births to teenagers predicted in sub-Saharan Africa by 2020 and HIV/AIDS increasing rapidly among youth, health experts stress there is an urgent need to provide adolescents with access to reproductive health services. To this end, more than 350 policymakers, health care providers, researchers, young people, and others from throughout Africa will meet in Addis Ababa January 20-24 for the African Forum on Adolescent Reproductive Health, at the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa.

The Forum, which is sponsored by the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) Africa Division, and coordinated by The Centre for Development and Population Activities (CEDPA), will adopt guidelines for policies and services to improve adolescent reproductive health. UNFPA is a world leader in promoting reproductive health and family planning and the largest multilateral funder of population and development programs. CEDPA, an international non- governmental organization that works to improve the status of women and youth, supports reproductive health programs in Africa and Asia. 

Unplanned pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases including HIV/AIDS, and unsafe abortion are having devastating effects on the health and economic prospects of youth as well as on development expectations for the region. More than 50 percent of young women in the region give birth before the age of 20, and in some countries as many as 40 percent have had their first child by age 18. Early pregnancy is life-threatening. Young women ages 15-19 are twice as likely to die during pregnancy and childbirth as older women; their infants also are more likely to die.

Africa has the highest HIV prevalence rate in the world, and the average age of infection and onset of AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa is younger than the global average. Women become infected about 4 years earlier than men -- 30 percent of female AIDS cases are in women under 25, and infection rates are high among pregnant young women.

High adolescent fertility is a major factor in continuing rapid population growth, widely acknowledged as a major problem in the region. Women who begin having children at an early age have more children than those who start in their twenties and thirties and often have fewer wage-earning opportunities, contributing to both accelerating population growth and poverty.

For moore information contact Sigrid E. Berg, Communications Assistant/Webmaster, The Centre for Development and Population Activities (CEDPA) 1717 Massachusetts Ave., NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20036, USA Tel. : (202) 667-1142. Fax: (202) 332-4496. http://www.cedpa.org


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

227 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Web Feet


BYLINE: Arthur Goldstuck, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Johannesburg - Notes from the Net

After reading all the FAQs (Frequently Asked Questions) highlighted in last week's column, you must be salivating at the idea of putting up a web page of your own. Problem is, you probably don't want to pay for the pleasure.

The good news is, you don't have to. If you already have an Internet service provider (ISP), you probably already have free space that you're not using: most ISPs offer between 500kb and 1Mb free space on their system for their subscribers. 

Aside from that option, numerous sites on the web offer free hosting of web pages, as long as they are personal or non-profit type pages. Many of these services even include automatic page-creation systems, where you merely type the relevant information into the relevant spaces, and something like a web design robot puts it into web page format.

The main drawback of this auto-design system is that you get a fairly dull- looking page, with little option for spicing it up yourself.

However, if that suits your needs for the moment, you could start with Yahoo (http://www.yahoo.com/), where a request in their search box for Free Web Pages will throw up a handsome crop.

Many free services give you both the create-a-page option and do-it- yourself. The best of these is GeoCities (http://www.geocities.com/), which has created hundreds of "residential neighbourhoods" divided into 29 "themed communities". Each neighbourhood is capable of hosting hundreds of personal home pages. The neighbourhoods take the name of a city, representing the specific theme followed by its "inhabitants". For instance, Athens is a community based on education, teaching, reading, writing and philosophy; Colosseum caters for sports fans, and Enchanted Forest for kids.

The Hong Kong Cybercity (http://www.cybercity.hko.net/) is a similar concept, offering free space in a trio of themed neighbourhoods, namely Hong Kong, Singapore, and Tokyo. It is one of the more generous of these services, providing 5mb of space. However, it is on a very slow link to this side of the world.

Angelfire Communications (http://www.angelfire.com/) also offers free home pages but, like many of these services, imposes a number of restrictions. These include the obvious, like bars on pornography and illegal commercial activities, and the less obvious, like paid advertising from an outside source.

123 Go Global (http://www.10mb.com/) offers free sites for commercial web designers and resellers to start or expand their web business, obviously on the basis that they would bring paying customers to the site.

Many sites offering free space eventually find themselves overwhelmed by demand, and curtail the service. If you intend building up your page over many years, it might be wise to stick to your own Internet service provider.

For a more extensive list of free web services, visit the online version of this column at http://www.mg.co.za/mg/pc/pcrevie1.htm

Send comments and suggestions to arthurg@is.co.za


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Lamont's Quantum Leap


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Johannesburg - James Lamont tells Jacquie Golding-Duffy that fellow editors cannot afford not to take him seriously, despite his age

He is young and overly cautious, say some. Others argue that his track record is unimpressive and does not qualify him to sit at the helm of Business Report. But 28- year-old James Lamont, the newly appointed editor of The Star's business section, says South African journalism has always been his goal, and his career path has consisted of stepping stones towards that goal.

Lamont is the product of a private school - Winchester College, Britain, followed by the University of York, with a post- graduate degree in Southern African studies in 1991. 

His curriculum vitae includes a stint on the Middle East Times in Cairo, which, he admits, was "not a large publication", boasting a staff of not more than 15. He has also worked as a stringer for Opec news agency and a retail/consumer magazine, Link, in the south of England.

His list of achievements in the UK also include working for the Labour Party: "I was the election press officer for a small constituency," he says.

Why did he not serve on a British national newspaper before leaving? "I just never applied. My career is taking a logical path. I have had a sustained interest in Africa and South Africa and that is why I am here. The Middle East Times was a stepping stone to get where I am today.

"At a young age I left Britain to come to Africa and worked in Namibia as an economics teacher for a non-governmental organisation.''

Lamont's first job on arrival in South Africa in 1995 was business editor at Finance Week, followed by a move to Business Report where he was industrial editor. He served a term of one year before his promotion. He sits in the stark office occupied until recently by his predecessor, Peter Bruce, now Financial Mail editor.

One cannot help but compare Lamont to his predecessors: Bruce, a respected financial journalist and former home desk editor at the Financial Times, and Jim Smith, Business Report's first editor, a highly acclaimed journalist, writer and foreign correspondent.

Lamont is believed to be Bruce's appointment, an ironic scenario involving a rival editor exerting influence among the big boys at the Independent Group.

With six years' experience in journalism, Lamont says he hopes his colleagues will judge him on merit rather than prejudge him because of his age.

However, despite his projected confidence, he cannot help constantly referring to Bruce.

"As Peter always says, this newspaper has a robust financial team which will keep it at the forefront of business news," states Lamont, adding that although journalists on the team are young, they certainly are not novices.

Lamont says his age should not be seen as a handicap but an asset.

"It is not unusual in Britain to appoint young editors and this newspaper is young and vibrant which makes it appropriate that they should have chosen me," he says, hand on hip.

"The appointment of young editors is a trend which is likely to take off in South Africa alongside the shake-up of business titles and the constant change of owners. Business Report has been marketing itself as an innovative publication and the group needed someone at the helm who reflects that."

He says he regards his editorship as a "challenge", adding that Bruce has " taught me a lot".

On the issue of fellow editors' attitude towards him, Lamont says: "Editors at rival publications cannot afford not to take me seriously. The fact that I have been appointed as editor makes it clear that Independent's management takes me seriously. My job is to take this publication into the next era."

Lamont will be in charge of 48 staffers and does not seem intimidated by the task at hand. But some seasoned editors say he should be.

Although the business journal is believed to have played a role in upgrading the Independent Group's carrier newspapers in Gauteng and other regions, Lamont is faced with the challenge of ensuring that its position is consolidated and that it does not buckle from the competition of Times Media Limited's rival Business Day, recently taken aboard by the Pearsons group and its daily, the London Financial Times.

Some veteran editors argue that Lamont should have been allowed the time to nurture the "instinct" and "good judgement" that come with several years in the profession. However, as one editor pointed out: "William Pitt (the younger) was made prime minister of Britain at the young age of 21" - although another countered that Pitt was a product of the 18th century, not the 20th.

There is some tension brewing at Independent Newspapers with former colleagues of Lamont alleging it is inappropriate that a foreigner be chosen to head Business Report when the group has been punting its fast-tracking course for black and female journalists.

However, Lamont argues that he is not a foreigner. With a South African mother and a grandfather who was an industrialist from Vereeniging, Lamont is confident that he qualifies for the position: "I would like to stress that I am half South African."

Should critics want to argue that he was not born and bred locally, Lamont challenges them, arguing that a fresh eye will serve the publication well since locals are not as observant, often seeing events through tired eyes.

He contends that should a foreigner have been brought in (the group's deputy chief executive, Ivan Fallon, flew to London to scout for new talent) then "the newsroom would have had to gear itself towards being accustomed to an outsider. Instead I know them and they know me."

Lamont's permanent residency is not in order but he is applying for citizenship. He says he hopes to enjoy dual citizenship and that the matter should be wrapped up by month-end.

"Business Report's deputy, for the moment, remains John Spira," says Lamont. Spira has twice been overlooked for the editorship.

On the affirmative action front, Lamont says one in five journalists are black and he wants to improve that quota. "I want to encourage more black reporters to join the group. More black juniors need to be recruited and within two years they must be trained to be accomplished and respected names in the industry," he says.

Gauteng Newspapers managing director Deon du Plessis says Lamont has his eye firmly fixed on the 21st century and is a confident chap. "Besides that, our appointment has broken the mould that only long-serving members will get the post of editor."

On the issue of fast-tracking and the lack of black and female editors, Du Plessis argued that the fast-tracking course at Harvard University last year was to encourage reporters to be "active" within the stable. "It was not a guarantee towards an editorship."


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
In With The New, Out With The Old


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Johannesburg - Highveld Stereo's new managers are grappling with change, reports Jacquie Golding-Duffy

Former Highveld Stereo managing director Eon de Vos has left the radio station after an association of 17 years. De Vos and some of the new owners of Highveld differed on the strategy that should be used to take Highveld into the next century.

Tensions began brewing between the old and the new when Highveld's staffers moved offices in December and took up space at the Primedia Broadcasting location in Rivonia.

No one can put their finger on the problem but there existed differences of opinion between the new guard and the old-timers from the moment the sale was completed, says one Highveld DJ who refused to be named. The tensions varied from differences in attitude to change in the command structure with the new guard taking over the reins and transforming the newsroom by encouraging the influx of affirmative action cadets who are being trained as radio reporters. 

Highveld was sold last year at a cost of R320-million to the Africa on Air consortium, consisting of Primedia Broadcasting, the Mineworkers Investment Company, the South African Clothing and Textile Workers Union and the Women's Investment Portfolio.

De Vos this week told the Mail & Guardian that he agrees with the new owners that the main goal of commercial radio is to make money and offer advertisers a platform to market their wares. However, he argues that there existed differences between himself and management on the development of an on- air format and the manner in which the merging of cultures was taking place at Highveld.

Colleagues close to De Vos say that he was not fired nor did he resign, but there was an agreement that he and Primedia Broadcasting chief executive Stan Katz should part ways.

"It was amicable but I think De Vos reached the stage where he had to ask himself whether fighting out the differences with Katz was worth all the effort," said one colleague.

It is understood that it was not a quick decision and was mulled over by the people concerned for some months. De Vos's association with Highveld began as a DJ in 1979, followed by a management and public relations role in 1983 and 1984. He then went back on air in 1986 and has since been associated with Highveld in various ways, his last position being managing director.

"There are a couple of things that I am looking into but it is too early to reveal any of my plans," said De Vos, nearly a week after his departure.

Katz confirmed that there were differences between himself and De Vos but said this did not stem from any plans to transform Highveld. The parting, he said, was amicable.

Primedia Broadcasting has a 40% stake in Highveld. The group also holds the management contract for Highveld which effectively puts Katz in charge of the day- to-day running of the station.

Alongside Katz is Highveld Stereo's non- executive chair, Kuben Pillay. Katz, Pillay and a third party form a management committee which is responsible for the long-term plans of the station.

On the day-to-day running of Highveld, Katz cannot help but spew forth the station's progress as he sees it.

"There is a great deal of transformation taking place but we are not planning to change the music station's basic format. We are targeting a 25+ audience and are playing more mainstream adult contemporary music with a strong mix of familiar songs.

"Highveld Stereo used to play a lot of unfamiliar songs and we believe that people enjoy that which is familiar to them. We are conducting extensive research into what our target audience wants to listen to. Meanwhile, we assume that listeners do not like the unfamiliar."

Katz argues that Highveld's former managers had not conducted research for many years, thus forcing the station's new management to reassess its target audience.

Highveld, he says, is involved in an ongoing process of hiring people and has "a fully fledged news team" of 11 reporters. He admits there will be competition for Primedia's other radio station - Gauteng- based Radio 702 - but believes the roles of the two radio stations differ.

Africa on Air's Pillay agrees. He says Radio 702 and Highveld Stereo will compete for audiences and adspend which is healthy. However, he adds that the former is information and news-driven, which is typical of talk radio; while the latter is music-based, typical of commercial radio.

"The two news teams operate independently of each other and are targeting different listeners," says Pillay.

Those who have listened to Highveld Stereo will have noticed a "tweeking of the format" - it has been tightened with more golden oldies being played and there is aggressive marketing taking place on air (such as the punting of Highveld's place on the dial, 94,7FM).

While Katz talks of the great deal of "optimism and enthusiasm" in the Highveld newsroom, Pillay tells of the promise of performance made to the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA). Africa on Air vowed to use this investment opportunity to advance previously disadvantaged groups and concentrate on training potential reporters at Primedia's state-of-the-art facilities.

On affirmative action, certain sources in the consortium argue that some of the veteran staffers at Highveld are not keen to see their positions usurped by upcoming young black talent, while others say this projected paranoia is a misconception and that things at Highveld are "simply hunkydory".

However, it is believed that Africa on Air was forced to give the IBA and SABC an undertaking that it would not fire people at random on taking control of the radio station. Instead, Highveld's new management has to ensure that transferred staffers keep their jobs for at least one year, a promise which has, in some instances, proven to be a stumbling block towards progress.

Pillay refused to be drawn on the Katz/De Vos saga, saying simply that the latter decided to leave Highveld's employ last Thursday.

It is not clear why the two men clashed, but as well-known Radio 702 DJ Chris Gibbons says: "As with most mergers and new acquisitions, there is almost invariably a clash at the top, resulting in one of the big boys spending more time with the family.''

Gibbons, who is also managing director of Broadcast Resources at Primedia Broadcasting, says the company has made a "number of stabs" at affirmative action but these have been "without conspicuous success".

Primedia is now "going over the ground again", and has resorted to using a consultant and forming a policy committee which hopes to successfully tackle the issue.

Workshops and consultation are the keys words being bandied about the corridors of Primedia with management feeling the pressure to succeed on the affirmative action front.

"We feel we have a complexion which is pretty male and pretty white and there is a feeling that we have to access a diverse market. There has now been a management drive towards bringing staffers into the equation and hopefully we will get it (affirmative action) right this time round," says Gibbons.

Currently, the composition of Primedia Broadcasting in terms of affirmative action is 70% white to 30% black. "At Primedia we have one person of colour on the main board, but several affirmative action candidates hold senior positions throughout the company. Let us not forget that affirmative action is not only based on colour but is a question of gender as well and Primedia has several women in key positions."

Gibbons says Primedia has been around in one shape or another for more than 16 years. In 1980 its radio station was launched with a mixed race format - something which in the new South Africa would be dead right - but a year later, a decision had to be taken to "either go black or white". Radio 702 went the white route.

"Unfortunately, at the time, the deliberate crossover of cultures and an intentionally mixed format bombed."

Gibbons admits that Primedia is probably not moving at a fast enough pace for the new South Africa, but he says the company is probably faring better than most with affirmative action.

All eyes are on the Primedia group, especially with its latest and expensive acquisition - Highveld - officially forming part of the stable.

Africa on Air and Primedia take "complete control" of Highveld Stereo in March - which means they will start selling their own advertisements. Currently, the adspend of the radio station is being placed by the SABC, with Highveld's sales team impatiently waiting in the wings.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 17, 1997


South Africa;
South African Media In Brief


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Johannesburg - The task group on government communications (Comtask), which finalised its report for Deputy President Thabo Mbeki last November, has yet to see the fruits of its research being implemented.

According to Comtask convenor Mandla Langa, Mbeki has looked at the report and members of the team are scheduled to meet with him month-end. "The deputy president wants certain things clarified before going ahead with our recommendations," he said. Comtask's findings include streamlining government communications departments and improving South Africa's media image abroad. 

The debacle surrounding the Freedom of Expression Institute (FXI) and its chair Raymond Louw has been put on ice for now with no retaliation from Black Editors Forum chair, Thami Mazwai.

The FXI this week held a press conference explaining why it should head the investigation into the media on behalf of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. There has been a furore over the FXI's intended involvement with the Black Editors Forum claiming that it is inapproporiate for journalists (such as Louw) to investigate fellow journalists .

FXI deputy chair Mandla Seleoane says if the TRC decides against the FXI, then the institute "will conduct its own investigation and present its findings as a submission to the TRC".

The tendering process for The Flying Springbok publishing contract has been postponed from January 6 to January 23 at the request of several companies, says South African Airways representative Mike Pheiffer. The magazine which is read by about five million passengers annually is being hotly tendered for.

Pheiffer refused to divulge who requested an extension but it is believed that Thebe Investments wanted more time. Other contenders are rumoured to be Kagiso Trust Investments, Penta Publications and talkshow presenter Felicia Mabuza-Suttle.

Gauteng's auditor general Shauket Fakie has embarked on an investigation into alleged financial irregularities at the Independent Broadcasting Authority (IBA) following staffers' complaints. Fakie said his office was from time to time directed by the public protector to conduct special investigations. The investigation will focus on expenditures by the IBA.

British newspapers are trying everything to keep readers, but the latest Audit Bureau of Circulation figures indicate that most of the daily broadsheets, Sunday newspapers and even tabloids are freefalling.

Some newspaper groups are opting for a revamp by changing their masthead, while others are changing editors with the hope of "finding the right one" who will boost circulation.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 17, 1997


South Africa;
Fresh Current At SABC


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Johannesburg - Jacquie Golding-Duffy speaks to the people behind the sweeping changes in current affairs programmes

The launch this week of a new current affairs programme - Question and Answer (Q&A) - marks the revamp taking place within the SABC's television news department.

It has taken the new head of SABC-TV's Current Affairs division, Sarah Crowe, less than two months to begin giving her stable of current affairs programmes a facelift.

Her plans created in late October of "changing the focus of current affairs slots" has been put in motion with the go- ahead of SABC Television News editor-in- chief Joe Thloloe.

Thloloe says Q&A is "the biggest change in the reformatting of the current affairs programmes". 

Crowe agrees. "The style used in the studio is common abroad but is a television style which is foreign to South Africa and will be seen as fresh and new to local viewers."

Q&A, which will be broadcast on SABC 3 at 21h30 every Tuesday, encourages audience participation.

Panelists for the first episode included Minister of Environment Affairs and Tourism Pallo Jordan, Pan Africanist Congress MP Patricia De Lille and well-known economist and commentator Magnus Heystek. These three personalities fielded questions from the audience on a central theme: Muslim fundamentalism and the Cape Town community group, People against Gangsterism and Drugs (Pagad).

Crowe says the old actuality format, especially the Tuesday Debate, was scrapped because it was "getting tired".

The new programme offers greater flexibility. "In the Q&A format we can tackle softer issues. The Tuesday Debate sometimes did not have a contentious issue around which one could develop a debate."

Former Tuesday Debate host, Max du Preez, agrees. "This format allows for more leeway and draws in ordinary people who would otherwise not have an opportunity to ask questions which they feel are pressing," he says.

Crowe adds that ''a myriad of subjects are discussed and viewers can hear what the major power players such as ministers, businessmen and others think of issues which are outside their field of expertise".

Du Preez takes charge (or fails to take charge) of Q&A as he did at the Tuesday Debate, which has proven to be a recipe of success for him.

He stresses that Q&A "does not aspire to be another show of talking heads. nor does it want to be another Two Way.

"It's about tackling issues via questions from ordinary people in the street."

Thloloe said the revamp, which included a new, modern set that creates the illusion of space as well as brand-new logos "did not cost the corporation much" - an estimated R50 000. Most of the work, he says, was conducted by internal staffers using in-house facilities.

He says the five new-look current affairs programmes are an effort to look at current issues in a different way and to give news a bit of depth as well as a cutting edge.

The other current affairs programmes boasting a new look include Fokus with Freek Robinson every Wednesday on SABC 2 at 21h00 - to be a personality- driven show in Afrikaans and presented in the field. SABC 1 will continue to broadcast Focus at 20h00 where the main issues of the week will be discussed.

There will also be a Focus on Africa where it is hoped that stories concerning the continent will be highlighted and Focus Features, a new documentary programme.

Besides these changes, SABC is planning a monthly Focus on Business which will kick off on February 3 on SABC 2 at 21h00, followed by Focus on Media which will be broadcast on February 6 on SABC 3 at 21h30.

"The first Monday and Thursday of each month, viewers can enjoy these special Focus bulletins," says Thloloe, adding that the Focus on Business is not aimed at competing with other business programmes. The SABC currently commissions a programme from Business Day called Business Tonight which is aired every evening at 10pm.

Focus on Media hopes to look at "broad media issues" ranging from internal SABC issues to advertising and marketing.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
