Africa News


January 20, 1997


South Africa;
Only one Mpumalanga politician refuses expensive car


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 498 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's cabinet has continued to defy public opinion as well as advice from national transport minister Mac Maharaj and has opted to keep its contentious fleet of new luxury BMWs.

The ten new BMW 528i92s were ordered for Mpumalanga's MECs in December for R2,3-million, almost immediately after the province announced that severe budget constraints had forced it to cut all new schools, roads and other capital projects in the region. The deal was in direct defiance of advice from Maharaj, who pointed out that the cars cost R77 000 more per car than allowed for by ministerial handbook regulations. The regulations allow MECs to drive cars worth R154 000, while the BMWs cost R232 000 each. 

Although Mpumalanga has continued to ignore Maharaj's advice, the province has tried to defuse the budgetary implications of buying the vehicles. A cabinet resolution earlier this month ordered each MECs department and not the province's transport department - to pay for its BMW. Because the transport department is the only department to have budgeted for the vehicles, the move may be construed as unauthorised expenditure by the Auditor General. Mpumalanga's environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi, is the only politician to have refused his new BMW. He told African Eye News Service (South Africa) on Friday that his 1994 issue Mercedes Benz 155 was still good for another 50 000km and that his department was not prepared to "waste" money on vehicles unless absolutely necessary. "I'll only consider trading my Merc in when it gets to 200 000km. I also told the cabinet to go for Mercedes Benz in any case because they hold their market values better over a five year period than the BMW," he added.

Mkhwanazi has advised his transport counterpart, Jackson Mthembu, to keep the extra BMW for use as a pool vehicle for senior officials and so save on projected expenditure for rental cars. Mthembu declined to comment but his spokesman, Thabo Monareng, confirmed on Saturday that the costs for the luxury fleet had been shifted. He could not say what had prompted the shift or what the budgetary implications for recipient departments would be. Mthembu earlier dismissed Maharaj's call for MECs to follow his lead and drive cheaper cars as impractical and "out of touch".

He said that Mpumalanga's geographic size and poor road system demanded better performing vehicles and that the BMW had been "scientifically" proven to be the best for the job. Minister Maharaj drives a 1992 Volkswagen Jetta. Mpumalanga finance MEC, Jacques Modipane, also refused to comment on the issue other than to confirm that he was keeping his BMW and that his department would be paying for it. Modipane previously accused reporters of racism for questioning the deal and insisted that he had a "certain" status in his community as a political leader and could therefore not be expected to drive a smaller vehicle. - African Eye News Service (South Africa)

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Business and Finance;
Stock Market Starts Week Quieter In Zimbabwe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe's stock exchange started the week quieter Monday, with the watershed Industrial Index shedding 273 points to close trading at 10,018.4 points.

The index, which last week broke through the 10,000-point barrier for the first time in its 51-year history, was, however, very active, with reasonable turnovers in several counters, among them the construction group, Gullivers and the trading-to-manufacturing conglomerate, Mashonaland Holdings. 

Counters to lose included the transport group, Clan, the trading firm, Tedco, as well as the tobacco trading combine, TSL Ltd.

Among the most expensive counters to lose were, blue-chip Delta Corporation, and the merchant bank, FMB, which each shed 100 cents to 44 zimdollars (4.4 U.S. dollars) and 60 zimdollars (6.0 U.S. dollars), respectively.

This was in response to profit taking by investors who had gone on a buying frenzy during the beginning of January, sending the Industrial Index to new heights.

With reports of inflation falling to an annualized figures of 16.4 percent in December 1996, and interest rates softening further, analysts are expecting active trading on the local bourse during the next few months.

Investors have also been cheered by reports that the country will experience an agriculture-led growth of between 6 percent and seven percent in 1997.

Meanwhile, the Mining Index lost 25 points Monday to close at 1,091.2 points.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Science and Health;
African Adolescent Reproductive Health Forum Opens


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A major African adolescent reproductive health forum began Monday with an appeal for a solution to the gender-based problems afflicting women and youths.

Opening the forum, Ethiopia's social affairs minister, Kebede Tedesse, told the 300 delegates that currently such problems are blamed for the loss of 36 percent of the healthy years of life among women of reproductive age and 12 percent of men. 

He mentioned these problems to be unregulated fertility, maternal mortality and sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV/AIDS.

He urged the participants to find solutions within the continent's social realities, to ensure that "future generations of African population will live in an environment that is less oppressive and unjust to women."

However, he warned that government and other actors also needed to solve other related cultural, traditional and socio-economic problems of education, employment, living conditions, family education and gender relations.

One of the forum's organizers, Perry Curlin of the Washington-based Center for Development and Population Activities, told PANA Sunday that she hoped the meeting would come out with concrete solutions to the plight of sub- Saharan women.

The thrust of the four-day forum, being co-organized by the United Nations Population Fund, is to reverse the trend under which at least 50 percent or more of young sub-Saharan women give birth before the age of 20 years. INL002 from SSS.056 (970120-17:57) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG055G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2)

The fear is that if the situation is not contained, adolescent births could increase by 23 percent between 1995-2020.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


South Africa;
South Africa In Favor Of Syrian Arms Deal


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa's proposed 650-million-U.S. -dollar arms deal with Syria is only at a tentative stage, although the government is in favor of the transaction in principle, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said Sunday.

He pointed out that South African armaments company, Denel, had been issued with a marketing licence in Syria, following a Syrian request for tank firing systems. But, a tendering system of up to three years was involved, he added. 

Mbeki was speaking at Midrand, near Johannesburg, at the conclusion of a four-day meeting of the African National Congress hierarchy to discuss policy matters.

The question of the proposed supply of arms to Syria, he said, fell within the ambit of Pretoria's clear policy on arms sales abroad. Criteria included the human rights record of the country concerned, the likelihood that the weapons concerned would be used to suppress the local population, and whether or not a United Nations arms embargo was in force.

A Foreign Affairs spokesman explained that once the contractual stage of negotiation was reached in about two years time, it would be necessary for South Africa to review the situation in the Middle East and decide whether or not to go ahead with the Syrian arms deal.

"We don't pursue an apartheid policy in terms of our foreign relations in the Middle East," Mbeki said. "We don't follow a policy in the Middle East such as the policy that was followed by the previous regime, which was to form an alliance with Israel and be hostile to the rest of the countries in the region."

He said that the United States was being hypocritical in opposing the proposed sale of South African tank-gun aiming equipment to Syria. The U.S. threatened last week to suspend aid to South Africa if the Syrian arms deal went ahead. "U.S. equipment is being marketed in Syria for precisely the same thing," he added, "and the U.S. government has let that be because they understand precisely what is happening."

The South African cabinet is scheduled to discuss the Syrian arms deal at its first regular meeting of the year on Wednesday.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Mozambique;
Mozambican Police Destroy Arms Caches


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MAPUTO (PANA) - Mozambican police have uncovered and destroyed an arms cache in Manhica district, in the southern province of Maputo, the Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, reported Monday.

The cache, in the locality of Machahomo, contained 2,000 rounds of various types of ammunition, 77 AK-47 assault rifles, 34 hand grenades, three mortar barrels and seven rocket propelled grenade launchers. 

Police spokesman Armenio Panguene said local residents reported the location of the arms.

However, he said there was still a lot of weaponry hidden in the province, following the end of the 16-years civil war that was supported, on the rebel side, by apartheid South Africa.

Panguene said that it was important to destroy the arms caches because the provided ready supplies for gangs of armed robbers.

Meanwhile, the Beira daily newspaper, Diario de Mocambique, reported Monday that in the central province of Manica, police have dismantled three large arms caches believed to belong to the Zimbabwean dissident group known as the Chimwenjes.

The newspaper said the arms were found in the district of Sussundenga in December 1996. Among the weaponry were 300 mortar shells, 250 bazooka rockets, 71 AK-47s, and 42 boxes of land mines.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Annan Supports African Peacekeeping Force


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has said that the establishment of an African Peace-keeping Force would help strengthen the continent's capacity to deal with its crises.

Annan, 58, said told the Pan African News Ageny correspondent at the U.N. that the establishment of this force was particularly important in an era when peacekeeping operations were taking on a regional dimension.

He noted that though the peacekeeping operations in Cambodia and Bosnia were U.N. missions, Asian and European countries, respectively, played a major role. "I think it is normal that Africa should also develop capability to be able to either do it themselves or join in with others to solve some of the problems on the continent," he said Friday. 

Though a United States proposal, in 1996, for the establshment of an African Crisis Response Force elicited mixed reactions from African leaders, Annan said it was a good idea.

"I think the U.S. proposal is a helpful one," he said. "The proposal has been refined."

Under the proposal, which is still under consideration, nations would earmark military units to be trained and prepared for peacekeeping operations.

The units, which will also be given logistic support and training, could form part of an African force or part of a U.N. peacekeeping force.

Meanwhile Annan, who until his election as secretary-general was the U.N. under secretary-general for peacekeeping operations, said that the U.N. may increase its activities in Somalia and Liberia to help bring those war-torn countries back to normal.

On Somalia, he said that the world body, which he said was active on the humanitarian side, might become more actively re-engaged on the political front.

"We have an office in Nairobi which is still working on the Somali crisis and a group of ambassadors here in New York have formed Friends of Somalia, a group trying to explore what can be done (about the situation there)," he said.

On Liberia, Annan said the U.N. was in the process of increasing the number of its observers in the country while also becoming engaged in its electoral process.

"As of now, we have either doubled or we are about to double our observers in Liberia," he said.

As of November 1996, the U.N. had 23 military observers to that country.

He said that U.N. Assistant Secretary-General Lansana kouyate was is in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, discussing with the Liberian situation with President Sani Abacha.

Turning to Africa's economic problems, he said "a fresh strategy" was needed to stimulate private foreign investments in Africa.

"We cannot as Africans and the U.N. chase continuously diminishing donor dollars," he said.

"We need to adapt to the realities of the world economy today, and find ways and means of working with the private sector, ensuring of course that they do not dominate some of the smaller countries," he said.

He expressed support for the U.N. Special Initiative on Africa, launched in 1996 by his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt.

"Basically, if we accept that 80 per cent of international (financial) flows are in the hands of multinationals,...if we are going to assist developing countries, whether in Africa or Asia, we need to find ways of tapping into the capabilities of the multinationals," he said.

However, he said that Africa countries must first create political stability.

"So, first priority will be for us to settle the problems we have, whether in eastern Zaire, in the Great Lakes region, or in the Sudan.

"We should also try and respect the rights of our people and push democratization, to open up the society politically and free up the economies for people to use their initiative and energies to help develop their countries," he added.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Concerned About Opposition Arrests In Niger


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Washington - Statement issued by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns January 15 about arrests of opposition leaders in Niger.

The United States is deeply concerned about the arrest and imprisonment yesterday of opposition party leaders Mahamane Ousmane, Mahamadou Issoufou, and Tanja Mamadou and the announced use of a special tribunal by the government to deal with political crimes. The U.S. calls on the government of Niger to ensure the safety and well-being of all those in detention and to conduct any judicial proceedings openly and in a manner that is fair.

This latest repression of the peaceful political opposition clearly demonstrates the regime's continued determination to thwart democracy and basic human rights. This is another deplorable step in the wake of the military's seizure of power a year ago and its conduct of fraudulent Presidential elections in July. These actions inevitably undermine international confidence in Niger.

The United States has repeatedly expressed its concern about the economic ramifications of Niger's political situation. The United States terminated its assistance program to Niger in response to last year's coup. Political change, including early restoration of democracy and respect for basic human rights, is critical to Niger's political development and economic reform.

The United States again calls on Niger's regime to institute an early return to civilian, democratic government and to respect the rights of its people in the interests of Niger, its economic well-being, and its future.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian Air to Import Modern Passenger Aircraft


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Ato Kinfe Kahsay, fleet and equipment planning division manager of the Ethiopian Airlines (EAL) said that the national carrier has a plan to import modern passenger aircraft which will enable it compete successfully in the fast growing international market.

In an interview with ENA Ato Kinfe said in accordance with its five-year market forecast, it will buy modern-passenger planes as part of its modernization scheme now under way.

The manager said with a view to replacing the Boeing 767 aircraft that plunged into the Indian Ocean of the Comoro Islands late last year, the EAL will buy two passenger planes and will also lease two 234-seat planes in the coming six months. 

He further said the airlines has also a plan to add to its fleet big aircraft which can accommodate simultaneously many passengers and large quantity of cargo as the capacity of the existing B757 aircraft is low. It also has plans to sell one of them, he added.

A study is also under way to open new routes to Asia and Europe, Africa and U.S.A in the coming three years which include Lusaka, Kuwait, Maputo, Tel- Aviv, Paris Geneva, Copenhagen and Washington, Ato Kinfe said, adding that EAL will start flights to Lusaka, Tel-Aviv and Paris in the current and next Ethiopian Year.

The manager said work on the construction of a jet engine test cell being undertaken with 15 million dollars obtained from the African Development Bank (ADB) will be completed in the coming three months.

Ato Kinfe said a study on the construction of a cargo terminal at a cost of 30 million U.S. dollars has already been completed and added that the next measure will be borrowing the stated amount from creditors and launch the project, whose construction is expected to take four years.

He further said a similar study enabling the construction of a main tenance hangar has already been completd while preparations to lobby for loans from creditors amounting to 80 million U.S. dollars, the fund required for the construction of the maintenance hangar, has been finalised.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Somalia;
Refugees Say Trust Key For Peace In Somalia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Some Somali refugees residing here in the capital underlined the importance of tolerance, mutual trust and confidence among the 26 political parties which recently formed the National Salvation Council (NSC toward entering sustainable peace in that country.

The refugees approached by ENA reporters in connection with the formation of the NSC said peace will be a reality if ass parties are determined to jointly work for the reconstruction of Somalia.

Abduwehab Hassen who said he is still in the dark about the whereabouts of his wife lost in the civil strife in Somalia, said he is confident that the political movements could achieve the goals they have set provided they implement the consensus reached upon returning to Somalia. 

He expresses conviction if the 26 political parties remain united for the cause of peace, both Mohammed Igal of North Somalia and Hussen Aideed who did not take part in the peace deal will follow suit.

The former businessman who had been here for the past one and a half year expressed his belief that the international community will extend its support to the NSC if the political parties work in unison to promote peace and stability in that country.

Kedija Yesuf, a refugee living here with her four children told the journalists that Somalis are the ones responsible to come up with lasting solution to their own problems and she is eager to return to her homeland if the NSC succeeds in bringing about peace.

Citizens could not lead a peaceful life without the installation of a legal government, she said, and expressed her conviction that the future will be bright with the civil strife halted and an independent government put in place.

Yusuf Shersi, 60, said the Ethiopia government and the public at large, as they are well informed about the plight of the Somali people should consolidate efforts they have been exerting to restore peace and stability in Somalia.

All political parties should give priority to alleviating the misery of the people, another refugee, a veteran colonel under Said Barre said.

Ethiopia;
Schools Under Construction and Renovation


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The education department of West Shoa Zone said that 23 schools are under construction and renovation with anoutlay of more than 14 million birr.

According to Ato Tesfaye Jale, head of the department, the fund for the projects was obtained from the government, the Swedish International Development Agency (SIDA) and the African Development Bank (ADB).

Of the schools under construction, six are in rural areas that had no schools earlier, the head added.

January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
Potable Water Projects Under Way in Regions


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

REGIONS (ENA) - The water, mineral and energy department of Awi Zone disclosed that 21 different potable water projects are under way in four woredas of the Amhara Regional State.

Head of plan, design and construction inspection service in the department said the projects expected to benefit over 39,000 people include 13 hand- pumped and medium water wells, as well as seven springs. 

The projects being carried out at a cost of 2 million birr, in addition to labour and material contribution by the public are well under way.

Region supplies quality hides to central market

AYSSAITA (ENA) - Over 71,000 hides and skins were supplied to the central market during the past six months from Zone one in Afar Regional State, the zonal agricultural department reported.

According to the department, skins and hides supplied to the central market from the zone has increased by 39 percent when compared to the item dispatched the previous year.

It ascribed the rise in the supply to the successful control over illegal trade of the item.

Enterprise harvests 25,000 quintals of cotton

AWASSA (ENA) - The Brale Agricultural Development Enterprise, a privately owned agro-venture in South Omo Zone, has harvested 25,000 quintals of cotton this harvest season, its general manager said.

The enterprise obtained the harvest from the cultivation of 850 hectares of land, Ato Getachew Mulugeta, the general manager said.

The enterprise, which supplies cotton to the Akaki, Awassa and Arba Minch textile factories, intends to triple the area under cultivation and produce fruits and vegetables and oil seeds for export and the domestic market.

Ethiopia;
Lemon said scarce in Addis


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 93 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopian Horticultural Enterprise said scarcity of lemon in the capital surfaced some weeks back as it is being used as raw material by Mertifactory under the Uper Awash Agro-industry.

Some merchants approached by ENA reporters said the average price of a kilo of lemon which was only 1.50 birr a month ago has now soared to 5 birr, a piece of lemon costing 0.40 birr.

277 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
2,044 Women Treated For Abortion Related Problems


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MAKALLE (ENA) - The Tigray Regional Health Bureau reported that 2,044 mothers in the region were treated for sicknesses that resulted from abortions.

The bureau disclosed at a panel discussion that most of the women were single and between the ages of 15 and 28. 

Dr. Mengiste Mesfin, head of communicable diseases prevention and control department in the bureau told the panel that 12 percent of the victim who report to health institutions have died.

He said out of the 700 women who undergone gynaecological examinations in Makalle Hospital last year, 230 were found to have sustained internal injuries in the process of abortion.

In order to tackle the problem orientations are being given in connection with family planning services in 192 health institutions in the region, it was reported.

Traditional birth attendants assigned in more than 900 health stations were trained and they in turn have educated more than 20,000 mothers it was learnt.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
Police Apprehend 289 Alleged Criminals


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Region 14 Police Commission disclosed that it has arrested 289 alleged criminals in a major crack down during the past 10 days in the capital.

The commission said that the suspects, most of whom were reportedly operating under 91 criminals gangs, were engaged in a variety of criminal activities, including car theft, burglary and robbery. 

Most of the suspects had several criminal records, and are escapes, according to the commission.

Investigations have so far revealed that at least 91 criminal gangs are operating in Addis Ababa, police said.

Various electronic equipment, motors, parts, tyres, clothes and other looted goods were also seized from the suspects along with pistols and daggers reportedly used by the suspects, the commission said.

Residents of the capital have been cooperative during the operation, which is still going on, the commission said, adding that the community has an important role in the prevention and control of crime by exposing criminals.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court Hears Testimonies Of Prosecution Witnesses


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - One of the prosecution witnesses testifying against the former Derg officials told the Federal High Court yesterday that he was taken hosptal where he was receiving treatment and tortured for the fifth time while his hands and egs were bandaged for wounds he had suffered earlier.

The 117th prosecution witness said he was arrested and repeatedly tortured on January 15, 1978 in Higher 3 without arrest warrant for allegedly hiding arms and killing a man. The witness said his nails were damaged and finger broken during the torture. 

"A policeman tied my neck with an electric wire till my windpipe was blocked and harrassed me, saying unless you confess the truth you will be killed this way," the witness said.

He said his bladder was damaged under torture inflicted by drunk policemen.

The witness said he was permitted to go to the Black Lion Hospital for treatment as the stench from tortured victims became unbearable. He, However, was repeatedly tortured while on treatment and the hospital finally refused to admit him he said.

The witness said he was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment without appearing before the court of law but was released after serving his term for eight years following an amnesty by the government as officials has told him later.

The witness showed the scars he sustained and the damages inflicted on his body to the court.

The 118th witness said he was also arrested in January 1978 by members of the Revolution Squad and was made to visit victims of torture lying facedown with wounds on their back to later join their ranks.)

He said, while he was in prison, a policeman came on the morrow of the night prisoners were taken from the prison and told them that measures were taken against the inmates so as to dismantle the organizational structure of the EPRP, and named inmates whom he said did not return to their cells after they were called out.

He said he was arrested without arrest warrant and imprisoned for ten-years without appearing before court.

The 115th witness said his brother was jailed in different prisons and used to visit him but he was told later that he was not there and had never seen him since then.

Lawyers of the defendants have cross-examined the 117th and 118th witnesses.

The hearing was adjourned until January 21, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


280 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
'First-Ever' Organized Church Disturbances Incitement Ever


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 920 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Some elders have expressed grave concern over the recent trend of inciting organized disturbances within church precincts here during prayer services which the Secretary of the Holy Synod described ad "the first ever scandalous act in the 2000-year history of the EOC," Representatives of the group behind the commotion have meanwhile said that they would press ahead till their demands are met.

Approached by journalists here on Wednesday, Fitawrari Negash Worku said: " Act of violence such as that witnessed at the St. Stephen's Church on January 9 was disgraceful in a country noted for its long history of religious tolerance and forbearance." Another elder, Ato Gena Desta, stated that he was very much saddened to learn of such unseemly behaviour at a place of worship. The two people feared eventual church-laity disunity if the trend is allowed to run its course. 

The Secretary of the Holy Synod, His Grace Abune Gerima, said that the Questions which the group which illegally organized itself under " Mahberehawariyat" raised were mere rumour and described the means employed to get their voice heard as quite simply horrendous.

He said that contrary to EOC procedures, the so-called opposition group named itself the law maker and tried to impose its "strictures" on the Holy Synod.

Some of the demands of the self-styled "Maherehawariyat" included: Alleged maladministration and nepotism within the EOC be immediately ended; hemits be allowed to preach in any sanctuary in the metropolis; the patriarch should be accountable to the Holy Synod and not vice versa; the church establishment admit that electing a new patriarch while his predecessor is alive is against the law of the church.

"They brought these and similar other questions to my office and, after scrutinising each, I told them that they were all fabrications and not-worth presenting to the Holy Synod," said Abune Gerima, adding that they ultimately resorted to violence.

According to His Grace, religion was only a cover-up and the motive behind their acts was something else.

"The surprising thing is that some of the people opposed to the appointment of Abune Paulos and claiming that the Holy Synod is accountable to the patriarch are the very ones who endorsed his holiness's assumption of office by their signature and who very well know that he is accountable to the Holy Synod."

Melake Selam T/medhin G/Selassie, administrator of the St.Stephen's Church, Lique Tebebet Taddese Wube, who was with the patriarch when the attempt on the latter's life was made, as well as Deacon Alemseged Wosene, who got his left hand stabbed in the fracas, all said that while religious service was going on there some people shouted "We've got questions" from the right side. The assailant meanwhile came from the left side waving his meter-long sword, aimed it at the Patriarch's head but fell on the ground for he lost his balance. They said that on a second attempt, the assailant was shot dead from a distance.

Two policemen on duty said that members of the said group were hurling an avalanche of stones to where His Holiness the Patriarch was seated, and many apparently confused laity were running for cover.

Members of "Mahberehawariyat" said, on the other hand, that reinstatement of some clergymen who have been dismissed and allowing hermits to preach at any church will settle the issue.

Aba Afework Mersa, who claimed to have been an administrator of a sanctuary in Wollo and who said he was fired from his post by the personal order of the Patriarch, said that he joined the group to seek reinstatement. Asked if the association they formed has a legal status, he said it was the democratic right of every citizen to form any such society.

Another interviewee, Hermit Gebre-Mariam Gebeyehu, said that to be allowed to preach in any church remains his critical demand.

His Grace Abune Gerima said earlier that for any clergyman to be allowed to preach, he must first be certified of his competence.

Tesfaye Wondimu, who this reporter very well knows to be one of the scoundrels and drunkards in the metropolis, is also a member of the association. He accuses the patriarch of introducing " a Roman Catholic doctrine" in to the EOC.

"Mahberehawariyat" was founded by 15 members, including a retired colonel, and is chaired by Hermit G/Meskel H/Meskel who was once accused of inciting similar disturbances in and around churches in the the city.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
President Says Sudan Creates Own Political Problems


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - President Negasso Gidada said Ethiopia is not responsible for the political problem in the Sudan.

During talks yesterday with the departing Ambassador of Lesotho, J.T. Mestings, who took leave of him at the end of his tour of duty in Ethiopia, President Negasso said the instability in the Sudan is the creation of the Sudanese government which failed to pay due attention to efforts being exerted by member countries of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) including Ethiopia to peacefully solve the problem in that country. 

The provocative activities by the Sudanese governmental aimed at establizing neighbouring countries, urging and organizing extremist Islamist groups as is evident now, are not expected of a neighbouring country, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs quoted Dr. Negasso as saying.

He further said Sudan is engaged in disrupting peace in neighbouring countries including Ethiopia, at a time when Ethiopia is striving to do everything in her capacity to defuse the conflict in that country.

President Negasso said instability in neighbouring countries has a negative effect be it directly or indirectly and subsequently, Ethiopia has continued in its efforts to bring about peace in the Sudan and other countries in Africa, according to the spokesman.

The president said Ethiopia is bracing to export certain types of grains abroad as the country's food self-sufficiency programme has born fruit.

Ambassador Mestings on his part said that he was impressed by Ethiopia's economic achievements in the last five years.

The ambassador commended measures the Ethiopian government has taken to seeking peaceful solutions to political problems in Somalia and countries of the Great Lakes Region.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


282 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's Credit Service Grows


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) yesterday said that the amount of credit development agencies receive has increased as the government began reducing its domestic debts since the introduction of market economy in the country.

Ato Yohannes Ayalew, a senior research officer in the economic research department of the bank, told ENA that the amount of credit given last year to development agencies mainly to the private sector had increased because the government managed to reduce its debt by 2 billion birr last year from the total package of 9.8 billion birr registered a year before.

He said, the credit the private sector received in 1983 E.C., that is before the economic reform, was 391.6 million birr, adding that the amount offered for a similar purpose in 1988 had reached 5.4 billion birr owning the reduction of government domestic debts. 

Asked why the rise in the amount of credit does not entail inflation, Ato Yohannes said inflation was minimized because the increase in the fund set aside for credit is below the economic development and the reduction in government domestic debts decreased the amount of money in circulation.

The credit policy of the country was prepared in such a way that it could go along with the new market economy, discouraging credit discrimination prevalent during the previous command economic policy and normalising the credit rate with the rate of inflation, he said.

He also said the purpose of the policy includes the transfer of credit the government used to take for non-profit-making activities for the benefit of the privet ctor.

The research of said government intervention in providing credit services is now avoided and the 3 percent interest rate the government used to pay previously is also decided to be determined by the market.

Asked whether or not the similarity in the interest rate for all economic sectors could affect the agricultural sector, he said the low interest rate state farms and co-operatives' used to enjoy was loss incurring, adding that it would be possible to allocate the limited credit resource to fruitful sectors only when a similar interest rate is enforced in all the economic sectors.

Before the enforcement of the economic reform programme the government's domestic debt was 8.9 percent of the gross domestic product. However, the percentage dropped to only 1.9 in 1986 E.C., the research officer explained.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


283 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian Company to Set Up Sweets Factory


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopia Maize and Agro-industry Company, a private venture, announced that it has completed a study to set up a factory producing raw materials for the processing of sweets, drinks, textiles, medicines and edible oil from maize with a capital close to 150 million birr.

When the factory to be constructed at Kality area is completed it will produce sweet substances like glucose and fructose, crude oil from maize as well as fodder from the by-product, General Manager of the company, Dr. Birhanu Nega said. 

The construction of the factory will begin within the coming six months and takes a year and a half to complete, Dr. Birhanu told ENA reporters.

Upon commencement of production, the factory for sometime will use about half a million quintals of maize, he said, adding the amount of maize to be used by the factory may stabilise the price of maize in the market.

He indicated the possibility that the factory could help save the huge foreign currency expanded for the purchase of starches and sweet glucose.

He also disclosed the factory's plan to export 30 to 40 percent of its produces earning additional hard currency to the country. The company will also engage in maize farming.

The activities of the company will subsequently encourage the establishment of other factories which can use the produces of the factory as raw material, he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
House Speaker Commends Prison Administration


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Speaker of the House of Peoples Representatives, Ato Dawit Yohannes, yesterday commended the overall working procedures of the Region 14 Prison Administration saying: "The management and staff of the prison service are doing everything to ensure that the rights of prisoners are respected in accordance with the dictates of the constitution FDRE."

In a remark that was made after visiting the ins and outs of the Region 14 Central Prison together with members of the House sub-committee responsible for police and prisons, women's' affairs and legal matters. Ato Dawit said that though it can't be said that there are no problems or difficulties in the activities of the prison, there is every reason to believe that the administration has done its best to cater to the rights of the inmates in accordance with the country's capacity to provide the necessary inputs.

The half-day visit by the Mps was intended to get first-hand information about and personally observe the conditions of the prison and find out whether things are going smoothly there, or as one of them put it, "to see whether the articles of the constitution which provide for the protection of the human rights of prisoners or those stipulated by international laws with respect to the same are implemented in the proper manner." 

It was noted that this practice of getting eye-witness accounts of the performances of different executing agencies by Mps are a marked departure from the familiar one of hearing reports from executives of agencies and will continue to be put into effect at different times. Each and every executing agency will henceforth be falling under close scrutiny, one deputy said. Far from being able to get in touch with the real feelings and interests of the general mass of people benefiting from these agencies, this close following by Mps will made the executive agencies accomplish their tasks with utmost energy and honest, it was noted.

On arrival at the central prison, the deputies first listened to the head of the Central Prison Bureau, Ato Seifu Ahmed, who said that the facility suffered huge property losses and lootings at the collapse of the Derg but has then been taking all measures to not only rehabilitate itself in material services but also reorganize its staff.

He added that various changes have been made, especially since the last two years, to improve the living conditions of the prisoners and that the effort in this regard will continue.

The visitors were also briefed about the general picture of the prison by two managerial staff of the prison who spoke of the "relatively" comfortable living conditions the inmates are now leading as compared with the past. While most prisoners slept on rags of their own in the past, they are now provided with sponge mattresses. They also noted that health, education and other facilities were made available to prisoners, though not up to adequate standards, and special attention was paid to women prisoners. The deputies later posed various questions to the staff and were given due explanations.

The Mps then toured nearly all sections of the prison, visited with admiration different wood products and artistic works produced by the prisoners and also spoke with them about their conditions in the prison . Most prisoners said they were "confortable" with the conditions but appealed to the government to provide more support for the self help projects they undertake so that more prisoners will participate and acquire new skills either in handicrafts or other fields of work so as to be self-supporting citizens when they end their period of internment.

Company to set up 150 min birr factory

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ethiopia Maize and Agro-industry Company, a private venture, announced that it has completed a study to set up a factory producing raw materials for the processing of sweets, drinks, textiles, medicines and edible oil from maize with a capital close to 150 million birr.

When the factory to be constructed at Kality area is completed it will produce sweet substances like glucose and fructose, crude oil from maize as well as fodder from the by-product, General Manager of the company, Dr. Birhanu Nega said.

The construction of the factory will begin within the coming six months and takes a year and a half to complete, Dr. Birhanu told ENA reporters.

Upon commencement of production, the factory for sometime will use about half a million quintals of maize, he said, adding the amount of maize to be used by the factory may stabilise the price of maize in the market.

He indicated the possibility that the factory could help save the huge foreign currency expanded for the purchase of starches and sweet glucose.

He also disclosed the factory's plan to export 30 to 40 percent of its produces earning additional hard currency to the country. The company will also engage in maize farming.

The activities of the company will subsequently encourage the establishment of other factories which can use the produces of the factory as raw material, he said.

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) yesterday said that the amount of credit development agencies receive has increased as the government began reducing its domestic debts since the introduction of market economy in the country.

Ato Yohannes Ayalew, a senior research officer in the economic research department of the bank, told ENA that the amount of credit given last year to development agencies mainly to the private sector had increased because the government managed to reduce its debt by 2 billion birr last year from the total package of 9.8 billion birr registered a year before.

He said, the credit the private sector received in 1983 E.C., that is before the economic reform, was 391.6 million birr, adding that the amount offered for a similar purpose in 1988 had reached 5.4 billion birr owning the reduction of government domestic debts.

Asked why the rise in the amount of credit does not entail inflation, Ato Yohannes said inflation was minimized because the increase in the fund set aside for credit is below the economic development and the reduction in government domestic debts decreased the amount of money in circulation.

The credit policy of the country was prepared in such a way that it could go along with the new market economy, discouraging credit discrimination prevalent during the previous command economic policy and normalising the credit rate with the rate of inflation, he said.

he also said the purpose of the policy includes the transfer of credit the government used to take for non-profit-making activities for the benefit of the privet ctor.

The research of r said government intervention in providing credit services is now avoided and the 3 percent interest rate the government used to pay previously is also decided to be determined by the market.

Asked whether or not the similarity in the interest rate for all economic sectors could affect the agricultural sector, he said the low interest rate state farms and co-operatives' used to enjoy was loss incurring, adding that it would be possible to allocate the limited credit resource to fruitful sectors only when a similar interest rate is enforced in all the economic sectors.

Before the enforcement of the economic reform programme the government's domestic debt was 8.9 percent of the gross domestic product. However, the percentage dropped to only 1.9 in 1986 E.C., the research officer explained.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


285 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
Sudan an Obstacle, says Minister


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The extremist government of the National Islamic Front (NIF) in Khartoum has been a major obstacle to implementing Ethiopia's foreign policy which takes the promotion of good neighbourliness has one of its prominent objectives. Minister of Foreign Affairs of the FDRE said.

Speaking at a seminar convened here to discuss Ethiopia's new foreign policy, Ato Seyoum Mesfin said Ethiopia has tried its best to ward off infiltrates and teach a lesson the NIF administration which has consistently been engaged in provocative activities against Ethiopia by urging and organizing anti-peace elements. 

One notable testimony to the unfriendly activities of the Sudanese authorities against Ethiopia, the minister recalled, is the assassination attempt on President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Addis Ababa by a group backed by the NIF administration.

Ethiopia has consistently lobbied urging the United Nations and the OAU to take proper action that the crime calls for, Ato Seyoum noted.

Even though the case is still on the agenda of the Security Council, Ato Seyoum said that the manner in which it is being handled has not so far made Sudan abide by international laws.

The NIF administration has in fact intensified its destabilizing activities in the region and is urging for a jihad on Ethiopia and other countries, the minister said.

He added that member states of the Inter-governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) must not let Sudan's unbecoming engagements hamper their activities,.

Ethiopia is expected to give all the necessary support to IGAD's initiatives to bring about lasting peace in Sudan, said the minister.

With regard to Ethiopia's foreign relations, Ato Seyoum said Ethiopia has successfully consolidated her ties with neighbouring countries despite the obstacles from the Sudanese side.

At the continental level and beyond, the nation has won the friendship of many countries and development partners in the process, he said.

The country has also honoured her commitment to Africa, one instance being the dispatching of a contingent of her army to Rwanda to ensure peace in that country, he pointed out.

Ato Seyoum, however, noted that inspite of improved relations with Kuwait and Qatar, the task of consolidating ties with the Gulf countries leaves a lot to be desired.

LANGUAGE: English

286 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Somalia;
NSC Co-Chairmen Meet the press


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Addis Ababa - After six years of fratricidal war and immense blood-shed which failed to yield to repeated arbitration from both the continental and the world bodies, faction leaders of war-torn Somalia now seem to have realised beyond any doubt that the key to the normalisation's of situations in their country is within their hands.

The formation, recently, of the National Salvation Council (NSC following an intensive High Level Consultation at Sodere is a clear indication of their determination to relieve the sufferings of their people and to once again reconstitute the country into a functioning nation.)

Three days after the signing of the historic agreement, the five co- chairmen of the 41 member Council met the local press and correspondents at the Ghion Hotel on 6 January, during which they answered to a number of questions on various issues, including the sustainability of the agreement. following is the full text of the press conference.

Question:- Since the inauguration of the NSC there have been hostile reactions in Somalia against your agreement, particularly from Hussein Ideed's group and Al-Itihad. What will be your response? 

Answer:- It is not surprising to hear such a reaction from Hussein Idded. He was invited like any other faction leader to join us in the High Level Consultation so that we can together promote the cause of peace in Somalia, but refused. But we still hope that he will cone day reconsider his present stand and join the council.

Question:- Any guarantee that your agreements now will not fail as was the case in the past?

Answer:- In the past it was not uncommon to see us disperse after agreements were signed. Now, things are very different. Our people are tired of war and blood-shed. They need peace. They want to lead a new life. And we are here to reflect their wishes and aspirations. And unlike in the past, we not only signed the agreement but worked out a detailed strategy of implementation as well. as to our determination, you can read if from our faces.

Question:- A member of the Al-Itihad military command said in Mogadishu that Al-Itihad would not recognise and agreement that does not include the values of Islam. Would you kindly comment on this?

Answer:- We don't want Al-Itihad to recognise us. We even doubt its very existence; we don't recognise it as a legal organisation at all. We only know that Al-Itihad is a terrorist gang who wants to reimmerse Somalia in a new form of blood-shed and to destabilise the entire region in the name of Islam. But the fact remains that the Somali people are 100% Muslims and they don't want a new Messiah to bring the message. We know the teachings of Islam. It accepts neither violence nor the use of instruments of coercion. So we Strongly warn Al-Itihad and the countries behind its disruptive actions to refrain from destabilising the region. What we have achieved so far and the realisation of our declaration entirely depend on the will of our people, not on Al-Itihad's good will. And we are confident that we have got the trust of the majority of the Somali people.

Question:- do you think Al-Itihad is a Somali organisation?

Answer:- We truly believe that Al-Itihad's actions are being directed by foreign countries. Though we don't feel appropriate to mention their names now, one day we will talk face to face with the countries involved. We have got evidences proving their backing to Al-Itihad.

Question:- What is the position of the factions represented in the NSC as regards Ethiopia's military action against Al-Itihad both in its own soil and across border?

Answer:- We are completely against any kind of military confrontation which jeopardises the security of the region. We are for the sovereignty and security of Somalia and we will never encourage any country to violate our sovereignty. but we also recognise that every nation has got the right to defend itself whenever its internal security and stability are jeopardised.

Question:- Some factions represented in the council have been accused of allegedly receiving arms from Ethiopia. Is it true?

Answer:- It is not all true that Ethiopia has ever supplied military hardware to any of the factions represented here. The allegation is not only baseless but also has an ulterior motive to divert the attention of the world from the main issue of national reconciliation which we have embarked on. Ethiopia is committed to help the Somalis regain peace and cannot be a promoter of conflict in any way. It has, since 1992, been exerting tireless efforts to help bring peace and reconciliation in Somalia. In Somalia, as you know, we have got an arsenal that could last, say for 10 years hence. We need someone to disarm us. Those who have been spreading this and other unsubstantiated allegations are the same people who rebuffed the call to participate in the efforts underway for peace and reconciliation.

Question:- Could you give an overview of your main tasks during your 6- month term of office?

Answer:- The tasks ahead are serious and challenging ones. They are numerous that we cannot list them all now. But the main ones include: drafting a transitional national charter which will serve as the basic constitutional document throughout the transitional period, installing transitional government representing all the Somali people, work for the restoration of peace and stability in areas where conflicts still prevail, and eventually embark on inter-clan and inter-community reconciliation among our people.

Question:- In case you fail to achieve your objectives by employing peaceful means and if Husein Ideed launches an attack against one of the factions represented in the council, would you resort to military action?

Answer:- We are peace-oriented, basically. It's not in our plan to use military action as a means of realising the provisions of our agreement. We will employ or deploy peaceful means and dialogue to settle outstanding political differences. But this council is today a national institution which unifies most of the political movements in the country which represent the majority of the Somali people. An attack against any of the factions under the umbrella of the NSC means an attack against the entire institution, and the answer will be collective self-defence.

Question:- Can we take for granted that the council will be the legitimate representative of the people of Somalia in future continental as well as international meetings and conferences?

Answer:- Yes, we very much hope so.

Question:- what will the NSC's relations with the Arab world like?

Answer:- We are Muslims, we are a member of the Arab League, so we have traditional, religious and historical ties with the Arab world. During the past 6 years of civil strife in our country, the contribution of the Arab world has been far less than that we expected of it. And we don't know why this happened. But we still hope that that part of the world in particular will greatly contribute toward the reconstruction of Somalia.

Question:- What will be the function of the office that you are going to open in Addis Ababa?

Answer:- The office we are going to open in Addis Ababa will be an extension of our headquarters in Mogadishu and will have a Liaison character.

Question:- Is your council a clan based institution or one based on political views?

Answer:- We are political movements and we are clan based movements. Accepting our realities, we have used both the political instrument and the clan instrument to achieve our goal. In the past, we used to be clan- sensitive. But the realities today have taught us and compelled us to devise a way to merge the two together so that they can be viable instruments for political end.

Africa News


January 20, 1997


East Africa;
IGAD Presents Project Proposals to Donor Countries


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The revitalised Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) has presented 17 development project proposals to donor countries with a view to improving the economic conditions of members states, senior expert in the Ministry of Economic Development and Cooperation said.

Ato Moges Belayneh said the project proposals prepared by IGAD focus on the expansion of infrastructures, food self-sufficiency, environmental protection and conflict resolution. 

The proposals have enjoyed the approval of donor countries, he said, adding implementation studies are being carried out by agencies of donor states. About 15 of the total projects will directly benefit Ethiopia, the expert added.

The projects prepared by IGAD, which revitalised itself earlier include the construction of asphalt roads linking Gondar, Humera Barentu and Gedarit, renovation of the Ethio-Djibouti railway stations, as well as the expansion of telephone service in Addis Ababa, Dessie, Assab, Djibouti, Berahera, And Hargesa, Ato Moges said.

According to the expert, the execution of projects will be mostly financed by donor states and to this end heads of agencies of donor countries have begun discussing policy issues with officials in the IGAD.

He said the construction of roads and the installation of railway tracks could begin very soon through the European Union while other projects are waiting the completion of implementation studies being carried out by donor countries.

Member states of IGAD are Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Kenya Somalia, Sudan and Uganda.

The authority was revitalised in 1995 in such a way that it could bring about positive changes in promoting sustainable development and economic co- operation among member states.

IGAD was first established in 1986 by Ethiopia, Sudan, Somalia, Djibouti and Kenya mainly to address problems related to drought and aridity, Ato Moges recalled.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

288 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
ESDL-ONLF to Merge Soon


BYLINE: Elias Abebe, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Ethiopian Somali Democratic League (ESDL) and the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF) have agreed to convene a Somali National Congress (SNC) with the objective of forming "a single democratic organisation that will assume the mandate of the political guidance and will work toward the fulfilment of the political, economic, and social objectives of Ethiopian Somali", a joint statement issued at the Ghion Hotel here yesterday said.

Speaking at a press conference attended by representatives of the FDRE and various political organisations, resident ambassadors and members of the local and international media, Dr. Abdulmajid Hussien, Minister of Transport and Communication, said that "this was the culmination of a job that started nine months ago with the intention of coming up with unified democratic political guidance which can best serve the interests of the people of the Somali National Regional State (SNRS)".

According to the joint statement, all institutions and activities whether political or otherwise of both organisations are to be co-ordinated during the three transitional months in the run-up to the convention of the SNC itself. 

The statement also said that an eleven- man Supreme Unification Committee (SUC), which has "the sole responsibility for legal political leadership and guidance" on behalf of both organisations, will form a technical committee to unify and co-ordinate the activities and offices of the two organisations at all levels. "The SUC will initiate support and supplement all peace keeping efforts in the SNRS in close cooperation with the Regional Administration, the Federal Government, community leaders and elders, and the people at large, "it was noted.

The supreme Unification Committee which will be set up by the two organisations "will also promote and help facilitate the execution of the woreda elections and will se to it that the Somali National Congress candidates are fielded on a unified ticket," the statement pointed out.

Dr. Abdulmegid Hussien, who is also chairman of ESDL, said during the Press Conference that " in effect the two organisations have taken the real steps forward and have already reached agreement on a common platform."

The US Ambassador here, Mr. David Shinn, expressed admiration for the move the two organisations have taken towards integration and said that their unification "will significantly contribute to peace and stability in the entire subregion."

The OAU representative on his part commended the "major and historic" steps being taken towards unification.


LOAD-DATE: January 27, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

289 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethiopia Warns Sudan Not to "Externalise" Internal Debacle


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Ministry of Foreign Affairs yesterday reminded the Sudanese government that no useful purpose would be served by striving to " externalise" its internal military debacle for which Ethiopia has absolutely no responsibility.

In a statement it issued in connection with Sudan's allegation that Ethiopia has shelled its two border towns the ministry said: "It is time for Sudan to realize that it cannot always succeed to fool others believing that fabrications accompanied with great fanfare would be given the benefit of the doubt and some credence by the international community."

The statement sited the call by the Sudanese government for general mobilisation and for jihad. "accompanied with the beating of the drums of war" following the reported take-over of Kurmuk by the Sudan People's Liberation Army as the latest futile attempt to shift responsibility onto others.

The ministry said an alibi is being sought by Khartum by accusing Ethiopia of involvement in military activities against Sudanese troops as often happens when the National Islamic Front suffers military defeat. 

Such accusations were evident in the past two years, it added.

No one who has closely followed the activities in foreign policy of the new Ethiopia can doubt the deep commitment of the country and its peoples to live in peace with its neighbours, including with the Sudan, the statement noted.

Ethiopia, despite frustrations encountered so far, will continue, along with other members of the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), to do whatever is practically possible to help in the resolution of the crisis in the Sudan, the ministry said.

Following is the full text of the statement.

"No one who has followed closely the activities in foreign policy of the new Ethiopia and of the Federal Democratic Republic can doubt the deep commitment of the country and its peoples to live in peace with its neighbours, including with the Sudan. Nor can it be neglected, including by Sudanese authorities, that Ethiopia has made all the necessary effort, within the framework of IGA, to assist in the search for peace in the Sudan. Despite the frustrations encountered so far, the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia will continue, alone with other members of IGAD, to do whatever is practically possible to help in the resolution of the crisis in the Sudan.

"On the other hand, it has also been obvious to all those who follow developments in our sub-region that the Sudanese authorities have shown little respect, not only to their own people, bus also to their neighbours, including to Ethiopia.

"Often this has been reflected in the most blatant forms of acts of destabilisation and betrayal of friend-ship and trust, one instance of which is still before the Security Council, Another time the insanity in Khartoum takes the from a call for Jihad against its neighbours, the latest example of which was a declaration issued by the representative of the Sudanese government in Mogadishu calling for jihad against Ethiopia.

There have still been other occasions when the Sudanese authorities have deemed it useful to ascribe to others responsibilities for their domestic problems or for their military setbacks.

"The latest such attempt to shift responsibility onto others by Sudanese authorities which is also accompanied with the beating of the drums of war, with a call for general mobilisation and for jihad has taken place on 5 January, 1997, following the reported take-over of Kurmuk by the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army. As often happens when the National Islamic Front suffers military defeat, an alibi is being sought by Kahrtoum by accusing Ethiopia of involvement in military activities against, Sudanese troops. It is to be expected that this accusation would be taken by the National Islamic Front government to the Security Council with the additional aim of diverting the attention of the council from the unfinished business before it inconnection with a proven case of state sponsored terrorism and an assassination attempt by Sudanese authorities against a head of state.

"At the time of the release of this press statement the sabre rattling was continuing in Khartoum and the National Islamic front authorities were feverishly trying to convince the Sudanese people and the international community that their apparent military debacle was of Ethiopia's making. No one knows better than the Sudanese authorities themselves that the accusation has no bases and that Ethiopia has no hand in what is obviously a military setback suffered by the authorities in Kartoum. It is to be noted that this is not the first time that Sudanese accusatory finger was pointed at Ethiopia over the past two years whenever similar military defeats have been suffered by Sudanese authorities.

"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia wishes to remind the Sudanese authorities that no useful purpose would be served by striving to externalise what they know too well is an internal military debacle for which Ethiopia has absolutely no responsibility. It is time for the Sudanese authorities to realise that they cannot always succeed to fool others, and to dustup believing that fabrications accompanied with great fanfare would be given the benefit of the doubt and some credence by the international community. This would only hurt the Sudan and nor would it be in the interest of peace in our subregion".

Africa News


January 20, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (1/13 - 1/19)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Geneva - 14.01.97 Political prisoners

The F. Polisario delivers to the independant jurist of MINURSO, Mr. Emmanuel Roucounas, a list of political prisoners brought up to date by the AFAPREDESA.

15.01.97 Appeal for a "disappeared" Sahrawi

Amnesty International USA's Freedom Writers Network appeals this month to King Hassan of Morocco in the case of Baba ould Ahmed ould Abderrahman who was an electrician for a Spanish mining company when he "disappeared" in October 1975 following his arrest by the Moroccan security forces near Bir Enzaran in Western Sahara. Evoking the liberation in 1991 of hundreds of " disappeared" people who had been held in secret detention centers for more than a decade, the organization believes that Baba ould Ahmed ould Abderrahman may also be held in a secret detention center and asks for his immediate liberation, unless he is charged with a recognizably criminal offense. 

19.01.97 Diplomatic restart

At the beginning of the new year, the Sahrawi responsible for the Referendum, Mr. Bachir Mustafa Sayed, begins an important diplomatic tour including the first meeting with the new UN Secretary General mid-February. During his visit in Switzerland from January 19 to 21, he will be wellcome at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Cooperation at Berne and meet members of the Parliamentary Committee of Foreign Affairs. Questionned about the aims of his visit, Mr. Sayed answers that the first goal is to look for support in this delicate stage of the beginning negociations with Morocco, particularly to find mediators and a neutral place for the meetings. He adds that the Sahrawis put great trust in Switzerland, they know for its neutrality and tradition of mediation, and he recalls that the commitment of Ambassador Manz and the work of the Swiss Medical Unit in Western Sahara after the cease-fire have been very appreciated.
