Africa News


January 21, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Tanzania Heads Group Of 77


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 755 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Tanzania has assumed the chairmanship of the New York-based Group of 77 developing countries and China.

The permanent representative of Tanzania to the United Nations, Daudi Mwakawago, took over the mantle of office from his Costa Rican counterpart, Fernando Berrocal Soto, at a brief ceremony Tuesday in New York. 

Mwakawago will preside over the group, which was established in 1964 to foster economic cooperation in the developing world, for one year. Tanzania was elected, by acclamation, to the group's chairmanship in October in New York.

The group has 132 members from Africa, Asia, South and Central America, and the Caribbean.

Meanwhile, the secretary-general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, has described the group as "the moving spirit" in the U.N. in the areas of economic and social development.

In a speech at the ceremony, Annan said that the group had the responsibility of representing the interests, the hopes and the aspirations of the majority of the world's peoples.

"The group has always been a vital springboard for new development ideas and initiative.

"Your work has enabled the U.N. to respond positively to the challenges of a rapidly changing international economic and social environment," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ghana;
Test-tube Triplets Delivered In Ghana


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

TEMA, Ghana (PANA) - A set of triplets were delivered Monday to a 37-year- old woman at the Pro Vita Specialist Hospital at Tema through in-vitro fertilization (IVF).

This method of fertilization is the process whereby pregnancy is effected through the injection of a fertilized embryo into the womb through artificial insemination. 

The triplets, all boys weighing 2.4, 2.1 and 1.6 kilograms, were delivered by Caesarian section by the medical director of the hospital, Dr Joe Mainoo.

He told the media that mother and children were all doing well. However, he said that the baby with the least weight would be put under intensive care for an unspecified period.

Mainoo said the hospital has made eight IVF deliveries since 1995. These included the triplets, and other deliveries of five girls and six boys.

He put the cost of this delivery method at 2.6 million cedis or the equivalent of 1,500 U.S. dollars, excluding the cost of drugs which, he said, were very expensive.

The name of the parents were not disclosed. Mainoo said the couple had, for the past 17 years, sought in vain for a child before they were put on the IVF programme.

Mainoo said the fertilization method becomes necessary when normal conception becomes impossible as a result of blockage of the fallopian tubes.

A diversion will, therefore, have to be made through IVF, he said, whereby the sperms of the man and the egg of the woman are collected and fertilized in a test tube for between 40 and 72 hours before being implanted into the womb.

Mainoo said the pregnancy of the woman lasted 34 weeks and three days. He had expected the pregnancy to have travelled 36 weeks but had to deliver her when she started showing labor pains Sunday.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Mozambique;
Mozambican Army Arrests


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - At lease 18 officers and men of the Mozambican Defence Force have been arrested by the military police on suspicion of involvement in the theft of 83 million meticais (about 7,200 U.S. dollars) and the falsification of documents in the center and south of the country.

A military spokesman told the Mozambican news agency, AIM, that the thefts were discovered by the military's internal auditing services.

The main problem detected was at the Maputo Military Driving School. Several of the detained are accused of stealing 62 million meticais from the school, selling military driving licenses, falsifying the school's wage scale, and illegally selling fuel belonging to the armed forces in the period from June to December 1996. 

There was also theft within the military police. In the Maputo branch of the military police, 14 million meticais, intended to pay wages for October, went missing.

A similar theft occurred in the Southern Regional Military Command, where seven million meticais, the October wages for several civilian staff, were stolen.

To explain the disappearance of the wages, those in charge of the money said they were attacked by armed thieves on the way from the bank to the military units concerned and were forced to hand the cash over.

AIM quoted an unnamed military spokesman as saying that, even if this were true, it did not prove the innocence of those detained, since it meant they had disobeyed the army's security norms for the transport of money.

The military audit also detected forged signatures on the wage sheets of a brigade stationed at Chimoio, capital of the central province of Manica.

All those accused have been confined to their units, while the investigations continue. The military police intend to bring the cases to court.

The internal audit is continuing, in order to discover if there are any further cases of theft or misuse of funds.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


South Africa;
Israel, South Africa Relations To Remain, Says Envoy


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Israel has no intention of cutting its ties with South Africa and will retain friendly relations with Pretoria in the future, an official of the Israeli Embassy has said.

"We enjoy a good relationship with South Africa, and we wish to maintain that," said Zeev Luria, the Israeli Embassy political counsellor.

"But I want to reiterate that we are opposed to a South African arms deal with Syria because it could jeopardize the fragile peace process in the Middle East," he added. 

He was reacting to a statement Monday by the South African government that Pretoria would no longer maintain a pro-Israel bias in the Middle East.

Luria added that it was important to ensure that the peace process was strengthened instead of destabilized.

"We are doing all we can to change the government's mind, and intensive consultations and discussions with the South African Government are continuing," he said.

This official Israeli reaction follows Sunday's statement by Deputy President Thabo Mbeki that the new South Africa had scrapped the former government's pro-Israel bias in the Middle East.

"We don't follow a policy in the Middle East such as the policy that was followed by the previous regime," he said, "which was to form an alliance with Israel and be hostile to the rest of the countries in the region."

Meanwhile, the opposition National Party has appealed to Mbeki to veto the cabinet's provisional approval of a 650-million-U.S.-dollar arms deal involving the sale of tank-sighting equipment to Syria.

In a statement in Cape Town on Monday, National Party foreign affairs spokesman Boy Geldenhuys said: "As the future president of South Africa, Mr. Mbeki dare not allow the interests of South Africa and all its people to be sabotaged by politically-driven, ill-considered decisions by the African National Congress."

The South African Cabinet is scheduled to discuss the entire question of the proposed Syrian arms deal at its first meeting of the year, Wednesday.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


United States and Africa;
South Africa Accuses United States Of Bullying


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The African National Congress (ANC), the dominant party in South Africa's first post-apartheid government, has accused the United States of bullyboy tactics and hypocrisy for threatening Pretoria over its proposed 650-million-U.S. dollar arms sale to Syria.

Acting ANC secretary-general Cheryl Carolus told a news conference Monday that the United States was trying to force South Africa into a biased policy in the Middle East by favoring Israel over the Arab states.

"We take strong exception to any country acting like a bullyboy in trying to essentially usurp our own foreign policy-making capacity," she said. 

"The United States itself has contributed in a very biased way in the region and that in itself creates problems," she added. "It's really a bit much and self-righteous to then try to speak to other people about that."

These remarks echoed recent statements by South African President Nelson Mandela and Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. They said that South Africa would not be dictated to by any country and would make its own decision regarding arms sales.

This reaction followed last week's statement by the United States, threatening to cut off some 120-million dollars in aid if South Africa went ahead with the proposed deal to sell tank-sighting equipment to Syria.

In turn, South Africa has pointed out that an American defence contractor is involved in an at least one of three bids for the Syrian contract by companies in at least three European countries.

"That kind of hypocrisy of the United States -- to not do anything about that aspect of it -- we find quite disturbing and out of keeping with the role which we would hope that a major power such as the United States would play," Carolus.

She said South Africa was concerned that its actions should not upset the precarious balance in the Middle East.

"But we think the United States should also put its hand to its own bosom and take this question quite seriously," she added.

Carolus also criticized the manner in which the U.S. handled the matter. If the United States wanted clarification on the deal, she said, it could have used normal diplomatic channels rather than having "some petty government official standing up and attacking the sovereignty of another country."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
SA Music Videos Scoop Cannes Nominations


BYLINE: Charl Blignaut, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Johannesburg - SOUTH AFRICAN music videos have once again emerged in competition as the cream of the crop in Africa.

Six of the nine videos nominated for the R57 000 Best Music Video/Clip from Africa prize (Francophone countries excluded as they have their own award) at the highly influential annual Cannes Midem awards, hail from South Africa.

And of those six, Devereux-Harris and Associates, a Johannesburg film production house headed by Pam Devereux-Harris, has scooped three of the nominations. 

These are: Lucky Dube's I Want to Know What Love Is (directed by Kevin Yates); Woza Afrika's Buthetebele (directed by Lisa Brittan) and Tu Nokwe's Nyaka Nyaka (directed by Ivan Leathers).

In 1993 Devereux-Harris and Associates also won the Cannes Midem Best International Music Documentary Award with a film tracing the history of South African resistance pop, We've Got the Power, directed by Brittan. It was one of the more talked-about awards that year as it beat the acclaimed U2 Zoo Tour documentary to the prize.

Contacted this week, Devereux-Harris said, "It's a good thing South African music videos are being shown outside the territory. Hopefully this will open doors for young film-makers."

Other South African nominees are Mark Engels for his video of the Vicky Sampson song My African Dream; Melvin Khaoli and Life Morewane for their video of Buthi Hai Man by the new all-girl Soweto group Abo Babes and Lance Stehr for his Prophets of da City video, Understand Where I'm Coming From.

Engels has already won the 1996 Asami Best Video award and been a finalist in the 1996 Kora All Africa Music Awards for the same video.

When contacted, he said: "It stands to reason that South Africa has received so many nominations as we're the only sub- Saharan country with fully active film and music industries."

He added that in an industry renowned for its lack of budgets and tight work schedules, he and Devereux-Harris have steadily been targeting a highly specialised market and devoting themselves to the development of the medium.

Other nominees in the category include Zimbabwe's Tendai Mupfurutsa with Character; Cape Verde's Cesaria Evoria for her Petit Pays and R-Street for their song Cola Nha Terra.

Nominees in the same award for French- speaking African countries include Papa Wemba and Kofi Olomide; Ismael Lo; Youssou 'N Dour and Meiway.

The awards will be announced at a function in Cannes, France, on January 21 1997.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Sudan;
New US Foreign Policy Team Could be More Proactive Towards NIF


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

London - The announcement of the Clinton administration's new foreign policy team in December sent shock waves through the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime. Two of the four new appointees have first hand experience of the rogue regime's activities and are now in a position to do something about them. The appointees were: Ambassador Madeleine Albright as Secretary of State; Senator William Cohen as Secretary of Defence; former National Security Advisor Tony Lake as director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA); and Samuel Berger, as National Security Advisor. The new foreign policy team will have a far greater understanding of the situation in Sudan than any of its predecessors have done.

Understandably, the NIF regime greeted the appointments with apprehension and fear, and was tempted to make a knee-jerk response about the USA as the Great Satan. However, elements within the regime counselled caution and the NIF foreign minister, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, was instructed to send a perfunctory message of congratulations to Ambassador Albright, "wishing her well and looking forward to working closely together on matters of mutual concern." 

The NIF regime is perhaps correct to worry about the new appointments because in the past it has attempted to present itself as a regional superpower and knows that American foreign policy does affect events around the world. The NIF regime has attempted too to export its terrorism to the USA and members of the new foreign policy team should be well aware of the regime's criminal activities.

Ambassador Albright regularly dealt with the representatives of the NIF regime at the United Nations. She is on record when she visited Khartoum as President Clinton's special envoy, as telling the NIF leadership two years ago that if the rogue regime did not change its criminal ways and begin behaving as a responsible country ought to on the international scene, then others around the world would have to force the regime to change. Ms Albright knows full well that the changes have not taken place and now, as Secretary of State, she has the opportunity and power to make them happen. She will find documented evidence at the State Department of all the regime's crimes against the people of Sudan and the region . She will also inherit a team of young men and women who have put these crimes on the record over the past few years, and who will be pleased to help the new secretary of state act upon them.

Whilst it has never been the Gazette's practice to comment on appointments to the CIA or any other foreign intelligence agencies, former National Security Advisor Tony Lake brings a noteworthy knowledge of Africa to his new post at the CIA. It is to be hoped that he will use his experience in Africa as a young scholar and diplomat to devote some of the CIA's attention to the menace of the NIF regime.

Both Senator William Cohen at Defence and Samuel Berger at National Security are taking up positions in the two best informed departments of the US government with regards to the Sudanese conflict and the NIF regime. They would do well to continue with the administrators who covered the Sudanese situation during Mr Clinton's first administration.

Long Term Worries

The new appointments have come at a time when the USA is almost alone in recognizing the real menace presented by the NIF regime. If recent reports are to be believed, the USA is now prepared to move beyond words and to act practically to curb the rogue regime in Khartoum.

Recent media reports state that the administration has offered modest military assistance to the neighbouring countries to Sudan who have been targeted for destabilisation by the NIF regime. It is to be hoped that similar military assistance will also be offered to the Sudanese opposition which has recently opened up a further military front in Eastern Sudan. That would be the kind of help which would directly affect the regime. It is to be hoped too that the US administration's own considerations do not preclude such direct help to the Sudanese opposition.

It is heartening to note that the American media has begun to take a greater interest in the Sudanese conflict, and are urging the Clinton administration to adopt a more proactive stance. On 4 December the Washington Post newspaper published a strongly worded editorial in which it gave its support to current US policy towards Sudan and urged the international community to do even more:

"It is Sudan's distinction to be second probably only to Iran in propagating international terrorism and in subverting its weaker neighbours, all this by way of acting on the Khartoum regime's Islamic Fundamentalism tenets.

"It is the United Nations' shame to have demonstrated itself incompetent to deal with this authentic rogue state. Other African countries, including Egypt -whose president the Sudanese regime tried to murder last year - have appeased the regime, manufacturing considerations of African, Arab, or Islamic solidarity. Russia, China and France, from their seats on the Security Council, have devised one or another big power cause of convenience to protect Sudan from anything more that slaps on the wrist. As a result, the regime's external terrorism and subversion continue. So does its prosecution of long-standing internal religious war and its suppression of human rights.

"It is the Unites States' contribution to have accepted the implications of the United Nations' weak stance and to have sought out an alternative way to check Sudan's depredations. In a region grimly familiar with ethnic rivalries and cross-border incursions, the Clinton administration now is funnelling modest arms supplies to three neighbours that Sudan has tormented. Eritrea, Ethiopia and Uganda can use the help to defend themselves and to support the fragmented and needy Sudanese opposition - if not to unseat the regime, then to contain it. By remaining at a discreet remove from the front line action, Washington can hope to shield itself against charges of being anti-Islam and pro-intervention and yet still make a difference.

"Proposals for re-engaging diplomatically with Sudan periodically emerge in Washington. The argument is made that, with the military options being limited, the United States should wield a broader range of instruments, not just UN resolutions and American arms transfers but the contacts that come with diplomacy. At some point this will be good advice. At this point it seems a counsel of escapism. The well organised and financed National Islamic Front is the power behind the ruling military government. The front has a charismatic leader, Hassan El-Turabi, a vision of Sudan as the model of a new Islamic revolution and a focus on the United States as a useful devil. It menaces the peace and stability of its region, and beyond."

On 10 December the American television network NBC finally broadcast its programme on the NIF regime's condoning of slavery in Sudan. The film was made earlier on in the year but broadcast was delayed because of the presidential elections. The film showed convincingly that slavery remains one of the regime's tools for repressing the non-Arab and non-Moslem peoples of Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia;
Illegal Detention of Journalists


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Central Investigation Co-ordination Department has been detaining journalists in connection with news items and articles published in newspapers and magazines which it suspects of violating the Penal Code and the Press Proclamation. The individuals frequently detained are the chief and deputy editors and sometimes the manager of the publisher of the press.

According to Article 42 (1) of the Penal Code, in press matters it is the author of the text or the person who adopts it as his own and diffuses it with a criminal intent who shall be principally liable. If the person who committed the offence cannot be found, or if he is not amenable to Ethiopian courts, the editor of the printed publication shall have subsidiary liability.

Pursuant to Article 10(3) (a) of the Press Proclamation No. 34/1992, the editor or journalist or publisher shall be responsible for the offence committed through the printed matter. The liability is for failing to ensure that the press product is free from any content that can give rise to liability; any criminal offence against the safety of the State or of the administration or of the national defence; any defamation or false accusation against any individual, nation/nationality, people 

or organization; any criminal instigation of one nationality against another or incitement of conflict between peoples; and any agitation for war.

In both the Penal Code and the Press Proclamation the liability is in lieu of the other. If the person who has a principal liability is charged, the person who has a subsidiary liability should not be charged. Because in press matters the punishment of one of the parties responsible in the order fixed by law precludes punishment of the other (see Art. 17(2) (b) of the Press Proclamation and Article 46 of the Penal Code).

Therefore, it is not right to detain simultaneously the chief and deputy editors and the manager of the publisher of the press. This act appears to be aimed at stifling the freedom of the press which is guaranteed by the Constitution.

Basically in press matters there is no ground for detaining a person and then conducting the investigation. What is to be investigated? When an offence is committed through a press product, the evidence to be presented against the responsible person is the printed matter. It is the Court which determines whether or not an offence is committed through the printed matter. And the only evidence that will be presented to the court is the printed matter. There cannot be any other evidence against the accused. If there is any other thing that the police may wish to know, it cannot be other than the name, age and address of the editor of the newspaper or magazine, including whether or not the press has the necessary license. Since the editor cannot be liable if the text of the printed matter is true, the investigating police officer may also wish to ascertain this. Other than this, however, there is nothing that the investigating police officer has to investigate. And it cannot take more that 30 minutes to investigate this.

If so, what is the reason for detaining journalists for up to two months on the pretext of investigation? Why do courts frequently accept the request of the investigating police officers and repeatedly remand journalists to police custody for 14 days? Instead of watchfully safeguarding the rights of citizens, why do courts become instruments of the police and help them violate human rights?

Article 19(3), (4) and (6) of the Constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia provides that arrested persons have the right to be brought before a court within 48 hours; that on appearing before a court, they have the right to be given prompt and specific explanation of the reasons for their arrest; that they have the right to be released on bail; that when a request for a remand is made, the court may grant the request for a time strictly required to carry out the necessary investigation; that in granting the additional time, the court shall ensure the arrested persons right to a speedy trial. Article 63(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code also provides that any arrested person may be released on bail if the offence he is suspected of committing is not homicide, which carries a death penalty, or a rigorous imprisonment for fifteen years or more.

Furthermore, Article 28 of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that where the offence committed is not punishable with rigorous imprisonment as a sole or alternative punishment, the investigating police officer may release such a person on his executing a bond with or without sureties. Where the arrested person is not released on bond by the investigating police officer, he may apply to the court to be released on bail in accordance with the provisions of Article 64. If the police at the Central Investigation Coordination Department had no desire to harm the editors of the free press, they could and should have taken their statements and immediately released them on bail in accordance with Article 28 of the Criminal Procedure Code. However, the practice by both the police and the courts is contrary to the provision of the law. The proof for this is seen in what is happening to the editors of Tobya since last month.

The editor of Tobya newspaper and magazine, Ato Taye Belachew, was detained on November 22 and the deputy editor, Ato Anteneh Merid, was detained on November 25, 1996. These journalists did not appear before a judge within 48 hours in accordance with the law. However, the Investigation Department on its own authority detained Ato Taye for 14 days and Ato Anteneh for 11 days and then brought them to court for the first time on December 6, 1996. Nevertheless, they were returned to prison without appearing before a judge because it was said that the court would only see cases for which previous adjournments had been made. After staying for three days in prison, they were again taken to court on December 9, 1996. Again they were taken back because their turn did not come before the court wound its session. It was the same story on December 13, too. It was on December 16 that they appeared before a judge for the first time. However, on this day the Investigation Department requested for a remand on the pretext that it did not complete its investigation, that it had not yet received a response to its letter to the Ministries of Information and Trade, and that it had not yet got results of their finger print tests. But the legal counsellor of Ato Taye and Ato Anteneh opposed this request for remand on the ground that it was not necessary to detain a person to investigate press matters and that even if that was felt to be essential, the police had already kept the editors in detention for 24 days and hence had ample time to finalize their investigation within that time. Furthermore, as the police had already verified during previous detentions of the editors that the publisher of Tobya had the necessary legal licenses, no additional information was needed from these ministries. Nor is a finger print test required for a press case and even then their finger prints had already been taken and the results made available to the Department. On these grounds, the lawyer requested the court to release his clients on bail, but the judges rejected his pleas and granted the remand until December 23. Nevertheless, Ato Taye and Ato Anteneh were not brought to court even on this day.

When they were brought to court on December 27, they were told that the panel of judges was incomplete and so they were returned to prison. Again, the same thing happened on December 30. Except for December 16, therefore, they have not yet appeared before a judge and are still illegally detained.

Ato Goshu Moges, who replaced Ato Taye as editor and whose home was surrounded by policemen on December 12, was woken from his sleep and taken to the Investigation Department at 6:30 in the morning. After eight days of detention, he was brought to court. As usual the police requested for a remand saying that they had not completed their investigation and were granted to keep him in custody until January 3, 1997. However, the Department has not brought Ato Goshu to court either on that day or to date. He is being illegally kept under detention until this day.

Ato Arega Wolde Qirqos, who became the editor when Ato Goshu was detained, was taken into custody on January 6 and has been under detention until now. He has not yet been brought before a judge.

The actions of the Central Investigation Co-ordination Department appear to be taken out of malice and aimed at eliminating the free press. The weakening of the judicial system caused by the mass dismissal of judges also appears to have facilitated the conditions for the illegal detention of citizens on flimsy grounds.

Article 29 of the constitution of the FDRE which provides for the freedom of expression states that every one has the right to hold opinions and to freedom of expression without any interference; that this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either in writing or print, in the form of art, or through any media of his choice; that in the interest of the free flow of information, ideas and opinions which are essential to the functioning of a democratic order, the press shall enjoy legal protection to ensure its operational independence; that freedom of expression and information cannot be limited on account of the content or effect of the point of view expressed; that in order to protect the well-being of the youth and the honour and reputation of individuals, legal limitation may be laid down on these rights; and that any propaganda for war, as well as the public expression of opinion intended to injure human dignity shall be prohibited by law.

This provision is closer in spirit to the provisions of Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. However, the actions of the police against the editors of the free press contravene these constitutional provisions. EHRCO therefore requests the Ethiopian government to restrain the police from such acts and to effect the release of all journalists who are imprisoned without being convicted by a court of law.

EHRCO also calls on all States, human rights organizations, international agencies, religious institutions, and individuals who support the rule of law and respect for human rights in Ethiopia to do their best to make the Ethiopian government to respect freedom of the press and to stop the harassment and detention of the editors of the free press.

CC: House of Peoples Representatives; H.E. Dr. Negasso Gidada, President, The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia; H.E. Ato Meles Zenawi, Prime Minister, The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia; H.E. Ato Mahteme Solomon, Minister of Justice, The Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia; The Honourable Ato Kemal Bedri.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia and Sudan;
15,000 Sudanese Ready to Trek into Western Ethiopia


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - A joint press release by the United Nations Higher Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the Administration for Refugee and Returnee Affairs (ARRA), stated that 4,128 Sudanese refugees had settled in Western Ethiopia (near Kunche village at Tongo Wereda in Benishangul-Gumuz Region), starting Tuesday, 7 January 1997. On average, a further 80 persons arrive in Kunche every day. Local Authorities report that another 15,000 Sudanese were on the border with Ethiopia, ready to make their way to Benshangul-Gumuz region. The first group of refugees fleeing the civil war and famine in southern Sudan made their way to the Kunche area in mid- November, 1996. The UNHCR and ARRA said they have established a field presence and constructed a wet feeding centre. 

"The new arrivals are in a desperate state of famine, depending on wild yam- like tubers and various other roots," the press release stated. Findings of a joint assessment mission by the UNHCR, ARRA, and the World Food Programme (WFP) revealed that under-five malnutrition prevalence (less than 80 per cent weight for height) is around 22 per cent. The Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Commission (DPPC) brought initial food relief to the refugees, and 33mt of maize and other supplementary food items sent by the WFP arrived at the site on 30 December.

The release noted that, "The influx from the Blue Nile Region is expected to increase in the wake of an apparent massive military build-up by the Sudanese government in the Ura, Chali, Buny, Gezan and Kurmuk areas. Frequent flights of military planes over these areas are causing fear of aerial bombardment."

Around 72,804 Sudanese refugees have entered Ethiopia since mid-1991, escaping famine and civil war, UNHCR/ARRA said. "In view of the continuing conflict in Sudan," the release observed, "it is not likely that these refugees will repatriate in the near future."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 21, 1997


Business and Finance;
CPU Organises Seminar on the Internet


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Computer Professionals United firm (CPU) invited two distinguished doctors from the Addis Ababa University to demonstrate the internet to business men, government and non governmental employees at the Addis Ababa Hilton yesterday. 

Dr. Ahmed Hussien and Dr. Dawit Bekele, discussed during the half-day seminar the information highway, history of the internet, how to access the internet from Ethiopia, overview of networks, internet services, internet security, cyberethics, and intranet.

"It is true" they said, " that the costs may not be affordable for everyone. We hope that the sole provider will envisage, in the future, a cheaper way of providing some of the services."

309 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Third African Workshop to Close Tomorrow


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Third African Workshop on Human Rights Education will close tomorrow at the end of a five-day discussion. This is the third of an on-going workshop on human rights education in Africa. The workshop was conceived by African NGOs at a workshop organised by the International commission of Jurists in November 1993.

The first workshop, hosted by the South African Lawyers for Human Rights in South Africa, in 1994, was addressed by President Nelson Mandela. Forty-two delegates from thirty-eight African countries presented to the five-day workshop a report on the state of human right education in their respective country. The second workshop was in Cairo, Egypt, 25-29 September 1995.

Presentations by the participants in the third workshop, included those at the inaugural by Speaker of the house of peoples' representatives of Ethiopia, Ato Dawit Yohannes, on "The place of Human rights in the constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia", Ambassador Ahmmed Haggag, Acting Secretary-General of the OAU, on "OAU's new agenda for the promotion of human rights in Africa". A panel discussion on "Proactive leadership in the promotion of human rights education" was held Tuesday, While the honourable Kemal Bedri, president of the federal supreme court of Ethiopia, presented a paper on "The judiciary as a protector and pace-setter of human rights: the educational responsibility it has." Dr. David McQuiod-Mason, professor of law, university of Natal, South Africa, spoke on " The changing role of the university in human rights: From a secluded ivory tower to a torch bearer." In the afternoon, each country gave a report update for 1996.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


310 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia;
Enhance Human Rights Education At All Levels


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, (Editorial), Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Addis Ababa - It is ironic that Tobia, a private Amharic weekly newspaper did not appear yesterday, when prominent and distinguished scholars are discussing human rights education in the capital. The Human Rights Education Workshop is organized by InterAfrica Group, a local NGO. The Workshop was opened on Monday and it is expected to close today with major recommendations. Tobia didn't appear because, according to the publishers, they wanted to protest against the arrest of four of its top editors. Tobia is one of the most popular private newspapers. There is no doubt that regular readers felt its absence. 

There is no official word from the government why Tobia's editors are in jail. All of us, including the government will agree that Ethiopia would be better off with positive protection of freedom of expression and information. The importance of freedom of expression is expressed many times at many forums. The main problem is the implementation.

Freedom of expression and information has been recognized as an essential foundation of democratic society by institutions and governments around the world. The United Nations General Assembly, at its first session, on 14 December 1946, declared:

"Freedom of information is a fundamental human right...the touchstone of all the freedom to which the United Nations is concerned."

The European Court of Human Rights has repeatedly emphasized the fundamental importance of freedom of expression in a democratic society:

"Freedom of expression constitutes one of the essential foundations of (democratic) society, one of the basic conditions for its progress and for the development of every man. Subject to article 10(2), it is applicable not only to information or ideas that are favorably received or regarded as an offensive or as a matter of indifference, but also to those that offend, shock or disturb the State or any sector of the population. Such are the demands of that pluralism, tolerance and broadmindedness without which there is no democratic society. Let there be due process of the law. In the mean time let us enhance human rights education at all levels.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia;
Tobia Suspends Publication, Rights Group Expresses Concern


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Addis Ababa - Independent Amharic weekly Tobia newspaper yesterday suspended publication in protest against the detention of four of its top editors. AKPAC, the firm publishing the paper, last Thursday indicated that it would suspend the weekly publication indefinitely--but still publish the monthly magazine--if the issue was not resolved.

The Ethiopian Human Rights Council(EHRCO) 14 January expressed its concern over the arrest of Tobia's editors. The first to be taken in was the paper's editor, Ato Taye Belachew, detained on November 22 1996. Deputy editor Anteneh Merid was detained three days later. According to Tobia, the two were charged in connection with articles on Tobia's magazine written by an Ethiopian scientist in the United States entitled "A strategy to Unite Eritrea with Ethiopia".They both appeared in court on 6 December but did not appear before a judge because 'the court would only see cases for which previous adjournments had been made,' said EHRCO. They returned to prison without appearing before a judge a further two times, before doing so for the first time on 16 December. Upon the request of the Investigation Department, reported EHRCO, the two were remanded until 23 December. Both on the 27 and 30 December, they returned to prison without appearing in court because the panel of judges was incomplete. According to Tobia, they have yet to appear before a judge. 

The third to be arrested was Ato Goshu Moges. He had replaced Ato Taye, and was taken in on 12 December. He is supposedly charged in connection with an article on the recent hijacking of Ethiopian flight 961, said Tobia. When he appeared in court eight days later, the court accepted the police's request for a remand until 3 January 1997. Ato Arega Wolde Quirqos, who took over from Ato Goshu was detained 6 January. Both have yet to appear in court to have their cases heard.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia;
Problems Continue for Ethiopian Orthodox Church


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - The police reported disturbances during the annual observation of St.Yohannes the Baptist day Sunday 12 January, by who it called, "still unidentified

individuals." This appears to be the second incident in less than a week to have occured, highlighting a possible division within the Ethiopian Orthodox Church. 

The first occasion was a shooting in the St. Estifanos Church Thursday 9 January, which resulted in the death of hermit G/Selassie. According to a BBC report, the hermit was killed while trying to give a petition to the Patriarch. The hermit was believed to have been shot by someone from the patriarch's group, said BBC. Patriarch Paolos was also present during the ceremony in the St. Yohannes Church.

Heads of churches and monastries met at the auditorium of the Holy Synod Saturday to condemn the shooting as an attempt on the life of Patrairch Paolos. The assembled passed a thirteen-point resolution, said Addis Zemen, government Amharic daily, and asked the government to investigate and decide on the matter of political questions brought to the church disguised as religious ones.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


313 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Sudan;
Sudan Calls For Jihad


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Addis Ababa - Victories by the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) on the border with Ethiopia and in the Blue Nile Region has prompted the Sudanese government to accuse Ethiopia of helping the rebels. Sudanese girls, most probably students aged around fifteen, marched through the streets of Khartoum yesterday. The girls, new recruits into the Popular Defence Force (PDF) chanted slogans to the effect that they were going to destroy the 'Ethiopian in the East', reported BBC. The Khartoum government closed down the university to make it easier to recruit fighters and issued a Jihad. 

The Ethiopian Ministry of Foreign Affairs however, denied the allegation adding that, "No one knows better than the Sudanese authorities themselves that the accusation has no bases and that Ethiopia has no hand in what is obviously a military setback suffered by the authorities in Khartoum." The statement issued by the ministry 14 January said that, "It is to be expected that this accusation would be taken by the National Islamic Front Government to the Security Council with the additional aim of diverting the attention of the Council from the unfinished business before it in connection with a proven case of state sponsored terrorism and an assassination attempt by Sudanese authorities against a head of state." The statement ended with the warning," It is time for the Sudanese authorities to realise that they cannot always succeed to fool others, and stop believing that fabrications accompanied with great fanfare would be given the benefit of the doubt and some credence by the international community."

The Ethiopian Ministry of Foreign Affairs notified 8 January all Sudanese diplomats in Addis Ababa that they were no longer allowed to go outside the city. According to the government English daily, Ethiopian Herald, the move came in response to a "provocative and malicious" statement made by Mr. Ali Hassan Ali, the Sudan Charge d'Affaires to Somalia.

In its letter to the Sudanese government, the ministry accused Mr. Ali of having, "Urged Somalis to take up arms and fight Ethiopia in a Jihad (holy war) to counter the recent operation by Ethiopian armed forces against the fundamentalist Al-Ithad Al-Islam group".

The letter noted that the statement made by Mr. Ali was seen as "a hostile act directed against the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ethiopia and as such would like to request the Government of the Sudan to disassociate itself from the provocative statement by its diplomat in Mogadishu."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


314 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 21, 1997


Ethiopia;
Thirty-Thousand Hectares Unutilized Land in Addis Ababa


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Addis Ababa - Quoting "Addis Lisan", the press organ of Region 14 Administration (read Addis Ababa), "Addis Zemen", the government-owned Amharic daily newspaper, disclosed in its January 10 edition that detailed studies are being conducted on thirty-thousand hectares of land in preparation for use by private developers and investors and by the government.

"Addis Zemen" stated in one of its paragraphs on the topic that the thirty- thousand hectares of land had been prepared for private-sector and government development projects while in another paragraph it disclosed that detailed studies were being conducted, which would imply that the land is not really ready for use yet. Apparently in conformity with the latter statement, the Amharic daily said: "Although the city's Master Plan has enough information to indicate the city's future growth directions, there are no detailed plans showing the various specific development projects to be implemented in specific areas, thus necessitating a more detailed study which has been undertaken".

The question here is: are the detailed studies in the process of being carried out or have they been completed? this is important, because if they are not completed, we may have to wait years before land distribution for development (on whatever basis) is started! It was further disclosed that the total area of the city of Addis Ababa is 52,000 hectares of which 22,000 hectares have already been utilized. 

At the latest count, the population of Addis stands at about 2.3 million. One hectare is equal to 10,000 square meters, which means the total area of Addis Ababa is 520,000,000 square meters. Let us assume an average family size of 5 for Addis which would imply a total number of families of 460,000 for the total population of 2.3 million given above. Divide 520,000,000 square meters by 460,000 and that would yield a potential land holding of about 1130 square meters per family! Wow! That is a lot of land for a single family if only we could lay our hands on it! but why is there so much land and housing shortage in Addis Ababa? Why are tens of thousands people landless and homeless in Addis? Why are house rents skyrocketing? why are land prices soaring into the stratosphere? Why? Why?

Wait a minute. We can do a little more arithmetic on the 30,000 hectares of land still initialized in Addis And the total number of housing units (about 380,000) in the city. the 30,000 hectares are equal to 300,000,000 square meters. Assuming that each housing unit on average accommodates 5 persons or one family (or household), the total number of persons who have no shelter or are living in overcrowded conditions may be roughly estimated at 400,000 (i.e. 460,000 - 380,000 times 5) or 80,000 families or households. Divide the still initialized 300,000,000 square meters of land in Addis Ababa by these 80,000 families. It works out at 3750 square meters per family!

Clearly, there is plenty of land for everybody in Addis Ababa. On a purely per capita basis each person who has no housing or is living in overcrowded conditions can have as much as 750 square meters of land! This, of course, would not be realistic as a lot of land would be needed for industry and other enterprises, for government offices, road construction, schools, hospitals, sports grounds, parks, etc. Even then, a lot of this land would be required and utilized by private individuals in a professedly market-and private-property-based economy. The point at issue is that, contrary to common perceptions, there is a lot of land in Addis that is simply sitting idle, and the reason why land prices are so high at percent is clearly because of the government's monopoly on land ownership and the very inefficient manner of its distribution through the highly controversial land- lease mechanism! Why, may we ask should 250 square meters of land with a chicken coop on it cost 100,000 birr in a city where the average annual income (for those lucky enough to be employed) is no more than 2000 birr! For the purpose of comparison, even people with annual average incomes of 18,000 birr cannot afford such high land prices in their lifetimes! (Note: since all land is state-owned in Ethiopia, land on the free market is evasively sold by purporting to sell some cheap physical structures put on it).

Why, may we ask, should a modest villa cost 500,000 birr here in Addis? Why should it be so difficult to find housing to rent? Why is it an up-hill task to find office space? Why are no trees being planted on the outskirts of Addis or animals not being bred? Why are business enterprises not being set up as fast as they could be? Why should land lease fees rise as high as 10 million birr for a 200-square-meter piece of land in the midst of 300,000,000 million square meters of still initialized land in Addis Ababa? A riddle? Of course not, it is a clear as daylight. The problem lies in the government's land policy which may be broken down into three salient features: one is that only the state can own land: the second feature is that it cannot be bought or sold; and the third one is that it can be distributed (or made available) to users only through the land-lease mechanism. What this amounts to in the case of Addis Ababa is as follows:

* the 300,000,000 square meters of initialized land cannot be owned by private individuals or entities;

* all this land can neither be sold nor bought;

* the land can be made available to users only through the land-lease mechanism, which has so far released only a very limited amount of land per year;

* parts of already settled lands cannot be sold by private occupants because land cannot be bought or sold.

What all this means is quite clear. Potential private developers do not have access to land. Because the land-lease mechanism releases land on a very piecemeal basis, the artificial land shortage so created escalates, as it has very clearly done so far, land prices beyond everybody's reach. No ready access to land means no accelerated economic development and this means not enough new jobs and not enough new incomes, implying the worsening of poverty levels already badly aggravated by relentless population growth.

What to do? What to do is quite obvious. Even employing its land-lease policy, the government can very substantially improve access to land in Addis Ababa. (the author of this article is, however, of the opinion that the land- lease mechanism should only be one among several mechanisms of land distribution, including outright private ownership either through sale or grant). At any rate, here are a few general tips.

* clear satisfactorily any legal claims on the 300,000,000 square meters of initialized land;

* set up a land administration authority with a land distribution committee in each of the city's woredas:

* start distributing land in each woreda on a daily basis.

Government, please let go of all that idle land! We want to create value on it and make ourselves and the country prosperous. We could do a thousand and one things with the land including the following:

* build houses for ourselves and for rent. We promise we will almost get rid of the housing shortage in three years;

* put up all sorts of business enterprises;

* build private schools, hospitals and clinics;

* plant trees and breed animals.

Think of how substantially an unemployed man's life would be transformed if such a measure is taken. As a result of the highly increased economic activity in the city, he would find the highly increased economic activity in the city, he would find a job and earn an income; he would have a wide choice of houses to rent or may acquire land to put up his own house; he could now form a family and enjoy its warmth and affection; good food (including meat, milk and vegetables) would be available at a competitive price; he could send his children to private schools; with all these blessings, he would tend to be productive and efficient in his work, and be filled with hope and inspiration about his future! A once wretched unemployed man would be transformed into a cheerful and amicable human being, radiating warmth and hope to all those surrounding him! Wouldn't that be a wonderful thing to help bring about!


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 21, 1997


Sports - General;
Cross Country: Gete Still First After Spain Race


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ethiopia's Gete Wami, current World Cross Country Champion, came in second in the 5.45 km race in Spain Sunday with a time of 18:05. Elena Fidatov of Romania was first with a time of 18:03. The World Cross Country Challenge is a twelve-race event, and Fidatov, who missed the first race in Brussels in December, is second overall with seventy-two points. Gete, who was in all four races, remains at the top with 82 points. In the men's 10.85 km, Habte Jifar of Ethiopia was awarded third place over Benedict Ako of Tanzania. They both came in with the time of 33:51. The reigning world junior champion, David Chelule of Kenya, and his compatriot, James Moiben, came in first and second with a time of 33:45 and 33:50 respectively.

LANGUAGE: English
