Africa News


January 21, 1997


United States and Africa;
South Africa Accuses United States Of Bullying


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The African National Congress (ANC), the dominant party in South Africa's first post-apartheid government, has accused the United States of bullyboy tactics and hypocrisy for threatening Pretoria over its proposed 650-million-U.S. dollar arms sale to Syria.

Acting ANC secretary-general Cheryl Carolus told a news conference Monday that the United States was trying to force South Africa into a biased policy in the Middle East by favoring Israel over the Arab states.

"We take strong exception to any country acting like a bullyboy in trying to essentially usurp our own foreign policy-making capacity," she said. 

"The United States itself has contributed in a very biased way in the region and that in itself creates problems," she added. "It's really a bit much and self-righteous to then try to speak to other people about that."

These remarks echoed recent statements by South African President Nelson Mandela and Deputy President Thabo Mbeki. They said that South Africa would not be dictated to by any country and would make its own decision regarding arms sales.

This reaction followed last week's statement by the United States, threatening to cut off some 120-million dollars in aid if South Africa went ahead with the proposed deal to sell tank-sighting equipment to Syria.

In turn, South Africa has pointed out that an American defence contractor is involved in an at least one of three bids for the Syrian contract by companies in at least three European countries.

"That kind of hypocrisy of the United States -- to not do anything about that aspect of it -- we find quite disturbing and out of keeping with the role which we would hope that a major power such as the United States would play," Carolus.

She said South Africa was concerned that its actions should not upset the precarious balance in the Middle East.

"But we think the United States should also put its hand to its own bosom and take this question quite seriously," she added.

Carolus also criticized the manner in which the U.S. handled the matter. If the United States wanted clarification on the deal, she said, it could have used normal diplomatic channels rather than having "some petty government official standing up and attacking the sovereignty of another country."


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Science and Health;
Researchers Make Breakthrough In Locust Control Techniques


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Scientists at the Nairobi-based International Center for Insect Physiology and Ecology claim to have made a major breakthrough in understanding the phenomena that cause locusts to lay eggs en masse and keep the locust swarms together.

Researchers have said that the discovery is crucial in finding scientific methods to disrupt the life-cycle of the gregarious insects which currently pose a threat to crops in various parts of Africa.

Their effort complements a similar study by researchers at Oxford University in London. 

In its latest issue the monthly, The Zambian Farmer, the newspaper says that researchers at Oxford have identified a chemical which is sometimes found in the foam that surrounds locust eggs. It is believed the chemical could provide the key to locust control.

The chemical is thought to be responsible for turning young locusts into gregarious pests. It has been found that the locusts hatch as solitary insects where the chemical is absent.

Stephen Simpson and his colleagues at Oxford say the chemical acts on the locust embryos as they develop in the eggs and switches on the genes responsible for turning a locust from being a solitary into a gregarious insect.

"All the young hatch as gregarious locusts which is the key to the locust's importance as a pest. If it did not make that change then it would not become a pest," Simpson said.

His team also found that four hours of crowding by locusts was sufficient to stimulate the female species to produce the subject chemical.

With the knowledge gained at the institute and at Oxford, scientists say that they can develop ways to disrupt the locust's crucial life stages and find a long-term control strategy against the destructive pest.

Scientists say the locust consumes vegetation equal to its own weight of about two grams per day and that an average swarm is capable of devouring what 10 elephants are able to eat.

Locusts generally feed on green grass and are particularly attracted to crop plants like maize, sorghum, millet and wheat. The young hoppers like maize stalks more because it is succulent.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Nigeria;
Mixed Reactions To Nigeria's 1997 Budget


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Some provisions of Nigeria's 1997 budget which Finance Minister Anthony Ani explained Monday, has continued to elicit mixed reactions from a cross-section of the population.

While some economists have hailed it as realistic, others have raised reservations on how faithfully the provisions would be implemented.

Yet others have adopted a-wait-and-see attitude toward the 11.2-billion- dollar estimate dubbed "Budget of Growth and Development" by head of state Gen. Sani Abacha.

Kayode Familoni, an economic consultant at the University of Lagos, said the budget would raise standard of living in the country, if it is properly implemented. 

"I do believe it is designed to be welfarist and populist in the sense that it is a budget that takes cognisance of the problems of the people," he said.

In another reaction, Ismaila Funtua, publisher of the 'Democrat' newspaper, commended the government for its efforts aimed at alleviating the sufferings of the masses.

However, Ismaila, who had expected the government would scrap import duties on newsprint and other publishing accessories, said the budget did not contain any incentive to the media industry.

A renowned Nigerian banker, Samuel Falegan, is among those who believe that the budget holds the promise of growth.

But he warned that the decision to make the Central Bank of Nigeria independent, should be pursued with caution.

Falegan, former managing director of the Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria, said the apex bank could not be "completely independent of government in the interest of the nation," adding that instead, the bank should aim at greater efficiency and professionalism.

Two issues in the budget that have generated much debate are the retention of the dual exchange rate regime by government and the increase of the paid- up capital of commercial and merchant banks from 50 million to 500 million naira.

While bankers prefer a floating exchange rate to the current dual exchange regime of 22 naira to the dollar for government transactions and 80 naira to the greenback at the autonomous market, Ani said the government's ultimate goal to merge the two rates would have to wait.

Some bankers feel the jump in the paid-up capital for commercial and merchant banks "is on the high side".

But Paul Unongo, who was minister of steel development during the second republic, said the increase would help sanitize and strengthen the banking sector.

Previous liberal terms had resulted in several bank failures, prompting government to set up the Failed Bank Tribunal. Some 200 bank chief executives have either been tried and convicted or are awaiting trial before the tribunal.

Organized labor has also expressed some reservation with the decision to decentralize industrial bargaining.

Under the new arrangement, each of Nigeria's 36 states is free to fix wages and salaries for their workers, contrary to the previous arrangement in which the federal government set the ceiling for workers remuneration.

Labor leader Sylvester Ejiofor commended the government for harmonizing the emoluments of pensioners nationwide. But he warned that decentralizing wage negotiation could pose a big challenge to the state governments and labor unions.

State workers had gone on strike in the past over the failure by some state governments to pay salaries or fringe benefits fixed by the federal government.

Ejiofor said "deregulating collective bargaining may not pose an insurmountable problem" provided negotiations were conducted in good faith.

While the former petroleum minister, Tam David-West, described as realistic, government's decision to base the budget on oil price of 17 dollars a barrel, public servants are disappointed that the budget said nothing about any wage increase.

On the whole, Nigeria's former envoy to Canada, Ayodele Kadiri, summarized the general view on the budget, when he said that "implementation...is the crucial thing".

"A budget could be beautiful, but it may be truncated if not properly implemented," he added.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Nigeria;
22 People Arrested Over Lagos Bombings


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian security authorities have arrested 22 persons in connection with explosions that have rocked Lagos, the country's economic hub, in recent months.

A military spokesman said Tuesday that the 22 suspects were arrested in Lagos and its surrounding areas. 

The official, Col. Godwin Ugbo, the acting director of defence information, declined to disclose the identities of the suspects, or whether a former presidential aspirant and current opposition leader, Olu Falae, was among them.

"I don't know if the 22 persons include Chief Falae and I am not going to be categorizing whether they are civilians or military, politicians or not," Ugho told journalists.

Falae was arrested in the wake of the Jan. 7 explosion, which killed at least two soldiers and injured a dozen others in an army truck.

Two other bombs exploded in Lagos in Dec. 1996, apparently targeted at the military. At least one person died, and a score of others were wounded.

In November that year, an explosion killed three people, including the chief security officer of the Murtala Mohammed International Airport, in Lagos.

Nobody has claimed responsibility for the explosions.

But Ugbo said, "it is something positive that arrests have been made." He added that members of security forces were making progress in their investigations.

Urban terrorism, involving the use of explosives was alien to Nigeria until 1986 when Dele Giwa, the founding editor of the weekly magazine, Newswatch, died in a parcel-bomb explosion. The assailants have still not been identified.

Since then, there have been a dozen bomb attacks in different parts of the country, especially during the peak of political crisis in 1993 and 1994.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Southern Africa;
Common Market Boss Resists Probe


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The suspended secretary-general of Common Market of Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa), Bingu wa Mutharika, refused to be probed Wednesday by a committee constituted by the organization's Council of Ministers which he says is biased.

Rather, Mutharika demanded that a committee constituted by the Comesa heads of states and government, who appointed him, investigate his alleged misuse of funds at the organizations secretariat.

He has been accused of using the organizations resources for personal reasons and of frequent travel to Malawi, his home country, to indulge in politics, as well as trips to Zimbabwe, home of his wife.

He challenged his critics to check records in Malawi and verify whether or not he had registered with a political party to challenge President Muluzi. 

Mutharika was suspended Saturday by the Council of Ministers chaired by Chakakala Chaziya, the Malawian minister of commerce and industry. Chaziya said Mutharikas three-month suspension would facilitate investigations into the allegations.

A committee comprising of five member-states, to be headed by Zambia, was elected to probe the matter in three months.

At a news conference in the Zambian capital, Mutharika claimed Wednesday that his suspension was a political conspiracy hatched in Malawi by unnamed people who suspected that he wanted to run for the presidency.

He claimed to be the victim of a smear campaign intended to destroy his career and high reputation built over the years.

His suspension, he said, was the result of a carefully calculated political conspiracy. This was so, he added, because since the establishment, 15 years ago, of Comesa's precursor, the Preferential Trade Area for Eastern and Southern Africa, the council had never discussed documents which were anonymous and whose authors were afraid to append their signatures thereon.

"The principle is that if the charges are indeed true, then those making them must be prepared to put their names on them and stand by their charges," he said.

Mutharika said he would only appear for interrogation before a committee established by the heads of state and government, and not the one constituted by the council. He said that under the Comesa treaty the council had no powers to question him.

"I wish to observe that the council of ministers, through manipulation by Honorable Chakakala Chaziya, has already found me guilty even before the so called investigations are conducted," he said. "Therefore, it is doubtful if a committee constituted by them will truly be impartial."

Chaziya, he said "very hastily" accepted the anonymous documents and pushed a decision through council for the investigation.

Mutharika said he had a right to be provided with full details of the charges against him and to know the names and identities of his accusers. The council has refused to give him the details.

However, he suspects his accusers to be people from Comesa whom he had rebuked for indiscipline.

Mutharika also said the council had refused to allow him respond to the charges, which would have enabled council to examine both sides of the story before taking a decision.

"Honorable Chaziya refused to grant me the right of response," he said.

On the withdrawal of Mozambique and Lesotho from Comesa, Mutharika said that Chaziya was incompetent to dismiss his judgement that the problem lay with external forces influencing these members to leave the organization.

Mutharika told PANA that Comesa had major problems. The greatest of these, he said, was for the organization to resolve its relations with the 12-nation Southern African Development Community and having the commitment of member- states to run his 20-nation organization.

Last week, Chaziya sought to play down Mutharika's assertion that foreign forces had colluded to run down Comesa because it was one of Africa's economic success stories.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


334 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia Air Force Airlifts Medicines To Flooded Area


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)- The Zambia Air Force started airlifting medical supplies Wednesday to Maamba, southern Zambia, which has been cut off by floods following torrential rains since Sunday.

The air force delivered mainly anti-malarial, diarrhea and cholera medicines for the 85,000 affected residents, just in case of an outbreak of epidemics. This is because the floods have damaged sewerage systems.

The national radio quoted the Health Ministry as saying that the airlift was necessary because it was difficult to reach the area by road, since bridges had also been washed away.

Medical authorities at the Maamba Coal Mine were forced to evacuate patients from the local clinic Monday, after the buildings were submerged in water.

The Zambian Ministry of Mines also sent a team of five senior government officials from various government ministries to assess the situation, Wednesday. The team is expected to compile a report for government action.

Speaking from the town of Livingstone, the permanent secretary for the Southern Region, Sylvester Mpishi, who toured the area Wednesday, told PANA that the occasional airlift of medical supplies will be needed as long as the bridges remain unrepaired. Road engineers and electricians are already in the area to restore services.

He said that the floods had also swept some crops. The impact of this will only be felt at harvest in April and May.

The permanent secretary for the ministry of health, Kashiwa Bulaya, said that the cost and duration of operation could only be known after the senior government officials, sent to the area, compile their report.

Almost all parts of Zambia have been swamped by heavy rains. Meteorologists say the downpours have been mainly induced by a weather system from Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


335 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Ethiopia Cancels Africa Cup Preliminary Match


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia says it will no longer take part in Sunday's Africa Cup preliminary soccer match against Morocco, after most of its 23-man squad disappeared Tuesday in Rome, Italy, en route from Addis Ababa to Rabat.

The government press reported Wednesday, officials of the Ethiopian Football Confederation as saying that only seven members of the squad turned up at Rome Airport for the connection flight. The rest were assumed to have defected. No reasons have yet been given.

It is uncertain whether Ethiopia will withdraw from the remaining preliminary matches in Group C, for the 1998 Africa Cup of Nations. That event will be held in Ougadougou, Burkina Faso.

This is the second time Ethiopian soccer players have defected in Rome while en route to Morocco. Six players left the squad in October 1992 as the national team was heading for a preliminary World Cup contest.

Ethiopia, then, opted to field a weak team which included a reserve goalkeeper and the assistant coach, believed to be in his late 40s.

The game was abandoned when Morocco was leading 6-0 as most of the Ethiopian players left the field "faking" injuries.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Denies Threatening South Africa Over Syrian Arms Deal


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The United States has denied that it is threatening South Africa over a proposed 650-million-U.S.-dollar arms deal with Syria.

"No-one in the U.S. Administration is threatening South Africa," said James Joseph, the U.S ambassador to South Africa.

Joseph was addressing the Johannesburg Rotary Club Tuesday. 

He said that U.S. President Bill Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and himself had gone out of their way to demonstrate support of South Africa's sovereignty and to avoid intervention.

"We have laws on our books that the U.S. Government is required to implement," Joseph Said. "When a U.S. State Department spokesman was asked recently about this, he acknowledged that the government has to implement these laws. But such an acknowledgement should not be considered a threat."

Joseph's denial follows angry South African reaction to a reported statement, last week, by a U.S. State Department spokesman in Washington that the U.S. might cut about 120-million dollars in aid if South Africa goes ahead with the proposed Syrian arms deal.

Washington opposed the sale of arms or military technology to countries it considers are involved in international terrorism. Washington considers Syria one of these, although Syria was an ally in the U.S.-led coalition that defeated Iraq in the 1991 Gulf War.

Responding to the state department statement, President Nelson Mandela and Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki said South Africa would not be dictated to by any power and would make its own decisions regarding arms sales.

The acting African National Congress Secretary-General, Cheryl Carolus, also accused the U.S. of bullyboy tactics and of hypocrisy for threatening the South African Government over the Syrian arms deal.

In his address Tuesday, Joseph said that while South Africa was considering what to do, he would make no public comment on the issue.

"There has been a lot of speculation in the media on something that has not occurred," he said, "and we must await the South African government's decision. Then I will be willing to talk to you."

Joseph went on to say that the U.S. and South Africa had a shared value of curbing the spread of weapons of mass destruction.

Clinton had promised Mandela in 1994 that the U.S. would provide Pretoria with 600-million in aid for its social needs. South Africa received about 120 million dollars in U.S. aid in 1996 and a similar figure was envisaged for 1997.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


337 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Wants 'Amicable' Discussion with SA on Syrian Arms


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Washington - Text of the interchange between reporters and the State Department's Nicholas Burns at the daily Department briefing on January 21 on the subject of a possible South African arms sale to Syria.

QUESTION: (Inaudible) South Africa and Syria quickly, as a last question. What is your reaction to the comments from the ANC Secretary General's comments. She described America's Middle Eastern policy as "bullying and hypocritical," and says South Africa - 

MR. BURNS: What was the first word?

QUESTION: Bullying and hypocritical. It said South Africa might be frog- marched into a foreign policy not of its own choosing.

MR. BURNS: That's quite a statement.

QUESTION: Quite a statement. What's your reaction?

MR. BURNS: I would just say, let's look at the facts here. I don't think the Palestinians or the Israelis or Jordanians or Egyptians or Tunisians or Moroccans or the Saudis or the people in the Emirates or in Kuwait would ever describe the United States in those terms. I won't even repeat the words.

I think if you look at reality in the Middle East, the United States is widely seen, except in Baghdad perhaps, as the indispensable intermediary and sometimes mediator. We have played a historically positive role. Just look at the events of last week in the Hebron negotiations.

Now, on the issue that South Africa is concerned about, the same issue we're concerned about. Our view is that all of us, internationally, have a responsibility to our own countries to the global fight against terrorism.

Syria is a state sponsor of terrorism. It is inadmissible for countries, and unwise, to sell arms to Syria. That does not further the fight against global terrorism, nor will it bring stability to the Middle East. That's what we've all got to be interested in - peace and stability in the Middle East.

We have a difference of view here. We know that the South African Government has not made a decision, and we hope to continue an amicable, reasonable, and rational discussion of the issues in private. That's what friendly countries do, much in the way that we discuss our differences on Cuba with the Canadian Government. We discuss them respectfully and rationally and in a peaceful way.

So we would respectfully submit, it's better to have a useful, private discussion rather than this war of words which is not going to help South Africa or the United States. We won't engage in this war of words. We're not interested in doing that.

QUESTION: Can I just ask you about -- Senator Helms has reportedly written to the President asking that the ARMSCOR situation be linked to this controversy. In the eyes of the State Department, are the two issues entirely separate?

MR. BURNS: Excuse me -

QUESTION: The ARMSCOR situation.

MR. BURNS: ARMSCOR? They're entirely separate. Entirely separate.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


338 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


United States and Africa;
Helms to Clinton: Oppose SA Arms Sales to Syria


BYLINE: United States Senate


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Washington - Letter to President Clinton dated January 17, 1997, from Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, regarding a possible South Africansale to Syria.

Dear Mr. President:

Regarding South Africa's approval of a contracting permit for Syria for laser-guided tank firing control systems (valued at $650,000,000), I respectfully urge that you refrain from waiving the provisions of the Antiterrorism Act (22 U.S.C. 2378);

(As you are aware, these provisions require the President to withhold assistance to the government of any country that provides lethal military equipment to a terrorist country.)

It is imperative that the Administration communicate to the Government of South Africa, in no uncertain terms, that no ambiguity exists within the U.S. Government about laser-guided tank firing control systems being "lethal military equipment", and, consequently, that providing this system to Syria makes it mandatory that foreign aid to South Africa be suspended. 

Furthermore, I urge that your Administration cease all activities toward settlement of the ARMSCOR case unless and until the Government of South Africa provides credible assurances that the tank firing control systems will not be provided to Syria. It is unthinkable that the Administration would reward the South African arms industry with significant financial benefits resulting from resolution of the ARMSCOR case while the Government of South Africa is contemplating a major arms sale to a terrorist nation.

Syrian acquisition of state-of-the art military hardware runs counter to longstanding U.S. national security interests in the region and represents a significant new threat to Israel. Syria continues to support and shelter more than six of the most vicious terror groups in the world; including Hamas and Hezbollah. Syria has been identified by the Secretary of State as a state sponsor of terrorism every year since 1979, and it should be treated as a pariah state by all civilized nations until it ceases sponsoring terrorist activities.

There exists substantial American goodwill for the people of South Africa, as evidenced by the provision of $562,400,000 in foreign aid to them since Mr. Mandela's election in 1994. It is therefore puzzling that President Mandela and many ANC members in the South African Government are willing to jeopardize South Africa's friendship with the United States for the sake of terrorists who have a history of destabilizing the Middle East and targeting American citizens.

In light of intense Congressional interest in the Middle East peace process and combating terrorism worldwide, forceful action from you on this issue will receive strong support in Congress. The Government of South Africa should understand that, not only will U.S.-South African relations suffer if they arm a terrorist nation, but also a significant amount of U.S. foreign aid to South Africa will be cut off.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


339 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 84 on the Great Lakes (01/22)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1707 words


 

Nairobi - Mohamed Sahnoun, an Algerian diplomat who once headed UN operations in Somalia, will be named as special representative for both the United Nations and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) for the Great Lakes region of Central Africa.

* British Foreign Secretary Malcolm Rifkind on Tuesday admitted that a UN arms embargo on Rwanda had been circumvented from the British-ruled tax havens of the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands, said AFP. He also admitted that a subsequent inquiry had found delays in implementing the UN ruling in the British protectorates of Bermuda, Gibraltar and Hong Kong. Arms sanctions against Rwanda were passed by the UN on May 17 1994. Last November, documents found in a bus abandoned by Hutu extremist fleeing Allied Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) rebels near Goma in eastern Zaire, linked a British company, Mil-Tech, with weapons shipments to Hutu militias responsible for the 1994 Rwanda genocide. According to an AFP report, Mil- Tech is believed to have won orders from Rwanda worth more than $5.5 million US. 

* Following an assessment mission to northern Uganda on Saturday, UNHCR, UNICEF and International Services Volunteers' Association (AVSI) coordinated a relief operation for internally displaced people (IDP) in Kitgum district. Hundreds of people have been killed in Kitgum since early November and some 41,500 others have been displaced over the last ten years by fighting between government forces and the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA). The mission delivered food and non-food relief items and cash assistance of around 6.5 million Ugandan shillings to the IDPs. Further assistance could be provided to the area based on the outcome of an assessment by local authorities as well as reports to be submitted by UNICEF's health and water/sanitation experts.

* The Rwandan government issued a statement 22 January expressing its shock at the murder of three Spanish aid workers, and the wounding of an American. According to the statement read on Radio Rwanda, the government said that the recent acts of violence in Ruhengeri were being perpetrated by members of the ex-FAR and Interahamwe militia, who recently returned with the mass of Rwandan refugees from camps in Zaire and Tanzania. The Rwandan government claimed that the aim of the attacks was to "punish" humanitarian organizations who are working with the Tutsi-dominated Kigali government, said AFP. The government statement said Rwanda is paying the price for the government's leniency in forgoing screening to permit the quick and smooth resettlement of the returnees. The government said that it is now putting in place concrete security measures to ensure full security for local people as well as expatriates operating in the country.

Radio Rwanda also announced that a further 24 people had been killed on 21 January by unknown assailants in Nyamugali commune, Ruhengeri prefecture. Most of the dead were reported to be members of the civilian security patrols. They said it was unclear if suspects in the deaths had been apprehended.

* Over the weekend, AFP reported that some 1,500 Burundian Hutu refugees in a camp near Gikongoro, southwest Rwanda, could soon be sent back to Burundi. As most of the refugees have no intention of returning to Burundi voluntarily, many sources fear that authorities will have to resort to forced repatriation.Rwandan authorities had announced on 15 January that the refugees would be repatriated via the northern border post of Kanyaru-Haut, but there has been no movement to date.

* Amnesty International, in a statement carried by AFP, said that hundreds of refugees returning to Burundi from Tanzania and Zaire in recent weeks have been massacred. In the latest reported massacre earlier this month, Burundi troops killed 126 Hutu returnees expelled from Tanzania, prompting a UNHCR appeal to Tanzania to halt the deportations, said Reuters. Amnesty International is sending a high-level delegation, led by former Canadian foreign minister Flora MacDonald, to Dar es Salaam from January 22 to 27 to meet with Tanzanian officials. The delegation will urge the Tanzanian government to stop the forced repatriation of Burundian refugees. "This is a wider issue than refugees, it is the whole question of continued conflict and harassment in Burundi and people being forced back into that situation from refugee camps," MacDonald told AFP in London. The broader goal of the delegation's visit, she said, is to return the crisis in Burundi to public awareness.

* A spokesperson for the UNHCR told Reuters that some 22,000 Burundian refugees had arrived in neighbouring Tanzania during the first half of January and their exodus seemed to be accelerating. Over half of the newly arrived refugees are Zairians, fleeing fighting between Kabila's ADFL forces and the Zairian army (FAZ). The refugees joined some 36,000 who had fled to Tanzania in December and a further 98,000 in November.

A spokesperson for the Burundian army told AFP that the army had launched an attack on Hutu rebels in Kibira forest, northwest Burundi, on Saturday. He claimed that scores of Hutu rebels were killed and large numbers of weapons seized. The weapons were shown on national television on Monday. According to the spokesperson, one soldier was killed and three more injured during the attack.

* A Kigali court has sentenced Leonidas Ndikumwami, a Burundian citizen, to death for "leading a group of armed killers" in the 1994 genocide, a legal source told AFP. He is the nineth person to be sentenced to death since the trials began on December 27. The court rejected Ndikumwami's request on 14 January for more time to prepare his case with his new lawyer. He was not present for the sentencing Monday and no explanation for his absence was given. Many Burundian Hutus, most of whom were refugees in Rwanda at the time of the genocide, reportedly took part in the massacres. Calixte Ngendahimana, a former low-level local official, and Jovan Bavugayubisa, a former official of the ruling National Republic Movement for Democracy and Development were sentenced to death in Gisenyi court on Tuesday. An AFP report claimed that neither of the accused were represented by legal counsel at their 14 January hearing and both refused to plead guilty or not guilty.

* Humanitarian sources reported that some 5,000 Zairians were fleeing westward from Amisi, following unconfirmed reports of renewed fighting between FAZ and ADFL forces. A UNHCR spokesperson told Reuters that there had been no movement from the refugee camps in the same area.

* A Zairian military court has sentenced 4 officers and 10 soldiers to death for cowardice. The soldiers reportedly fled Amisi on 16 January in the face of a rebel offensive in which government troops have suffered a string of defeats, the soldiers' lawyers told AFP. The soldiers are expected to appeal within the statutory 24 hours for their case to be heard before the military court in Kinshasa. The defence argued that the soldiers were originally part of the Zairian police force, and therefore not prepared for combat. "It was chaos," one captain told AFP, adding that everyone fled in different directions.

Zairian President Mobutu Sese Seko announced Tuesday that Ramazani Baya, Zaire's ambassador to France, had been fired and would be returning to France by the end of the week to face prosecution for the killings of two teenagers in a car crash of 23 November 1996, said AFP. The decision ends a struggle between France, one of Zaire's main political allies in its bid to recover territory from ADFL rebels, and Zaire over the lifting of the ambassador's diplomatic immunity.

In Tripoli, Great SPLAJ radio reported that Zairian Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo had met with the Libyan foreign minister on 21 January in Kinshasa. The report said that emphasis in the meeting had been placed on ending foreign intervention in the continent and greater reliance on African solutions. Libya has agreed to help Zaire in its counter-offensive against the ADFL rebels but has not specified what form that aid will take, reported Reuters.

RTM television in Morocco reported that Honore Ngdanda, a special envoy of President Mobutu, had arrived in Rabat for meetings with Moroccan officials. Moroccan troops were used to quell separatist movements in Shaba province following independence in the 1960s.

Reuters reported that Egypt also has a special envoy visiting government authorities in Kinshasa.

Nairobi, 22 January 1997, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

Africa News


January 22, 1997


South Africa;
Tutu Responds to Racial Tension Charges


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Cape Town - Statement issued by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Chairperson, Truth and Reconciliation Commission, January 22, 1997

Newspaper reports on the alleged marginalisation of black members of the TRC have forced me into doing something which I should not be doing, which is issuing a statement from my sick bed.

Firstly, all major decisions are taken by the full Commission. Most Commissioners are black. Most members of each of the three constituent committees of the TRC are black. The chairpersons of each of the Committees, as well as the Chief Executive Officer, are black.

Secondly, the suggestion from anonymous sources in the Commission that it is run by a clique of liberals is insulting to me and I take very strong umbrage.

The implication is that I am almost a token chairperson who is not in control. Anyone who knows me is aware that I am not a person to be manipulated by cliques. Dr Alex Boraine consults closely with me on what he is doing. He does not take decisions other than those delegated to him without discussing them with me.

What is more, when we were appointing a Chief Executive Officer last year, Dr Boraine was quite insistent that a suitably qualified black person should be appointed.

It is sad that anonymous individuals are not using the existing channels laid down in the TRC to resolve grievances because it undermines the tremendously committed and conscientious work being done by staff, Committee members and Commissioners.

ends statement

ADVISORY NOTE: Archbishop Tutu dictated this statement from his bed and asks me to advise you he will not be available for the flood of follow-up interviews he is expecting, not even from radio stations needing sound-bites. He regrets this but asks for your understanding.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Business and Finance;
Millers Warned Against Increasing Meal Price in Zambia


BYLINE: Sam Mujuda and Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - IF mealie-meal dealers increase the price of the commodity farther than the present prices they will only be attracting the wrath of government, warned agriculture minister Edith Nawakwi yesterday.

Nawakwi, at a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday, said there was no justification for the price increase of the staple food because there was no maize crisis in the country.

"The price of maize has been the same for the past two months. There is no justification of the price increase of mealie-meal. It is a very clear intention by some people to cause something. And if the price is increased farther than this they will be twisting my arm. If they do so I will move in and they should not protest of interference because I will be protecting the innocent consumers," warned Nawakwi. 

Nawakwi threatened that if millers and traders continued to increase mealie- meal prices she will flood the market with cheaper mealie-meal.

"As Minister of Agriculture I have enough stocks to dampen the prices," said Nawakwi, condemning millers and traders who she accused of forming a price cartel. "The rise in price is a result of the selfish behaviour of some people. I have everything at my disposal to frustrate the private sector but that is not my duty. I want to be a friend to the private sector."

The minister did not, however, quantify the stocks of maize in the country but pointed out that it was easy to call her Zimbabwean colleague to get maize on credit or cash terms.

"We liberalised to create efficiency and not oligopolies. If my arm is twisted further I can land that maize from Chinoi at half the price," she warned. "I should not be forced to take measures that will dampen the market."

Answering concerns expressed by the Zambia National Farmers Union on the participation of government in the purchasing of fertiliser, Nawakwi said the government will continue to identify gaps left by the private sector and satisfy people's needs accordingly.

"No one would take fertiliser to Libonda, Namushakende and all those far- away places but the government can reach there," she said.

Mealie meal prices, particularly in Lusaka, have risen from the K8,200 price per 25kg bag to K12,500 in some cases.

A number of millers, including National Milling in Lusaka yesterday, denied they had increased the price of mealie-meal and blamed the hike on retailers. However, some millers believe the price of maize will soon be going up and a hike in the mealie-meal price is inevitable.

Nawakwi also disclosed that government was releasing an undisclosed amount of money to rehabilitate the dilapidated National Resources Development College (NRDC).

"We are putting in money to rehabilitate the college. The other colleges will have to wait. I will try to rehabilitate them within the next two years," Nawakwi said. - The Post/ZNBC

LANGUAGE: English

January 22, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Party Accused Of Offering Jobs To Friends


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - LUENA independent member of parliament Chrispine Sibetta has accused MMD and the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) officials of having offered recent coaching jobs to their friends so that they can "chew" the money together.

Sibetta, speaking in Parliament yesterday, requested FAZ to recall the Danish trainer Rould Poulsen if Zambia has to win any of the remaining World Cup qualifying games. 

"Zambians are known as the people who know sport, but what is happening to the world of football?" Sibetta asked."You have brought your friends to come and coach the team so that you can chew the loot together."

Sibetta said unless Poulsen is brought back, Zambia will lose to Congo again.

"We could have crushed South Africa but because of mismanagements of MMD and its officials we failed." Sibetta charged. "Unless Poulsen does come back you are losing to Zaire, to Congo and South Africa again."

FAZ have contracted the duo of Fred Mwila and Samuel "Zoom" Ndhlovu to replace Poulsen whose contract ended late last year.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


343 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Zambia: Melu - A Talented Striker, Defender


BYLINE: Ponga Liwewe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lusaka - FEW players have had the ability to play in two fundamentally different positions at the highest level and done so with great success.

Ashios Jordan Melu was one such player, first breaking into the national side as a striker and then returning a few years later to hold the fort at the back as a central defender.

In both positions he excelled, scoring 41 goals in 1983 to become the league's highest scorer and winning the Rothmans footballer of the year award. 

His football career began in the seventies on the Copperbelt, the birth place of most of Zambia's greatest players, and in his teens he was already on the books of the Bankroft Blades.

His shooting ability was soon noted and inevitability he wound up playing center forward. In the later part of the seventies, Bankroft Blades fortunes declined and not surprisingly, Melu was signed on by the Mufulira side, Wanderers.

At Wanderers Melu was a first team regular. Not renowned for his dribbling ability, it was for his goal scoring ability that earned him a place in the national team under the then coach Colonel Brightwell Banda. His first spell was rather brief as Zambia moved from one coach to another and each brought in players to suit their style.

In 1984 Samuel "Zoom" Ndhlovu, then Wanderers coach, took the unorthodox step of asking Melu to play in the backline for Mufulira Wanderers and it marked the start a revitalised career.

It was in his second spell as a defender that Melu made his mark. Despite playing at the back he got his name on the scorer charts regularly, mainly because of a ferocious shot that either rocketed into the net or brought down many a defender who stood in his way.

In 1988 Zambia qualified to the Olympic games in Seoul and Melu was instrumental in Zambia's exceptional performance that took them all the way to the quarter finals.

Against Italy, Melu and Samuel Chomba played in the central defence and held off the challenge of Italy's Carnevale and Virdis, two strikers who went on to play for Italy at senior level.

Melu played in the qualifying series for the 1990 World Cup in which Zambia were eliminated by Tunisia. To this day many fans feel this was the best side Zambia has ever produced and Melu was instrumental in marshalling the backline.

Soon after the Southern, East and Central African Football Association (SECAFA) Cup in 1990, Melu was signed on by the Greek side, Olympiakos, one of the top sides in the Greek league. Olympiakos fielded Melu for a full season before he was sold to an Australian side in 1991.

Melu's playing career came to an end soon after the 1992 Nations Cup in Senegal. In the tournament he played his part in getting Zambia to the quarter final where they lost 1-0 to the eventual winners of the competition, Cote de' Ivoire.

His love for the game ensured that his knowledge was not lost and he was appointed to the coaching staff at Mufulira Wanderers.

Before he took over the reigns, Wanderers had not won a the league since 1978. In 1995 Wanderers went on to lift the league championship with relative ease. Melu had moulded a side reminiscent of the great Wanderers side of the seventies.

In 1996 Melu led wanderers to their second successive championship and firmly re-established Wanderers as the top club in the country.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Zambia;
Magistrates Go On Strike


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 107 words


 

Lusaka - MAGISTRATES and local court justices yesterday went on strike to press for better working conditions. 

They vowed not go back to work until their demands are met.

Negotiations for better working conditions started in 1995 but the magistrates and local court justices said they had yielded nothing.

The strike yesterday affected court proceedings as the magistrates stayed away from work. The Post/ZNBC

Africa News


January 22, 1997


Zambia;
Minister Calls For Outlawing Of Polygamy


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - POLYGAMY must be outlawed in all its forms because it is contributing to the spread of AIDS, Mongu Central Agenda for Zambia (AZ) member of parliament Inonge Mbikusita-Lewanika told the House yesterday.

Mbikusita-Lewanika said there was a need for systematic legal system which benefit all Zambians. 

"The government should outlaw polygamy, formal or informal, it is contributing to the spread of AIDS and HIV," Mbikusita-Lewanika said. "We need a legal system which will benefit all Zambians, the poor, the young, the children and all the marginalised people."

But Siavonga MMD member of parliament Frederick Hapunda, rising on a point of order said polygamy was part of the nation's culture.

"I don't think it is in order for the honorable member of parliament who has been advocating for culture to call for the outlawing of polygamy," Hapunda said.

And an MMD back bencher, Roan member of parliament Vernon Mwaanga warned government not take for granted its majority presence in parliament to pass bills which have no benefit to the nation.

Mwaanga said all bills will be scrutinised to ensure that they were in the interest of the people.

"There should be no expectation by the government for an automatic passing of the bills just because they know they have majority support. Every bill shall be thoroughly scrutinised and ensure that they are fair, rational and in the best interest of the country," Mwaanga said.

Mbikusita-Lewanika also said people in rural areas were not happy with the current Land Act.

"People in rural areas have no money to buy the title deeds and even if they can buy them they don't have the capital to develop the land," She said. "They are now very afraid of the current system which only favour those with money."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 22, 1997


Science and Health;
Researchers Make Breakthrough In Locusts Control Techniques


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 893 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Scientists at the Nairobi-based International Center for Insect Physiology and Ecology claim to have made a major breakthrough in understanding the phenomena that cause locusts to lay eggs en masse and keep the locust swarms together.

Researchers have said that the discovery is crucial in finding scientific methods to disrupt the life-cycle of the gregarious insects which currently pose a threat to crops in various parts of Africa.

Their effort complements a similar study by researchers at Oxford University in London. 

In its latest issue the monthly, The Zambian Farmer, the newspaper says that researchers at Oxford have identified a chemical which is sometimes found in the foam that surrounds locust eggs. It is believed the chemical could provide the key to locust control.

The chemical is thought to be responsible for turning young locusts into gregarious pests. It has been found that the locusts hatch as solitary insects where the chemical is absent.

Stephen Simpson and his colleagues at Oxford say the chemical acts on the locust embryos as they develop in the eggs and switches on the genes responsible for turning a locust from being a solitary into a gregarious insect.

"All the young hatch as gregarious locusts which is the key to the locust's importance as a pest. If it did not make that change then it would not become a pest," Simpson said.

His team also found that four hours of crowding by locusts was sufficient to stimulate the female species to produce the subject chemical.

With the knowledge gained at the institute and at Oxford, scientists say that they can develop ways to disrupt the locust's crucial life stages and find a long-term control strategy against the destructive pest.

Scientists say the locust consumes vegetation equal to its own weight of about two grams per day and that an average swarm is capable of devouring what 10 elephants are able to eat.

Locusts generally feed on green grass and are particularly attracted to crop plants like maize, sorghum, millet and wheat. The young hoppers like maize stalks more because it is succulent.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


347 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Nigeria;
Mixed Reactions To Nigeria's 1997 Budget


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Some provisions of Nigeria's 1997 budget which Finance Minister Anthony Ani explained Monday, has continued to elicit mixed reactions from a cross-section of the population.

While some economists have hailed it as realistic, others have raised reservations on how faithfully the provisions would be implemented.

Yet others have adopted a-wait-and-see attitude toward the 11.2-billion- dollar estimate dubbed "Budget of Growth and Development" by head of state Gen. Sani Abacha.

Kayode Familoni, an economic consultant at the University of Lagos, said the budget would raise standard of living in the country, if it is properly implemented. 

"I do believe it is designed to be welfarist and populist in the sense that it is a budget that takes cognisance of the problems of the people," he said.

In another reaction, Ismaila Funtua, publisher of the 'Democrat' newspaper, commended the government for its efforts aimed at alleviating the sufferings of the masses.

However, Ismaila, who had expected the government would scrap import duties on newsprint and other publishing accessories, said the budget did not contain any incentive to the media industry.

A renowned Nigerian banker, Samuel Falegan, is among those who believe that the budget holds the promise of growth.

But he warned that the decision to make the Central Bank of Nigeria independent, should be pursued with caution.

Falegan, former managing director of the Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria, said the apex bank could not be "completely independent of government in the interest of the nation," adding that instead, the bank should aim at greater efficiency and professionalism.

Two issues in the budget that have generated much debate are the retention of the dual exchange rate regime by government and the increase of the paid- up capital of commercial and merchant banks from 50 million to 500 million naira.

While bankers prefer a floating exchange rate to the current dual exchange regime of 22 naira to the dollar for government transactions and 80 naira to the greenback at the autonomous market, Ani said the government's ultimate goal to merge the two rates would have to wait.

Some bankers feel the jump in the paid-up capital for commercial and merchant banks "is on the high side".

But Paul Unongo, who was minister of steel development during the second republic, said the increase would help sanitize and strengthen the banking sector.

Previous liberal terms had resulted in several bank failures, prompting government to set up the Failed Bank Tribunal. Some 200 bank chief executives have either been tried and convicted or are awaiting trial before the tribunal.

Organized labor has also expressed some reservation with the decision to decentralize industrial bargaining.

Under the new arrangement, each of Nigeria's 36 states is free to fix wages and salaries for their workers, contrary to the previous arrangement in which the federal government set the ceiling for workers remuneration.

Labor leader Sylvester Ejiofor commended the government for harmonizing the emoluments of pensioners nationwide. But he warned that decentralizing wage negotiation could pose a big challenge to the state governments and labor unions.

State workers had gone on strike in the past over the failure by some state governments to pay salaries or fringe benefits fixed by the federal government.

Ejiofor said "deregulating collective bargaining may not pose an insurmountable problem" provided negotiations were conducted in good faith.

While the former petroleum minister, Tam David-West, described as realistic, government's decision to base the budget on oil price of 17 dollars a barrel, public servants are disappointed that the budget said nothing about any wage increase.

On the whole, Nigeria's former envoy to Canada, Ayodele Kadiri, summarized the general view on the budget, when he said that "implementation...is the crucial thing".

"A budget could be beautiful, but it may be truncated if not properly implemented," he added.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Nigeria;
22 People Arrested Over Lagos Bombings


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian security authorities have arrested 22 persons in connection with explosions that have rocked Lagos, the country's economic hub, in recent months.

A military spokesman said Tuesday that the 22 suspects were arrested in Lagos and its surrounding areas. 

The official, Col. Godwin Ugbo, the acting director of defence information, declined to disclose the identities of the suspects, or whether a former presidential aspirant and current opposition leader, Olu Falae, was among them.

"I don't know if the 22 persons include Chief Falae and I am not going to be categorizing whether they are civilians or military, politicians or not," Ugho told journalists.

Falae was arrested in the wake of the Jan. 7 explosion, which killed at least two soldiers and injured a dozen others in an army truck.

Two other bombs exploded in Lagos in Dec. 1996, apparently targeted at the military. At least one person died, and a score of others were wounded.

In November that year, an explosion killed three people, including the chief security officer of the Murtala Mohammed International Airport, in Lagos.

Nobody has claimed responsibility for the explosions.

But Ugbo said, "it is something positive that arrests have been made." He added that members of security forces were making progress in their investigations.

Urban terrorism, involving the use of explosives was alien to Nigeria until 1986 when Dele Giwa, the founding editor of the weekly magazine, Newswatch, died in a parcel-bomb explosion. The assailants have still not been identified.

Since then, there have been a dozen bomb attacks in different parts of the country, especially during the peak of political crisis in 1993 and 1994.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Southern Africa;
Common Market Boss Resists Probe


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - The suspended secretary-general of Common Market of Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa), Bingu wa Mutharika, refused to be probed Wednesday by a committee constituted by the organization's Council of Ministers which he says is biased.

Rather, Mutharika demanded that a committee constituted by the Comesa heads of states and government, who appointed him, investigate his alleged misuse of funds at the organizations secretariat.

He has been accused of using the organizations resources for personal reasons and of frequent travel to Malawi, his home country, to indulge in politics, as well as trips to Zimbabwe, home of his wife.

He challenged his critics to check records in Malawi and verify whether or not he had registered with a political party to challenge President Muluzi. 

Mutharika was suspended Saturday by the Council of Ministers chaired by Chakakala Chaziya, the Malawian minister of commerce and industry. Chaziya said Mutharikas three-month suspension would facilitate investigations into the allegations.

A committee comprising of five member-states, to be headed by Zambia, was elected to probe the matter in three months.

At a news conference in the Zambian capital, Mutharika claimed Wednesday that his suspension was a political conspiracy hatched in Malawi by unnamed people who suspected that he wanted to run for the presidency.

He claimed to be the victim of a smear campaign intended to destroy his career and high reputation built over the years.

His suspension, he said, was the result of a carefully calculated political conspiracy. This was so, he added, because since the establishment, 15 years ago, of Comesa's precursor, the Preferential Trade Area for Eastern and Southern Africa, the council had never discussed documents which were anonymous and whose authors were afraid to append their signatures thereon.

"The principle is that if the charges are indeed true, then those making them must be prepared to put their names on them and stand by their charges," he said.

Mutharika said he would only appear for interrogation before a committee established by the heads of state and government, and not the one constituted by the council. He said that under the Comesa treaty the council had no powers to question him.

"I wish to observe that the council of ministers, through manipulation by Honorable Chakakala Chaziya, has already found me guilty even before the so called investigations are conducted," he said. "Therefore, it is doubtful if a committee constituted by them will truly be impartial."

Chaziya, he said "very hastily" accepted the anonymous documents and pushed a decision through council for the investigation.

Mutharika said he had a right to be provided with full details of the charges against him and to know the names and identities of his accusers. The council has refused to give him the details.

However, he suspects his accusers to be people from Comesa whom he had rebuked for indiscipline.

Mutharika also said the council had refused to allow him respond to the charges, which would have enabled council to examine both sides of the story before taking a decision.

"Honorable Chaziya refused to grant me the right of response," he said.

On the withdrawal of Mozambique and Lesotho from Comesa, Mutharika said that Chaziya was incompetent to dismiss his judgement that the problem lay with external forces influencing INL002 from SSS.073 (970122-18:30) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG072G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) these members to leave the organization.

Mutharika told PANA that Comesa had major problems. The greatest of these, he said, was for the organization to resolve its relations with the 12-nation Southern African Development Community and having the commitment of member- states to run his 20-nation organization.

Last week, Chaziya sought to play down Mutharika's assertion that foreign forces had colluded to run down Comesa because it was one of Africa's economic success stories.

LANGUAGE: English

350 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia Air Force Airlifts Medicines To Flooded Area


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)- The Zambia Air Force started airlifting medical supplies Wednesday to Maamba, southern Zambia, which has been cut off by floods following torrential rains since Sunday.

The air force delivered mainly anti-malarial, diarrhea and cholera medicines for the 85,000 affected residents, just in case of an outbreak of epidemics. This is because the floods have damaged sewerage systems.

The national radio quoted the Health Ministry as saying that the airlift was necessary because it was difficult to reach the area by road, since bridges had also been washed away.

Medical authorities at the Maamba Coal Mine were forced to evacuate patients from the local clinic Monday, after the buildings were submerged in water.

The Zambian Ministry of Mines also sent a team of five senior government officials from various government ministries to assess the situation, Wednesday. The team is expected to compile a report for government action.

Speaking from the town of Livingstone, the permanent secretary for the Southern Region, Sylvester Mpishi, who toured the area Wednesday, told PANA that the occasional airlift of medical supplies will be needed as long as the bridges remain unrepaired. Road engineers and electricians are already in the area to restore services.

He said that the floods had also swept some crops. The impact of this will only be felt at harvest in April and May.

The permanent secretary for the ministry of health, Kashiwa Bulaya, said that the cost and duration of operation could only be known after the senior government officials, sent to the area, compile their report.

Almost all parts of Zambia have been swamped by heavy rains. Meteorologists say the downpours have been mainly induced by a weather system from Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Ethiopia Cancels Africa Cup Preliminary Match Against Morocco


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopia says it will no longer take part in Sunday's Africa Cup preliminary soccer match against Morocco, after most of its 23-man squad disappeared Tuesday in Rome, Italy, en route from Addis Ababa to Rabat.

The government press reported Wednesday, officials of the Ethiopian Football Confederation as saying that only seven members of the squad turned up at Rome Airport for the connection flight. The rest were assumed to have defected. No reasons have yet been given.

It is uncertain whether Ethiopia will withdraw from the remaining preliminary matches in Group C, for the 1998 Africa Cup of Nations. That event will be held in Ougadougou, Burkina Faso.

This is the second time Ethiopian soccer players have defected in Rome while en route to Morocco. Six players left the squad in October 1992 as the national team was heading for a preliminary World Cup contest.

Ethiopia, then, opted to field a weak team which included a reserve goalkeeper and the assistant coach, believed to be in his late 40s.

The game was abandoned when Morocco was leading 6-0 as most of the Ethiopian players left the field "faking" injuries.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 22, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Denies Threatening South Africa Over Syrian Arms Deal


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - The United States has denied that it is threatening South Africa over a proposed 650-million-U.S.-dollar arms deal with Syria.

"No-one in the U.S. Administration is threatening South Africa," said James Joseph, the U.S ambassador to South Africa.

Joseph was addressing the Johannesburg Rotary Club Tuesday. 

He said that U.S. President Bill Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and himself had gone out of their way to demonstrate support of South Africa's sovereignty and to avoid intervention.

"We have laws on our books that the U.S. Government is required to implement," Joseph Said. "When a U.S. State Department spokesman was asked recently about this, he acknowledged that the government has to implement these laws. But such an acknowledgement should not be considered a threat."

Joseph's denial follows angry South African reaction to a reported statement, last week, by a U.S. State Department spokesman in Washington that the U.S. might cut about 120-million dollars in aid if South Africa goes ahead with the proposed Syrian arms deal.

Washington opposed the sale of arms or military technology to countries it considers are involved in international terrorism. Washington considers Syria one of these, although Syria was an ally in the U.S.-led coalition that defeated Iraq in the 1991 Gulf War.

Responding to the state department statement, President Nelson Mandela and Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki said South Africa would not be dictated to by any power and would make its own decisions regarding arms sales.

The acting African National Congress Secretary-General, Cheryl Carolus, also accused the U.S. of bullyboy tactics and of hypocrisy for threatening the South African Government over the Syrian arms deal.

In his address Tuesday, Joseph said that while South Africa was considering what to do, he would make no public comment on the issue.

"There has been a lot of speculation in the media on something that has not occurred," he said, "and we must await the South African government's decision. Then I will be willing to talk to you."

Joseph went on to say that the U.S. and South Africa had a shared value of curbing the spread of weapons of mass destruction.

Clinton had promised Mandela in 1994 that the U.S. would provide Pretoria with 600-million in aid for its social needs. South Africa received about 120 million dollars in U.S. aid in 1996 and a similar figure was envisaged for 1997.


LOAD-DATE: January 22, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Science and Health;
Prehistoric Stone Tools Found In Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopian and U.S. scientists involved in archeological work say they have found what could be man's oldest stone tools in the Afar depression of north-eastern Ethiopia.

The scientists said the stone tools "were probably made by ancestral humans (homo) that lived between 2.5 and 2.6 million years ago along ancient streams.

The Ethiopian Centre for Research and Conservation of Cultural Heritage that announced the find in a statement on Wednesday, said however, that " Fossils of the makers of the tools have not yet been found." 

The Gona area, about 300 kms north-east of Addis Ababa and 75 kms north of Aramis, where the oldest fossil "hominids" were recently found, is known to contain small patches of "even earlier stone tools, but their age was not confirmed until March 1995," the statement said quoting a research paper on the discovery.

"These are the oldest stone tools ever found," Ethiopian paleontologist and the main author of the paper, Sleshi Semaw, said.

J.W.K. Harris, the American co-author of the paper and chairman of the anthropology department of Rutgers University in New Jersey, said: " Surprisingly, for this earlier date, the tool makers had a clear understanding of producing sharp-edged tools, an ability which probably gave them a comparative advantage in exploiting a wider range of food sources in the ancient Savana landscape."

The makers of the Gona prehistoric stone tools are still unknown, and the research team made up of geologists, archaeologists, and paleontologists from Ethiopia and the United States involved in the work plan to continue the search for fossils and the painstaking task of identifying the makers of the tools.

In November, last year, a team of scientists from Ethiopia, Israel and the United States announced the discovery of the remains of early human fossils dating 2.33 million years in the Hadar area of north-eastern Ethiopia close to Aramis, where the earliest known ancestor of early man, the famous "Lucy," was discovered in 1974.

"An upper jaw of early Homo, the genus to which modern man belong, has been recovered with primitive tools," the scientific team sponsored by the Institute of Human Origins (IHO) of the University of California at Berkeley, said in a statement in Addis Ababa on 19 November.

The scientists said these remains may hold clues to the ancestry of living humans, since they represent "the oldest family dated association of stone tools with a fossil of human ancestors."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


354 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africans Urged To Support Adolescent Health Programmes


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A senior United Nations official on Thursday, challenged civil societies in Africa to press their governments to implement the pledges they made toward funding adolescent reproductive health programmes.

Marie Angelique Savane, the Africa division director of the UN Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA), told journalists in Addis Ababa that it was up to governments to provide the financial resources to take care of crucial health problems, including AIDS, which mainly afflict the youth. 

"We in UNFPA shall play a catalysing role and create a conducive atmosphere for donors to come in," she said in reply to a question as to how funds will be raised to finance the numerous recommendations that are expected from the five-day African Forum On Adolescent Reproductive Health, which ends here on Friday.

Savane, who is Senegalese, revealed that in its new programme cycle for 1997, the UNFPA would be implementing projects in 12 African states, which have adolescent health as a priority.

"We will strengthen our family life education programme and enhance youth groups with management skills to ensure they take action in favour of their fellow youths," she said.

Savane also said the UN agency would embark on a programme to make men more receptive to issues related to family planning. Hitherto, she said, family planning and other issues have been monopolised by women.

Asked why UNFPA chose the Washington-based Centre for Population and Development Activities (CEDPA) as its executing agency for the adolescent reproductive health package instead of an Africa-based group, Savane said she and her experts failed to find an African organisation with appropriate skills.

The CEDPA president, Peggy Curlin, who co-addressed the news conference, suggested that a community-based approach could be employed to solve problems of funding adolescent reproductive health programmes.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia Air Force Airlifts Medicines To Flooded Area


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)- The Zambia Air Force started airlifting medical supplies Wednesday to Maamba, southern Zambia, which has been cut off by floods following torrential rains since Sunday.

The air force delivered mainly anti-malarial, diarrhea and cholera medicines for the 85,000 affected residents, just in case of an outbreak of epidemics. This is because the floods have damaged sewerage systems.

The national radio quoted the Health Ministry as saying that the airlift was necessary because it was difficult to reach the area by road, since bridges had also been washed away.

Medical authorities at the Maamba Coal Mine were forced to evacuate patients from the local clinic Monday, after the buildings were submerged in water.

The Zambian Ministry of Mines also sent a team of five senior government officials from various government ministries to assess the situation, Wednesday. The team is expected to compile a report for government action.

Speaking from the town of Livingstone, the permanent secretary for the Southern Region, Sylvester Mpishi, who toured the area Wednesday, told PANA that the occasional airlift of medical supplies will be needed as long as the bridges remain unrepaired. Road engineers and electricians are already in the area to restore services.

He said that the floods had also swept some crops. The impact of this will only be felt at harvest in April and May.
