Almost all parts of Zambia have been swamped by heavy rains. Meteorologists say the downpours have been mainly induced by a weather system from Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Ghana;
Ghana Telecom Workers Protest Sale Of Shares


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Communications Workers Union (CWU) of the Trade Union Congress of Ghana has criticized the sale of 30 percent of the equity shares of Ghana Telecom (GT) without considering workers interest in the deal.

The union also balked at the price at which the shares were sold.

Therefore, It has appealed to the government to cancel the deal and channel it through the "established order" to save the country and the telecommunications industry from labor unrest. The general-secretary of the workers union, identified by the Ghana News Agency as D. Odum-Ewuakye, told a news conference Wednesday, in Accra, that the 38-million-dollar deal, was struck without the Divestiture Implementation Committee and without public knowledge of the real value of Ghana Telecom. 

The sale was made to G-Com, a consortium led by Telekom Malaysia,

The workers union said that the Ministry of Transport and Telecommunications also supervised the sale without the committees knowledge. The committee is the statutory body in charge of all matters on divestiture.

Odum-Ewuakye said the real value for the 30 percent GT stake was 100 million dollars and the acquisition of a licence for a second net operation in Ghana by ACG (Ghana) Telesystem Company should have earned 30 million dollars instead of the 10.12-million-dollar offer.

The workers said that Ghana Telecom remained a viable and strategic national asset, whose preservation must be the concern of all.

The minister of transport and telecommunication, Edward Salia, has described the Union's call for the sale review as "uninformed and unfortunate. "

Reacting to the union's pronouncements Wednesday, he said the equity share sale process was conducted by a competent and well-represented body, guided by international bidding rules.

He said three workers from Ghana Telecom, the majority group, with a representative from the committee served on the board.

Salia said that G-COM won the bid because it was the only group which satisfied bidding requirements and demonstrated the willingness to invest in Ghana, "in spite of the biased views held by foreign investors on the African environment."

Salia said his ministry's exclusive supervision of the sale was in line with its sector reform program. This system aims at restructuring the entire telecommunication system to make it responsive to the demands of the day.

He said that G-COM was a good financial administrator and had a reputation for adherence to working ethics, which were capable of making Ghana Telecom profitable.

On the viability of Ghana Telecom, Salia said the company's liability exceeded its assets by 100 million dollars. The company may have made strides lately, he said, but its rate of recovery was discouraging.

He said the ministry only sold 30 percent of the shares because it wanted to avoid the transfer of a public monopoly into private monopoly, which is against the government's economic philosophy of competition and diversity.

"The remaining 70 percent would adequately cater for the employee share ownership program, which makes all workers in GT share owners," he said.

Salia said GT had demonstrated that it could not cope with the current demands for communication gadgets.

"It has grown over the years by 50,000 lines, the majority of which was actualized in the last two years.

"The inefficiency of GT is legendary and any attempt to keep it in its present state would create problems for the industry and the nation.

"It is certainly an anachronistic instrument due for transformation; our only chance to change it is now," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Kenya;
Moi Wants Nairobi Rid of Mounting Garbage


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - President Daniel Arap Moi has ordered the Nairobi City Council to privatize, immediately, the collection of garbage in the Kenya capital.

Moi lamented that although the council collected a monthly service charge on city residents, it had failed to meet its obligations. 

Moi, who was addressing scores of Nairobi residents outside his office Wednesday, also announced that the city would soon be divided into eight boroughs to improve administration.

Moi's order on garbage collection will be welcomed by residents and visitors who have had to live with the offensive stench of heaps of garbage across this city of two million people.

The once beautiful city dubbed "The Green City In The Sun" is now considered to be one of the dirtiest in the world, characterized by uncollected garbage in residential estates and even in parts of its central business district.

Moi said that Nairobi, being an international gateway, must project a clean image.

He blamed the city's unhealthy state on incompetent management.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Nigeria;
Visa Scam At The British High Commission In Lagos


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - An embarrassing visa scam, said to involve diplomats at the British High Commission in Lagos, has resulted in the recall to London of some officials, diplomatic sources said Thursday.

"The alleged racket is so serious that London is sending a team of investigators to Nigeria," the sources added. 

But a spokesman of the high commission decline to comment Thursday.

"I am afraid I cannot comment on the issue. I will like to refer you to the Home Office in London," the official said.

The scope of the racket is sketchy, with British diplomats saying little on the issue, but diplomats of other nations claimed the indicted officials were alleged to have charged applicants as much as 3,000 U.S. dollars per visa.

A single entry visa to Britain costs less than 40 dollars.

The British High Commission in Nigeria receives the highest number of visa applications, estimated at 200 a day. But only a fraction of these are successful, because of London's restrictions on Nigerians travelling to Britain.

Nigeria is a former British colony and, until a few years ago Nigerians, as citizens of the British-led Commonwealth, did not require visas to travel to Britain.

But London introduced the visa regime to stem what it called the influx of illegal immigrants, who constitute a burden on the British government.

Despite the restrictions, hundreds of desperate visa-seeking Nigerians throng the visa office of the high commission in Lagos on a daily basis.

The indicted immigration officials apparently took advantage of these desperate applicants in the racket.

Independent diplomatic sources said the current scam would be particularly embarrassing for London, which often castigates African Governments and officials for corruption.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 85 on the Great Lakes (01/23)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1907 words


 

Nairobi - International pressure to have the regional economic sanctions against Burundi suspended or lifted is gaining momentum.

A German parliamentary delegation, currently visiting Burundi, said the sanctions were of no benefit and that Burundians themselves should find solutions to their own problems. Speaking to the press, after meeting Pierre Buyoya, the MPs said they would urge their parliament to support peace programmes in African countries, national radio reported.

South African President Nelson Mandela's special envoy is also in the country on a week-long visit during which he will have talks with top officials.

Heightened concern has been expressed by the UN and NGOs over the dire fuel supply situation: a direct consequence of the regional embargo. Faced with the refusal of the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) to act upon new requests for fuel supplies exempted from the embargo, one UN official remarked that "we're running on fumes". 

UN agencies have consistently warned that unless action to remedy the situation is taken soon, they may be forced to buy fuel on the black market or suspend operations. If this happens 150,000 displaced people, returnees and other vulnerable groups will not receive the basic food rations they require to survive. Additionally, 60,000 malnourished children under five will not be provided with supplementary food in health centres throughout the country and some two million hospitalised people will not receive essential drugs and other medical supplies. Hundreds of thousands of people will also be affected by the non-distribution of seeds, fertilisers, water and sanitation supplies. Essential vaccines in cold storage, needed to treat some 190,000 children, will have to be destroyed.

However the Organisation of African Unity stuck to its position in favour of maintaining sanctions against Burundi. In a statement issued yesterday in Addis Ababa, following a meeting of its conflict prevention committee, the OAU claimed sanctions should continue because of a "multiplication of human rights violations" in Burundi. In particular it highlighted the recent killing of some 120 returnees from Tanzania by the army. The Burundi authorities have said the returnees, forced out by Tanzania after trouble in the camps, were members of the outlawed Hutu rebel movement, Palipehutu. The OAU committee also announced it was sending a fact-finding mission to Zaire and other nations in the Great Lakes region.

With mounting concern over the fate of Burundian refugees in Tanzania, the state-owned Tanzanian 'Daily News' on Tuesday reported that police had discovered the bodies of 14 Burundians buried near a refugee camp in the Ngara area. Local authorities believed the refugees had been buried alive and that the killers lit a bonfire over the gravesite to camouflage it. As a result, police had increased security in the Tanzanian camps which shelter some 230,000 Burundian Hutu refugees.

Tanzanian President Mkapa told a visiting Amnesty International delegation that his country was well aware of the situation in Burundi and would not force out the refugees. He said the 126 refugees who went back to Burundi had refused to abide by Tanzania's refugee regulations and had "volunteered" to return. "The Tanzanian government was not involved in any way in forcing these people to return to Burundi," he told the AI team.

* A former UN military official with extensive experience in Rwanda warned that security incidents in the northwest of the country may just be the tip of the iceberg. Noting that the Ruhengeri and Gisenyi areas have always been the heart of Hutu extremism, he pointed out that ex-FAR/Interahamwe may resort to their often-used tactic of mining roads as aid agencies pull out of the troubled regions and travel up from Kigali instead. A possible response by the RPA would be to move some of its integrated ex-FAR soldiers into those sectors, as in the past they have proved effective at convincing Hutu civilians to support the Rwandan government.

In a hard-hitting statement yesterday, Rwandan Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana pledged to put the perpetrators of violence "out of action". Measures had been taken to counter the spiral of violence, which he described as a " provocation that calls for tough intervention and a riposte without delay". " Those who have taken to the art of killing ... will find they face a resolutely determined government, ready to act and strike equally hard to discourage their intentions," he said. According to AFP, Gasana added that his government did not want aid agencies to pull out because they were doing valuable work.

Thousands of refugees, thought to be emerging from the forests of eastern Zaire, have been crossing into southwest Rwanda from Bukavu. The ICRC said since January 8 nearly 2,000 people a day had been crossing the border, arriving around the town of Kamembe. UNHCR said a total of 30,000 returnees had arrived as of January 22, malnourished and generally in very poor shape. From the Nyagatare transit centre, they were walking on to their home communes, with the most vulnerable being taken in trucks. It is probable that yet more people are crossing the border.

* Medecins du Monde (MDM) have pulled out most of their staff in Rwanda, following the murder of three Spanish employees in Ruhengeri. Three French volunteers remain in Kigali. MDM workers throughout the world observed a minute's silence in memory of their Spanish colleagues, who appear to have been specifically targeted by gunmen dressed in khaki fatigues. Three Rwandan soldiers were also killed. The Rwandan vice-president's political adviser, Claude Dusaidi, said three ex-FAR soldiers were in custody in connection with the incident. On Sunday, a security guard was killed following an attack on the CONCERN compound in Ruhengeri. Dusaidi said the army was sealing off the area in a bid to contain the violence and flush out the perpetrators. Following the killing of the MDM workers and speculation about a Zairean counter-offensive, some NGOs in eastern Zaire have been scaling down their operations. MSF have reduced their staff in Tingi-Tingi camp, while Action contre la Faim (ACF) has suspended its activities there.

* Zairean ADFL rebels yesterday denied that number two in the alliance, Commander Andre Ngandu Kisase, had been killed. Reports earlier in the week claimed Kisase had been killed by Mai-Mai militia in an ambush near Butembo on January 8. However a rebel commander, interviewed on ADFL's Radio of the People, described the reports as "absolute lies", saying Kisase had been injured and was receiving care. "Very soon you will see he is back to normal," the commander said. The denial followed Monday's announcement by Zairean Premier Kengo wa Dondo that a "war" would be waged to regain rebel-occupied territory in eastern Zaire. The Zairean authorities appear to be launching a campaign to raise morale in the country. Army chief General Mahele Lioko has set up a command post at the airport in Kisangani and reports from the town say disciplined troops are now guarding public buildings. Military sources, quoted by AFP, said the latest element in Mahele's morale-boosting efforts was the court martial and subsequent death sentencing of 14 officers for cowardice. The soldiers have appealed, but the sources believe the sentences will be carried out to make an example of them.

* Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni has returned to the war front to continue the military campaign against rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army in the northern Gulu area. A report in the Kenyan "Daily Nation' newspaper today said army commander Maj-Gen Mugisha Muntu was also in the area where new military strategies were being worked out. Their visit north comes amid conflicting reports of civilian massacres allegedly committed by LRA rebels early this month. According to official sources, 40 people were killed but independent assessments put the figure as high as 300, the 'Daily Nation' said. Coinciding with Museveni's departure north, came claims in the state- owned 'New Vision' on Monday that rebels were planning a major offensive against government troops. The article alleged that Sudanese fighter planes were dropping food supplies to rebel positions in the Gulu and Kitgum areas.

Sudan yesterday accused Uganda of a troop build-up along the southern front of their common border. The troop reinforcements were "within the framework of the acts of aggression to which Sudan is being exposed," Sudanese Information Minister Brig. Dr Tayyib Muhammad Khayr claimed, according to Sudanese radio. He added that his government had made "all necessary arrangements to confront every act of aggression against the southern border".

* Two of the major players in the Great Lakes conflict, President Museveni and his French counterpart Jacques Chirac, are set to discuss the deteriorating situation in the region on February 11. Museveni will stop off in Paris en route from Washington where he is to attend a UN credit summit. According to Museveni's press secretary Hope Kivengere, economic ties were expected to take centre stage but regional security would also form part of the agenda.

* Mohammed Sahnoun of Algeria looks set to be named the joint UN-OAU special representative for the Great lakes region. If the post is approved by the Security Council, it is proposed he report to the secretaries-general of both the UN and the OAU in order to strengthen coordination between the two organisations.

Nairobi, 23 January 1997, 15:00 gmt (END)

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Zambia;
Post Reporter Detained


BYLINE: Staff Reporters, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lusaka - A POST Newspaper journalist was yesterday arrested and detained at Woodlands police station for effecting a "citizen's arrest" of a police intelligence officer who was impersonating as Chronicle newspaper reporter.

Post reporter Kunda Mwila, at a press conference of Common Market for East and Southern Africa (COMESA) secretary general Bingu Mutharika in Lusaka yesterday, challenged a security officer who had introduced himself as a Chronicle Newspaper journalist to prove his identity.

Detective Constable Innocent Kanunga who arrived late for the press briefing introduced himself to COMESA secretary general Mutharika as Vincent Mugala of the Chronicle when asking for a copy of his speech. 

But when Mwila, who was standing nearby and overheard his Chronicle connection claims asked him about the whereabouts of 'his' newspaper's offices and when he joined the paper, Kanunga fumbled saying they had several offices and him was based at the town office. He could not tell where the rest offices were located.

And when asked by stated owned Zambia Daily Mail reporter, Isaac Chimpampe, a former Chronicle employee to mention some of his work mates, Kanunga failed to name any.

"I joined the Chronicle sometime last year and my telephone number is 236368 (but actual number is 233594)," Kanunga said. "I am new and I don't know many people and where other offices are located."

But Kanunga, under interrogation by ARMCO security officers, admitted he was impersonating.

"It was part of our professional tactics. We have a right to cover in any way which you can't know. I have been attending all the press conferences in Zambia, even in Katete," Kanunga boasted. "We are sent by the state, if I am not here how do you expect the President to know what is happening?"

Mwila and ARMCO officers confiscated his identity card, and rushed him to Woodlands police station.

Kanunga, upon arrival at the police station took revenge on Mwila and charged him with conduct likely to cause bleach of peace.

Kunda was locked up in cells from 11:00 hours and was only released around 14:00 hours.

Chronicle editor, Lwendo Hamusankwa, described the act by Kanunga as " stupid and should be stopped at once".

Hamusankwa, in an interview yesterday, said police should not infiltrate the media with stupid intentions of tarnishing the image of the independent press in the country.

"Impersonating is evil, a crime to anybody who commits it, and we as an organisation will protest formally to the Inspector General of Police and home affairs minister because we feel they have no right whatever to impersonate us in their clandestine moves," Hamusankwa said.

"We have reports, from within the police and state security agencies, that we are being followed," Hamusankwa disclosed. "The move by police to impersonate us maybe just one of the attempts to monitor our employees."

LANGUAGE: English

January 23, 1997


Zambia;
Female Minister Denounces NGO Women


BYLINE: Kunda Mwila, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Agriculture, food and fisheries minister Edith Nawakwi yesterday warned feminist NGOs to keep away from her.

Nawakwi, seconding the motion of thanks to President Chiluba's speech, described most NGOs as "people who cry after milk has been spilled".

"We have heard of the so called Women's Lobby Group, the so called Women for Change with their perpetual cries. But I want to tell them today, I don't expect them to invite me to any of their meetings because they are a type of people who cry after milk has been spilled," Nawakwi charged. "I am a woman, I stood in 1991 and I ran in the 1996 elections but I had none of these NGOs who came to my help. 

She said NGOs should not plan their programmes in the Ivory Towers of the Pamodzi Hotel but should go to rural areas were people need change.

"Real women are in the rural areas and those are the women who need change," Nawakwi said.

Nawakwi also said the UNIP candidates who boycotted elections will not be missed in parliament.

"How could such a group like Professor Mvunga, Reverend Zulu be told not to stand. We shall not miss them and I am sure their Great Leader needed them for company at his Kalundu house," Nawakwi said.

And Mangango MMD member of parliament Shumina charged that Women for Change were misleading people in Kaoma's Kalundu area that MMD government had sold their land.

"NGOs are indispensable in the well-being of Zambia but they should not dictate what government should do," Shumina said.

Shumina said the bill to regulate NGOs was long overdue.

But Kapiri-Mposhi member of parliament MacDonald Nkabika said the main players in the political arena need to come together and reconcile if national challenges had to be met.

"Mr Speaker, it is high time we injected maturity, reasoning, understanding, humility and tolerance in our new found democracy. This tug-of-war will lead nowhere," Nkabika said.

Nkabika said while he did not want the First Republican president Kenneth Kaunda back in the presidential seat, the man should be given the position of statesman and those close to him should let him know that the country wants him to play such a role.

Science and Health;
Lusaka Hosts Aids Workshop


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Lusaka - HIV/AIDS has become a global village problem with the same economic and social impact on the people, observed Dr Perolou Olove in Lusaka on Tuesday night.

Closing a two week HIV/AIDS medium-term plan review (1994 -1998) workshop Dr Olove, who is leader of the national review team of the HIV/AIDS medium term plan for Zambia, said AIDS has become a global. 

"AIDS is a more specific disease which can only be compared to poverty and its impact is felt in all aspects of human development, it is one disease which has brought us together globally" Dr. Olove said, "We need concerted efforts if we have to fight this disease, and we should include even the people who have come out to confess they are HIV positive."

And health deputy minister Professor Nkandu Luo said government is committed to the fight against HIV/AIDS because it is well aware of its socio- economic impact.

"But the fight of HIV/AIDS will be futile if we leave the matter with the health ministry alone, we need to fight together with all ministries and the community," Professor Luo said.

Africa News


January 23, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Kalusha's Proud Of Honour


BYLINE: Jay Mwamba, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

United States - Kalusha Bwalya has received his being voted the World's 14th best player with pride.

"One of the greatest honours in this business is to be recognised in the world, and this is a great honour indeed," said Kalusha in Mexico City, where the news made headlines in the Mexican press, after he was voted 14th in the 1996 FIFA World Player of the Year poll. "We play soccer to be recognised in the world, and nobody can take this away from me. I'm very proud of this honour, just as I'm proud of the African Footballer of the Year award I won in 1988." 

Brazilian whizkid Ronaldo won the award in a poll of 120 international soccer coaches.

Kalusha finished behind only two African players, 1995 FIFA Player of the Year George Weah of A.C. Milan and Liberia, and Nigeria's Olympic gold medal winning skipper Nwankwo Kanu.

The durable 33 year-old Mexico's Club America superstar and Zambian skipper was voted ahead of a galaxy of international stars, including Italian maestro Roberto Baggio, Chilean goal-poacher Ivan Zamorano, Bulgaria's Hristo Stoitchkov, Brazilian midfield ace Juninho and the French-Ghanaian Marcel Desailly.

Kalusha had a big year in the international game in 1996, leading Zambia to third place in the African Nations Cup finals in South Africa, and finishing as the tournament's top scorer with five goals, ahead of a classy field of scorers led by Ghana's Tony Yeboah.

He also inspired Zambia's World Cup first round come-back from a 2-0 hole against Sudan, captaining his side to a 3-2 aggregate victory.

Kalusha's jubilation at receiving the acknowledgement of top national team coaches from around the world was, however, dampened by the news from Zambia of the passing away of his former Mufulira Wanderers and Zambia teammate Ashios Melu.

"Zambia's lost one of its greatest sons," he said. "Ashios was a friend, companion and great footballer. On behalf of my family I'd like to pass my condolences to the Melu family."

Kalusha had another soccer figure to mourn, in FIFA vice-president Guillermo Canedo who died at age 76. Canedo served as chairman of Club American from 1966 to 1986, and his son is the team's current president.

The top 15 finishers in the 1996 FIFA World Player poll, meanwhile, were: 1. Ronaldo (Brazil), 2. George Weah (Liberia), 3. Alan Shearer (England), 4. Matthias Sammer (Germany), 5. Jurgen Klinsmann (Germany), 6. Nwankwo Kanu (Nigeria), 7. Paolo Maldini (Italy), 8. Davor Sukor (Croatia), 9. Gabriel Batistuta (Argentina), 10. Romario (Brazil), 11. Zvonimir Boban (Croatia), 12. Eric Cantona (France), 13. Roberto Carlos (Brazil), 14. Kalusha (Zambia), 15. Predrag Mijatovic (Yugoslavia).

Zambia;
Drinking Water Crisis Hits Flooded Maamba


BYLINE: Mabeni Sikalyabwanda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - DRINKING Water is a major problem in Maamba at the moment, disclosed Southern Province permanent secretary, Slyvester Mpishi, yesterday.

Mpashi, in an interview in Livingstone yesterday, said he had instructed the regional water engineer and provincial head engineer to rush to Maamba and assist in identifying the exact damage caused by last Sunday's floods. 

He disclosed that water pipes have been sourced from the Copperbelt to repair the damaged supply lines.

"A water tanker has been dispatched there to help serve the situation," Mpishi said.

Mpashi also disclosed that Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) engineers were in Maamba to restore power which was cut off.

"The Ministry of Health has air lifted drugs to service people in Maamba," Mpashi said.

Maamba Coal Mine managing director, Austin Chipenza, had earlier on expressed fears of a possible outbreak of diseases due to sewer that was spilling in the main street near to where people were drawing water.

Three years ago Maamba had one of the worst Cholera and dysentery outbreak in the country.

Sports - Soccer;
All Is Set, Says Zambian Player


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The boys are psychologically, physically and mentally ready for Saturday's encounter Africa Cup encounter with Malawi, assured Zambia national soccer team technical advisor, Samuel "Zoom" Ndhlovu yesterday.

Ndhlovu, in an interview at Lusaka's Hotel InterContinental yesterday shortly before the team left for the airport, said "the mood in camp is what it is supposed to be". 

"We are ready to pounce on them," Ndhlovu said. "We are going there to play a good game and have good results."

Ndhlovu allayed fears that the exclusion of Jonson Bwalya and Charles Musonda and the absence of other professionals will cost Zambia the match.

"We have a lot of local professionals in the team and they will do the job as expected of them," "Zoom" assured.

And Mordon Malitoli, captaining the Blantyre bound squad, was bubbling with confidence.

He said the Malawians must fall if Zambia has to enjoy her supremacy in soccer in the continent.

"We are just going there to fulfil the fixture because we are beating Malawi no matter how much it takes," Malitoli assured in an interview yesterday. " We shall definitely be the victors at the end of the day."

The other two in the group, Mauritius and Mozambique have no points after losing their first engagements in October last year.

Zambia and Malawi top the group with three points while Mauritius and Mozambique, who are meeting in Maputo on Sunday, are at the bottom with a point each.

Africa News


January 23, 1997


Science and Health;
Prehistoric Stone Tools Found In Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Ethiopian and U.S. scientists involved in archeological work say they have found what could be man's oldest stone tools in the Afar depression of north-eastern Ethiopia.

The scientists said the stone tools "were probably made by ancestral humans (homo) that lived between 2.5 and 2.6 million years ago along ancient streams.

The Ethiopian Centre for Research and Conservation of Cultural Heritage that announced the find in a statement on Wednesday, said however, that " Fossils of the makers of the tools have not yet been found." 

The Gona area, about 300 kms north-east of Addis Ababa and 75 kms north of Aramis, where the oldest fossil "hominids" were recently found, is known to contain small patches of "even earlier stone tools, but their age was not confirmed until March 1995," the statement said quoting a research paper on the discovery.

"These are the oldest stone tools ever found," Ethiopian paleontologist and the main author of the paper, Sleshi Semaw, said.

J.W.K. Harris, the American co-author of the paper and chairman of the anthropology department of Rutgers University in New Jersey, said: " Surprisingly, for this earlier date, the tool makers had a clear understanding of producing sharp-edged tools, an ability which probably gave them a comparative advantage in exploiting a wider range of food sources in the ancient Savana landscape."

The makers of the Gona prehistoric stone tools are still unknown, and the research team made up of geologists, archaeologists, and paleontologists from Ethiopia and the United States involved in the work plan to continue the search for fossils and the painstaking task of identifying the makers of the tools.

In November, last year, a team of scientists from Ethiopia, Israel and the United States announced the discovery of the remains of early human fossils dating 2.33 million years in the Hadar area of north-eastern Ethiopia close to Aramis, where the earliest known ancestor of early man, the famous "Lucy," was discovered in 1974.

"An upper jaw of early Homo, the genus to which modern man belong, has been recovered with primitive tools," the scientific team sponsored by the Institute of Human Origins (IHO) of the University of California at Berkeley, said in a statement in Addis Ababa on 19 November.

The scientists said these remains may hold clues to the ancestry of living humans, since they represent "the oldest family dated association of stone tools with a fossil of human ancestors."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


367 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africans Urged To Support Adolescent Health Programmes


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A senior United Nations official on Thursday, challenged civil societies in Africa to press their governments to implement the pledges they made toward funding adolescent reproductive health programmes.

Marie Angelique Savane, the Africa division director of the UN Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA), told journalists in Addis Ababa that it was up to governments to provide the financial resources to take care of crucial health problems, including AIDS, which mainly afflict the youth. 

"We in UNFPA shall play a catalysing role and create a conducive atmosphere for donors to come in," she said in reply to a question as to how funds will be raised to finance the numerous recommendations that are expected from the five-day African Forum On Adolescent Reproductive Health, which ends here on Friday.

Savane, who is Senegalese, revealed that in its new programme cycle for 1997, the UNFPA would be implementing projects in 12 African states, which have adolescent health as a priority.

"We will strengthen our family life education programme and enhance youth groups with management skills to ensure they take action in favour of their fellow youths," she said.

Savane also said the UN agency would embark on a programme to make men more receptive to issues related to family planning. Hitherto, she said, family planning and other issues have been monopolised by women.

Asked why UNFPA chose the Washington-based Centre for Population and Development Activities (CEDPA) as its executing agency for the adolescent reproductive health package instead of an Africa-based group, Savane said she and her experts failed to find an African organisation with appropriate skills.

The CEDPA president, Peggy Curlin, who co-addressed the news conference, suggested that a community-based approach could be employed to solve problems of funding adolescent reproductive health programmes.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 23, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia Air Force Airlifts Medicines To Flooded Area


BYLINE: Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA)- The Zambia Air Force started airlifting medical supplies Wednesday to Maamba, southern Zambia, which has been cut off by floods following torrential rains since Sunday.

The air force delivered mainly anti-malarial, diarrhea and cholera medicines for the 85,000 affected residents, just in case of an outbreak of epidemics. This is because the floods have damaged sewerage systems.

The national radio quoted the Health Ministry as saying that the airlift was necessary because it was difficult to reach the area by road, since bridges had also been washed away.

Medical authorities at the Maamba Coal Mine were forced to evacuate patients from the local clinic Monday, after the buildings were submerged in water.

The Zambian Ministry of Mines also sent a team of five senior government officials from various government ministries to assess the situation, Wednesday. The team is expected to compile a report for government action.

Speaking from the town of Livingstone, the permanent secretary for the Southern Region, Sylvester Mpishi, who toured the area Wednesday, told PANA that the occasional airlift of medical supplies will be needed as long as the bridges remain unrepaired. Road engineers and electricians are already in the area to restore services.

He said that the floods had also swept some crops. The impact of this will only be felt at harvest in April and May.

The permanent secretary for the ministry of health, Kashiwa Bulaya, said that the cost and duration of operation could only be known after the senior government officials, sent to the area, compile their report.

Almost all parts of Zambia have been swamped by heavy rains. Meteorologists say the downpours have been mainly induced by a weather system from Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Ghana;
Ghana Telecom Workers Protest Sale Of Shares


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - The Communications Workers Union (CWU) of the Trade Union Congress of Ghana has criticized the sale of 30 percent of the equity shares of Ghana Telecom (GT) without considering workers interest in the deal.

The union also balked at the price at which the shares were sold.

Therefore, It has appealed to the government to cancel the deal and channel it through the "established order" to save the country and the telecommunications industry from labor unrest. The general-secretary of the workers union, identified by the Ghana News Agency as D. Odum-Ewuakye, told a news conference Wednesday, in Accra, that the 38-million-dollar deal, was struck without the Divestiture Implementation Committee and without public knowledge of the real value of Ghana Telecom. 

The sale was made to G-Com, a consortium led by Telekom Malaysia,

The workers union said that the Ministry of Transport and Telecommunications also supervised the sale without the committees knowledge. The committee is the statutory body in charge of all matters on divestiture.

Odum-Ewuakye said the real value for the 30 percent GT stake was 100 million dollars and the acquisition of a licence for a second net operation in Ghana by ACG (Ghana) Telesystem Company should have earned 30 million dollars instead of the 10.12-million-dollar offer.

The workers said that Ghana Telecom remained a viable and strategic national asset, whose preservation must be the concern of all.

The minister of transport and telecommunication, Edward Salia, has described the Union's call for the sale review as "uninformed and unfortunate. "

Reacting to the union's pronouncements Wednesday, he said the equity share sale process was conducted by a competent and well-represented body, guided by international bidding rules.

He said three workers from Ghana Telecom, the majority group, with a representative from the committee served on the board.

Salia said that G-COM won the bid because it was the only group which satisfied bidding requirements and demonstrated the willingness to invest in Ghana, "in spite of the biased views held by foreign investors on the African environment."

Salia said his ministry's exclusive supervision of the sale was in line with its sector reform program. This system aims at restructuring the entire telecommunication system to make it responsive to the demands of the day.

He said that G-COM was a good financial administrator and had a reputation for adherence to working ethics, which were capable of making Ghana Telecom profitable.

On the viability of Ghana Telecom, Salia said the company's liability exceeded its assets by 100 million dollars. The company may have made strides lately, he said, but its rate of recovery was discouraging.

He said the ministry only sold 30 percent of the shares because it wanted to avoid the transfer of a public monopoly into private monopoly, which is against the government's economic philosophy of competition and diversity.

"The remaining 70 percent would adequately cater for the employee share ownership program, which makes all workers in GT share owners," he said.

Salia said GT had demonstrated that it could not cope with the current demands for communication gadgets.

"It has grown over the years by 50,000 lines, the majority of which was actualized in the last two years.

"The inefficiency of GT is legendary and any attempt to keep it in its present state would create problems for the industry and the nation.

"It is certainly an anachronistic instrument due for transformation; our only chance to change it is now," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 23, 1997


Kenya;
Moi Wants Nairobi Rid of Mounting Garbage.


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - President Daniel Arap Moi has ordered the Nairobi City Council to privatize, immediately, the collection of garbage in the Kenya capital.

Moi lamented that although the council collected a monthly service charge on city residents, it had failed to meet its obligations. 

Moi, who was addressing scores of Nairobi residents outside his office Wednesday, also announced that the city would soon be divided into eight boroughs to improve administration.

Moi's order on garbage collection will be welcomed by residents and visitors who have had to live with the offensive stench of heaps of garbage across this city of two million people.

The once beautiful city dubbed "The Green City In The Sun" is now considered to be one of the dirtiest in the world, characterized by uncollected garbage in residential estates and even in parts of its central business district.

Moi said that Nairobi, being an international gateway, must project a clean image.

He blamed the city's unhealthy state on incompetent management.

Africa News


January 23, 1997


Nigeria;
Visa Scam At The British High Commission In Lagos


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - An embarrassing visa scam, said to involve diplomats at the British High Commission in Lagos, has resulted in the recall to London of some officials, diplomatic sources said Thursday.

"The alleged racket is so serious that London is sending a team of investigators to Nigeria," the sources added. 

But a spokesman of the high commission decline to comment Thursday.

"I am afraid I cannot comment on the issue. I will like to refer you to the Home Office in London," the official said.

The scope of the racket is sketchy, with British diplomats saying little on the issue, but diplomats of other nations claimed the indicted officials were alleged to have charged applicants as much as 3,000 U.S. dollars per visa.

A single entry visa to Britain costs less than 40 dollars.

The British High Commission in Nigeria receives the highest number of visa applications, estimated at 200 a day. But only a fraction of these are successful, because of London's restrictions on Nigerians travelling to Britain.

Nigeria is a former British colony and, until a few years ago Nigerians, as citizens of the British-led Commonwealth, did not require visas to travel to Britain.

But London introduced the visa regime to stem what it called the influx of illegal immigrants, who constitute a burden on the British government.

Despite the restrictions, hundreds of desperate visa-seeking Nigerians throng the visa office of the high commission in Lagos on a daily basis.

The indicted immigration officials apparently took advantage of these desperate applicants in the racket.

Independent diplomatic sources said the current scam would be particularly embarrassing for London, which often castigates African Governments and officials for corruption.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Science and Health;
Baboons Destroy Timber Plantations


BYLINE: Sandra Nyaira, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - What started as a way of survival, during the great drought of 1992, has developed into a full-blown taste for the 8,000 baboons roaming Zimbabwe's precious timber plantations in the eastern Manicaland province.

The simians are stripping the bark of young wattle and pine trees at an alarming rate causing damage to the plantations in excess of five million U.S. dollars every year.

The baboons, whose natural diet includes a variety of plants and animals such as small mammals, birds, eggs, insects, slugs and small reptiles, were forced into chewing the bark of young commercial trees in the plantations when their diet was not readily available.

But after the drought, they developed a taste -- and a sport -- for the bark in the plantations, leaving investors and conservationists scratching their heads as to how to deal with what has become an "expensive nuisance." 

The grotesque-faced but highly intelligent simians target trees between eight years and 10 years old, strip the bark off the branches or, in some cases, strip off the whole tree of its bark and leave it to die, worthless.

It takes a tree 25 years to mature and get maximum commercial value. Now, the three major timber companies which own 80 percent of the country's 110, 700 hectares of commercial plantations are spending millions of dollars trying to replace damaged trees by replanting.

Estimates are that in most plantations the baboons have destroyed up to 3 percent of the trees to a level beyond commercial utilization. One company has lost at least 600 hectares of trees.

Baboons are a menace, especially when two troops meet and engage in a contest of stripping the bark off the trees, causing extensive damage in their new-found sport.

The timber industry, whose major stakeholders in the province and the country as a whole are the Wattle Company, Border Timbers and the state-owned Forestry Commission, has been hit hard by the problem.

The baboons have, for a long time, been notorious for being a problem animal in the rural areas where they steal poultry, raid crops or snatch groceries from children.

Some people say that baboons have taken to this kind of behavior because man has been collecting wild fruits for sale in towns, leaving the primates with insufficient food. However, others contend that there is enough wild fruit, only that the animals have developed bad habits.

For the timber companies, the problem is growing along with the baboon population. Females give birth to one young at a time after a gestation period of seven months.

The timber industry says it has reached a point where it has to deal with the animals to avoid further losses.

The industry, which in 1996 produced at least 120 million dollars worth of timber goods, has suggested birth control measures to stabilize the baboon population. Other strategies such as culling or hounding them out of the plantations have also been proffered.

However, the idea of killing this human-like animal has met with resistance from traditional leaders and environmentalists. Traditional leaders say that African customs forbid the wholesale killing of baboons, because doing so could cast a disastrous spell, such as perennial droughts, on the country.

Environmentalists say that the culling of the animals could disturb the ecological balance.

But those bearing the brunt of the problem think otherwise. So, the battle lines are drawn between humans even before the fight is taken to the baboons.

"The industry is currently losing millions due to the big baboon population that we have in the forests and we have no choice but to look at ways of how we can prevent them from destroying the trees," says Edward Mutsvairo, the Forestry Commission acting general manager.

The Wattle company's operations manager, Nigel Payne, says: "The baboons seem to have quite a taste in pine bark and they have become a pest causing a lot of damage and losses to the industry as they have moved from their traditional food."

He says the rapid growth in the baboon population could also be attributed to the lack of a natural predator, such as the leopard, in the forests.

Paynes says contraception would fail in the short-term, as an immediate solution was to arrest the losses.

"The idea of contraception sounds good on paper but practically it would be something else so we need to reduce the population first and then think of long term strategies latter," he says.

The chief executive officer of the Timber Producers Federation, Bill Johnstone, thinks the baboons have just developed a hedonist habit, like smoking, of destroying the trees not because they want food but because they just love the fun.

"The problem has been in existence before with only minor cases being recorded," he says. "But today, the problem has reached extremely serious proportions and if not controlled will endanger the future of the timber industry."

Various ways, such as trappings, have been explored, he says, but the baboons learn quickly and know how to avoid the danger.

The sharp increase in the baboon population has also been attributed to the lack of proper control by the Problem Animal Control Section, a unit within the Department of National Parks and Wildlife Management, which used to control the animals by using a very poisonous chemical known as Teladrex to kill them.

Use of the chemical was then banned worldwide in the 1980's resulting in the rapid population growth.

Johnstone thinks the baboon problem can only be dealt with after a short- term method has been introduced first. So, the industry is trying to get help from countries Kenya, and Sweden which have experienced the same problems.

In Sweden, the clever animals were conquered by spraying of wolves' urine in timber plantations to scare them away as they do not stay anywhere near danger signals.

"For the industry's survival we have to reduce the baboons immediately then we can start talking about long-term solutions which would have to be environmental friendly," Johnstone says.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa: Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - African newspapers commented at length on the bombings in Algeria, Zaire's military counteroffensive against anti- government forces, student demonstrations in Cote d'Ivoire, the suspension of Bingu Wa Mutharika, the secretary-general of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) and the state of the continent's universities.

Since the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan, Algeria has been hit by bombings not experienced since the end of its war of independence.

Confronted with this, the country's papers said, government has remained incredibly mute. The papers asked many unanswered questions, which seemed to highlight their frustration at official silence. 

Al-Watan wondered why it had been so easy for the bombers to set off their devices in this "very well guarded" capital of three million people.

"Why such ease of action?" it said.

Al Khabar could not fathom what the bombers wanted to prove by destroying everything in sight, while Liberte wondered where the bombs had come from.

"According to unconfirmed reports," it said, "between three thousand and four thousand tons of explosives have been stolen from warehouses in the last two years."

"Each day," Liberte said, "demolition experts defuse these bombs." But more importantly, it said, "who are the masterminds behind these attacks?"

The press also asked what game the government was playing since, Le Matin said, it had maintained an "irresponsible silence" throughout the entire affair.

As the Zaire military gears up for its counteroffensive in the east of the country, two of Dakar's newspapers commented on the state of the army and its preparations for battle.

Le Soleil said that if Kinshasa failed to defeat the anti-government forces, then "the most serious threat" to Zaire would be to keep the country as one entity.

"Is the Zairean army not a reflection of a government nearing its end, as many observers think?

"Is it not a reflection of a government that finds it hard to identify with anything but power?

"If Laurent-Desire Kabila's resounding victory is an answer to all these questions, so too is the time it has taken the central government to retaliate," it said.

"It is certainly this (government) reaction which will help us gauge the real situation Zaire," it said.

Turning to the police shooting of university students in Cote d'Ivoire on Tuesday, Sud Quotidien said that the government's decision to use force appeared more like a "declaration of war."

This action, it said, showed that African governments "still have a lot to learn" about managing social conflicts, especially student demonstrations.

"Government authority is not judged by its ability to deploy security forces at the slightest sign of social tension. Rather, it lies in its ability to make timely concessions without appearing to concede defeat," it said.

It warned that the hardening of attitudes was dangerous because it could so easily lead to an escalation of violence.

"Today only one student has died but clashes tomorrow will cause new victims and the cycle will continue," it said.

Lusaka dailies commented on the suspension of Bingu wa Mutharika as secretary-general of COMESA, following anonymous accusations of his misuse of the organization's resources.

The Council of Ministers of the COMESA suspended him for three months and ordered him before them for a hearing. Mutharika refused, saying the ministers were not authorized for this sort of thing.

The Post said that there may have been "valid reasons" for Mutharika's suspension "but the Council of Ministers should have been extra careful to avoid even a hint that the action was dictated by the exigencies of internal Malawian politics."

"It failed in this respect," it said.

However, the Zambia Daily Mail said because Mutharika -- a Malawian -- is a public servant heading an organization funded by tax payers money of member states, "he should feel duty-bound to open himself up to an inquiry, whether he believes it is a kangaroo court or not.

"The Council of Ministers, on the other hand, should give the accused...the opportunity to respond to the charges levelled against him," it said.

Nigeria's Daily Times, published in Lagos, stayed with the problems of African universities.

It said that the Association of African Universities, which met recently in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, "needed to re-examine closely" the role of the continent's universities "with a view to making them more relevant to their societies."

This, it noted, had been the case elsewhere in the world, with the results of their research efforts benefitting their public.

"The secret of their success has to do with how well they have been able to impact upon their host communities," it said,

African universities, which were established with similar ideals, it said, had for the most part failed to live up to their billing.

"Rather than provide a strong basis for development, they are becoming a perpetual liability to the governments," it said.

This state of affairs has created many problems in its wake: the dwindling resources to universities has kept the remuneration of university teachers, as well as non academic staff very low; and led to the loss of highly skilled manpower to foreign institutions.

"It has also ensured a continuous dearth of lecturers and facilities, and a consequent fall in academic standards," it said.

"As the 21st century beckons, the Lusaka delegates have the onerous responsibility to come up with workable proposals to make universities in Africa more responsive to the needs of their environment," it added. "A situation where many centers of excellence spend far more of their meagre resources on housing, transportation and other services is unhelpful. They should think of new ways of better managing their funds. Like their counterparts in other parts of the world, they should learn to spend more on research activities which should be the fulcrum of academia," it said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Senegal;
Taiwan pledges Support For Senegal's Food Programme


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Taiwanese Foreign Affairs Minister John Chang has promised his country's help to Senegal's in increasing agricultural production to achieve food self-sufficiency.

He told reporters after discussions Friday in Dakar with Senegalese Prime Minister Habib Thiam that agricultural cooperation was the focus of their deliberations. 

Chang's Senegalese counterpart, Moustapha Niasse, attended the one-hour meeting. Chang said they discussed implementation of a major irrigation project covering 75,000 hectares of the Fossil Valley, in northern Senegal.

Both delegations also discussed road construction projects.

Chang, who arrived in Dakar on Thursday, for a 72-hour official visit, was received by President Abdou Diouf.

On Friday, he met with Niasse; the Economy, Finance and Planning minister, Pape Ousmane Sakho, and the the minister of agriculture, Robert Sagna.

Chang is on an African tour which has already taken him to Swaziland, Malawi, Guinea-Bissau and Gambia. He will leave Dakar Sunday for Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.

China suspended diplomatic relations with Senegal in 1996 after Dakar decided to restore ties with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Stock Market Ends Week Active


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Stock market ended the week, on Friday, active and firmer with the key Industrial Index putting 93 points to end the day at 10,112.80.

Ferro-alloy, building and construction manufacturer PG, tea producer Tanganda and the Tedco group of companies all went up 10 cents to 790, 610, 360 and 1170 points respectively. (1 U.S. dollar = 10 zimbabwe dollars). 

The tobacco trading group, TSL, gained 25 cents to 775 points in reasonable turnover while publishing group Zimpapers rose 50 cents to 2,950 and National Foods put on 70 cents to 700 cents.

Banking giant Barclays and the merchant banking group, FMB, both in reasonable turnover put on 100 cents as did Porthold to 3,400, 5,800, and 1, 700 respectively.

Chemical manufacturer Chemco, in reasonable turnover, closed 400 up at 4, 000 cents.

Counters to lose included the battery manufacturer, Chloride, transport company Clan and seed producer Seed-Co all down 10 cents to 140, 520 and 230 cents, respectively.

Tea producer Eastern Highlands, lost 15 cents to 130, tyre manufacturer NTS shed 20 cents to trade at 530 cents while metal industries manufacturer Radar, and cigarette maker Rothmans dropped 25 and 100 cents to close at 475 and 6, 000 respectively.

Meanwhile in minings, trading was firmer than of late, with gold miners Ashanti, Falgold and Mhangura all unchanged.

Falcon warrants rose 10 points to 40 while nickel producer, Bindura put on 40 points to trade at 850.

The ferro-alloy producer, Alloys Mines, on the other hand, lost five points to 115 and coal producer Wankie dropped 25 points to close at 475.

The mining index put on 7.05 to close at 1,054.49.

LANGUAGE: English
