Africa News


January 24, 1997


Science And Health;
'Unhealthy Example' In South Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG - THE extraordinary Cabinet meeting this week in which ministers stood up and applauded a "breakthrough" in Aids research raises intriguing questions about Health Minister Nkosazana Zuma's approach to the crisis.

Still smarting from the R14,2-million Sarafina II debacle, Zuma turned down the scientists' request for funding from her department late last year, claiming she could not authorise the R3,7-million they wanted. Instead Zuma directed them to the Cabinet, personally arranging Wednesday's audience. 

Her spokesman, Vincent Hlongwane, said on Thursday that decision was because the Aids crisis "is not the preserve of the Department of Health".

Zuma's funding stance does, however, seem strange, given the R40-million assigned this year to her department's HIV/Sexually Transmitted Diseases Directorate, which counts research among its various operations. The directive - the government's main Aids initiative - also has European Union money and a hefty budget from the RDP at its disposal.

It is not clear what role the directive played in bringing the Pretoria treatment to the fore. New head Rose Smart was out of the country this week, and health department director general Olive Shisana was not taking calls.

The Cabinet meeting is a slap in the face for funding agencies like the Medical Research Council and the Foundation for Research Development, which apply strict criteria when funding scientists.

It also comes at a time when subsidies to universities (and, consequently, university research) have been slashed, leaving many scientists scrabbling for funds. They feel the rules of fairness have been breached, as they have to go through a set of processes to earn the right to funding.

Zigi Visser, husband of researcher Olga Visser, said Zuma had "supported them" when they were being "blocked" in their research. It was Zuma who set up the Cabinet meeting, he said.

Professor Peter Owen, a medical professional at the University of Western Cape, who helped develop the African National Congress's health policy before 1994, said: "The minister herself used to work in the Medical Research Council - how could she allow something like this to get to the Cabinet? Any Tom, Dick or Harry can now come forward to the Cabinet with the flimsiest evidence."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


427 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Science And Health;
Aids 'Breakthrough' Broke All The Rules


BYLINE: Lesley Cowling, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

JOHANNESBURG - THREE Pretoria scientists broke every rule of scientific method this week when they took their research to a Cabinet meeting, saying they might have a cure for Aids. But the man representing them says they did this because they had been "blocked" by the Aids research establishment, who refused to collaborate with them when they wouldn't share their patent rights.

The three scientists, who are attached to the University of Pretoria - cryogenics researcher Olga Visser, and cardio-thoracic surgeons Professor Dirk du Plessis and Dr Kallie Landauer - have patented a formula they call Virodene, which they say kills HIV. They presented their findings to the Cabinet this week and asked for R3,7- million to continue their research. 

But although Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said the government would consider funding the scientists, and members of the Cabinet applauded at the end of the presentation, real doubts have emerged about the validity of the research. These include:

* The National Institute of Virology has confirmed that the researchers approached the institute some months ago and asked it to run laboratory tests on certain compounds. HIV research specialist Dr Des Martin said the tests had been inconclusive - in other words, had no effect on the virus. However, he said he didn't know whether the substances they had tested were the constituents of Virodene, as the researchers could have changed the formulation.

* The researchers have not submitted their work for peer review (either by publishing, announcing their findings at the recent Aids conference in the United States, or presenting it to experts in the field of HIV research). They have also not released the details of the compound called Virodene, which it makes it difficult to assess the validity of their conclusions.

The dean of the University of Cape Town's Medical School, Professor JP van Niekerk, said: "We don't know enough to comment properly, because we were informed by the media. It would be usual if there was a breakthrough of a medical kind to first inform the scientific community, which would need to hear it and evaluate it."

Zigi Visser, Olga Visser's husband, who is representing the researchers, said they "have been blocked" by the Aids establishment, and implied that they had received little co-operation because they weren't prepared to share their patent rights.

* The strongest evidence was human - the patients themselves, who told the Cabinet that their condition had miraculously improved. But David Spencer, who runs the Johannesburg Hospital's Aids clinic, said it was not possible to assess the trial because the researchers have not shown what controls they used. "We need to know that they controlled for other drugs, for example."

Medical Research Council president Dr Walter Prozesky said testing the drug on 12 patients was known, in pharmacological practice, as a Phase 1 trial. " There are many Phase 1 trials for drugs run all over the world, but they don't give the correct answers. They don't give the side effects, which only become known after a few years."

* An HIV researcher from the Aaron Diamond Aids Research Centre in New York called the scientific evidence presented in a South African Press Association story on how Virodene works "far-fetched". The story quoted Visser saying Virodene attacks the RNA of the virus. However, the researcher pointed out that Visser has not explained how Virodene distinguishes between human RNA (made up of the same basic building blocks as the viral RNA) and the viral RNA.

* The researchers are not experts in HIV, or in virology and microbiology. The Medical Research Council, which funds the work of medical scientists, has no record of any of the researchers receiving grants or awards from the council in the past 10 years.

Pretoria University was unable to provide curriculum vitae for the scientists, or information on their research achievements and funding. However, the researchers have had some international success in their field of cryogenics - the preserving of live organs.

* A senior Aids researcher at a leading drug company said it appeared irresponsible of the scientists to make such a fanfare when they had not put their drug through controlled clinical tests. It was very unusual to approach the government directly for funding. If the team had approached his company or any other company, their work would have been given very serious consideration. "The money involved in Aids drugs is huge. Any company would be mad to pass up an opportunity."

Zigi Visser said: "We did follow procedures, going to major pharmaceutical companies, who originally supported us, but as soon as results began to prove more and more successful, they pulled out,"

He said some of the companies wanted them to give them substantial shares of the patent in order to continue with the research.

"When we realised some people were not happy with what we are doing, we went underground and had to pay for the research ourselves."

Dr Ute Jentsch of the South African Medical Research Institute, a microbiologist with an interest in Aids, said she had not heard of the Pretoria University work until Wednesday's press announcement. She said all new treatments had to be approached with a degree of scepticism until controlled clinical tests had been executed. "Lots of people claim breakthroughs which come to nothing."

Despite the doubts, it seems unlikely three established scientists would go public in this fashion if they did not have good evidence that Virodene works. And, according to Zigi Visser, all the research to date - about R800 000 worth - had been funded by his wife and himself, an investment they would have been unlikely to make without some hope of a return.

He said the researchers had taken their work to HIV experts, who sometimes helped them, but they always hit problems "when the subject of patents came up". They would be publishing in the next few months, he said.

The three researchers want to experiment on 30 more people within the next six months, and hope to have the medicine commercially available by 2000.

Additional research by Mungo Soggot, Marion Edmunds, Tangeni Amupadhi, Andy Duffy


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


428 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


South Africa;
Dolphin Deal: Hanks Resigns


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

JOHANNESBURG - DISSENT over the Mpumalanga Parks Board's (MPB) decision to place its prime nature reserves in the hands of the shadowy Dubai- based Dolphin Group deepened this week with the resignation of one of the provincial parks board's most influential members.

John Hanks, who is also executive director of Worldwide Fund for Nature South Africa, resigned on Wednesday to protest the manner in which the parks board "steamrollered" the secret deal without presenting it to the full board or consulting affected communities.

In his resignation letter, Hanks also asked why he had not yet received a response to a formal letter of protest he sent to board chairman Patrick Maduna on November 29 last year. In the letter he asked six questions about the board's handling of the deal, and about the financial credibility of Dolphin Group. 

The contract, details of which were secret until reported by the Mail & Guardian, grants Dolphin exclusive commercial rights to Mpumalanga's most popular nature reserves, including the Blyde River Canyon, for the next 50 years.

The parks board not only failed to mention Hanks's letter, but the issues he raised were not addressed during a seven-hour crisis meeting between the parks board and the provincial watchdog Environmental Council (EC) late last week.

"The meeting was a complete waste of time," Hanks said. "It's really a hopeless situation when not even the (parks) board's own board is consulted on what is potentially the most important conservation deal ever in South Africa."

Hanks said board members were not informed that the meeting was to address the Dolphin case. "All we were told was that it would be a normal board meeting," he said. "I just cannot go on like this and so I submitted my resignation."

In any case, he said, the meeting failed to address the concerns of the EC and other environmentalists. And a press statement by Maduna afterwards has angered land-reform lawyers, who accuse the parks board of failing to take seriously potential land claims involving such areas as the Blyde River Canyon and Koskop Dam, dismissing them as "irrelevant issues that cannot stand in the way of development."

"What do they mean by 'irrelevant'. They're a state body operating on state land and as such cannot contradict core central government policies such as the land reform programme," said Durkje Gilfillian, an attorney with the Legal Resources Centre in Pretoria. "Some of these claims were lodged as far back as August 1995 but the parks board has ignored them."

MPB chief executive Alan Gray, who masterminded the Dolphin deal, refused to comment on Hanks's resignation, or on reports in the M&G last week that the Dolphin Group and its chief executive Ketan Somaia are under investigation in Kenya for misappropriating R35-million.

"I have done my homework," he told the M&G, refusing to elaborate.

Gray said he went to Kenya to check on Somaia and Dolphin, and was satisfied with his findings.

But at the time of his visit, the Kenyan media were reporting Somaia's business dealings under such headlines as: "Loathed and despised." There were also reports on his alleged refusal to heed three summonses to appear before a parliamentary Public Accounts Committee.

Committee chairman M Wamalwa confirmed that his committee had recommended that the government refrain from future contracts with any company associated with Somaia.

Meanwhile, Somaia and a delegation of Dubai businessmen visited Namibia two weeks ago, following a meeting with Namibia's trade and industry minister. Reports in the Namibian press indicate that he is interested in buying into the Swakopmund Entertainment Centre, which includes a casino, as well as a private game reserve reportedly owned by Stocks & Stocks.

The M&G confirmed this week that Dolphin is negotiating local financing for the developments with at least two commercial banks.

Sources indicate that Dolphin hopes to obtain at least 40% of its investment capital from the South African market.

Mpumalanga environmental affairs MEC David Mkwanazi said he could not accept that the entire contract was flawed. "It is all a matter of interpretation and now that we know there are certain problems we can renegotiate the points," he said.

Pallo Jordan, minister of environmental affairs and tourism, this week requested a copy of the contract and a background briefing on Dolphin.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


429 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
South Africa: Lauded Abroad While Banned By SABC


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

JOHANNESBURG - SABC this week hastily unbanned a Prophets of da City video after it won a prestigious international award.Charl Blignaut reports

CAPE Flats hip-hop outfit Prophets of da City scooped the prize for Best Music Video/Clip from Non-Francophone Africa at the prestigious annual Cannes Midem international music awards this week. But, while in France a clip off the video was being screened at a glittering ceremony, back home it was revealed that the video was still banned from airplay on SABC-TV.

The R42 000 Midem award went to the Prophets's co-manager, Lance Stehr, who directed the video for their song Understand Where I'm Coming From off their breakthrough album Age of Truth (1993). 

Originally screened in 1993/94 on two of the corporation's most popular music shows, Studio Mix and Ezimtoti, the music video picked up on the latent street-level frustration of the country's youth before the 1994 elections. But when the SABC bosses saw it, they were outraged by its "spirit of violence" and banned it outright. Ironically, the video was awarded Ezimtoti's Music Video of the Year Award in 1994.

Lobbied by Stehr, the SABC music video committee promised to review the banning after the elections. But the committee decided to uphold the ban as the video, it said, did not endorse the spirit of the Reconstruction and Development Programme.

When the video was nominated for a First National Bank South African Music Awards (Sama) prize in 1995, the SABC had no option but to allow a clip to be screened. But still the ban was not revoked.

When contacted this Wednesday by a cultural show on SABC3 for permission to screen the video, the show's producers were told this would not be possible as an outright ban existed on the material. When approached for confirmation by the Mail & Guardian at 10am on Wednesday, an employee at the SABC's Dramatic and Literary Rights Organisation (Dalro) office reiterated that the video was banned but said the ban could be revised.

When pressed for further comment, it was later disclosed that the committee met at 2pm that afternoon and, without any further ado, proceeded to lift the four-year ban. A publicist at the corporation then contacted the M&G to say that the video was, in fact, not banned.

Ironically, at least three members of the current committee - Dave McBirnie (chair), Noleen McKenzie and Belinda Beneke (all from the Dalro office) - were also on the committee that originally banned the video. Other members present this week included SABC-TV music programme producers Thami Shabangu, Joe Correia and Melanie Son.

At the time of going to press no official banned video revision policy was offered by the corporation's policy-makers. Programme producers at the SABC disclosed, however, that a lengthy list of banned videos existed - most of these international - and that these were revised only if Dalro was lobbied by producers or interested parties.

The Age of Truth album was also a victim of a 1993 SABC radio ban - 15 of its 21 tracks were prohibited, but not Understand Where I'm Coming From. This proceeded to reach the number one spot on Radio Metro - but fans were not allowed to see the matching images.

According to Stehr, the 15 songs are still banned on the SABC. But when approached for comment this week SABC radio boss Govin Reddy said that, as far as he was concerned, no political bannings could be upheld in the new South Africa. Still, he admitted that no firm banning revision policy existed at SABC radio besides a standard committee similar to the television committee.

Music video producers have for a long time expressed concern at the SABC's tight control of music videos. The SABC puts up a third of a video's budget and then insists that record companies join the umbrella music body Association for the South African Music Industry before they can receive screening on the public broadcaster.

The SABC also has the creative power to veto video pitches, and insists that often cash-strapped production houses put up the capital for all videos, paying them 30 to 60 days later.

Irritated and disillusioned with the local music industry, Prophets of da City went to London and a lucrative deal with leading label Beggar's Banquet in 1995. They have recently returned and their new album, Ghetto Code, is due out at the end of February.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zambia;
Media Group Advises Government On Press


BYLINE: Staff Reporter, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Unnecessary harassment of journalists gives a bad impression of Zambia overseas and should be avoided, advised Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA) chairman David Simpson yesterday.

Commenting on Wednesday's brief detention of Post Newspaper reporter, Kunda Mwila for effecting a citizen's arrest of a police officer who was impersonating a Chronicle Newspaper reporter, Simpson said it was unfortunate that the government finds it necessary to resort to the Second Republic practice of infiltrating the ranks of various organisations, and especially the media. 

"To detain a reporter on a charge of 'conduct likely to cause a breach of the peace', when in fact he was simply exercising his rights as a citizen, is unacceptable,"Simpson said in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday." This creates an atmosphere of suspicion which is inappropriate for a liberal democracy."

He said the charge of 'conduct likely to cause a breach of the peace' is one of the many laws that needed to be re-examined because it can too easily be abused to harass individuals on baseless personal grounds.

The ZIMA chairman appealed to the government to avoid unnecessary harassment of media personnel.

"Such acts are widely reported overseas and tend to give a bad impression of Zambia. The blame for this is then placed on the media, instead of where it rightly belongs," Simpson said, adding: "Moreover it is becoming tedious to have to issue protest statements almost daily."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zaire;
Zairean Mine Sues Bank In Zambia


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Sodimiza Mines of Zaire has taken Meridien BIAO Bank (in liquidation) to court to examine payments made to the liquidator and to try and determine why he has not held a creditors' meeting to date.

An affidavit obtained by The Post yesterday confirmed that Levy Mwanawasa, counsel for Sodimiza Mines, is battling to recover at least part of the US$27. 6 million stuck in the defunct Meridien BIAO Bank.

"We act on behalf of Sodimiza of Zaire and are instructed in respect of monies which were held to our client's account with the above-named bank... Our clients are especially concerned about the sum of US$27, 592,000 which was supposed to be paid to Kafironda Zambia Limited who, because the bank did not pay, are now making a claim against our clients," said a letter to the Meridien liquidator dated October 10, 1996. 

Sodimiza Mines, in their affidavit, revealed that they had received " disturbing news from persons concerned with this liquidation, but who do not want to be named for fear of recriminations, that the liquidator has sold a number of assets of the respondent bank ostensible in the course of the liquidation and unfortunately quite a substantial portion of this exceeding 75 per cent has been used to pay substantial "remuneration" to the liquidator running into millions of Kwacha per month and this is at a time when the creditors and the depositors have received nothing," read the affidavit.

Sodimiza Mines, in their affidavit, said they were informed by such persons that at one time the Bank of Zambia engaged a liquidator from South Africa as there was nobody in Zambia who could do the job. His expenses, comprising of weekly air fares, hotel expenses, transport, etc, were paid from the proceeds of the liquidation.

"The liquidator is required by law to convene at least one general meeting of the creditors at which he must table his account of his actions and dealings in the litigation and to my knowledge this has not been done," read in part the Sodimiza Mines affidavit.

Sodimiza Mines, through there lawyer Mwanawasa, applied that orders be made to review remuneration of the liquidator following Section 320 (3) of the Companies Act 1994 and to compel the liquidator to convene a general meeting of the company under Section 323(1) and to determine whether it is lawful or proper for the liquidator to keep the company's creditors and depositors uninformed of his acts and dealings and of the conduct of the liquidation, under Section 326 of the Companies Act.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


432 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zambia;
World Bank, Government Deal Exposed


BYLINE: Bright Mwape, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

Lusaka - A top World Bank official, John Todd, this week blew the lid off a deal with government exposing a joint intention to introduce legislation to control the press and Non Governmental Organisations (NGOs).

Todd told a meeting he called with Lusaka based NGOs that the bank and the Zambian government had reached an undertaking last year to satisfy a number of benchmarks by December of last year prior to future negotiations on aid.

This deadline was moved to March this year after the Bank gave consideration to last year's elections.

Among the agreed benchmarks was enactment of a regulatory policy on the press and NGOs.

Todd also revealed to the same gathering, held at the World Vision offices in Woodlands on Monday, that the Zambian Land Act was the work of a South African Peter Moll, now a World Bank employee. 

Both revelations stunned the NGOs leaders who immediately took on Todd, demanding to know the motive of the World Bank/Zambian government alliance. They also questioned the relevance of any further consultations on a pre- determined matter.

Among the NGOs who attended Monday's meeting are World Vision, Afronet, Women for Change and NGO Co-ordinating Committee and Zambia Civic Education Association(ZCEA).

At least three of the NGOs were by yesterday plotting international protests against Todd's revelations while ZCEA chairperson, Lucy Sichone, had written a four page harsh petition to Todd with copies to the World Bank president and the entire donor community.

"If the World Bank was populated by human beings, as understood, they would not have signed a co-agreement with another human government that deprives another person of the rights to life, liberty, freedom of expression, of the press, assembly, association and the God-given and inalienable right to land," she said.

Under the coming legislation it is envisaged that government would sanction all donations to NGOs, and regulate their operations. It would do the same to the press, licensing journalists and regulating their practice.

The motive for this apparently contradictory position by the Bank is not yet clear. Speculation is, however, high among NGOs that the World Bank may be moving along a government move either out of ignorance or to shield its harsh policies from critical attacks by NGOs and the press.

"You contracted with our animal farm government to outlaw all rights and freedoms in order to protect your inhuman policies from being questioned," Sichone said.

This position appeared justified after revelations by Todd that the land Act, by far the country's most controversial piece of legislation since MMD rule, was sponsored by the World Bank. NGOs and the press have been highly critical of this law.

Todd told NGOs, he supported the Land Act which was drafted by a man he highly rates, Peter Moll. He disputed claims by NGOs that Moll's Land Act transplanted the apartheid spirit into Zambia, saying Moll was a noble man who refused to fight in the South African army for the love of man and ended up in prison.

NGOs dismissed this as a cheap reference to respect for humanity.

"You hypocrite Todd, have you never heard of Robben Island, Nelson Mandela, Steve Biko, the Sharpeville massacres. Those men and women who defied apartheid on political grounds did not spend their time in comfortable prison cells (like Moll) from which they emerged to work for the World Bank, they were murdered and killed in cold blood, they spent their most productive years at Robben Island, their marriages and family were destroyed," Sichone said.

When contacted from his room at Hotel Intercontinental in Lusaka Todd confirmed a World Bank-Zambian government meeting.

"We discussed the NGO policy but we only encouraged the government to see how it can create a mutual relationship with NGOs," he said.

Asked if the encouragement included legislation, Todd replied: "If legislation is part of the solution yes but we never said anything on that."

He claimed he has been misunderstood: "We have no position on NGOs and the media in Zambia."

But Afronet director, Ngande Mwananjiti, believes the World Bank is uncertain about what it is backing.

"The bank itself seems confused about what it needs. What is clear from what Todd told us, is that they endorsed government plan on legislating against NGOs . The ongoing plan is therefore with their blessing," Mwanajiti said.

He said the concern of NGOs is that the two sides have a set position and are making dialogue a mockery.

"Whilst government is giving us an impression it wants to dialogue with us first, the World Bank has given us the opposite signal," Mwanajiti said.

He said the solution does not however lie in legislation but the political will of NGOs to survive and defy the wrong thing.

Women for Change executive director, Emily Sikazwe, said her organisation would resist any move by anyone to legislate against NGOs.

"Whether it is World Bank sponsored or not we shall not accept regulation," she said.

Sikazwe who also confirmed Todd's disclosure of government moves on NGOs and the media said it was however likely that government would defy them and legislate. She cited examples of the Constitution, Nikuv,

Land Act, and elections as cases were public opinion has not mattered to government.

"We are not a supper body so we are not optimistic that legislation won't take place, but nothing defeats our resolve to own and enjoy our rights. No law shall take that away from us," Sikazwe said.

Sichone deplored the use of apartheid methods to control Zambia saying the country has people intelligent enough to determine their destiny.

"Under apartheid, South Africa had a media council, regulated freedoms of assembly and association and used the land Act to displace the local people in exactly the same way as 'the Boers on the World Bank' are doing to Zambia," she said.

She appealed to the donor community, as members of the World Bank, to stop the legislation of the media council and NGO bureau and review the Word Bank charter, character and qualification of personnel.

"Donors funding the world bank have come to accept without exception the common humanity of all people as one family. It is this acceptance that is at the root of tying aid to the rights and freedoms of individuals in my country, " she said. "It was therefore unacceptable for the Bank to encourage and abet crimes that have defied humanity on the basis of economic benchmarks narrowly defined."

Sichone suggested that the Bank "created in the cold war to check anti- communist dictatorships" should fold if its usefulness is no more.

The World Bank has often taken a different position on Zambia from other donors. When almost all donors froze aid to Zambia over the constitution and elections, the Bank announced the release of US $90 million with praise about her performance.

Towards the end of last year and parts of this year government has been making pronouncements in favour of legislation. A meeting it called a few weeks ago at Kafue Gorge to get NGOs approve a draft regulatory policy flopped after NGOs threw it out. Government declared it would find another way into it.

International human rights and media organisations around the world,

including Reporters San Frontiers, in Paris, Committee for Protection of Journalists in New York , the Freedom Forum in Washington, the Commonwealth Press Union in England and Media Institute of Southern Africa in Windhoek said they are now studying the World Bank position.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


433 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zambia;
World Bank 'Legislation' - (Editorial)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - It is disheartening, but not surprising, to learn that the World Bank is in league with the Zambian government to enact laws that will curb the activities and limit the capacity of the independent press and Non- Governmental Organisations (NGOs).

The World Bank, and its 'sister' institution - the International Monetary Fund (IMF), have every 'good' reason for not liking the independent press and NGOs. They have never been bedfellows with NGOs, especially grassroot ones.

The revelations in Lusaka this week by World Bank official, John Todd, that his organisation was working with the Zambian government on media and NGO legislation, as they had done on the unpopular Land Act, speaks volumes about the institution's political morality. 

The World Bank is one of the most powerful institutions in the world. Along with the IMF, it is playing a very crucial role in the reorganisation of global production.

For poor Third World journalists and NGO leaders to confront and challenge the philosophy and epistemology of an institution, like the World Bank, that has the power to implement this systematic process of re-colonisation requires a tremendous amount of courage and conscience.

The last years of this century and millennium have been characterised by sweeping political and economic change. Demonstrating the power of grassroot political mobilisation, the forces behind this change quickly challenged established centres of political and economic power. The common denominator of the demands generated by these forces has been insistence upon accountability to those whose lives are directly affected by those who wield power.

It is unlikely that this contagious mass mobilisation will be easily contained in one region of the world. Nor is it likely to be confined to producing change only in national governments. Established economic and political institutions everywhere are going to be, in the years ahead, subject to demands for greater accountability for their actions.

Accountability is, in the final analysis, what Emily Sikazwe of Women for Change, Lucy Sichone of Zambia Civic Education Association and us, through this editorial comment, are trying to achieve from the World Bank and Zambian government.

By exposing what the World Bank's connivance with the Zambian to curb the scope of press and NGOs' activities, the groundwork, albeit weak, is being laid for imposing on the Bank new standards of accountability to the institutions and people affected by its actions.

Historically, the World Bank has been primarily accountable to those who have provided the lion's share of its financial resources. This is no longer enough. We - the citizens of the world - are all stakeholders in the World Bank. And those who have the greatest stake are the citizens of countries that have had to endure the harsh economic and political adjustments imposed by the World Bank as a condition of its providing assistance.

The World Bank needs to change its ways and attitudes. If it does not change it may lose its relevance in today's fast changing world where the struggle for human rights is getting higher and higher on the political agendas of most nations.

The World Bank has paid very little attention, if any, to good governance in Zambia.

When most of the country's cooperating partners were pushing the Zambia government to adhere to good governance, international civil servants in charge of the World Bank were letting them of the hook with new disbursements and praises.

We know it is not easy to take on the World Bank but most NGOs leaders will not be defeated by this weight. They will reject and fight World Bank's bad laws agreed to by their weak, spineless and uncreative politicians in power.

It is only through struggle that the World Bank "Goliath" will be tamed.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zambia;
Weekly Express Ordered To Pay Priest


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - A bid by The Weekly Express to set aside a judgement in which the High Court had granted K55 million to Catholic priest Father Davoli Umberto in damages against the newspaper was yesterday lost.

Deputy Registrar of the High Court in Ndola, Mwambazi Chitika, yesterday threw out the application with costs. 

The action was taken when the newspaper's advocates failed to show up at the hearing set for yesterday.

Initially, judgement had been delivered in default against the International Book Company Africa Limited which owns The Weekly Express on April 2,1996, after lawyers for the newspaper had consistently missed a number of hearing dates set by the court.

Following delivery of the judgement, The Weekly Express applied on September 25, 1996 that the judgement in default be set aside but they were again absent at yesterday's hearing of their case.

Counsel for Fr Umberto, Levy Mwanawasa, said the lawyer for The Weekly Express, A. Mbushi, had withdrawn from the case two days before the hearing and had given notice of his withdrawal to Fr Umberto's lawyers.

But no representative from The Weekly Express came forward to defend the paper yesterday prompting the deputy registrar to order that the papers application be thrown out and an order to pay the earlier decreed figure of K55 million with interest be upheld. The new amount may run close to K100 million.

The Express had in various articles complained of, allegedly portrayed Fr Umberto as an immoral priest and one working against the interests of the MMD government and called for his deportation.

January 24, 1997


Zambia;
Rains Displace Luapula Villagers


BYLINE: Sam Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Lusaka - Over 2,500 people have been displaced in Luapula Province following heavy rains on Monday. 

Luapula Province deputy minister Norman Chibamba said the rains had caused havoc, especially at Mbabala island where it left buildings razed.

"Kapoma Primary School, which caters for 300 pupils, has been completely razed down and a Catholic church with about 500 worshipers has also been completely destroyed," Chibamba said.

Floods in Zambezi have also forced school going children to abandon classes in Kajongo and Tambula as the river they usually cross is infected with crocodiles.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian Official Protects Consumers


BYLINE: Milimo Moyo, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Lusaka - Some pre-packed products are weighing lower than what is indicated on labels, revealed commerce, trade and industry deputy minister Ackim Nkole yesterday.

Nkole yesterday also accused retailers of evading tax by using street vendors to sell their products.

The commerce, trade and industry deputy minister, carrying out a random survey at leading shops in Lusaka yesterday, charged that manufacturers were cheating the Zambian people. He said he was disappointed, especially with bread and mealie meal, which were notoriously sold underweight. 

"This is mostly with pre-packed products and they are cheating. While the labels, on the product indicate a higher weight, when the actual weight is lower," Nkole said. " According to the law (Cap 707) this is unfair trading."

He warned manufacturers who are selling underweight products to clean up their act or face the wrath of the law.

Nkole said his ministry has received complaints on the weight of products and decided to take a hard-line stance on the matter.

"From today we shall carry out random checks on these shops. We want Zambians to be paying the right amount for the right weight of products," Nkole said.

Nkole also gave Shoprite and Melissa 48 hours in which to produce their 1997 trading licenses.

Earlier in the day, Nkole visited Melissa, Shoprite, Gift Box, Limbada, Helium and Castle shops where he found that most products were underweight.

Shoprite Checkers manager, Basil Hajivasiliou, attributed the problem to poor packaging while Castle's manager, John Ioannou, blamed his measuring scale.

And Nkole said his ministry would severely deal with retailers who used street vendors to evade tax.

"We shall not harass the street vendors but we are going to deal with those that supply the boys and are creating artificial employment," he warned. " That is money-laundering because no one is accounting for the money obtained from the street vending sells."

But Limbada general manager, Rashid Ackman, said shop owners were wary of dealing with street vendors because "they are the Office of the President".

"Being the Office of the President, the vendors do what they like. They are creating a hassle and people are even afraid of coming to town because of them," Ackman said.

Helium acting manager, Anthony Pathy, denied supplying the vendors saying there appeared to be a conspiracy between his shop workers and the vendors to rob his shop of merchandise.

"We do not supply the vendors. They do buy some items but the bulk is stolen from here. There seems to be a link between the people inside (the shop) and the vendors," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Zambia;
Landmine Clearing Is Not A Priority


BYLINE: Sundie Sinkala, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Clearing of landmines is not one of the government's priorities and accordingly no funds have ever been allocated for such an exercise, disclosed Ministry of Defence spokesman, Major General Jack Mubanga, on Wednesday.

Major General Mubanga, in an interview on Wednesday, said the landmine situation in the country has remained the same since 1994, when the Ministry of Defence had openly acknowledge it as a serious problem, due to non availability of funds to clear them.

But Interim chairman of the newly-formed Zambia Campaign to Ban Landmines (ZCBL), Johnson Sakala, said it was unfortunate if the landmine problem was not considered a priority. 

Sakala said it was crucial that the issue is taken seriously because it affected the lives of people. He noted that in affected areas residents could not farm or collect firewood and that their lives were generally restricted because of landmines.

Mubanga said the government and the defence ministry had other priority tasks other than landmine clearing where the little available resources were being channeled.

"The landmines are still there but the government will only attend to this problem when funds are available," he said. " At the moment there are other areas of priority in the defence force which have to be addressed."

He explained that what was important was that the people had been informed about the existence and the whereabouts of these landmines in different areas.

Mubanga told journalists in 1994 that Zambia still had uncleared landmines in Western, Southern and Lusaka Provinces which had remained after the liberation wars. And yesterday, he reiterated his position, saying nothing had changed since then.

Major General Mubanga has, however, pledged that the Ministry of Defence will cooperate with the committee to sensitise the population on the subject of landmines.

He said that it was the duty of every Zambian to join this campaign in order to make the majority of the people aware of the existing problem.

Major General Mubanga said Zambia was a member of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) organ of the Defence and Security at which level they deal with similar problems in the region.

He said Zambia was keen to attend the forthcoming Maputo Conference on " Towards a Mine-Free Southern Africa" which takes place in February to discuss with other member countries.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Malawi Misses Her Professionals


BYLINE: Sheikh Chifuwe, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - MALAWIAN national team technical advisor Manfred Hoener has expressed fears over the absence of professionals from the squad that meets Zambia in the Africa Cup qualifier in Blantyre tomorrow.

Hoener, a Germany national, was most worried about the South African based Charles Gondwe and Enerst Mtawali's absence. 

"I foresee problems in the 'Flames' (Malawian national team) midfield if Gondwe and Mtawali do not show up," Hoener told Malawi's The Nation newspaper yesterday. "The midfield definitely needs improvement".

Despite Hoener's concern about his side's weaknesses, the morale in his camp was said to be very high and the 'Flames' trainer, Reuben Malola, was confident his side will 'scotch' the Zambian side.

"Every team plays the game to win and we are looking for that," Malola told The Nation yesterday.

Meanwhile, the 'Flames' yesterday retreated to Blantyre after a two weeks camping at Kamuzu Academy, about 450 kilometres north of Blantyre.

439 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Malawi;
Malawi Denies Conspiracy Against COMESA Official


BYLINE: Masauso Lungu and Sam Mujuda, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - There is no conspiracy to discredit or destroy Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) secretary general Bingu Wa Mutharika's reputation, said Malawi High Commissioner to Zambia, Reverend Emmanuel Chinkwita Phiri yesterday.

And Zambia's commerce, trade and industry minister Alfeyo Hambayi yesterday said the resolution to send Mutharika on forced leave was reached at after the committee of 14 ministers agreed unanimously.

High Commissioner Reverend Phiri, in an interview in Lusaka yesterday, said it is unfortunate Mutharika wants to politicise the issues at the COMESA secretariat. 

"There is no personal vendetta from the government of Malawi against Dr Mutharika," High Commissioner Reverend Phiri said. "We have done so much to promote COMESA, that is our interest. It would not help us in any way to be part of a campaign against him."

Hambayi said the committee was empowered under article 9 to met out such punishment and the probe team was legitimate.

Mutharika alleged at a press conference in Lusaka on Wednesday that COMESA Council of Ministers chairman, Malawi commerce and industry minister Chakakala Chaziya is behind the allegations of mismanagement and abuse of power leveled against him and would not accept the council's decision made through the manipulation of Chaziya to send him on forced leave.

"Allegations of financial mismanagement and abuse of power against me are as a result of carefully calculated political conspiracy, to discredit my high reputation in Malawi, COMESA and the United Nations," Mutharika charged.

But High Commissioner Reverend Phiri said it is rather unfortunate that Mutharika has chosen to think the decision to send him on leave is the making of Malawi.

"In fact, it is not Dr Mutharika as an individual being probed but the secretariat as a whole, except that he had to go on leave to facilitate these investigations, and then the committee will make recommendations if necessary, no one has charged him yet," High Commissioner Reverend Phiri said. "But if there are any serious allegations against him, its only proper that they are looked at and a report made."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Maamba Floods Force Zambian Company To Import Coal


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM)is being forced to import coal from Wankie Mine in Zimbabwe due to the closure of the Maamba coal mine after heavy floods.

ZCCM's Nkana division which uses the bulk of Maamba coal, at an average of 250 tonnes per day through its smelter, has already started importing coal from Zimbabwe. 

ZCCM, in a press statement released in Lusaka yesterday, said it was not known when operations at the Maamba mine would return to normal.

"The division (Nkana) is currently using its strategic stockpile of coal to ensure smelter operations continue uninterrupted," said the statement.

The statement said the Wankie coal would be delivered with added costs which were not tabulated.

"Some extra cost is involved since the Wankie coal has to be railed from Zimbabwe to Masuku Siding in Zambia which is an extra distance compared to the Maamba Coal trip from Masuku to Kitwe," noted the statement.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambian Mining 'Deal' To Be Sealed


BYLINE: Chilombo Mwondela, The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - The Konkola Deep Mining Project 'deal' is finally to be signed in February 1997 after three years of deliberations, revealed mines minister, Christon Tembo, in Parliament yesterday.

Tembo, in a special address to the House on the progress being made in the mining sector, said the privatisation report submitted by NM Rothschilds of Britain had resulted in the packaging of the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) into nine units. Already, he said, Kansanshi Copper Mine had been purchased by Cyprus Amax, a USA-based mining company. 

"Development of the Konkola Deep negotiations have reached an advanced stage and the Memorandum of Understanding is to be signed in February," he said.

He also stated that another agreement is soon to be signed by the government and South African mining company, AngloVaal, over the Konkola North orebody.

But during question time, Chipili MMD member of parliament, Ntondo Chindoloma, wondered why Cyprus Amax had been given a grace period of 30 months before having to add another US$5 million to the $3 million it has paid upfront.

Tembo explained that mining was a large exercise and it would take time for the company to realise the payment.

MMD member of parliament for Pemba, Aaron Muyovwe, wanted to know the interest rates used in assessing the value of the mines and what was the value of the deposits. He also demanded the period of time over which the value had been calculated.

Tembo, replying to Muyovwe, said the question was "outside the scope" of his address. And in answer to a question on what would happen to the labour force, Tembo said the mine was being operated only on caretaker basis, but that the government would be in touch with the Mineworkers Union of Zambia to make sure that the workers were not inconvenienced.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Family Planning Pill here by End of Year


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Addis Ababa - DKT-Population Services International Ethiopia (DKT-PSI/E) is a non-profit, non-government organization that works in close collaboration with the Ministry of Health. DKT-PSI is now expanding its activities to include the promotion of family planning to accompany its ongoing efforts to promote AIDS prevention.

The goal of this new DKT-PSI initiative is to contribute substantially to accomplishing the specific objectives of the National Population Policy:

1) A reduction of the current total fertility rate of 7.7 children per woman to approximately 4.0 by the year 2015. 

2) An increase in the prevalence of contraceptive use from the current 4.0% to 44% by the year 2015.

DKT-PSI Ethiopia focuses on AIDS prevention, and family planning by distributing primary health care products through its Ethiopia Social Marketing Program. DKT-PSI's approach to social marketing emphasizes three principles with regard to its products: availability, accessibility, affordability, and motivation to use.

Since 1990, the ESMP has sold 81,137,929 HIWOT brand condoms, including over 20 million in 1996. Now the ESMP is introducing a new low dose oral contraceptive pill under the brand name PRUDENCE Duofem. This is an important development as it will dramatically increase the accessibility and affordability of another effective and popular family planning method.

"Duofem," a low dose oral contraceptive pill manufactured by Wyeth-Ayerst International of U.S.A., will be branded for Ethiopia as "PRUDENCE". Duofem is registered with the Pharmacy Department of the Ministry of Health, and is already on the market and available at pharmacies and drug shops in Addis Ababa. By the end of 1997, PRUDENCE Duofem oral contraceptive pills will be available in Pharmacies, Drug Shops, Private Clinics and Hospitals, Factory Clinics, Enterprise Health Facilities and Health Related NGOs in all of the major cities of Ethiopia.

PRUDENCE Duofem is presented in attractive single cycle packs. Instructional inserts with information on dosage, contraindications and other related advice are prepared in Amahric and folded into the packs. Brochures and informational leaflets will also be available to the public. As the program is extended to the Regions, the inserts will be prepared in the appropriate languages. The price of one prudence cycle to retailers is sixty- five Ethiopian cents with the intent that customers will buy them for 1 Birr.

Information, education and communication (IEC) are in important part of any public health campaign. As such, it has been a principle tool of the ESMP in its AIDS prevention efforts to date. It will also be a significant element of this new family planning initiative, as the communications staff will be offering educational seminars and lectures for the public, and training workshops and seminars will be offered to all levels of family planing providers. These training and workshops will cover all aspects of reproductive health. It is anticipated that the ESMP will collaborate closely with community based distribution (CBD) efforts as they are implemented around the country.

In the first five year period, the ESMP target will be to socially market over 8 million cycles of PRUDENCE Duofem which represents 676,985 Couple-Year of Protection (CYP): yielding a substantial 5% social marketing contribution to the contraceptive prevalence rate in the fifth year.

LANGUAGE: English

443 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
A History of Early Twentieth Century Ethiopia - 3


BYLINE: Dr Richard Pankhurst, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Addis Ababa - Menilek's Failing Health, European Attempts to Partition Ethiopia, and the Rise of Lej Iyasu

Having, in the last two weeks examined the beginnings of modernisation in the last part of Menilek's reign, we turn now to the political crises of the time:

Succession Problems

The last years of Menilek's reign, like those of several earlier Ethiopian rulers, were bedevilled by the problem of succession. This became particularly serious after 1904, when the Emperor's health began visually to deteriorate. The question of the royal inheritance was the more serious in that the ageing monarch by then had no recognised living son. The presumption was that the throne would pass to the monarch's cousin, Ras Makonnen, but he predeceased his ailing master in March 1906, thus leaving the succession wide open.

The European Diplomats, and the Tripartite Convention of 1906

The impending demise of Menilek, victor of Adwa and founder of the modern Ethiopian state, gave rise to the persuasive idea, on the part of European diplomats in Addis Ababa, that his empire, which they regarded as an anachronism in the era of the Scramble for Africa, would soon disintegrate. The three neighbouring colonial powers, Britain, France and Italy, whom Menilek had played one against the other, now came together with a view to mutual cooperation. 

The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Edward Grey, and the French and Italian ambassadors in London accordingly signed a Tripartite Convention, on 13 December 1906. It declared, in Article 1, that it was the "common interest" of the three powers to "maintain the integrity of Ethiopia", while "arriving at an understanding as to their conduct in case of a change in the situation", by which they meant Menilek's demise.

The three signatories jointly agreed, in Article 3, that in such an eventuality they would maintain a policy of neutrality, and refrain from military intervention, except to protect their legations and foreign nationals, and that not one of the three powers would take any military action in the country except in agreement with the other two.

Economic Partition of the Country

To ensure their respective interests they agreed, however, in Article 4, to partition the country into three spheres of influence. These were defined as a British, and Egyptian, interest in the Nile basin, and in particular in the regulation of the Nile waters; an Italian interest in the "hinterland" of the Italian colonies of Eritrea and Somalia, and in their linkage west of Addis Ababa; and a French interest in the "hinterland" of the French Somali Protectorate, and in the territory along which the railway from Addis Ababa to Jibuti was then already partially built.

The three signatories further agreed, in Article 10, that their representatives in Addis Ababa would keep each other mutually informed, and would cooperate in protecting their respective interests. If they were, for one reason or other, unable to do so, they were to inform their respective governments.

Without Consulting the Emperor

This agreement was concluded, significantly enough, without consulting the Emperor. When he was afterwards presented with a copy he ironically thanked the representatives of the three powers for acquainting him with their governments' desire, as the treaty put it, to "consolidate and maintain" the independence of his realm. He observed, however, that the convention was " subordinate" to his authority, and could not 'in any way' bind his decisions.

"In the Interests of Whites against Blacks"

The British representative in Addis Ababa, John Harrington, one of the drafters and keenest supporters of the convention, was insistent that he and his French and Italian colleagues should abide closely by it. He urged the Foreign Office, most forcefully, in February 1907, that all three representatives should receive "strict orders to follow a policy in the interests of whites against blacks", and that if any of them were "not in accord about any particular point, they should not disclose their difference of opinion to King Menelik, but refer the question to their respective Governments".

Klobukowski

Despite his displeasure with the Convention, Menilek entered into a Treaty of Friendship and Commerce with France, on 10 January 1908. Signed by Antony Klobukowski, the French Minister in Addis Ababa, and generally referred to by his name, it laid down, in Article 5, that Ethiopia had the right freely to import fire-arms. This important proviso was intended to legalise the entry of weapons through Jibuti and the French Somaliland Protectorate. Menilek in return accepted a measure of French extra-territorial privilege. Article 7 specified that French subjects in Ethiopia involved in legal cases had to be tried according to French law, and, if detained, placed in the custody of the French Consul.

The Appointment of the First Ministers

Failing health, the increasing complexity of government, the danger to national independence inherent in the Tripartite Convention, and the need to take account of the question of succession, caused the Emperor to decide on the establishment of the country's first cabinet. Established in October 1907 it consisted initially of nine trusted noblemen. They were respectively responsaible for justice, war, the interior, trade and foreign affairs, finance, agriculture, "writing", i.e. of diplomatic correspondence and the royal chronicle, public works, and the palace. Their appointment stemmed, according to his chronicler, Gabra Sellas, Menilek's desire to "implant European customs".

Menilek also attempted to solve the succession question more directly. By then largely incapacitated by several strokes, he took the decisive step of designating a successor in May 1909. In a remarkable proclamation he reminded his subjects of the political difficulties which had followed the deaths of his predecessors Twodros and Yohannes, and announced that his twelve-year-old grandson Lej Iyasu, the son of his daughter Shawaragga by Ras Mika'el, the Oromo and former Muslim ruler of Wallo, was his chosen heir.

Despite Iyasu's nomination as heir power was soon usurped by the dying monarch's formidable wife Empress Taytu, who claimed to be acting in accordance with her incapacitated husband's wishes. She succeeded in ousting some of her principal opponents, as well as in arranging a number of politically advantageous marriages. Her influence was, however, resented by many of the Shawan nobles, who feared that she, as a woman of Gondar, was bent on destroying their own political power. They rallied against her, and with the help of Abuna Matwos, and of the mahal safari, or palace guards, banished her from the capital. The government was then entrusted to one of Menilek's loyal chiefs, Ras Tassama Nadew. He was appointed as Lej Iyasu's regent, but soon afterwards fell ill, and died in April 1911. Two and a half years later Menilek himself finally passed away, on 13 December 1913.

On the death of Ras Tassama the Council of Ministers proposed appointing a new regent, but Iyasu, who had begun to enjoy his freedom, refused to accept one. Brushing aside the Ministers, he impetuously declared, "My father Menilek gave me a Regent, but God took him away!" Thus asserting his independence, he took control of the government, and toured the country. Returning to Addis Ababa he tried to remove his dying grandfather from the palace, but was prevented by the latter's wife, Taytu, and daughter, Zawditu, supported by the palace guards. When eventually Menilek died Iyasu insisted on keeping the news secret, and offended many of his subjects by forbidding public mourning. He later became increasingly disrespectful to Menilek's old nobles, and sneered at them that they had "grown old, and fat". Not long after this he exiled both Taytu and Zawditu from the capital. The vested interests of Shawa retaliated by using his youth as a pretext for preventing him from being crowned.

Next Week: The Fall of Lej Iyasu.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopian Exhibit - Reality of Life


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Addis Ababa - The works of 12 Ethiopian and Dutch artists are currently on exhibit at the Addis Ababa Fine Arts School until 15 February.

The exhibition, 'Reality of Life' was opened Monday by Ambassador Jone Bos of the Netherlands, who noted that, "the initiative goes back to a particular friendship between an Ethiopian and a Dutch artist, Ato Anteneh and Wim 't Mannetje. They met some years ago, both here and in Holland and they developed the idea of an exchange of works that were inspired by each other's thoughts about the other country. 

The idea was not dropped when the Dutch painter died but the Interchurch Organisation of Urk, a remarkable former island but now linked to the mainland of Holland, picked it up and supported it like they did in the 25 years of its life with many initiatives in Ethiopia. Being a typical fisherman's place they supported for example, the modernisation of fisheries in Tana Lake, but they did a lot more. The basic idea remained : to express what one thought about the other country!

What made the exhibition most interesting was not only did the Dutch paint their idea of Ethiopia and vice versa, but also that most paintings had the artist's explanations underneath. Anteneh Seyoum put under his 'Mr. Holland', "Volume of my work is based on the life and the personality of Vincent Van Gogh, who is the real hero of Dutch artistic tradition."

Eskender Seyoum on his part explained his 'Holland within my point of view' by saying, "My main title is 'Holland within my point of view' at night. I try to represent the very hot and bright (shining) colours. I don't know, maybe it could be cold in Holland and full of grey colours, anyhow either bright colours or cold, in the future I will use the real one when I get the chance to visit your country."

Wilma Klaver in her 'Contemplate if you will' says, "Oddly enough I could, in the place where I live, find totally nothing about Ethiopia in the library. I could find something about Africa in general but not about this country specific. That's why I will make a painting which springs from my fantasy, fed by a few vague things which I once heard about this country."

As Jacoba Schroevers-- the only one of the Dutch artists present in this country at the moment--out it in her 'Confrontation', "The exchange of arts is important to bring the people together. In my opinion all the people on earth are valuable. We may learn a lot of each other as long as we accept everybody as he is. We can learn of each other's cultures, faiths, the way we are and no domination, exploitation or manipulation takes place. Only then a good interaction may be effected, which will lead to understanding, peace on earth and a good existence for everyone."


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopia's Creative Heritage


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - An exhibition of crafts from southern Ethiopia opened at Asni Arts Veranda 17 January with a lecture by Dr. Alula Pankhurst who led a reasearch team of twelve students from the Addis Ababa University. The exhibition, lasting until 8 February, featured traditionally made baskets, musical instruments, hunting weapons, pottery, and woodworks. 

Sadly, these highly skilled artisans are the poorest of the population, living a life of isolation, and considered 'impure and polluting'. " Traditionally," explained Dr. Pankhurst, "most of them have been despised and kept apart from the rest of society, being denied access to land and livestock and restricted to their craft and forging activities." He noted that after the 1974 revolution, the status of these people seemed to improve, "some gained status through religious conversion, notably to evangelical churches; others were successful as traders or urban migrants, in particular the weavers." Unfortunately, the old prejudices have resurfaced, and," there are accounts of artisans losing their land and being forced to migrate to look for work," he remarked.

The research project was funded by OXFAM and NOVIS.

LANGUAGE: English
