Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Is Airbus Overshadowing Boeing?


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Addis Ababa - The two companies are currently in Ethiopia to sell their planes to the national carrier

The media inched their way through numerous body-checks Tuesday on their way to the tarmac at the Bole International Airport to see the Airbus Industrie introduce its biggest airplane-- the A340. According to Mr. Alain Dupiech, manager of press relations, this was the first time a plane of this size--it seats from 250 to 350--has landed in this country.

As well as testing the plane's performance in a high altitude, Airbus will be presenting the A340 to Ethiopian Airlines. Traditionally, ETHIOPIAN has dealt with American based Boeing, but former secretary of state Warren Christopher's tour of the airline during his visit to Ethiopia last October, has led to speculation that the relationship might be faltering. Airbus Industrie -- the European aircraft manufacturing consortium co-owned by Germany, France, Britain, and Spain--has been negotiating with ETHIOPIAN for the past two years, said Dupiech. 

Claiming the highest safety record in the industry--only six crashes during its twenty-five years operation--Airbus is eating into the older Boeing's lead with 38-42% of the market at present. The industry is a lucurative business, worth between 200-250 million USD. Ask them why they change from Boeing after many years of association, Dupiech challenged the press, going on to list the four-engine A340's edge over its competitors. It has the 'quietest cabin in the sky' is fuel efficient, environmentally friendly, and provides 'unrivaled profit potential for non-stop long range operations on routes with medium passenger demand, as well as the ability to increase flight frequencies on other more heavily traveled services', according to an Airbus press release.

This confidence seems to be shared by Ed. Strongman, engineering test pilot, who had a chance to assess other manufacturer's products when he worked for the aviation authority in the UK. As Strongman--who was last here the day the 1974 revolution broke-out--indicated, flying with Airbus insures that he has the best technology at his disposal.

Airbus' arrival in Addis Ababa coincides with Boeing's presentation of its proposal to the ETHIOPIAN management. ETHIOPIAN board chairman Siye Abraha and other members of ETHIOPIA's management including the general manager, Dr. Ahmed Kellow have been to see the A340. According to sources, the national carrier is expected to purchase upto four airplanes as it extends its flight to North America and Japan. Airbus has stated its willingness to lease planes to ETHIOPIAN.

Whether ETHIOPIAN buys from Airbus or not, the latter has certainly made its presence known to everybody with the whole press according it front page coverage. A lavish cocktail reception, attended by French Ambassador Mr. Alain Rouquie, German Ambassador Mrs. Wiltrud Holk, and Mr. Karl Harbo, head of the European delegates presented a united front for the bid.

In the time of the previous government, Boeing supplied ETHIOPIAN with credit to purchase its fleet.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Fertilizer Subsidies Discontinued, Land Distributed


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Addis Ababa - In the past week, we had quite a flood of economic news. Fertilizer subsidies financed from the government budget have been discontinued since January 9, 1997 ("Addis Zemen", Tir 11, 1989 E.C.). The Ethiopian Investment Authority (EIA) announced that fifty-two investors were granted land in Addis Ababa outside the government's land-lease system (" Addis Zemen" Tir 11, 1989 E.C.).

The Executive Director of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) is scheduled to pay a three-day visit to Ethiopia ("The Ethiopian Herald", January 14, 1997). Farmers' cooperatives are to receive loans from the Development Bank of Ethiopia without collateral requirements ("Addis Zemen", Tir 10, 1989 E.C.). It was also announced that Ethiopia's main (Meher) harvest in 1996 was 11.7 million MT ("The Ethiopian Herald," January 18, 1997). 

Well, the cessation of fertilizer subsidies is bad news for farmers, but good news for the IMF, which has been pressing the government for just such a move. Taxpayers will hardly feel the difference. On the other hand, farmers will have to pay the full price of 250 birr per quintal for DAP and 240 birr for UREA as against the subsidized previous prices of 200 birr and 190 birr, respectively. On its part the government would save 160-178 million birr in the 1996/97 crop year. Although the government has terminated fertilizer subsidies, it intends to continue fixing wholesale fertilizer prices, leaving retail prices to the forces of supply and demand. Why the workings of the market are confined to only retail pricing and why the government does not fully disengage from price fixing are questions that remain unclear.

The consequences of the cessation of fertilizer subsidies are difficult to gauge at this early stage. Would it cause a cutback on fertilizer use or force farmers to mark up their crop selling prices?

Increased fertilizer use appears to be something of a mixed blessing, because while yields obviously increase, the downward impact on produce prices has definitely been unwelcome. As the farmers' leeway on produce prices is thus limited, the only choice they would have would probably be to cut back on fertilizer use, which would be bad for overall agricultural production. All the same, the government's decision to end fertilizer subsides should be regarded as a step in the right direction as subsidies run counter to the principle of efficency in resource utilization through artificial underpricing.

Perhaps the most dramatic economic news to have come out in the past week was the announcement by the EIA that a substantial amount of land was being granted to investors in Addis Ababa outside the government's highly controversial land-lease mechanism. No better proof could be found of the government's own doubts about the rightness of its own land policy. We have repeatedly argued in the past that a land policy which restricts ownership to the state and which insists unto death on an extremely sluggish land distribution system based on leasehold by auction is a veritable stranglehold on economic growth. It seems now that the pressures of economic momentum are beginning to break asunder an artificial barrier that should never have been there in the first place.

But, as always, when man-made laws are overtaken by events, the need to put the reins back on becomes an unavoidable preoccupation. Actually, granting land outside the land-lease mechanism, which is the only legal way the government has instituted, is tantamount to an infringement of the law. By which law and according to which specific rules, regulations and procedures is land being handed out to potential users outside the land-lease systems? Are we now entering a periods of chaos on the issue of land distribution? What guarantees are there that government officials are not handing out land to people on the basis of the oppositeness of their gender and the fatness of their wallets? Putting the land-lease law in mothballs is good news, but operating without a substitute law would be equivalent to opening the floodgates of corruption wide open!

Also in the news in the past week was the scheduled visit by the Executive Director of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. No doubt this would be a great honour for all those Ethiopian professionals engaged in implementing the government's population policy, which is understandably still a long way from showing its first signs of reducing Ethiopia's extremely high average fertility of nearly 8 children per woman. There is not an iota of doubt that excessive population growth in Ethiopia is a major problem. The nutrition standards of the population are going downhill as could be appreciated from the pitiable height, weight and skin tone of the average Ethiopian. Children are not as lovable as they used to be, now posing not an inconsiderable menace in the streets. Above all and somewhat paradoxically, burial places are in extremely short supply with tales of fees running into thousands of birr for choice burial spots! Not even the merciless juggernaut of death could dampen the prolificity of copulation! It would not be in bad taste to quote at this point what a certain cynic, Ethiopian by nationality, said in connection with the population explosion in the country: "Thank you for smoking, because you are contributing to increasing the death rate". Well, well, what do you say to that!

And now on to the other two bits of economic news: the one about the plan by the DBE to grant loans to farmers' cooperatives without collateral and the other about the estimate of the "Meher" crop production. Regarding the first one, the appropriate question would be: is the DBE planning to give such credits of its own free will or is the government arm-twisting it do so? If the DBE is going to extend the loans of its own accord, considering the move a profitable activity, nobody should stop it from going right ahead with its plan.

But the DBE should remember that a government bail-out such as the one it received sometime in late 1994 would not be forthcoming should its plan to engage in cooperative credit extension without collateral negatively affects the quality of its asset portfolio. Concerning the estimate for the 1996 " Meher" crop production, the 11.7 million metric tons of 117 million quintals given by the FAO/WFP Crop and Supply Assessment Mission represents a significant departure from the historical statistical trend observed in crop production figures issued by the Central Statistics Authority.

Here, for example, are CSA's estimates for the production of major crops in Ethiopia in the past.

1990/91 66 million quintals

1991/92 52 million quintals

1992/93 not available

1993/94 70 million quintals

How could agricultural production increase by more than 67 percent in a matter of only about two years in the Ethiopian development context? Wouldn't this call the reliability of the estimates into serious question?

The Assessment Mission also assigned the following percentages to the factors contributing to the increase in agricultural production:

Good weather conditions

50 percent

Increased acreage

6 percent

The government's agri.

extension programme

20 percent

The percentage attributed to the government agricultural extension programme in the increase in agricultural production appears to be on the high side, considering the relatively short period the programme has been in operation and its limited coverage of the farm population. At any rate, the Mission's growth attribution exercise still indicates the high degree of vulnerability of Ethiopian rain-fed agriculture to the vicissitudes of the weather.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Dr. F. Mekuria - Serious about Communications Technology


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Addis Ababa - In an exclusive interview with Addis Tribune last month, Dr. Abdulmejid Hussien, Minister of Transport and Communication observed that, " During the last 100 years, only 150,000 lines have been installed. This is a shame for an institution which is considered to be one of the oldest in Africa.

"However, it is envisaged that within the next five years, this country will have an additional half-million telephone lines."

He went on to add that cellular phones will soon be installed throughout the country. 

His remarks were followed closely by many Ethiopians, especially Dr. Feseha Mekuria, senior staff engineer for Ericsson-- said to be one of the three top firms in the world engaged in communication technology. To achieve the minister's goal for the next five years, Dr. Feseha reckons that it would take more than five years. Probably ten years. "But if we use the new technology--the new wireless technology," he noted, "we could do this type of subscriber connection very fast. It doesn't need so much maintenance as we have it for wire networks." Though officially on holiday, Dr. Feseha is very eager to get to work discussing the system with concerned ministries before returning to Sweden. According to him, Ericsson is not really trying to penetrate a new market, but rather re-establishing old links. "Actually," he explained, "Ericsson used to be the supplier company during Haile Selassie's time. I've seen old Ericsson telephones in several homes here in Ethiopia. They are supposed to be also the people who built the first local telephone exchange in Ethiopia."

Born in Axum in 1962, the seventh out of ten children, Dr. Feseha grew up with the desire to become just like his elder brother who had died during the trouble after the 1974 revolution. "He studied electrical engineering and I had the books he had bought while he was a student." With a burning ambition and the grades to match, in 1980, he got a Water Resources Authority scholarship to India to study civil engineering. As soon as he got to India though, he managed to convince the university authorities that it would be better if he took electrical engineering instead. "Since I went to a vocational school, the Asfawossen, I had taken electrical engineering, otherwise I would not have been able to change from the civil engineering course Water Resources wanted to give."

At the end of 1984, he graduated with a Bachelor's in Electrical and Electronics Engineering from the Autumadras Building and Engineering College. "The curriculum was the same" recalls Dr. Feseha, but, " when you have millions of students competing to come to the university, it was tough for us to go there and compete with the Indian students. We showed also that our high school status was very good." But first, the Ethiopian students had to be shocked out of their complacency. "It was during our first exams. We noticed that while we were writing short answers, the Indian students were asking for extra answer sheets. We were so surprised and many of us were disappointed that we couldn't do just as well." With a few extra lessons, though, the Ethiopians managed to even come first in their section, Dr. Feseha is proud to say. One of the minor disappointments of his stay in India, remains that he was not able to learn the local language. "It was a very difficult language to pick up, and the students wanted to speak only in English. There was also no initiative from the university. "

Dr. Feseha stayed some six months in India after graduation, deciding that he did not as yet want to come back to Ethiopia, but would look for schools to do post graduate studies. It was not, however, the United States that he finally went to--as he had planned -- but to Sweden where his wife was studying. When he arrived there, he got another 'shock'. In India, there were people in the streets at all times of the day, he said, but in Sweden it was very quiet. " It was a well built city, but very quiet. I thought at first that there was some kind of restriction" he mused. Dr. Feseha was able to learn the language after six months of intensive training, and get on with his studies which required him to teach at the university (University of Linkoping). In 1989, Dr. Feseha got his Technology Licensiate (a degree between a Masters and a Ph.D.). For his Ph.D., he focused on applications for speech communication. In 1993, he took his Ph.D.. in applied electronics.

In 1995 he joined Ericsson and was last year promoted to his present post of senior staff engineer. "The challenge is" Dr. Feseha explained of his new found passion, "to push the technology to its limits. How to make the mobile telephone more user friendly, for example to see the person you talk to on the phone. At the same time there is the basic application for developing countries-- how to make this highly developed mobile technology available to developing countries at low cost. That is also one of my challenges. Telecom. structure is a key factor in many developing countries for their socio- economic development."

Dr. Feseha is not however, blind to the problems posed by inadequate administration. "The greatest problem in developing countries remains bureaucracy, and lack of trained manpower," he said, adding that he hoped that in this country there was "a much more determined kind of vision to improve the situation."

Dr. Feseha Mekuria is married and has two daughters. He is a member of the International Electronics and Electronics Engineers society, and the European Speech Communication Association. "I try to play basketball," he said, "but most of my free time is spent driving my young daughters to places they want to go."

LANGUAGE: English

January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Patriarch Says Church Ready to be Reconciled


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa - The celebration of the Ethiopian Epiphany passed off peacefully in Jan Meda Sunday despite worries of possible disturbances.

A hermit was killed during a shoot-out on 9th January in the St. Estifanos Church, while police reported disturbances in the St. Yohannes the Baptist Church, 13 January. 

Patriarch Paolos of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church (EOC), seemed to indicate his wish for the rift within the church to heal when he said, "The doors of the church are open to hear the wrongs done to those who claim mistreatment as it firmly stands for peace. EOC promotes reconciliation and is ready to be reconciled" reported ENA. Government Reverses Stand on Fertilizer Subsidy

by Our Staff Reporter

A statement from the Ethiopian Fertilizer Industry Agency said 18 January that as of this month, the government will end subsidizing fertilizers as it has been doing so for the past four years. According to ENA, only wholesale price of fertilizers will continue to be regulated at the national level, leaving dealers to 'benefit from the competition in distributing the input'.

Indicating that that the change in policy was necessitated because the practice was doing little to help the national economic development, the agency admitted that the 338 million birr the government spent for subsidy and extension programs in the past two years, could have built 1,126 schools.

Ethiopia;
Oromo Group Sends Warning to its Members


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - Just four months after Tamrat Layne was stripped of his post of secretary general of the Amhara National Democratic Movement (ANDM) -- and subsequently from the post of Defence minister and deputy prime minister for 'gross misconduct' -- the Oromo People's Democratic Organisation (OPDO) is sending a clear message to its members that it will not hesitate to punish those who fail to discharge their responsibilities.

Both the OPDO and the ANDM are part of the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF), the ruling party in the government. 

Ato Hassen Ali, Vice President of Oromia region, indicated that performance assessments of OPDO members will soon be held in Woreda and Kebele levels, reported government run English daily, Ethiopian Herald. Ato Hassen admitted that there were members at both the central and zonal committees who were found during the last appraisal guilty of incompetence, corruption, violating democratic and human rights, and narrow nationalism.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Needed: Customer-Oriented Culture


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele (Editorial), Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - In the last five years customer-oriented new businesses have opened. New banks, insurance companies, restaurants, hotels, night clubs, boutiques, grocery stores, pubs, video rentals, auto dealers, clinics and all kinds of shops. The list is too large to enumerate.

With few exceptions, most of the business in Addis Ababa doesn't pay sufficient attention to customers. Even in a highly placed industry as banks, insurance and hotels "customer satisfaction" is not a top priority.

Quality products and quality service are in demand. Customers are literally begging to be served in many places. Courtesy and smiles are rare. The success and failure of many enterprises as we may see in the next few years will be determined by "customer satisfaction." A business enterprise that does not focus on customer satisfaction will not even qualify for the finals in world class competition, despite its attention to price and cost reduction, technology, product quality, or all three put together.

As management experts would tell us, customer satisfaction is but a milestone on the long, hard road to customer loyalty and lifelong retention. It is about time the business community in this country get involved to set up a Customer-Oriented Culture.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


453 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
Oldest Stone Tools found 75 km from Oldest Fossil


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa - The oldest stone tools ever found, presumed to have been made over 2 million years ago, were discovered in Gona, Afar, by scientists from Ethiopia and the United States, announced the Centre for Research and Conservation of Cultural Heritage Thursday 23.

The tools were found just 75 km north of Aramis, the sight of the oldest fossil hominid's discovery. "Surprisingly, for this early date " ENA quoted Dr. J. Harris, chairman of anthropology department at Ruterg University, New Jersey, as observing, " the tool makers had a clear understanding of producing sharp-edged tools, an ability which probably gave them a competitive advantage in exploiting a wider range of food sources in the ancient savannah landscape".

Members of the Gona excavation team plan on searching for fossil animals, plants as well as fossil hominids to identify the makers of the tools.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 24, 1997


Ethiopia;
European Commissioner Arriving to sign NIP


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - Professor Pinheiro, the European commissioner for the external relations with African, Caribbean, and Pacific (ACP) countries will be arriving on the 25 January for a three-day working visit. This was announced by Mr. K. Harbo, head of EU delegation in Ethiopia, at a press conference 22 January. 

Professor Pinheiro will be meeting with Prime Minister Meles Zenawi and other government officials to discuss future relations between Europe and Africa. On his last day in the country, Professor Pinheiro and the Ethiopian government will sign the National Indicative Programme (NIP) covering a five- year period. The fund, 370 million USD or approximately 2.4 billion birr, was made available to the country under the Revised Lome IV Convention signed in Mauritius 4 November 1995.

On Tuesday, Professor Pinheiro will sign with neighbouring East African government officials, a Regional Indicative Programme (RIP) worth over 240 USD. According to Mr. Harbo, the largest portion of its regional fund is at present going to a telecommunication programme for Ethiopia, Eritrea, and Djibouti.

Ethiopia joined the ACP countries in 1976, receiving a total of over 1628 million USD during these years under Stabex from the European Investment Bank, from the regional section of the European Development Fund, and other instruments.

LANGUAGE: English
