Africa News


January 24, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Ethiopian Team Members Seek Asylum in Italy


BYLINE: Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - by Our Staff Reporter

On their way to Morocco for a crucial African Cup of Nations qualification match, sixteen members of Ethiopia's national soccer team have decided to stay in Italy.

It was a case of 'now-you-see-them, now-you-don't' as even Italian police had no idea of the players whereabouts. Now it has become clear that the 16 wish to gain asylum in Italy due to political differences. The remaining members returned to Addis Ababa Thursday 23.

This is not the first time there has been such an occurance involving the national soccer team. Three years ago, 6 players abandoned the team in Morocco. There is no doubt that this is a very serious blow to Ethiopian football and the shock waves are beginning to be felt. Not only is it a great loss for the National side, the team also contained numerous top players from league clubs.

Soccer players are not the only ones to be lured into leaving their country to see what awaits. Boxers and athletes have recently 'missed' the plane home from high-level sports meetings. There has been no word on what the fate of the 16 will be, nor there been has any statement by the football federation here.

Regardless of the motives behind the athlete's risky decision, the fact remains that Ethiopia has lost a number of top-level players and the side will now have to start from scratch. It appears that the Ethiopian Football Federation would welcome more than just the return of the Axum obelisk from Italy.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


456 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's Current Macroeconomy: What Official Stats Say


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1760 words


 

Addis Ababa - It may sound incredible, but we are already almost seven months into the current fiscal year of 1996/97, which means some 60 percent of the budget year has already elapsed. Time does fly, doesn't it? At any rate this is an appropriate time for a mid-year assessment of how the nation's economy is doing, but unfortunately the relevant statistics are either altogether unavailable or, if available are inadequate and not up-to- date enough. For example, the following data as of at least November 1996 would have been highly enlightening if they were available:

*coffee production

*industrial production

*estimates of retail sales

*housing starts

*exports

*imports

*government current and capital expenditure

*estimates of government investment and domestic and foreign private investment

*total numbers of new jobs created

*major public and private investment projects implemented What kind of a bureaucracy do we have? It can't produce even very basic data on the economy which are fairly reliable and up-to-date? Why should taxpayers foot its wage bill? For a mid-year assessment, such essential economic data should as a matter of statistical routine, generally be placed on the desks of policymakers by about the middle of February. 

These need not be final figures, but need only be reliable estimates. However, there seems to be no such statistical tradition, and statistics are usually put together on an ad hoc basis at the last minute when some bigwig suddenly realizes that he needs such basic data to make the decision he is about to make or, as is often the case, he has already made privately. How can any major or even minor decision be made without sufficient information? How can any respectable judgment be formed about the economy or any other matter without recourse to the relevant information? On top of all this, there is the problem of "doctoring" or "massaging" official economic statistics so that they put the performance of the national economy in a good light! This only makes matters even worse. Reliable information is to decision-making as unpolluted air is to the lungs!

So much for the diatribe and exhortation. Now, let us try to assess the current Ethiopian macroeconomy on the basis of what little relatively up-to- date economic data we have been able to lay our hands on. The Central Statistical Authority (CSA) says that the rate of inflation in the country in November 1996 (the latest figure available at the time of writing) was lower by 6.5 percent than what it was in November 1995. So, during the first five months of the current fiscal year of 1996/97, we are officially being told that the term to use in connection with the movement of domestic prices is not the usual "inflation" but rather its opposite "deflation". Do you agree or not? Voices of protest such as the following may be heard:

*What about the astronomical rent increases on government-owned houses in August 1996?

*Are the fuel price increases made in September 1996 peanuts? If so, for whom?

*Are the prices of land, houses and used cars included in the price indicator?

*There is not much of a decrease in the price of "teff" per quintal, nor in cooking oil per liter and butter per kilo. Teff is currently selling at over 280 birr per quintal

*Have any of the statistical boffins at the CSA taken into account the price rises in water, electricity and telephone services charges in their esteemed calculations?

*At the restaurant where I take my lunch, I have seen with my own two eyes the price of a dish going up from seven birr to twelve birr.

*My statistical literacy is not that much, but I do read the government- owned Amharic daily "Addis Zemen", and only the other day the newspaper was saying that the prices of domestically produced pharmaceuticals were skyrocketing ("Addis Zemen", Tir 4, 1989 E.C).

*Orange prices are going up to 3.50 birr per kilo on the private market. Has that been factored into your price calculations?

The statistical wizards at the CSA may understandably feel a little irritated at this point and reply:

"We are not responsible for your lack of statistical literacy. If you don't know a mode from a median or statistics as a science from statistics as a set of data, we would advise you to buy one of the statistics books entitled " Statistics Made Easy". As for your comments, we do have some explanations to provide. First, house rent is not included in the index. So, your objections concerning rising house rents are well taken, but these are just not shown in our index. The other thing you must remember is that our price index is supposed to capture price movements both upwards and downwards. Hence, what you observe in the general index is the net outcome on those positive and negative movements. In any case, although what you say may be true when taken in isolation, in general it is quite difficult to deny the fact that there has at least been price stability on average in recent months".

Well, well, you are up against the experts: What can one say, on matters statistical, against the masters of stochastic regression models, analysis of variance, homoscedasticity, autocorrelation and multicollinearity!? But who is going to be browbeaten into silence by those tongue-twisters!? They had better put them back in their statistics or econometrics text books! What we are telling them is the exact bills we paid at supermarkets and restaurants the other day!

Now, let us move quickly to the other experts, the monetary economists. These breeds of experts seem to be careful with the statistics they spew, perhaps because they are dealing with money. They say, officially, that what they call broad money (currency outside bank demand, savings and time deposits) rose by 11.7 percent in November 1996 (again the latest figure available as we go to press) when compared to the level in November 1995. An increase in the total volume of money of that magnitude would normally be expected to show up as price inflation, because as monetarists are wont to say, "inflation is a monetary phenomenon". But, alas, the stochastic nature of economic variables in Ethiopia is such as to defy any such neat economic principle. As we have tried to indicate, what actually transpired on the price front during that period was not inflation but rather deflation. However, during the first five months of the 1996/97 fiscal year, broad money increased by only 1.5 percent, lending some credence to the famous monetarist tenet of inflation being largely determined by the magnitude of monetary expansion. One point five percent is not much of an increase. The official reason given for the overall decline in domestic prices are: the bumper harvest in 1995/96 (remember the all-time high of 96 million quintals?), and the reduction in customs duties, pushing domestic prices of imports downwards despite exchange rate depreciation. "If you don't agree, you are perfectly entitled to your opinion", say government officials.

Looking at the country's foreign exchange reserves, whose level is an important indicator of the health of the nation's macroeconomy, we observe that things are not as good as they appear to be on the price front. During the first five months of the current fiscal year of 1996/97, foreign reserves went down from 6.2 billion birr to 5.6 billion birr or by about 10.7 percent. As would be expected, the collapse of coffee prices on the world market from peak levels in 1994/95 was an important contributing factor here. Trends in other economic variables are briefly as given below, although figures available are not up-to-date and cover for the most part only the first three months of the current fiscal year.

Value of Exports: unfavorable, dropped by over 30 percent

Coffee export unit price: went down by 27 percent

Imports: down by 44 percent

Exchange rate: the birr depreciated marginally

What should we make of the overall macroeconomics picture during the first five months of the current fiscal year of 1996/97 on the basis of the above official statistics? Well, they say inflation is down. That remains a big question mark. Monetary expansion appears to be slowing down, which is good for price stability, but is also a sign of recession. Foreign reserves are down by over ten percent; world coffee prices are still depressed. So, overall Ethiopia's macroeconomy during the first five months of the current fiscal year looks like being anything but buoyant.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


457 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Science and Health;
Baboons Destroy Timber Plantations


BYLINE: Sandra Nyaira, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

MUTARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - What started as a way of survival, during the great drought of 1992, has developed into a full-blown taste for the 8,000 baboons roaming Zimbabwe's precious timber plantations in the eastern Manicaland province.

The simians are stripping the bark of young wattle and pine trees at an alarming rate causing damage to the plantations in excess of five million U.S. dollars every year.

The baboons, whose natural diet includes a variety of plants and animals such as small mammals, birds, eggs, insects, slugs and small reptiles, were forced into chewing the bark of young commercial trees in the plantations when their diet was not readily available.

But after the drought, they developed a taste -- and a sport -- for the bark in the plantations, leaving investors and conservationists scratching their heads as to how to deal with what has become an "expensive nuisance." 

The grotesque-faced but highly intelligent simians target trees between eight years and 10 years old, strip the bark off the branches or, in some cases, strip off the whole tree of its bark and leave it to die, worthless.

It takes a tree 25 years to mature and get maximum commercial value. Now, the three major timber companies which own 80 percent of the country's 110, 700 hectares of commercial plantations are spending millions of dollars trying to replace damaged trees by replanting.

Estimates are that in most plantations the baboons have destroyed up to 3 percent of the trees to a level beyond commercial utilization. One company has lost at least 600 hectares of trees.

Baboons are a menace, especially when two troops meet and engage in a contest of stripping the bark off the trees, causing extensive damage in their new-found sport.

The timber industry, whose major stakeholders in the province and the country as a whole are the Wattle Company, Border Timbers and the state-owned Forestry Commission, has been hit hard by the problem.

The baboons have, for a long time, been notorious for being a problem animal in the rural areas where they steal poultry, raid crops or snatch groceries from children.

Some people say that baboons have taken to this kind of behavior because man has been collecting wild fruits for sale in towns, leaving the primates with insufficient food. However, others contend that there is enough wild fruit, only that the animals have developed bad habits.

For the timber companies, the problem is growing along with the baboon population. Females give birth to one young at a time after a gestation period of seven months.

The timber industry says it has reached a point where it has to deal with the animals to avoid further losses.

The industry, which in 1996 produced at least 120 million dollars worth of timber goods, has suggested birth control measures to stabilize the baboon population. Other strategies such as culling or hounding them out of the plantations have also been proffered.

However, the idea of killing this human-like animal has met with resistance from traditional leaders and environmentalists. Traditional leaders say that African customs forbid the wholesale killing of baboons, because doing so could cast a disastrous spell, such as perennial droughts, on the country.

Environmentalists say that the culling of the animals could disturb the ecological balance.

But those bearing the brunt of the problem think otherwise. So, the battle lines are drawn between humans even before the fight is taken to the baboons.

"The industry is currently losing millions due to the big baboon population that we have in the forests and we have no choice but to look at ways of how we can prevent them from destroying the trees," says Edward Mutsvairo, the Forestry Commission acting general manager.

The Wattle company's operations manager, Nigel Payne, says: "The baboons seem to have quite a taste in pine bark and they have become a pest causing a lot of damage and losses to the industry as they have moved from their traditional food."

He says the rapid growth in the baboon population could also be attributed to the lack of a natural predator, such as the leopard, in the forests.

Paynes says contraception would fail in the short-term, as an immediate solution was to arrest the losses.

"The idea of contraception sounds good on paper but practically it would be something else so we need to reduce the population first and then think of long term strategies latter," he says.

The chief executive officer of the Timber Producers Federation, Bill Johnstone, thinks the baboons have just developed a hedonist habit, like smoking, of destroying the trees not because they want food but because they just love the fun.

"The problem has been in existence before with only minor cases being recorded," he says. "But today, the problem has reached extremely serious proportions and if not controlled will endanger the future of the timber industry."

Various ways, such as trappings, have been explored, he says, but the baboons learn quickly and know how to avoid the danger.

The sharp increase in the baboon population has also been attributed to the lack of proper control by the Problem Animal Control Section, a unit within the Department of National Parks and Wildlife Management, which used to control the animals by using a very poisonous chemical known as Teladrex to kill them.

Use of the chemical was then banned worldwide in the 1980's resulting in the rapid population growth.

Johnstone thinks the baboon problem can only be dealt with after a short- term method has been introduced first. So, the industry is trying to get help from countries Kenya, and Sweden which have experienced the same problems.

In Sweden, the clever animals were conquered by spraying of wolves' urine in timber plantations to scare them away as they do not stay anywhere near danger signals.

"For the industry's survival we have to reduce the baboons immediately then we can start talking about long-term solutions which would have to be environmental friendly," Johnstone says.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


458 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa: Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - African newspapers commented at length on the bombings in Algeria, Zaire's military counteroffensive against anti- government forces, student demonstrations in Cote d'Ivoire, the suspension of Bingu Wa Mutharika, the secretary-general of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) and the state of the continent's universities.

Since the beginning of the holy month of Ramadan, Algeria has been hit by bombings not experienced since the end of its war of independence.

Confronted with this, the country's papers said, government has remained incredibly mute. The papers asked many unanswered questions, which seemed to highlight their frustration at official silence. 

Al-Watan wondered why it had been so easy for the bombers to set off their devices in this "very well guarded" capital of three million people.

"Why such ease of action?" it said.

Al Khabar could not fathom what the bombers wanted to prove by destroying everything in sight, while Liberte wondered where the bombs had come from.

"According to unconfirmed reports," it said, "between three thousand and four thousand tons of explosives have been stolen from warehouses in the last two years."

"Each day," Liberte said, "demolition experts defuse these bombs." But more importantly, it said, "who are the masterminds behind these attacks?"

The press also asked what game the government was playing since, Le Matin said, it had maintained an "irresponsible silence" throughout the entire affair.

As the Zaire military gears up for its counteroffensive in the east of the country, two of Dakar's newspapers commented on the state of the army and its preparations for battle.

Le Soleil said that if Kinshasa failed to defeat the anti-government forces, then "the most serious threat" to Zaire would be to keep the country as one entity.

"Is the Zairean army not a reflection of a government nearing its end, as many observers think?

"Is it not a reflection of a government that finds it hard to identify with anything but power?

"If Laurent-Desire Kabila's resounding victory is an answer to all these questions, so too is the time it has taken the central government to retaliate," it said.

"It is certainly this (government) reaction which will help us gauge the real situation Zaire," it said.

Turning to the police shooting of university students in Cote d'Ivoire on Tuesday, Sud Quotidien said that the government's decision to use force appeared more like a "declaration of war."

This action, it said, showed that African governments "still have a lot to learn" about managing social conflicts, especially student demonstrations.

"Government authority is not judged by its ability to deploy security forces at the slightest sign of social tension. Rather, it lies in its ability to make timely concessions without appearing to concede defeat," it said.

It warned that the hardening of attitudes was dangerous because it could so easily lead to an escalation of violence.

"Today only one student has died but clashes tomorrow will cause new victims and the cycle will continue," it said.

Lusaka dailies commented on the suspension of Bingu wa Mutharika as secretary-general of COMESA, following anonymous accusations of his misuse of the organization's resources.

The Council of Ministers of the COMESA suspended him for three months and ordered him before them for a hearing. Mutharika refused, saying the ministers were not authorized for this sort of thing.

The Post said that there may have been "valid reasons" for Mutharika's suspension "but the Council of Ministers should have been extra careful to avoid even a hint that the action was dictated by the exigencies of internal Malawian politics."

"It failed in this respect," it said.

However, the Zambia Daily Mail said because Mutharika -- a Malawian -- is a public servant heading an organization funded by tax payers money of member states, "he should feel duty-bound to open himself up to an inquiry, whether he believes it is a kangaroo court or not.

"The Council of Ministers, on the other hand, should give the accused...the opportunity to respond to the charges levelled against him," it said.

Nigeria's Daily Times, published in Lagos, stayed with the problems of African universities.

It said that the Association of African Universities, which met recently in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, "needed to re-examine closely" the role of the continent's universities "with a view to making them more relevant to their societies."

This, it noted, had been the case elsewhere in the world, with the results of their research efforts benefitting their public.

"The secret of their success has to do with how well they have been able to impact upon their host communities," it said,

African universities, which were established with similar ideals, it said, had for the most part failed to live up to their billing.

"Rather than provide a strong basis for development, they are becoming a perpetual liability to the governments," it said.

This state of affairs has created many problems in its wake: the dwindling resources to universities has kept the remuneration of university teachers, as well as non academic staff very low; and led to the loss of highly skilled manpower to foreign institutions.

"It has also ensured a continuous dearth of lecturers and facilities, and a consequent fall in academic standards," it said.

"As the 21st century beckons, the Lusaka delegates have the onerous responsibility to come up with workable proposals to make universities in Africa more responsive to the needs of their environment," it added. "A situation where many centers of excellence spend far more of their meagre resources on housing, transportation and other services is unhelpful. They should think of new ways of better managing their funds. Like their counterparts in other parts of the world, they should learn to spend more on research activities which should be the fulcrum of academia," it said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


459 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Senegal;
Taiwan pledges Support For Senegal's Food Programme


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Taiwanese Foreign Affairs Minister John Chang has promised his country's help to Senegal's in increasing agricultural production to achieve food self-sufficiency.

He told reporters after discussions Friday in Dakar with Senegalese Prime Minister Habib Thiam that agricultural cooperation was the focus of their deliberations. 

Chang's Senegalese counterpart, Moustapha Niasse, attended the one-hour meeting. Chang said they discussed implementation of a major irrigation project covering 75,000 hectares of the Fossil Valley, in northern Senegal.

Both delegations also discussed road construction projects.

Chang, who arrived in Dakar on Thursday, for a 72-hour official visit, was received by President Abdou Diouf.

On Friday, he met with Niasse; the Economy, Finance and Planning minister, Pape Ousmane Sakho, and the the minister of agriculture, Robert Sagna.

Chang is on an African tour which has already taken him to Swaziland, Malawi, Guinea-Bissau and Gambia. He will leave Dakar Sunday for Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.

China suspended diplomatic relations with Senegal in 1996 after Dakar decided to restore ties with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


460 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Stock Market Ends Week Active


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Stock market ended the week, on Friday, active and firmer with the key Industrial Index putting 93 points to end the day at 10,112.80.

Ferro-alloy, building and construction manufacturer PG, tea producer Tanganda and the Tedco group of companies all went up 10 cents to 790, 610, 360 and 1170 points respectively. (1 U.S. dollar = 10 zimbabwe dollars). 

The tobacco trading group, TSL, gained 25 cents to 775 points in reasonable turnover while publishing group Zimpapers rose 50 cents to 2,950 and National Foods put on 70 cents to 700 cents.

Banking giant Barclays and the merchant banking group, FMB, both in reasonable turnover put on 100 cents as did Porthold to 3,400, 5,800, and 1, 700 respectively.

Chemical manufacturer Chemco, in reasonable turnover, closed 400 up at 4, 000 cents.

Counters to lose included the battery manufacturer, Chloride, transport company Clan and seed producer Seed-Co all down 10 cents to 140, 520 and 230 cents, respectively.

Tea producer Eastern Highlands, lost 15 cents to 130, tyre manufacturer NTS shed 20 cents to trade at 530 cents while metal industries manufacturer Radar, and cigarette maker Rothmans dropped 25 and 100 cents to close at 475 and 6, 000 respectively.

Meanwhile in minings, trading was firmer than of late, with gold miners Ashanti, Falgold and Mhangura all unchanged.

Falcon warrants rose 10 points to 40 while nickel producer, Bindura put on 40 points to trade at 850.

The ferro-alloy producer, Alloys Mines, on the other hand, lost five points to 115 and coal producer Wankie dropped 25 points to close at 475.

The mining index put on 7.05 to close at 1,054.49.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


461 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 24, 1997


Science and Health;
Call For Comprehensive Reproductive Health Policies


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - African governments were urged Friday to formulate comprehensive adolescent reproductive health policies which recognize the rights of youths.

In one of their recommendations at the end of the Forum on Adolescent Reproductive Health, delegates said that these policies should be developed with the participation of the concerned age groups. 

The focus of the forum was on preparing African youth for the next millennium.

The forum's 500 delegates also urged regional groups to "support and encourage appropriate adolescent reproductive health programmes and services, particularly among sexually active adolescents."

They asked the Organization of African Unity, the continent's most important political body, and other regional groups, to try and influence governments to promoting adolescent reproductive health.

Closing the forum, the executive director of the United Nations Population Fund, Nafis Sadik, said she was concerned at the persistence of harmful practices such as female circumcision, which is practiced in 26 of Africa's 53 states.

"Some one hundred and twenty million women worldwide have suffered female genital mutilation. This is a painful and unnecessary procedure," she said.

However, Sadik said that some countries had started looking for alternatives to female circumcision.

Yet, she said that parents had a key role in shaping their adolescents' reproductive health by giving them correct education and advise on sexuality.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


462 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Investigating Possible Libyan Air Violation


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Washington - State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns issued the following statement January 23 on a possible sanctions violation by a Libyan airliner at a Ghanaian airport. 

We have seen press reports that a Libyan airliner was permitted to land and take off from Ghana's Accra airport last Tuesday, January 21.

We are investigating this report to confirm the facts. This would be a serious violation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 748, which prohibits Libyan aircraft from engaging in international flights, and we will pursue the matters in the Security Council and Sanctions Committee.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


463 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. 'Profoundly Worried' About Situation In Zaire


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Washington - Text of comments by State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns issued January 23 on Zaire.

The United States is profoundly worried by signs that the conflict in Zaire may soon escalate. Increased combat in Eastern Zaire would not only threaten the civilian population in the area -- including the internally displaced and remaining Rwandan refugees -- but also risk a direct confrontation among national armies in the region. We renew our call for an immediate cease-fire and dialogue among belligerents to achieve a peaceful political settlement of the crisis. We also call for withdrawal of any foreign forces -- including mercenaries -- currently in Zaire. 

From the start of this crisis, we have urged neighboring governments not to join the conflict, and have pressed them to use their influence to restrain the rebel forces operating in the Kivus. The United States strongly reaffirms its recognition of the territorial integrity of Zaire and the inviolability of the existing borders of all states in the region. This stance is consistent with declarations of African regional leaders at the November 5 Nairobi summit and in U.N. Resolution 1078 of November 10.

To bring a lasting end to this crisis, a political settlement is needed not only among Zaire and neighboring countries, but also between the authorities in Kinshasa and disaffected groups in the east. We and other members of the international community will continue to work closely in support of African peacemaking initiatives, which have included the regional summit meetings convened by Kenyan President Moi and a meeting of the U.N.'s Standing Advisory Committee on Security Questions in Central Africa hosted by Congolese President Lissouba. As a further step to promote a peaceful settlement, the imminent appointment of a U.N. Special Representative to the Great Lakes region is a welcome development.

While an end to the fighting in Eastern Zaire is an urgent objective, Zairians must also continue to focus on the preeminent goal of their democratic transition. Establishment of credible governing institutions is essential to provide for stability and return to economic development in Zaire. Moreover, popular participation in selecting political leaders and greater decentralization of authority to the regions hold the keys to addressing the demands of disaffected groups in Eastern Zaire and elsewhere.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


464 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 86 on the Great Lakes (01/24)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Nairobi - There have been conflicting reports on the number of people killed in the Rwandan army's clean-up operation in the northwest of the country following increasing violence in the region. Speaking on the BBC yesterday, Vice-President Paul Kagame said 80 people had been killed, including civilians, but NGO sources have spoken of hundreds of deaths.

Observers from the UN Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (UNHRFOR) are currently visiting the communes to establish the extent of the sweep. Kagame's adviser Claude Dusaidi, in an interview with the BBC, said violence had intensified since the mass return of refugees to the country. The government was mobilising the people politically, he said, and military vigilance was being increased. Dusaidi denied reports that two of three people, taken into custody in connection with the killing of three Spanish Medicos del Mundo (MDM) employees in Ruhengeri, had died. In further remarks, broadcast by Rwandan radio yesterday, Dusaidi also categorically denied allegations that the Rwandan army was involved in the deaths of the aid workers. 

Rwandan radio yesterday reported that two genocide suspects had committed suicide in Gisenyi prison. It named the two as ex-FAR soldiers Lt.Col Nzabanita and Lt.Innocent Nsabimana. They apparently used their clothes to strangle themselves while in a latrine on Tuesday. Their deaths were discovered after the prison guard went to investigate why they were spending so long in the latrine. A probe into their suspected involvement in the 1994 genocide was underway, the radio said. In a separate despatch, the radio said an ex-FAR major, his six children and a neighbour were killed on Wednesday in the Nyamyumba commune of Gisenyi prefecture. An investigation was being held into the incident.

As the Rwandan authorities launched their crackdown on Hutu extremists, army spokesman Emmanuel Ndahiro briefed the international community in Kigali on the measures currently underway. He said the number of soldiers in the area had been increased and patrols were working round the clock. Civilians had also been urged to cooperate with the military. "We assure you that we shall deal with this problem and...bring back the confidence you've had in us, " he stated. A report by Amnesty International meanwhile, released today, warned that the "rushed and forced nature" of refugee returns could lead to increased human rights violations.

* The long-expected Zairean counter-offensive appears to be underway, with reports yesterday of the capture of Walikale from rebels of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL). The Zairean defence ministry announced that 100 rebels, including one of their leaders, were killed in the fighting, with 20 soldiers wounded on the government side. According to the statement, Zairean forces (FAZ) used air cover to deal a " deadly blow to the enemy". Gabonese Africa No.1 radio, in a broadcast from Kinshasa, said FAZ troops were now heading for Bukavu and Goma. It quoted a FAZ communique as calling on people to vacate the battle zones. "The counter- offensive will not spare anybody, and the war will be fought to the end, whatever the price," the statement said. Sources in Kisangani told AFP late yesterday that Zairean helicopter gunships staged raids on rebel supply lines near Walikale, destroying several trucks carrying ammunition to the rebels.

Commenting on the widely-reported presence of foreign mercenaries in eastern Zaire, the French daily 'Liberation' today alleged a Belgian was heading a force of 280 white mercenaries in Kisangani to fight alongside Zairean troops. The paper's correspondent in Kisangani said the Belgian, named Christian Tavernier, was a friend of French mercenary Bob Denard, and had been in touch with advisers of President Jacques Chirac, as well as with President Mobutu. The paper said Tavernier, described as in his sixties, had set up base at Watsa, a mining town 700km northeast of Kisangani. The mercenary force allegedly financed by Kuwait, included Serbs, Croats, Russians, Poles, Belgians, Italians and a "significant number of French".

Speaking ahead of the reported capture of Walikale, Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila had urged Goma residents to stop panicking over Zairean Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo's announcement on Monday of a major counter-offensive in the east. "It seems people in Kinshasa will counter-attack, but why are you running away," Kabila told a news conference in Goma on Tuesday. However some aid agencies in north and south Kivu have begun scaling down their operations and some western embassies called on relief organisations to pull out altogether. Aid sources in Goma say the rebels have been requisitioning aid vehicles.

Hundreds of thousands of refugees and displaced people trapped in eastern Zaire will be the worst-affected victims of a Zairean counter-offensive, coupled with reduced relief operations. The UN Humanitarian Coordinator Martin Griffiths described the plight of refugees and IDPs in the Shabunda and Lubutu regions as "dire" and warned that the situation could reach crisis proportions if the Kinshasa authorities prevented aid agencies from operating outside Kisangani. Humanitarian operations are being seriously hampered by the Zairean government's decision not to issue "sauf-conduit" permits due to the military operation. UNICEF said a total of 88 people, 47 of them children under five, had died in Tingi-Tingi between 15 and 19 January, mostly from malnutrition, malaria and diarrhoea. It reported 5,907 unaccompanied children in Tingi-Tingi, and 1,500 in Amisi.

Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi yesterday urged ADFL rebels to withdraw from the key towns of Goma, Bukavu, Uvira and Bunia to avert "imminent war" in the area, Kenyan radio reported. Once the rebels had moved out of these areas "it will enable those concerned to seek solutions to the problem facing the Great Lakes region without further bloodshed," he was quoted as saying. He added that he was opposed to foreign intervention in eastern Zaire as this would escalate existing problems.

* The foreign ministers of four countries charged by the Nairobi-II regional meeting last month to oversee the Great Lakes conflict will meet in Pretoria, South Africa, on Monday and Tuesday. The Kenyan, South African, Zimbabwean and Cameroon foreign ministers will be joined by their Congolese and Tanzanian counterparts for what a Kenyan official described as a " brainstorming session". The OAU secretary-general has also been invited to the gathering.

* Diplomatic contacts with Burundi continued yesterday as Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu met Burundian leader Pierre Buyoya in the southern Rwandan town of Butare. Buyoya, who was accompanied by his foreign minister Luc Rukingama and defence minister Firmin Sinzoyiheba, held talks on the regional economic sanctions against his country. The two leaders also discussed the Great Lakes conflicts in general.

Meanwhile, concern continues to be expressed over the lack of fuel and difficult operating conditions for NGOs and the UN in Burundi. The existence of some 200 displaced people's camps has been reported in the country and there are heightened worries over conditions at the Maramvya camp, near Bujumbura. Over the past few weeks, hundreds of people have gathered spontaneously at the camp, with many suffering from severe malnutrition.

* Four major suspects in the Rwandan genocide of 1994 arrived in the Tanzanian town of Arusha yesterday where they will be tried by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR). The four, who were extradited from Cameroon, include Theoneste Bagasora, former defence ministry cabinet director who is accused of directing events in the first days of the massacres. The other three are a former transport minister Andre Ntagerura, a senior official of the extremist Mille Collines radio, Ferdinand Nahimana and a former lieutenant colonel Anatole Nsengiyumva. The four are now in detention in Arusha. Chief Prosecutor Louise Arbour said the transfer of the four from Cameroon "marks a capital turning point for the credibility of the international tribunal".

Nairobi, 24 January 1997, 15:00 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


465 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 4 - Africa (1/24)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3227 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania B) Uganda C) Somalia D) Angola E) Liberia and Sierra Leone

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Zaire - most information as of 19 January a) UN 1997 Inter-Agency Appeal for the Great Lakes regional Operation scheduled to be released second week of February. b) Air operations from Kisangani to Tingi Tingi/Amisi disrupted due to non-availability of planes. c) Air operations to Kisangani are expected to resume on 24 January, after a break for plane maintenance. d) Zaire formally announces a counteroffensive to recover territories currently occupied by Tutsi rebels. e) In Goma area, repatriation slows. Communications equipment of some agencies expropriated. f) Organised and spontaneous repatriation through the Bukavu areas still increasing.

2. Rwanda a) Medicos del Mundo (MDM) suspends activities in Rwanda, following an incident in which three MDM staff were shot dead and another seriously wounded. Aid agencies are enhancing security measures. WFP international staff has been temporarily withdrawn from Ruhengeri and Gisenyi and operations have scaled down. 

3. Burundi a) Residents of the new "regroupement", or collection camps, and other displaced people in Ngozi and Karuzi province are receiving food assistance by WFP. b) Violence continues with increasing numbers of attacks, killings and ambushes now customary.

B. UGANDA

1. Update a) Recent fighting in Kitgum, northern Uganda has resulted in the death of 400 people and the displacement of some 20,000 others. WFP is identifying resources to cover immediate needs.

C. SOMALIA 1. Update a) Contingency plans in place relating to reports of drought in the region. Stocks to be pre-positioned in Dadaab in Kenya to respond quickly to needs in the Juba Valley.

D. ANGOLA 1. Update a) WFP Protracted Relief Operation (PRO) 5602 expansion approved on 22 January by the WFP Executive Board. Operation covers needs of 662,000 displaced and war affected persons from March 1997-February 1998 (total food requirements: 96,033 metric tons). Project continues relief efforts, but emphasizes increasing support for resettlement and rehabilitation activities. b) Vulnerability Analysis and Mapping Unit is being established in WFP Luanda.

E. LIBERIA AND SIERRA LEONE

1. Liberia a) Demobilisation rate picks up; 400 soldiers demobilising per day, but lack of sufficient logistical support along with insecurity in many parts of the country are hindering the demobilisation process. b) Humanitarian activities have resumed in Grand Cape Mount County, but general distribution has not yet re-commenced. c) WFP successfully delivers food to Zwedru in first humanitarian mission to this area since the April 1996 crisis.

2. Sierra Leone a) All general food distributions in Sierra Leone now phased out, as part of transition from relief to resettlement and targeted food assistance. b) Significant numbers of internally displaced persons have resettled, as a result of improved security in most of the country. c) WFP resettlement package distributions begin in Bo district.

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, EASTERN ZAIRE TANZANIA

1. GENERAL

1.1 The 1997 UN Consolidated Inter-Agency Appeal for the Great Lakes Region is now scheduled to be released during the second week of February. The appeal will provide detailed caseload planning figures, food requirements and expected shortfalls for the region for the period January-December 1997.

2. EASTERN ZAIRE - most information as of 19 January.

2.1 Kisangani

a) The first 250 metric tons of maize, of a consignment of 2,000 metric tons, arrived by a combination of rail and river barge in Kisangani on 22 January from Lusaka, Zambia. The cereal will be onforwarded overland and by aircraft to reach the refugees gathered in Tingi Tingi, Amisi and the Shabunda area.

b) Airlift operations from Kisangani to Tingi Tingi and Amisi resumed after a brief suspension which had been at the request of Zairean authorities, but normal schedules are being disrupted due to insufficient availability of planes. Only 19 metric tons were dispatched during the week: 12 metric tons to Tingi-Tingi, 5 metric tons to Amisi and 2 metric tons to Shabunda.

c) No flights to Kisangani took place during the present week due to maintenance of the Boeing 707. Air operations are expected to be resumed on 24 January. Between 13-19 January 364 metric tons of food were delivered to Kisangani, plus non-food items from WFP, MSF and UNHCR.

d) On 20 January, the Prime Minister of Zaire announced a counteroffensive to recover territories currently occupied by Tutsi rebels. Kisangani is witnessing increased military activities but the security situation is reported to be normal.

e) Stocks in Kisangani as of January 20 amounted to 446 metric tons of food, of which 110 metric tons were UNICEF Unimix. WFP has three warehouses in Kisangani with an estimated capacity of 1,000 metric tons.

2.2 Tingi Tingi and Amisi

a) About 150 cases of diarrhoea are being diagnosed every day in Tingi Tingi, some of which are reported as being cholera cases. UNICEF and MSF are endeavouring to control the situation. Lack of water in Amisi is a matter of concern.

2.3 Shabunda

a) As described in the previous Emergency Report, Shabunda hosts thousands of refugees from Rwanda and Burundi and internally displaced Zaireans. Refugees, mostly arrived from Bukavu and Uvira, are spontaneously settled at three locations on the left bank of Ulindi river while displaced Zaireans are living in poor conditions among local population. WFP has delivered by air 4 metric tons of Unimix and maize flour and UNICEF will arrange the distribution.

b) Some 550 families from Kaseke/Shabunda arrived at Tingi Tingi on 17 January. These families were registered by UNHCR and given high-energy biscuits before settling. Some refugee groups are still arriving in Shabunda from Katshunguru.

2.4 Goma

a) General insecurity appears to have slowed down the rhythm of repatriation. A total 863 refugees repatriated during the week of 13-19 January at a daily average of 144 persons. This is a reduction by 43% as compared to the previous week.

b) Efforts to assess situation in Masisi frustrated as still no passage is allowed beyond the last rebel held check point at Mushaki.

c) Communications equipment of various agencies has been expropriated by the local authorities in an action seen as an attempt to curtail external communications.

2.5 Bukavu

a) Organised and spontaneous repatriation through the Bukavu areas still increasing. Between 13-19 January, 12,855 persons repatriated, an increase of almost 30% as compared to the previous week. WFP distributed 9 metric tons of high-energy biscuits to a total 28,659 returning refugees. The transport capacity to shuttle returning refugees has been increased. UNHCR can now transport a maximum 2,500 refugees per day.

b) Road access from Bukavu to Shabunda still not permitted to humanitarian agencies. Access to northern areas is restricted to 115 km on the Bunyakiri road.

3. RWANDA

3.1 In an overnight attack on the past weekend in Ruhengeri, three Medicos del Mundo (MDM) staff were shot dead and another was seriously wounded. MDM have suspended activities in Rwanda until a thorough investigation is carried out. Humanitarian operations in insecure areas in Rwanda will not be suspended but international aid agencies are enhancing security measures. This decision was agreed at a joint UN/NGO/Government meeting in Kigali, following the above incident and other recent incidents targeting aid workers in Ruhengeri and Gisenyi.

3.2 WFP has acceded to a request from the Government of Rwanda to extend food distributions to returnees from two to six months. At the end of this period, the situation will be reviewed. It was further determined that food- for-work activities to be implemented will emphasise house building and land reclamation projects.

3.3 While food distributions are being handed over from NGOs to local authorities, WFP will continue to deliver the food to the communes for handling and distribution by the communal authorities. WFP has proposed guidelines to ensure transparent and effective implementation of food distributions. To date, WFP has provided 23,810 metric tons of food (1.48 million monthly rations) for distribution to returnees.

3.4 The Government of Rwanda announced that Burundian refugees must go home. UNHCR is discussing the issue with the Government.

3.5 An average 1,000 people a day are still crossing the border at Rusumo, coming from Tanzania.

4. BURUNDI

4.1 Residents of the new "regroupement" camps and other displaced people are receiving food assistance from WFP in Ngozi and Karuzi provinces. The current distribution programme will assist approximately 80,000 people in this area. Populations affected by the conflict in Burundi have been grouped by the authorities in these collection camps over the past six to eight months, apparently to protect them from being used as shields by the rebels fighting the Government.

4.2 Fuel shortages likely to hamper humanitarian activities, as no authorisation has so far been received from the Regional Sanctions Co- ordinating Committee. Only one fuel shipment has been allowed since the beginning of the embargo in July 1996 and agencies' stocks are virtually depleted.

4.3 Violence continues to plague Burundi with increasing numbers of attacks, killings and ambushes now becoming customary. During the last week, security incidents were reported in the majority of the provinces of the country.

4.4 From 13-19 January, WFP Burundi assisted 167,951 people, mostly displaced populations affected by the civil strife who received two week rations. Total food distributions during the week amounted to 746 metric tons. Stocks in Burundi as of 19 January totalled 2,445 metric tons of various foods.

B. UGANDA

1. Update

1.1 The Government of Uganda has requested WFP to provide immediate food assistance to 20,000 displaced people who fled their homes after fighting broke out in Kitgum district, northern Uganda. About 400 people lost their lives during the attacks. Resources need to be identified for this group, for a total 291 metric tons of mixed foods.

C. SOMALIA

1. Update

1.1 WFP-Somalia is preparing a contingency plan for various supply channels into Somalia relating to the reports of drought in the region. Preparations are underway for WFP to move 800 metric tons of mixed commodities from Dar Es Salaam and Mombasa to the Somalian refugee camp warehouse at Dadaab (Kenya) in order to be in a position to respond quickly with an intervention in the Juba Valley.

D. ANGOLA

1. Update

1.1 The second expansion of WFP Protracted Relief Operation (PRO) 5602 was approved on 22 January by the WFP Executive Board. This operation calls for 96,033 metric tons of food commodities to assist some 662,000 displaced and war affected persons from March 1997-February 1998. The project, while continuing to contribute to relief efforts, emphasizes increasing support for resettlement and rehabilitation activities, for example through food-for-work.

1.2 A Vulnerability Analysis and Mapping (VAM) Unit is being established within the WFP office in Luanda. The unit will work with the Government of Angola, NGOs and donors to collect and analyse data to identify areas of food insecurity and beneficiaries in need of assistance.

1.3 WFP participated in a second UCAH-led (DHA) joint assessment mission to the Chicuma area in Benguela province on 14-15 January. The mission confirmed that reports of a large-scale emergency due to population displacement were overstated.

1.4 WFP has signed bilateral agreements with Save the Children Federation- USA and World Vision. WFP will provide handling, storage and transport for approximately 30,000 metric tons of food aid (about 15,000 metric tons each) during 1997.

E. LIBERIA AND SIERRA LEONE

1. LIBERIA

1.1 Demobilisation has picked up in the past week, with 400 soldiers demobilising per day. A total of 9,084 soldiers have been demobilised from 22 November-21 January. A new demobilisation site at Saw Mill (ULIMO-K) was established.

1.2 The international humanitarian community continues to note that a lack of sufficient logistical support, combined with insecurity in many parts of the country, are hindering the demobilisation process. Although some faction leaders have claimed to be committed to completing disarmament by the 31 January deadline, many factions continue not to co-operate in the process.

1.3 Nine persons were killed on the Bomi Highway in an ambush on 16 January. ULIMO-J fighters are said to be among the victims. Reports also indicate increased tension in Monrovia with incidents of kidnapping, murder and police brutality.

1.4 The 20 December 1996 suspension on humanitarian activities in Grand Cape Mount County was lifted at the beginning of January. The suspension was put into effect following a series of incidents, including the harassment of civilians and humanitarian aid workers, the seizure of a European Union truck and the attempted hijacking of a DHA vehicle. General distribution has not yet re-commenced.

1.5 In the first humanitarian mission to Zwedru since the April 1996 crisis, WFP successfully delivered 8.3 metric ton food. Food and supplies are also being positioned in Greenville, where demobilisation is expected to begin this week. Medical NGOs are also in the process of reactivating hospital activity in this area.

2. SIERRA LEONE

2.1 In the transition from relief to resettlement and targeted food assistance for 1997, all general food distributions in Sierra Leone have been phased out, with the last distributions completed on 24 December.

2.2 Four agencies will be responsible geographically for the food supply to Sierra Leone in 1997: WFP, CRS, World Vision and CARE. This approach is expected to ensure better targeting of available resources and avoid parallel distribution among suppliers and implementing partners. WFP will concentrate distribution in the north-west, western area and adjacent areas of Tonkili and Moyamba districts, Bo north, and the south-eastern part of the country.

2.3 Significant numbers of internally displaced persons have already been resettling throughout the country with an estimated 25% of displaced persons nation-wide and 50% of the registered displaced in Bo town having returned to their place of origin in the past month. Improved security in most of the country has been the main factor behind this return.

2.4 The first WFP resettlement package distributions began on 21 January in Bo district. Some 7,450 persons are expected to be served from the Yormandu, Gerihun and Baoma distribution centres.

(End WFP Emergency Report No. 4 of 1997 - January 24, 1997)


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


466 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 19


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4360 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 19 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, January 24, 1997.

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted the Banyarwanda in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control. In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified. On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, and south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma. As a result of shelling October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps near Goma, fled south to Mugunga camp. After Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the ADFL counter-attacked from the east on November 14, forcing the ex-FAR and Interahamwe to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to return to Rwanda, while others fled north and west into Zaire.

During the last two months, the ADFL has continued its advance north of Goma, capturing the gold-mining town of Bunia on December 24. Zairian prime minister Kengo wa Dondo announced on January 20 the beginning of a counter- offensive to retake territory lost to the rebels, and issued a declaration of war against them.

USAID Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date) -$121,754, 335

Numbers Affected

Rwandan refugees: An estimated 555,000 Rwandan refugees have returned from the Eastern Zaire camps to Rwanda between November and the end of December. About 730,000 have returned since November, 1996, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) reports.

The UNHCR claims there are about 320,000 Rwandans stranded in Eastern Zaire, including 120,000 in Tingi-Tingi, just to the south of Lubutu, 40,000 in Amisi, 70 km southeast of Lubutu, Haut Zaire; 60,000 in Shabunda, including about 5,000 Burundians, and about 100,000 others are dispersed in smaller groups in South Kivu and Maniema provinces. Since January 13, about 2,000 refugees a day have been returning to Rwanda from South Kivu.

Of the 540,000 Rwandan refugees who were in Tanzania, 483,445 returned during 1996, according to the UNHCR.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area, some 64,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania. Between 45,000-55,000 refugees are missing, with 38, 000 believed by the UNHCR to be in Shabunda, others between Fizi and Kalemie, and an unknown number dead.

There are currently about 243,000 Burundian refugees in Tanzania.

Newly Displaced: Fleeing continued fighting in Burundi, a new caseload of about 100,000 Burundian refugees has entered Tanzania since December. Approximately 35,000 Zairians have fled to Tanzania. Since October 1996, about 600 Rwandan, Burundian, and Zairian refugees have entered Zambia from Zaire and Tanzania, the UNHCR reports. Some 800 Rwandan and Zairian Tutsis remain in the Congo and 11,500 Zairians are reported in Uganda.

The UNHCR estimates there are 7,000 internally displaced Zairians in Shabunda, and about 5,000 have fled towards Amisi.

Current Situation

Since December 31, about 100 people have died in a dozen armed clashes in Rwanda. On the evening of January 18 in Ruhengeri town, about 100 km northwest of Kigali, gunmen killed three Spaniards and seriously wounded an American. All worked for Medicos del Mundo (MDM), a relief agency funded by USAID/BHR/OFDA. Three Rwandan soldiers were also killed. The American, who consequently had a leg amputated, was evacuated to Nairobi. At nearly the same time as the attack on the MDM house, other attacks were launched on houses occupied by workers with Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) and Save the Children Fund (SCF). There were no casualties in the other attacks.

The Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) states that the killers belong to the ex- FAR/Interahamwe. The press reports that two suspects arrested in connection with the MDM killings have died in Government of Rwanda (GOR) custody. NGO operations in the prefecture have been scaled back but not suspended. Also in Ruhengeri prefecture, unidentified persons on January 20 killed at least 24 unarmed Rwandans belonging to a civil patrol in Ruhengeri prefecture. Rwandan security forces are searching for the gunmen.

The violence follows disturbing events of the previous week in northwest Rwanda. On January 11, about 60 armed Rwandans, believed to be Interahamwe, attacked the hospital in Kabaya, in Gaseke commune, Gisenyi prefecture. The attackers killed one person, wounded three, and looted medical supplies, according to MSF, which works in the hospital. On January 13 in Giciye commune, also in Gisenyi prefecture, armed men destroyed a vehicle belonging to the U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR). No one was injured, although two HRFOR expatriates were threatened. The next day, a Chinese road crew in Gisenyi prefecture was attacked and beaten by armed men. The RPA is undertaking a cordon and search operation to find the attackers, the USAID Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) reported. Since the attacks, most NGOs have scaled back their activities in the communes in Gisenyi that lie east of the Gishwati forest.

The UNHCR reported that as of December 31, 473,082 Rwandan refugees had returned from Tanzania since December 14, and that the mass return from Tanzania has ended. Although most Rwandan refugees have returned from Eastern Zaire, about 320,000 remain, the UNHCR states. Relief agencies are concerned about the refugees' health, especially the children in the Tingi-Tingi and Amisi camps, in Haut-Zaire province.

MSF conducted an epidemiological survey in Tingi-Tingi, which showed a mortality rate in children under five of 10/10,000 per day, between January 6 and 13. The rate was five times the alert threshold. The main causes of death are malnutrition, diarrhea, and malaria. UNICEF on January 24 reported an average death rate in Tingi-Tingi of 20 per day, of whom half are under five. With Action Contre la Faim (ACLF), MSF operates a supplementary feeding center in Tingi-Tingi that is treating 2,200 children, and a therapeutic feeding center that is treating 250 children.

MSF reported that as of January 21, 526 refugees had died at Tingi-Tingi, 287 of them under five, since December 18, with 22 dying on January 21 alone. UNICEF reports that it is targetting 20,000 children and vulnerables at the seven health centers in Tingi-Tingi. It has a staff of 19 who operate in the Kisangani/Tingi-Tingi/Amisi area.

Political/Military Situation

In Eastern Zaire, foreign mercenaries are believed to be assembling in Kisangani, as reinforcements for the FAZ, in preparation for a counter-attack against the Alliance rebels.

Alliance leader Laurent Kabila stated on January 13 that FAZ and ex-FAR soldiers had entered the Bukavu-Shabunda-Kindu area recently, but had been defeated by the Alliance. On January 10, an Alliance officer told reporters of fighting at Mushaki, in the Goma area, in which at least three persons died.

In Burundi on January 10, Burundian soldiers killed 126 returnees who had just arrived from Tanzania. The killings occurred at Kobero, Muyinga province, where the returnees had been brought in Tanzanian army trucks. The massacre followed the Tanzanian authorities' decision to expel the returnees, who belonged to the militant Palipehutu faction, after they clashed with another Burundian military group in the Kitali Hills refugee camp.

The U.S. Government (USG) and the U.N. Secretary-General on January 13 expressed shock at the massacre, and urged the Government of the Republic of Burundi (GRB) to prevent further killings. After the massacre, the Burundi army arrested seven soldiers who are suspected of involvement in the killings. WFP recently reported fighting in Muramvya and the presence of land mines on roads in Kayanza province.

Cameroon deported four Rwandans to the International Criminal Tribunal on Rwanda in Arusha, Tanzania. The four suspects, who were due to arrive in Tanzania by airplane on January 23, include Theoneste Bagasora, who is accused of participating in the planning of the genocide. In Arusha, the trial of Jean-Paul Akayesu, accused of involvement in the murder of 2,000 Rwandans in Taba, continues. Another 12 suspects remain in custody in Arusha, awaiting trial.

Relief Efforts The Government of Canada hosted a multi-donor meeting in Kigali on December 13 on the reintegration of Rwandan refugees. Representatives from 12 countries, the European Union, U.N. agencies, and the Government of Rwanda (GOR) met to discuss developments since the refugees began returning on November 15, to present GOR priorities, to review donor programs, and to discuss donor coordination efforts. The GOR reiterated its priorities of housing, security, justice and human resource development and called on donors to support whole communities, including returnees and existing residents alike.

A briefing given by the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) and the WFP in Rome on January 13 stated that food availability in the Great Lakes is satisfactory for the immediate future, and that the main need was to reestablish traditional production methods. The assessment contrasted with an FAO/WFP report on Rwanda on January 15, which stated that for the first half of 1997, Rwanda faced a shortage of 30,000 MT of cereals, 45,000 MT of pulses, 124,000 MT of roots and tubers, and 522,000 MT of bananas. The return of more than one million returnees, coupled to the effects of dry weather and low pulse yields, are responsible for the shortages, the organizations reported.

Zaire: Between January 6 and 12, WFP transported 451 MT of food to Kisangani, and 72 MT to Tingi-Tingi. WFP trucks are hauling some food overland from Kisangani to Lubutu, despite incidents of intervention by the FAZ. Other food supplies are flown to Lubutu, where the airstrip can accomodate aircraft carrying 3 MT. >From there food is trucked to Tingi-Tingi. The Amisi airstrip can receive aircraft bearing 6 MT, and from there trucks also take food to Tingi-Tingi. WFP has distributed 260 MT in Tingi-Tingi, 24 MT in Amisi, and 19 MT to internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Kisangani.

On January 15, the WFP plane in Amisi was surrounded by several dozen members of the FAZ and refugees who wanted to be flown to Kisangani. WFP workers fended them off, however. The governor of Kisangani cancelled commercial and humanitarian flights out of Kisangani on January 16-18.

WFP is operating two way stations to receive Rwandan returnees on their way home via Goma. Karuba station is 17 km west of Sake, and Kilolwire station is 35 km north of Sake.

>From January 6 to 8, 4,181 Rwandan returnees entered from Zaire at border crossings in Cyangugu, the USAID/DART reported. The figure of these three days represents about one-half the number who returned during the entire month of December 1996. The International Rescue Committee (IRC) reported that 5,000 refugees were seen heading southeast on the Walikale-Bukavu road, and Rwandan refugees claimed that 20,000-50,000 of their compatriots remained in Hombo, north of Makwe. The ICRC is transporting refugees from Shaminunu to the Ruzizi crossings at the Bukavu-Cyangugu border. The ICRC quoted Zairians as claiming that another 30,000 refugees were near Shaminunu, west- northwest of Bukavu. The IRC, which operates a transit point with MSF/International at Bunyakiri, reported that refugees arriving from Makwe were in fairly good health. The UNHCR reported shortages of fuel and jerrycans, and stated that it would hire more trucks in Zaire.

Rwanda: The UNHCR reports that 1,300,582 refugees returned to Rwanda in 1996: 719,307 returned from Zaire, 483,445 from Tanzania, 88,309 from Burundi, and 9,521 from Uganda. About 11,000 Rwandans entered Rwanda at Cyangugu during January 11-18, including 4,000 on January 17-18, the UNHCR reported.

On December 31, the GOR announced that all food should be distributed through local authorities, and not NGOs, as previously practiced. The WFP was requested to transport food to the communes, from which the UNHCR would take it to distribution points. After several meetings in early January, the GOR and WFP agreed that NGOs would complete their work as food distributors by January 22, and the GOR, as formally head of implementation, would assist in unloading food trucks at extended supply points. Since mid-November, WFP has provided and has helped distribute 16,256 MT of food, representing monthly rations to 972,752 people throughout Rwanda.

By mid-December, GOR authorities hade also registered 1,931 members of the ex-FAR in Gisenyi prefecture. Authorities are still compiling registrations in other prefectures.

The need for permanent shelter poses a major concern for the GOR, which estimates that there is a need for 200,000-250,000 homes nationwide. WFP and UNHCR both report to have built about 6,000 new houses in 1996. The UNHCR distributed 13,182 shelter kits as of November 30, 1996. Officially, the GOR gives squatters two weeks to vacate dwellings belonging to returnees but implementation of this policy appears varied at the commune level. In Gitarama, Kibuye, Cyangugu, and Butare prefectures, USAID/DART has observed that shelter programs targeted at old caseload returnees and vulnerable persons often suffered from these shortcomings: settlements are sometimes in areas without water or adequate land for farming, used inadequate construction materials, and did not involve future occupants in the construction. In contrast, USAID/DART noted that the scattered settlement shelter programs have been more successful. The 1,300 units which Concern built in Butare prefecture and 1,600 in Cyangugu prefecture are occupied.

Trials of Rwandans suspected of involvement in the 1994 genocide began on December 27 in Kibungo. There are 1,914 names on the category one list, which refers to defendants who are suspected of having planned, organized, instigated, supervised, or led the genocide or a crime against humanity. If found guilty, category one defendants face the death penalty. Eight defendants have been found guilty to date.

Burundi: Six months after neighboring countries imposed economic sanctions against Burundi, NGOs and U.N. agencies are encountering delays in importing essential goods, and their fuel reserves are nearly empty.

Much of the country remains insecure, due to ethnic tensions. Fighting is reported to be increasing in northern Kayanza province, thereby limiting NGOs' ability to deliver assistance. MSF Holland (MSF/H) announced on January 6 that it was suspending its operations because of insecurity. In the past two months, 12 confirmed mine explosions have destroyed military and civilian vehicles, UNDHA reports. Eight of the explosions occurred in Bujumbura Rural province. Burundi authorities accused Hutu rebels of killing 22 people in Rugombo, Cibitoke province, on January 13. UNHCR reports that as of January 6, about 64,000 Burundian returnees arrived from Zaire. Most returned directly to Cibitoke and Bubanza, both severely affected by the war.

In the past several weeks, about 250 people are suspected of having contracted cholera in communities near Rumonge, Bururi province, about 80 km southeast of the capital. Ten have died from the disease. The World Health Organization (WHO) is investigating the suspected outbreak. Also in Rumonge, Burundi state radio reported the deaths of at least 15 persons in attacks on January 18-19 by unidentified armed men.

The USAID/OFDA Emergency Disaster Relief Coordinator (EDRC) reported during a trip to Muyinga and Ngozi provinces on December 5-7 that much land was poorly tended and malnutrition rates had reportedly risen. Much of the rural population of Muyinga had left for Tanzania, residents said. Because of the low-level civil war, traditional life in the two provinces had given way to mono-ethnic communities which were not agriculturally self-sufficient. In contrast, the EDRC found traditional life relatively unchanged while visiting Ruyigi and Rutana provinces on December 14-17. In Ruyigi, many people appeared to have stayed to work the land, despite recent fighting.

Tanzania: The Government of Tanzania (GOT) announced on January 21 the formal end to its exercise to repatriate Rwanda refugees. The GOT is cleaning up the campsites, and has declared that those Rwandans who escaped from the Tanzanian camps instead of repatriating, and who are now hiding, would be considered illegal aliens. About 278,000 refugees, of whom 243,000 are Burundian, remain in Tanzania, the UNHCR reports. In the Ngara camps, there are 82,100 Burundians; in Kibondo, there are 96,813 refugees; in Kasulu, there are 89,702 Burundians and Zairians; in Kigoma town there are about 5, 000 refugees. UNHCR reported that 34,000 new refugees arrived in Tanzania from Zaire and Burundi in December.

Tanzanian security forces have identified 51 Rwandan intimidators and moved them to facilities in Mwiza, 10 km west of Kyaka, Karagwe district. The camp opened on December 20 with 51 refugees, all male except for a woman and her child. Most if not all are believed to have been heavily involved in the genocide. One has since voluntarily repatriated to Rwanda, leaving 50 at Mwiza, USAID reported.

Before the forced repatriation of the 122 Palipehutu Burundians, who were immediately massacred by the Burundian Army on January 10, internecine clashes had resulted in 10 deaths and the arrest of 200 refugees in late December. Of the 200, 118 were taken to Ngara and 48 of the them were turned over to Burundian authorities and reportedly killed.

USG Assistance

On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, report on the situation, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist with repatriation efforts. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda Robert Gribbin, declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire posed a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda. On November 12, U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire as a result of the violent break- up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire. On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region. On November 25, Ambassador Morris Hughes declared a disaster in Burundi as a result of continuing civil strife.

USAID FY 1997 Assistance (to date):

BHR/OFDA Assistance

To date, BHR/OFDA funding has been obligated as follows:

Grant to Action Aid for shelter in Kibuye - $774,700

Grant to AMREF for medical services - $212,129

Grant to ARC for water/sanitation/health - $3,094,857

Grant to CARE International for shelter/water/sanitation/food/non-food activities - $1,967,853

Grant to Christian Reformed World Relief Committee for seed

distribution - $854,645

Grant to Concern for food and non-food distribution - $1,546,611

Grant to CRS for food distribution - $328,846

Grant to Doctors of the World for medical services - $370,189

Grant to FHI for shelter and seeds - $1,941,054

Grant to ICRC for assistance to Rwandan refugees and displaced

persons in eastern Zaire - $5,000,000

Grant to IRC for water/sanitation/health - $1,149,835

Grant to Medecins du Monde for medical services in Byumba and

Gisenyi - $652,760

Grant to Mercy Corps International for shelter in urban Kigali - $1,475,794

Grant to SCF/UK for unaccompanied children - $468,612

Grant to World Relief International for shelter in urban Kigali - $624,295

Grant to WVRD for medical and food distribution - $858,704

Grant to UNDHA for information coordination - $151,178

Plastic sheeting, blankets for UNHCR - $778,000

Airlift of relief supplies to Rwanda for UNICEF - $90,000

Provision of health kits to GOR Ministry of Health - $252,309

Communications equipment for the GOR - $415,000

BHR/OFDA Assistance - $23,338,964

BHR/OTI Assistance BHR's Office of Transition Initiatives (BHR/OTI) has provided a total of $375,000 to the Women in Transition project and to fund visits by local reporters to the Tribunal in Arusha. BHR/OTI also funded experts to travel to Rwanda to conduct an evaluation of the genocide trials.

BHR/OTI Assistance -$408,000

BHR/FFP Assistance In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, Uganda, and Tanzania.

BHR/FFP Assistance - $72,500,000

Department of State/Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration (PRM) Assistance In FY 1997, PRM has obligated funding to the IRC for the Rwandan reintegration and rehabiliation program

State/PRM Assistance - $2,500,000

TOTAL USG FY 1997 HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE (to date) - $121,754,335
