467 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 25, 1997


Sudan;
An International Church Appeal for Sudan


BYLINE: Action by Churches Together(ACT)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Geneva - SUDAN EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (ERP) January - June 1997

AFSD71 -- Appeal Target: US$ 867,894

Disease, floods and drought conditions have exacerbated the serious conditions of the war-affected people of Sudan. The situation in the country has also been created and compounded by continuing economic and political factors. Here is a complex emergency that has largely been forgotten by the outside world but which continues to cause death, destruction and enormous suffering. Therefore emergency needs will continue in 1997 for a carefully targeted and programed response to reach out to the people of this land in crisis.

The fundamental causes of human suffering in the Sudan since 1983 have been civil war and drought. The war, which erupted in 1983 has claimed many lives, destroyed property, created massive displacement of people and diverted large amounts of money out of development. According to the United Nations Humanitarian Coordination Unit (UNHCU), an estimated 2.5 million Sudanese are internally displaced, including 1.8 million in Khartoum, 350,000 in the transition zone (southern Darfur, southern Kordofan, northern Bahr el Ghazal and the northern Upper Nile States) and government-held garrison towns, 150, 000 in camps in Equatoria and additional tens of thousands elsewhere. In addition, Sudanese continue to flee from southern Sudan because of insecurity and civil strife. Currently, there are an estimated 399,500 Sudanese refugees in neighbouring countries. 

Attempts to resolve the current war peacefully have been unsuccessful. And though the theatre of this civil war is mainly in the south, its effects are seriously felt throughout the country. In the north the effects of war has paralysed the economy, weakened basic infrastructures and claimed the lives of many youths conscripted into the army to fight what is claimed as a *holy war' against the southerners. Moreover, the north, and particularly Khartoum, is host to a massive number of internally displaced people and refugees. In the south, the fragmentation of political factions and the subsequent intra- factional feuds have only compounded the situation of this war-torn society. Ongoing insecurity and population displacement in the south and the transition zones have not only interrupted or destroyed most of the indigenous trading and productive systems, but have also been a major impediment to relief efforts. And against this backdrop, the civil war continues with the people being subjected to aerial bombings, conflict on the ground and forced relocations due to the fighting.

The recent Food and Agriculture Organization/World Food Program (FAO/WFP) Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission to Sudan and our own Network conclude that, in view of the economic situation which continues to create instability in the north and the prevailing civil strife and insecurity in the South, food aid assistance will still be necessary for the following categories of displaced persons and other affected people in 1997:

Internally displaced camps and villages within their own communities

Drought and flood victims

Other vulnerable groups

ACTion

For some time it was proposed to carry out an evaluation of the Sudan Council of Churches Emergency Response Program. This wasachieved in October/November 1996, prior to the Round Table. The Terms of Reference of the evaluation team were: to describe and analyze the current structure and functioning of the ERP; to evaluate ERP's efficiency and effectiveness in reaching its objectives; to identify internal and external constraints and describe how ERP is dealing with these constraints; to give recommendations on how SCC can improve ERP's future performance; and, to evaluate the role of humanitarian assistance in the context of the Sudan.

After thorough evaluation of the ERP program, several conclusions were reached and recommendations were made (copies of the detailed report are available at the ACT Coordinating Office). It was proposed that while the recommendations were being implemented during the first six months of 1997, an interim budget, addressing solely the emergency needs within the ERP program, should be elaborated.

The SCC has therefore developed a proposal that will a) implement the recommendations of the ERP evaluation and b) focus the emergency response in the Northern Region (Khartoum and Kosti), Equatoria (Juba), Upper Nile (Malakal, Wadakona and Bentiu), Western Region (El Obeid, Kadugli, Abyei and Meiram), Bahr el Ghazal (Wau, Raga and Aweil), Blue Nile Region (Damazin) and Eastern Sudan (Gaderef), to reach 172,028 beneficiaries as follows:

Vulnerable groups - 92,499 persons

Supplementary Feeding - 21,417 persons

School Feeding - 29,323 persons

Emergency Relief - 28,789 persons

Relief Distribution to the target groups - the vulnerable, supplementary feeding, school feeding and emergency relief - will be preceded by a needs assessment. The needs assessment teams in each program area will be composed of SCC/ERP staff, Inter-church Committee (ICC) members, beneficiary representatives, representatives of Local Relief Committees and SCC Nutritionists. Each team will compile a register of those who are assessed as being critically insecure in food and nutritionally vulnerable. The actual distribution of relief food to the registered beneficiaries will be preceded by the distribution of ration cards in order to avoid duplication or misuse. The teams will monitor the distribution of food up to end use.

This appeal focuses on the acute survival needs of the above mentioned categories. In the *Vulnerable' target group, ACT/SCC will provide cereals, pulses and edible oil to a total number of 92,499 pregnant women, lactating mothers, the elderly, handicapped, orphans and widows over a period of 90 days. The supplementary feeding program will assist 21,417 children under the age of five for 180 days. They will receive rations comprising cereals, pulses, oil, sugar, dried skimmed milk (DSM) and biscuits.

Schools run by member churches will receive cereals pulses and oil to provide food for 29,323 school children for a period of 168 days. Emergency relief for 28,789 new arrivals and the destitute who have been affected by drought and floods will receive rations of cereals, pulses and oil for 90 days.

In order to enhance the capacity of the Emergency Response Program staff and the churches involved in the ERP program, regional workshops will be held in Eastern/Blue Nile, Bahr el Ghazal, Northern Region, Equatoria and Western Region. These workshops will focus on all aspects of relief management. Moreover, the ERP national staff will undertake visits to program areas on a regular basis to provide technical support, assess the performance of the program and review human resources.

The overall budget has been calculated at a total amount of $1,489,544 for this six-month period. However, after taking into account anticipated remittances from donors for funds to cover inland transport/storage/handling costs of stocks currently in the pipeline and an outstanding pledge, the amount being sought from ACT Partners in this appeal stands at $867,894.

Implementing Partner: Sudan Council of Churches (SCC)

BUDGET: $867,894. NOTE: Full details of the budget are available from the ACT Co-ordinating Office upon request.

Program Duration: January - June 1997

Please kindly send your contributions to the ACT bank account.

For further information, please contact: ACT Co-ordinator, Miriam Lutz (phone ++41 22 791 6032 or mobile phone ++ 41 89 203 6055) or ACT Appeals Consultant, Geof May (phone +41 22 791 60 36)

We thank you in advance for your support.

Rev. Myra Blyth, Miriam Lutz, Rev. Rudolf Hinz

Action by Churches Together(ACT) is a worldwide network of Churches and their related agencies meeting human need through co-ordinated emergency response and common identity. Ecumenical Centre, 150, route de Ferney, P.O. Box 2100, 1211 Geneva 2, Switzerland. Phone: ++41-22-791.60.33 / Fax: ++41-22- 791.65.06 / E-mail: act@wcc-coe.org / Telex: 415 730 OIK CH.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


468 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
College To Commence Distance Education Training


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Addis Ababa Commercial college yesterday said it would soon commence a distance education training programme in five regional states in a bid to upgrade the management skills and techniques of workers in regional offices, government agencies as well as in development and private organizations.

Ato Kumlachew Abera, dean of the college and head of the Ethiopian Development Project Office told ENA that the management education programme organized in collaboration with the Open University business School of UK part of the federal government's effort geared toward alleviating shortage of skilled manpower. 

The first intake of students for the professional certificate in management programme is estimated at 6000 to be recruited from Tigray, Amhara, Oromiya, Addis Ababa and Southern Ethiopia regional states, he said. There will also be an entrance exam and fee for the training programme to start after two months, he added.

According to Ato Kumlachew the programme will cover the remaining regions in the coming three years and operate nation-wide. he said the programme is to be launched in higher educational institutions of the stated regional states.

The Makalle business College, Bahir Dar Teachers college and Poly-Technic Institute, the Nazareth Technical College, the Jima and Awassa colleges of Agriculture and the Addis Ababa commercial College are the institutions where the training programme is to be conducted, he said.

The project office has a plan to train more than 2,000 workers in the coming three year, he added.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


469 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court Sentences Hijackers to Prison


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Federal High Court yesterday sentenced to ten years regorous imprisonment two persons who tried to take by force to Djibouti the Ethiopian airliner Boeing 737 after incapacitating the passengers and the pilots.

The Second criminal Bench of the Federal High Court passed the verdict on Wednesday on Lemma Hunde Kissis and Lieutenant Gubenti Binegdi Tolossa for attempting to force the plane bound to Addis Ababa to fly to Djibouti on 26 July 1985 E.C.

The verdict says the convicts are to serve the ten years term as of the day they were apprehended.

The individuals, armed with hand grenade and an automatic dagger part of their preparation to commit the unlawful act left here for Dire Dawa on July 20, 1985 E.C., according to charges filed by the prosecution against them. 

The convicts were apprehended while trying to force the airliner to fly to Djibouti using the aforementioned weapons at 9 a.m. on 26 July 1985 E.C. it added.

The defendants, it said were accused of holding unlicensed arms to carryout the unlawful act agreeing both in the thought and deed as well as the repercussions.

The prosecution has asked the court to pass a verdict commensurate to such a criminal act condemned at the international level as it posses a threat to the life of passengers.

The first defendant had asked the court to sent him free consideration his age, and the time he has spend in prison where he has learnt the duty of a citizen to abide by the law.

The crimes, the convicts were found to have committed are punishable by life or death depending on the seriousness of the damage inflicted.

The court has passed the verdict having taken into consideration the innocence of the culprits prior to their illegal act and the aversion of the attempt before causing any damage.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


470 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
Workers say reestablishing CETU indispensable


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemmeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Following the break up on the Confederation of the Ethiopian Trade Union(CETU) it has totally been impossible to protect Ethiopian workers' rights, benefits and their common property, according to Ato Gebremeskel Argaw, Chief Secretary of the Industrial Federation of Textile, Leather and Garment Workers Trade Unions.

"It is quite difficult to restore and protect the rights and benefits and to guarantee jobs for workers without a well established and capable national confederation," Ato Geberemeskel reiterated.

Addressing the meeting of Addis Ababa Leather Factory workers held yesterday at the premises of Tikur Abay Shoes Factory, Ato Gebremeskel said the main objective of the meeting was to discuss issues related to the activities of an properties that belong to federations and the reformation of the CETU. 

According to him over 50 vehicles all property of the former conf. were damaged while hotels in different regions were being used by individuals due to absence of management, moreover, 450 employees of the same confederation are being paid 65,000 birr monthly salary out of the treasury of the non- existent confederation without rendering any service on the part of the former, he added.

Ato Geberemeskel, noted that to settle these and bring other problems of the workers to the attention of the central government for their resolution, the reformation of the CETU and the active participation of the workers to that effect was indispensable. Ato Shenkute Abate., Chairman of the Labour Union of Addis Ababa Leather Factory expressed satisfaction that the workers after intensive discussion on the issues have unanimously supported the immediate reestablishment of the CETU. The Workers also vowed to support the 16-member committee which was earlier formed to activate the reformation of the Confederation, Ato Gebremeskel confirmed.

The Addis Ababa Leather Factory which is over 70-years-old has 348 workers(268 male and 80 female), it was learned.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


471 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
Diplomats urged to gather business information


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - A senior official of the Ethiopian Government yesterday reminded missions abroad to gather business information and assess markets as the country is currently capable of supplying the world market with its agricultural products.

Speaking at a meeting of the Ethiopian ambassadors discussing the foreign policy of the country, Ato Kassahun Ayale, Minister of Trade and Industry said Ethiopian diplomats are expected to forge contacts between importers and exporters as agricultural production is likely to further increase next Ethiopian year. 

He said, Ethiopian diplomats are also expected to pass on business information to concerned offices with a view to facilitate the country's trade activities.

Besides the increase in agricultural productivity, exportation of industrial products particularly that of textile and leather outputs was thriving, the minister said.

He said his office has drafted a policy enabling coffee producers raise the quality and quantity of the item.

Ethiopian embassies in Kenya, Djibouti and Eritrea had played significant role in providing business information and making contacts with clients since the country had started exporting maize, he said, urging missions in other countries to follow suit.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


472 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Ethiopia;
House endorsed two proclamations


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday approved proclamations providing for the establishment of the Federal Inland Revenue authority and the ratification of the loan agreement between Ethiopia and the International Fund of Agricultural Development.

The 25th regular meeting of the House has approved the two proclamations following discussions and amendments on various provisions. 

As stipulated in the proclamation for the establishment of the Federal Inland Revenue Administration, the authority will be responsible to enforce and implement tax laws, regulations and directives.

The authority will assess, collect and execute taxes specifically categorized by law for collection by the federal government.

Another major objective of the authority is undertaking studies necessary for the initiation and amendment of tax law, regulations and directives, according to the proclamation.

The proclamation providing for the ratification of the lean agreement between Ethiopia and the International fund for Agricultural Development stipulates that the loan amounting to 6.6 million US dollars will be used for partially financing the national seed project. The agreement was signed in Rome on October 11, 1996.

The non-interest loan with 0.75 per cent service charge per annum is paid within four decades the first decade being a grace period.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


473 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Science and Health;
Climatic Changes Threaten Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

KADOMA, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Projected diminishing rains in sub-Sahara Africa will likely harm man, the ecology, reduce food production and shut down dams, a Zimbabwean government official has said.

"By 2025 it is estimated that all the major river basins in Africa, other than the Congo, will be water scarce," Todd Ngara said.

He was making a presentation on climate change at an environment workshop in Kadoma, about 150 kilometers south-west of Harare. 

Ngara, who heads the Climatic Change Department in the Ministry of Environment and Tourism, said Hydro-electric projects in many countries like Ghana, Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe were at risk of collapsing because of the climatic changes which brought recurrent droughts.

The major source of electricity in Zimbabwe, Lake Kariba is at its lowest level ever, threatening the generation of electricity serving the country and Zambia.

More vector-borne diseases would affect people, he said, because of the changes.

He said atmospheric concentrations of green house gases, which are responsible for the climatic changes, were increasing rapidly due to the continued use of fossil fuels, changes in land use and agricultural practices.

"Energy generation from fossil fuels like petrol, diesel and jet fuel are a source of high carbon content in the atmosphere," he said.

Cement and fertilizer factories are a source of the poisonous nitrogen and carbon dioxides in the air.

The felling of trees and burning of forests for agriculture has also contributed to carbon dioxide in the air, while resettlement of landless people has contributed to the clearing of indigenous woodlands, which are a source of fresh air.

"However, (Zimbabwe) government is encouraging afforestation so as to achieve a zero net of green house gas emissions to balance between depletion and regeneration," he said.

The workshop, which ended Thursday, was organized by the Ministry of Environment and Tourism. It was in preparation for the production of the State of the Environment Report in 1998.

At least 70 participants attended. They were drawn from various government departments, non-governmental bodies, scientific and research organizations.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


474 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Mozambique - Uganda;
Chissano Launches Museveni's Autobiography


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique has launched an autobiography of his Ugandan counterpart, Yoweri Museveni, entitled "Sowing the Mustard Seed: The Struggle for Democracy in Uganda".

The book's launch Sunday in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, was among highlights of the events marking the 11th anniversary of the seizure of state power by Museveni and his National Resistance Army guerilla fighters, on Jan. 26, 1986. Speaking at a commemorative state banquet the same day, Chissano, who was the anniversary's chief guest, called for greater cooperation between Mozambique and Uganda. "We must identify further areas of cooperation, able to give great dynamism to our desire for the economic development and the well-being of our peoples," Chissano said. 

Reporting this, the Mozambique news agency, AIM, said Chissano challenged both governments "to encourage our citizens, our businessmen and our governmental institutions to come together and develop a greater interest in promoting areas of cooperation for the common good."

In his banquet speech Museveni said Uganda, which registered a 3 percent inflation rate in 1996, could transmit to Mozambique its achievements in " macro-economic stabilization."

Uganda is regarded as one of the few African states which has implemented successful economic structural adjustment programmes.

Earlier at the peak of the anniversary, Museveni decorated Chissano with the Ugandan Order, the Jewel of Africa First Class. This was in recognition of what Kampala said were Chissano's efforts "to make Mozambique free, and his exemplary leadership and service to the Mozambican people."

In his commemorative address, Museveni said that even as FRELIMO, the Mozambican liberation front, fought its own war against Portuguese colonial rule, it helped train Ugandan guerrilla fighters for the struggle against the tyranny of Idi Amin, who was ousted in April 1979.

Museveni recalled that he first met Chissano in 1968 in the Tanzanian capital, when Chissano was head of FRELIMO's security department. Museveni was a student at the University of Dar Es Salaam.

Chissano eventually arranged Museveni's involvement in the Mozambican liberation struggle, which culminated in the country's independence from Portugal, on June 25, 1975.

After winning independence, FRELIMO remained committed to the fight by Ugandans to overthrow Amin, who had seized power in a January 1971 coup.

A Mozambican military unit fought alongside the Tanzanian army all the way to Kampala, after Amin's costly mistake of invading a portion of Tanzanian territory in the last quarter of 1978.

Accepting the award, Chissano also recalled the military cooperation between FRELIMO and Museveni's guerrilla army.

"While we Mozambicans were waging the struggle against colonial rule, our Ugandan brothers were fighting against the Idi Amin dictatorship.

"These were two realities in two different scenarios but what they had in common was the struggle for the freedom and dignity of our peoples," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


475 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Kenya;
Kenyan Opposition Party Re-elects Wamalwa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - A Kenyan opposition party, Ford-Kenya, has re- elected its chairman, Michael Kijana Wamalwa, and confirmed him as its candidate to challenge incumbent President Daniel Arap Moi in presidential polls to be held later in the year.

He was elected by the 2,463 delegates to the party's congress, which took place Sunday in Nairobi. This followed the departure of his main rival, Raila Oginga, son of the late Jaramogi Odinga Oginga, Kenya's fiery opposition leader.

Raila has now joined a little known opposition group, the National Development of Kenya.

In the past two years, Ford-Kenya has been dogged by violence, wrangling and court battles between Wamalwa and Raila which seriously undermined the opposition's credibility.

Shortly after his re-election, Wamalwa was mandated by the congress to enter into any workable alliances with other opposition parties to ensure the opposition captured the presidency from Moi, who won the country's first multiparty polls in 1992.

He said his first task was to rid the party of greedy officials and opportunists.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


476 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigeria Fires National Soccer Coach


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian Football Association announced Monday that it had sacked the national soccer coach, Shuaibu Amodu for what it termed as "gross misconduct."

Amodu's dismissal came just hours after the association's chairman, Abdulmumini Aminu, told PANA that Amodu was on an indefinite suspension.

"The reason should be clear to every Nigerian," Aminu told PANA in Lagos. 

He was referring to Amodu's recent press statements criticizing the association and the minister of sports, Jim Nwobodo, on their recent decision to hire a foreign technical adviser for the national team.

In a statement, the association's secretary, Sani Toro, said Amodu was fired because he breached his contract agreement by granting unauthorized press interviews.

Despite "several warnings," Toro said, Amodu granted an interview to a national newspaper in which he made "embarrassing remarks on the activities of the association as well as the person of the sports minister."

Aminu said that Amodu's absence would not affect the national team's programme, especially the planned qualification for the 1998 World Cup final in France.

"We are going ahead with the plan to hire a foreign technical adviser, but we must take our time to avoid mistakes of the past," Aminu said.

The appointment, he added, would be made in time for Nigeria's crucial World Cup qualification match against Guinea in early April.

Nigerians have expressed dismay at the disappointing results of the country's national teams at all levels, coming after the nation's Olympic soccer victory in Atlanta, in 1996.

The nation's Under-17 and Under-20 squads have been tossed out of current international competitions, while the senior team, returned a disappointing 1- 1 draw two weeks ago against lowly rated Kenya in an Africa zone qualification match for the World Cup.

Amodu could not be reached for a reaction to his sacking. But he had often told critics he could deliver the goods if given the level of encouragement and support, often lavished on foreign coaches hired by the country.

Amodu's wife also joined the fray, saying in a recent press interview that Nigeria should not only hire a foreign technical adviser but also appoint a foreigner as sports minister.

Amodu, former coach of Nigeria's BCC Lions, was appointed national coach after the unceremonious exit of former Dutch technical adviser, Clemens Westerhof, who led Nigeria to its first World Cup appearance in U.S.A.'94.

Amodu had been asked to coach the national team after Westerhof's compatriot and successor, Johannes Bonfrere, ditched Nigeria for the Gulf state of Qatar, in September 1996.

Bonfrere, who took Nigeria's Under-23 team to win the Olympic soccer gold in Atlanta, turned his back on the country mid-way into a two-year contract, alleging mistreatment by some of the country's football association officials.

The association has reported him to the world's soccer governing body, FIFA, for alleged breach of contract.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


477 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 27, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe Stockmarket Starts Week Firmer


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The Zimbabwe Stock Exchange started the week active and firmer Monday with the Industrial Index putting on 61.22 points to close at 1,0174.02.

A reasonable volume of shares trading in stationery producer, Art, remained unchanged at 12 cents (One U.S. dollar = 10 Zimdollars) while Meikles, in reasonable turnover, put on 15 cents as did Hunyani Warrants at 2,015 and 165 respectively. Tobacco trading company, TSL, in reasonable turnover, edged up 25 cents to trade at 800 and banking giants Barclays, also in reasonable turnover, gained 100 cents to trade at 3,500.

Cigarette manufacturer Rothmans and food processor Cairns had the largest gains at 200 and 250 cents to trade at 6,200 and 1,900 respectively. The discount house, DCZ, in reasonable turnover, lost 5 cents to trade at 240.

Battery manufacturer Chloride shed 10 cents to trade at 130 while the cable manufacturer, Bicaf, dropped 20 cents to 400. Cigarette maker, Bat, closed 200 down at 2,100.

Other counters to trade were largely unchanged.

In minings, trading was quiet with gold producers Ashanti trading unchanged at 9,000 while Bindura gained 10 cents to 860 points. The coal producer, Wankie, lost 256 cents to 450.

The index continued weak with a loss of 5.93 points to close at 1,048.56.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


483 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


United States and Africa;
Consolidated Great Lakes Report No. 10 (1/18- 24)


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3576 words


 

Washington DC - GREAT LAKES GENERAL: Mohamed Sahnoun, an Algerian diplomat who once headed UN operations in Somalia, will be named as special representative for both the United Nations and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) for the Great Lakes region of Central Africa. (IRIN Emergency Update *84, 1/22/97)

* According to sources in the Zambian government and the local UNHCR office about 600 refugees have entered Zambia since October, 1996. Most are refugees who were forced to leave Tanzania...Local refugee officials are increasingly concerned, however, about the prospect of a major refugee influx from Shaba province or other areas of Zaire...Any serious refugee movement would quickly outstrip available resources and require significant donor intervention. (Lusaka 470, 1/21/97) 

* MSF and UNICEF told the VOA on January 14 that "the camp at Tingi-Tingi is controlled by former Rwandan officials of ethnic Hutu origin and armed Hutu militias." On January 20 UNHCR pulled out of a Kurdish refugee camp in northern Iraq because control of the CAM had been lost to guerillas, who are believed to hold the rest of the camp population hostage. The same logic should apply in Tingi-Tingi...The best way we can help is to stop feeding the killers, who will then run away to look for other sustenance, leaving their hostages behind. If we do not we will be trading the children in Tingi-Tingi against the children who will be killed and orphaned in Rwanda. (Kigali 283, 1/21/97)

REPATRIATION TO RWANDA:

* The flow of Rwandan refugees returning to Rwanda via Bukavu continues at a slow pace. The UNHCR office in Cyangugu reported the following numbers of Rwandan refugees crossing the border at Ruzizi I and II crossing points: on January 13 - 2005; January 12 - 1085; January 11 - 1530; January 10 - 1623; January 9 - 1963; January 8 - 1988; January 7 - 1661; and January 6 - 876. (Kigali 342, USAID/DART Field Sitrep *36, 1/23/97)

* The Government of Rwanda (GOR) has put into effect a 2100 hours curfew for the majority of the Cyangugu area and a 2000 hours curfew for the area around the Cyangugu airport. The GOR continues to press for a quick transit of returnees through the transit centers onto their homes. Exceptions are made only for returnees with severe health problems. (Kigali 342, USAID/DART Field Sitrep *36, 1/23/97)

* Thousands of refugees, thought to be emerging from the forests of eastern Zaire, have been crossing into southwest Rwanda from Bukavu. The ICRC said since January 8 nearly 2,000 people a day had been crossing the border, arriving around the town of Kamembe. UNHCR said a total of 30,000 returnees had arrived as of January 22, malnourished and generally in very poor shape. (IRIN Emergency Update *85, 1/23/97)

ATTACK ON AID WORKERS IN RWANDA:

* Three Spanish aid workers belonging to the non-governmental organization Medicos del Mundo have died in Rwanda after an attack carried out by an armed group on its humanitarian compound in Ruhengeri (northwestern Rwanda)...an American aid worker was very seriously injured; he later had to have one leg amputated. (Courtesy FBIS, 1/19/97)

* The U.N. refused to suspend activities in any part of Rwanda after three Spanish aid workers were murdered and an American badly wounded in an attack in a northwestern town at the weekend. (Associated Press, 1/20/97)

* The murderers of the three Spanish aid workers killed in Rwanda (on 19th January) have been identified...They are three Hutu soldiers from the former Rwandan Army, assisted by a local security guard who allowed them access to the enclosure where the three Medicos del Mundo workers were. (Courtesy FBIS, 1/21/97)

* The Union for the Return of the Refugees and Democracy to Rwanda (RDR) issued a statement today blaming recent attacks on humanitarian organizations in Rwanda on the regime there...As evidence of prior Kigali regime animosity towards some humanitarian organizations, the communique claims some were expelled from Rwanda at the beginning of 1996 for opposing human rights violations,...that the RPF hates Spanish humanitarian organizations for refusing to abandon the refugees, and says Spanish Caritas workers were killed by the RPA in Nyamirangwe and Mudaka camps in South Kivu last fall. (Kinshasa 430, 1/22/97)

* We have obtained a copy of the latest communique from the People in Arms to Liberate Rwanda (PALIR).

Begin embassy translation: The Internal Resistance Front (FRI) of PALIR makes the following announcement: .. The objectives of the FRI combatants are strictly military and target only positions of the army of occupation. At the same time, the FRI declines all responsibility for injuries which may be sustained by those who work and live with the soldiers of the army of occupation. It is therefore astonishing to remark that expatriates calling themselves humanitarians live with the army of occupation, ...where they are used as human shields...Since PALIR is determined to track down every soldier of the army of occupation wherever he may be, we can only counsel expatriates to keep their distance...(Kigali 330, 1/23/97)

* At least two suspects arrested in connection with the slayings of three Spanish aid workers have died in the custody, diplomats said today...State- run radio reported that one of the suspects had confessed to helping plan a robbery that turned violent. (Associated Press, 1/23/97)

* Troops killed more than 50 civilians in Rwanda in a crackdown this week triggered by the slaying of three Spanish aid workers...Rwandan Vice- President Maj.-Gen. Paul Kagame in Kigali told the British Broadcasting Corporation 80 people were killed in army search operations in Ruhengeri prefecture in the northwest and any civilians among them had been caught in crossfire. (Reuters, 1/23/97)

SITUATION IN RWANDA:

* Unidentified gunmen killed at least 24 Rwandans on an unarmed civilian night patrol in northern Rwanda, state-run radio said today. The attack Monday took place in northwestern Ruhengari prefecture, 60 miles northwest of the capital, Kigali. (Associated Press, 1/22/97)

* Kigali's recent reporting on refugee reintegration issues was sparked by a specific tasking from Washington: what is the Government of Rwanda's reaction to the UNHCR reintegration plan? It turned out that the "plan" was a fund-raising tool sent only to donors...Goodwill prevails despite the coordination problems, which are to be expected when there are so many organizations involved in doing the same work...The coordination problems here are not the fault of the individuals at the various IOs and NGOs, but of their respective headquarters which sent them out on overlapping mandates. (Kigali 281, 1/21/97)

* As of January 1, UNHCR is phasing down all activities related to the repatriation movement: transit centers will either will be closed down or used for other purposes; the distribution of repatriation packages will be completed by the end of March 1997 (Geneva 368, 1/22/97)

* NGO health experts assisting returnees at the Nyagatare camp told field officer that the worst health cases -- both mentally and physically -- were the unaccompanied children, particularly those under five years of age. (Kigali 342, USAID/DART Field Sitrep *36, 1/23/97)

Schools * Rwanda seeks $18 million on an urgent basis to rehabilitate its primary and secondary school systems...Now, 677 classrooms need repairs and 1490 new classrooms are needed to cope with population growth and the 200,000 school kids who just returned...Schools and educational opportunities are densely intertwined with Rwanda's prospects for reconciliation. Implementation of justice will see to the past, but education is the hope for the future. (Kigali 365, 1/24/97)

GENOCIDE TRIALS:

* A special court in Rwanda has sentenced two more men to death for genocide, bringing the number of capital sentences so far to at least eight. (Reuters, 1/22/97)

* Col. Theoneste Bagasora has been safely transferred to Arusha, Tanzania, where he is being detained until his trial before the tribunal. Three other defendants were transferred from Yaounde to Arusha as well: Andre Ntagerura, Ferdinand Nahimana, and Anatole Nsengiyumva. According to the indictment issued by the International Criminal Tribunal, Col. Bagasora was one of the main planners and leaders of the 1994 Rwandan genocide. (State 013437, 1/24/97)

* Rwandan radio yesterday reported that two genocide suspects had committed suicide in Gisenyi prison. It named the two as ex-FAR soldiers Lt.Col Nzabanita and Lt.Innocent Nsabimana. (IRIN Emergency Update *86, 1/24/97)

SITUATION IN ZAIRE:

* Zaire formally declared war on Tutsi-backed rebels Monday, announcing a massive counteroffensive to recover territory along its eastern border. (Associated Press, 1/20/97)

* The Zairian government claimed Thursday to have retaken the eastern town of Walikale, which never was confirmed to be in rebel hands. (Associated Press, 1/24/97)

* There is agreement among Geneva-based humanitarian agencies that there are three large concentrations of mostly Rwandan refugees stranded in eastern Zaire. Tingi Tingi has an estimated 120,000 Rwandan refugees, Amisi has an additional 40,000, while Shabunda has an estimated 40,000, which includes a small portion of Burundi refugees. (Geneva 296, 1/17/97)

* The French-based Doctors Without Borders reported 105 cholera cases. It said 526 refugees have died at Tingi-Tingi, 287 of them under the age of 5. (Associated Press, 1/21/97)

* The court-martial in the field in Kisangani sentenced 14 soldiers to death for cowardliness on Tuesday.(Courtesy FBIS, 1/22/97)

* Some 280 European soldiers of fortune have gathered in east Zaire under the command of a veteran Belgian mercenary to help Kinshasa's counter- offensive against rebels, according to a French daily. (Reuters, 1/24/97)

* Hundreds of thousands of refugees and displaced people trapped in eastern Zaire will be the worst-affected victims of a Zairean counter-offensive, coupled with reduced relief operations. Humanitarian operations are being seriously hampered by the Zairean government's decision not to issue "sauf- conduit" permits ... UNICEF said a total of 88 people, 47 of them children under five, had died in Tingi-Tingi between 15 and 19 January, mostly from malnutrition, malaria and diarrhoea. It reported 5,907 unaccompanied children in Tingi-Tingi, and 1,500 in Amisi. (IRIN Emergency Update *86, 1/24/97)

SITUATION IN BURUNDI:

* Continuing economic sanctions against Burundi are rendering relief operations virtually impossible, with one of the greatest difficulties being the refusal of the Regional Sanctions Coordinating Committee (RSCC) to acknowledge requests from humanitarian agencies for the exemption of more fuel supplies. (IRIN Emergency Update *81, 1/17/97)

* Armed attackers set fire to two houses and ambushed two minibuses over the weekend, killing at least 15 people in southern Burundi, state-run Burundi radio reported today. (Associated Press, 1/20/97)

* The recent cholera outbreak which occurred in Rumonge, in the south of the country bordering Lake Tanganyika, is continuing and up to 13 January a total of 482 cases with 21 deaths have been reported. (WHO, Courtesy ReliefWeb, 1/17/97)

SITUATION IN TANZANIA:

* Nearly 22,000 Burundian refugees have fled their violence-hit country for neighbouring Tanzania so far this month and the pace of their exodus is picking up, the United Nations refugee agency UNHCR said on Tuesday. (Reuters, 1/21/97)

* Police recovered the bodies of at least 14 Burundians buried near a refugee camp in northwestern Tanzania, a government-owned newspaper reported Wednesday...authorities in Ngara believe the victims had been buried alive. (Associated Press, 1/22/97) APPENDIX ACRONYMS:

(Note: U.S. Government cables are denoted by a capital city name followed by a number. Ex: KIGALI 4831. The Consolidated Great Lakes report is a compilation of information from the following sources: USG cables; U.N., IO, and NGO situation reports; press clips; and USG departments, bureaus, and offices. The date and source of each entry are noted, but the information should be checked against source materials. Information is reported as of the date of the source; however, conflicting information may appear within the consolidated report due to rapidly changing events in the region.)

484 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 87 on the Great Lakes (01/25-27)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

Nairobi - Well-placed sources informed IRIN today that there has been intensive fighting around Walikale, including fixed-wing aircraft bombing raids. The sources indicated that the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) were still putting up resistance to the Zairean counter-offensive, and that the effect of bombing raids on the forested area was minimal.

Many inhabitants of Walikale town have reportedly fled to the surrounding areas.

The ADFL strenuously denied that Walikale had fallen to government troops. Two reports in quick succession, broadcast by rebel radio (monitored by the BBC) on 24 and 25 January, accused the government of "psychological warfare". The commander of the rebel Armed Forces for the Protection of the Congolese People, a little-known ally of the ADFL, Col Francois Kipulu Waluwalu, asserted that Walikale was still under rebel control and claimed Zairean forces had lost 3,000 men since the war began. On 24 January, the radio said the government was "engaged in a war of nerves through a media campaign". Rebel radio also reports fighting at the Oso river bridge between Walikale and Lubutu. 

Mystery surrounded the whereabouts of rebel commander Andre Ngandu Kissasse, described by Col. Waluwalu earlier this month as "equivalent to 21 Zairean generals". Sources in eastern Zaire reported that Kissasse had been evacuated to Kampala along with Kisase, who according to rebel radio reports, had been wounded. Some reports say that Kisase had died in the Ugandan capital.

According to Belgian daily Le Soir, a Belgian mercenary, Christian Taverniers, has admitted leading a force of 280 soldiers of fortune, equipped with combat helicopters in eastern Zaire. France continued to deny military involvement in Zaire and a foreign ministry spokesman contended that any French mercenary in Zaire was operating on a private basis and had no connection with French policy. AFP reported that some Zairean press reports accused the western media of "hypocrisy" by highlighting the fact that Zaire was using mercenaries while ignoring the alleged use of Rwandan, Burundian and Ugandan troops by the rebels.

Zaire meanwhile again rejected holding any dialogue with the rebels and a statement broadcast on national radio Saturday following a cabinet meeting, reaffirmed Kinshasa's resolve to recapture all territory under rebel control. The statement also again accused Rwanda and Uganda of aiding the rebels. Regional analysts point out that should the rebels start losing ground to government forces, it may be unlikely that Rwanda and Uganda will stand by and watch.

Aid agencies continue to experience logistical problems in the refugee camps around Lubutu and Shabunda. WFP reported that some 550 families from Kaseke/Shabunda arrived in Tingi Tingi on 17 January, and refugee groups were still arriving in Shabunda from Katshungu. About 150 cases of diarrhoea are being diagnosed every day in Tingi Tingi, some of which are reported to be cholera cases. Humanitarian agencies are still being denied road access from Bukavu to Shabunda, and access to northern areas from Bukavu is restricted to 115km along the Bunyakiri road. Lack of access to affected populations and insecurity have been identified by UN agencies as the key operational problems in eastern Zaire at present.

In Shabunda, refugees are spontaneously settled at three locations on the left bank of the Ulindi river, while displaced Zaireans are said to be living in poor conditions among the local population. Between 13-19 January, 12,855 people repatriated from Bukavu - an increase of almost 30 percent compared to the previous week, WFP said. However, further north in Goma, the rhythm of repatriation appeared to have been slowed down by general insecurity. In the same week, a total of 864 refugees repatriated, signifying a decrease of 43 percent compared to the previous week.

WFP also reported that the first overland consignment of food from Zambia (200 tonnes) arrived in Kisangani today. Another 250 tonnes are on the way. The food travelled 2,000 km by train, truck, barge and ferry.

Referring to the appointment of a UN special representative for the Great Lakes, Zairean Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda stressed his government wanted domestic issues, such as the democratisation process and elections, treated separately from Great Lakes issues. Zaire, therefore, had told the UN Secretary-General it wanted separate envoys to tackle the two issues. Kamanda wa Kamanda was in New York last week and was due to meet the prospective UN/OAU special envoy for the Great Lakes, Mohammed Sahnoun.

* Residents and bar owners in Bujumbura have hailed an announcement to ease the curfew in the Burundi capital. In an apparent indication of reduced tension in Bujumbura, national radio on Saturday said the curfew had been relaxed by two hours and would now begin at midnight local time. The measure coincides with a national debate which kicks off in Burundi tomorrow. Speaking on Gabonese Africa No.1 radio, a government spokesman said the debate "excludes no-one", although the authorities have said that groups, such as the banned National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD), must renounce violence before they can participate. According to the radio, the main opposition party FRODEBU and three other parties grouped under the Forces for Democratic Change have refused to take part in the debate.

Rwandan radio meanwhile reported yesterday that a FRODEBU delegation, led by its chairman Jean Minani, had just paid a visit to Rwanda and held talks with President Bizimungu and Vice-President Kagame, during which they discussed the economic embargo against Burundi. They agreed that solutions could not be found through fighting. Minani said FRODEBU would also be visiting other countries of the region such as Uganda and Kenya, noting this did not mean mediator Julius Nyerere had been bypassed, only that the Burundi issue was of concern to all countries who imposed the embargo.

Nyerere himself, in an address to mark the 25th anniversary of the International Peace Academy in New York, acknowledged that peace efforts in Burundi had been largely unsuccessful. He argued that ethnicity was not a sufficient explanation for the conflict as ethnic groups had previously lived side by side and intermarried. He said he believed the root of the conflict lay in economics. "The fight for power is mainly a fight for economic resources. Ethnicity is simply being exploited," he claimed.

The authorities in Burundi have denied allegations that troops massacred 400 civilians in the province of Muramvya earlier this month. Army spokesman Isaie Nibizi described the reports, which quoted alleged eyewitnesses, as " absolutely and completely false". On January 5, the eyewitnesses said, soldiers and displaced Tutsis allegedly shot or hacked to death the civilians in Bukeye commune. "Nothing happened in Bukeye on January 5," Nibizi affirmed.

* Insecurity continued to dominate news from Rwanda with reports late Friday that a gang of some 21 unidentified gunmen attacked a secondary school in Bumba, Mabanza commune, Kibuye prefecture, killing a night watchman. Radio Rwanda said local residents were cooperating fully with the security forces. In the troubled northwest Ruhengeri area, UN human rights monitors were still assessing the extent of the government's security sweep and terror acts by armed gangs.

* Major Western donors have written off one billion US dollars' worth of foreign debt, owed by Tanzania, expressing satisfaction with Tanzania's economic reforms. Acting Finance Minister Daniel Yona said the decision was taken by the Paris Club countries last Tuesday. He added that the remainder of the debt - $17 million US - would be repaid before the end of June. However, the move by the Paris Club would be meaningless if the government failed to collect revenue fully and if production continued to be low, he warned.

* In a bid to persuade Ugandan rebels inside Sudan to surrender, the Ugandan army has delivered thousands of letters to rebel camps stating that a presidential amnesty still stands, the state-owned New Vision newspaper reported Saturday. An army officer told the newspaper that the armed forces would give protection to any member of the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) who gave himself up. AFP said the army's attempt to talk the rebels out of the bush comes amid reports of escalating rebel activity in the West Nile. Sixty members of another rebel group, the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), managed to reach the outskirts of Kasese town in the southwest, but were beaten back by the army, a Ugandan military official said on Saturday.

Nairobi, 27 January 1997, 15:40 gmt (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. 485 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Swaziland;
South African Labor Group Meets with Swazi Federation


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Johannesburg - COSATU and the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU) met in Johannesburg on Monday the 27th of January 1997.

The SFTU delegation was made up of their President Richard Nxumalo, and General Secretary Jan Sithole. COSATU's delegation was led by the Assistant General Secretary, Zwelinzima Vavi. 

The meeting took place at the request of the SFTU which wanted to brief COSATU on the developments in Swaziland, and SFTU's decision to embark on the two day national general strike on the 3rd and 4th February 1997.

COSATU is convinced that the blame for this strike action lies squarely with the Swaziland government. Only two of the 27 demands have been met. About 20 of the demands of the workers have been ignored or refused by the Swaziland government.

The demands relating to the democratisation of Swaziland have all not been met. The King has instead appointed a hand picked committee which is supposed to review the constitution. Once the international focus shifted from Swaziland, the King followed this appointment with a decree which made the work of the committee completely secret and undemocratic.

For example the decree states the following :

(a) the constitutional review committee must not divulge to the public its work and deliberations

(b) the constitutional review committee must not report back to the public including the organisations which commissioners are members of

(c) the constitutional review committee is made up of individuals, not representatives of the people.

COSATU pledges its support and solidarity with the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions, the workers in general and the people of Swaziland.

We condemn the delaying tactics of the Swaziland government and their denial of worker and human rights in the strongest possible terms. To this end we call on COSATU members to go slow in handling the goods to and from Swaziland on the 3rd and 4th of February.

The Swaziland government is attempting to resist the inevitable. Democracy shall triumph in Swaziland whether the current privileged few like it or not. COSATU wishes to give Swaziland's undemocratic and unelected regime little advice that they should enter into genuine negotiations with the SFTU and other banned political organisations now instead of entering into negotiations when they are already on their knees.

COSATU calls on all the employers in Swaziland to give full backing to the endeavours of the Swaziland workers to democratise Swaziland. There can be no stability in Swaziland until all the demands of the Swaziland majority have been met. Certainly the status quo is not in the interests of business as well.

The vain attempts of the Swaziland government to aportion the blame to " foreign forces" is not going to help the situation. COSATU rejects with contempt these dirty tricks. The same tricks are familiar to COSATU as they were employed by the apartheid regime of the National Party.

For more information contact Mxolisi Dlamini International Relations Unit at COSATU Head Office or Jan Sithole of the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions. (09268) 52171

Issued by Nowetu Mpati COSATU Head of Communications, Tel: + 27 + 11 + 339- 4911 Fax: + 27 + 11 + 339-2281 E-mail: nowetu@cosatu.org.za


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


486 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Zaire;
UNHCR Worried About Refugees in Eastern Zaire


BYLINE: UN High Commission for Refugees


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Geneva - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees expressed grave concern today about the refugee situation in eastern Zaire.

"The options are limited and stark, and things are getting worse not better, " said High Commissioner Sadako Ogata in a statement issued in Geneva.

UNHCR is coordinating relief efforts for more than 200,000 refugees in Shabunda, Tingitingi and Amisi. It is looking at ways of repatriating those who want to go home. Delivery of emergency assistance remains difficult.In Shabunda, the airfield is waterlogged five out of seven days a week. UNHCR, the only agency present in Shabunda, has managed to set up health facilities with assistance from locals and refugees and reactivate and chlorinate water systems unused since agencies departed in December because of security conditions 

However, despite best efforts of UNHCR and its partners, Ogata said it was impossible to meet even the lifesaving needs of the most vulnerable refugees. Insurmountable logistical difficulties in operating in refugee hosting areas are compounded by lack of security for people in need and staff of international agencies.

"There is now a trickle of food coming through the international organizations," said UNHCR's Dillah Doumaye, who heads operations in the region, referring to some areas. "However, the situation is extremely precarious, and if things do not improve, we will head toward a humanitarian disaster."

Many refugees, especially children, have already died from malnutrition or disease. In addition, the refugees risk finding themselves in the midst of war, as the conflict in Zaire moves closer to them.

"While UNHCR, with its partners, is continuing to do what it can, and is in contact with authorities at the highest level, humanitarian organizations alone have little influence on events that threaten the lives of large numbers of refugees, and indeed of many Zairian civilians," Ogata said.

Another problem is that many refugees remain under the control of the former Rwandan leadership, elements of which are armed. Separation of these people and the refugees is even more difficult now than in the previous camps.

Many refugees have indicated to UNHCR that they wish to repatriate to Rwanda. But repatriation would require a safe passage through the conflict zone and security and assistance along the route.

(ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. 487 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


South Africa;
Trade Union Federation Wants Employment Standards Bill


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Johannesburg - COSATU has been involved in negotiations with government and business on the Employment Standards green paper since the Ministry of Labour released the document in February 1996.

While progress has been achieved in many areas, the gap between parties is still very wide. Many stumbling blocks have emerged with business adopting a " scatter gun" approach to the negotiations. Business main strategy has been to reverse the current rights enjoyed by workers and water down even the inadequate and minimum provisions of the green paper. They are motivated by their ideology as pronounced in the "Growth for all" policy proposals viz. labour flexibility and the two tier labour market system. 

On the other side the government has been occupying middle ground and willing to embrace some position of business under pressure. The overall policy shift in the government at macro economic level has created an extra pressure on these negotiations.

COSATU had discussed this state of affairs in its November 1996 EXCO and felt that there was a need for a sharp campaign to shift the ground. COSATU Affiliates, Regions and Locals have been asked to discuss the report on the status of negotiations. This includes areas where our constituency thinks we should modify some of our demands. The affiliates and regions will report to the EXCO scheduled for the 11-12 February 1997 where a programme of mass action will be developed.

COSATU re-iterates its demands as follows:

1. Variations - a "more favourable" test should apply which substitute the section of the act.

2. Six months maternity leave

3. 40 Hour working week should at least be introduced in the next five(5) years

4. Double pay for Sunday work and etc.

We call on all our members to attend meetings called by affiliates and regions to ensure that their views in this important matter are taken into consideration when the matter is finalised by EXCO.

Issued by Nowetu Mpati, COSATU Head of Communications, Tel: + 27 + 11 + 339-4911 Fax: + 27 + 11 + 339-2281 E-mail: nowetu@cosatu.org.za


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


488 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Zaire;
Refugees Found But Assistance May Not Reach Them


BYLINE: Refugees International (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

Washington - This urgent bulletin contains the findings and recommendations of a joint assessment mission to Zaire just completed by Refugees International and the U.S. Catholic Conference (USCC) Migration and Refugee Services. There are well over 200,000 refugees from Rwanda in the Lubutu and Shabunda areas of eastern Zaire and additional numbers of Zairian displaced persons, many of whom are clinging tenuously to life.

For three months the refugees and those internally displaced who accompanied them have been cut off from regular UN relief supplies of food and water. Owing principally to the resultant malnutrition, the health of the refugees is now declining precipitously. Many of the most vulnerable -- including infants and young children -- have already died, and more young lives are in the balance. For example, in Tingi Tingi alone, there are over 2, 000 children under five years old being kept alive with emergency supplementary feeding; more are being admitted each day. The cumulative effects of malnutrition, exhaustion and malaria will continue to cause mounting deaths among the refugees and internally displaced; nearly two- thirds of the deaths among this population have been children ages five years and under. 

The humanitarian emergency in eastern Zaire has unfolded quietly and beyond the range of TV cameras and is therefore relatively unknown. In fact, after the repatriation to Rwanda of many refugees in November, doubt had been expressed in some quarters that there were many refugees still in Zaire. There is no doubt now that they are in Zaire, but unless urgent measures are taken, many more will die. The objective of the international community should be to stabilize the refugees with emergency assistance and prepare the way for a safe repatriation to Rwanda.

The continued fighting in the area, which has intensified with the recent launch of the Zaire counteroffensive, makes immediate mass repatriation impossible and complicates the delivery of even limited, life-sustaining emergency assistance. In this context, averting a humanitarian catastrophe in eastern Zaire will require extraordinary efforts by the international community, the relief agencies and the government of Zaire. There should be additional efforts elsewhere in eastern Zaire to identify refugees still missing, but, by accounts trying to survive and return home.

Refugees International sent its president Lionel Rosenblatt along with Advocacy Associate Kirpatrick Day, and the U.S. Catholic Conference Migration and Refugee Service was represented by Shep Lowman, USCC's director of international refugee affairs. The assessment team recommends that:

* Given the extraordinary humanitarian and political stakes in eastern Zaire, the international community -- especially the U.S. -- must give much higher priority to the crisis. The prompt appointment of Mohammed Sahnoun by UN Secretary General Kofi Annan as his Special Representative for the Great Lakes (wearing both UN and OAU hats) is a welcome first step. The Special Representative's efforts to negotiate a cease-fire and to protect and provide emergency assistance to refugees should begin immediately.

* There is broad consensus that no permanent refugee camps should be established. The objective is instead to provide minimum, temporary assistance until safe repatriation can be arranged. Supplies should be distributed through an ad hoc structure created by the relief agencies; the former commune structure, which exercised so much control in the former camps, must not be entrusted with distribution. Consideration should be given to a possible security role for the remaining element of the CZSC, the contingent assigned to and paid by UNHCR. Strong diplomatic pressure should be placed on the governments of Rwanda and Uganda to obtain rebel cooperation with any further overland repatriation to Rwanda.

* The key to providing emergency assistance in time to avert massive loss of life will be to expand the delivery of the needed humanitarian supplies, equipment and personnel. While we understand Zaire's current preoccupation with the counter-offensive, the need for immediate, expanded access for relief flights is absolutely vital. Perhaps, opening up the use of the second, smaller airport at Kisangani would facilitate this if the flight slots for the regular airport cannot be immediately expanded.

* The logistical obstacles to supplying the refugees are formidable. The road from Kisangani to the Lubutu area (where most of the refugees are located) is poor, and trucks take at least 4-5 days to make the round trip. Unfortunately there are presently virtually no usable trucks on the ground. Hence, in addition to expanding cargo flights into Kisangani, smaller aircraft are required to shuttle between Kisangani and the refugee/displaced sites. Measures to maintain (and perhaps expand) the runways at Amisi and Shabunda will be needed. Donors should signal immediately to WFP and the other UN agencies their willingness to fund the complex logistical measures required. In this regard, we were heartened to learn of the long-awaited decision to send an OFDA assessment mission to Zaire and look forward to a positive and generous U.S. response to the UN appeal for emergency assistance in eastern Zaire.

* To reach the 30-40,000 refugees and displaced at Shabunda is particularly difficult. Light, DC-3 type aircraft land on a grass strip, which is damp and deteriorating even under the existing, light pressure. Flour sacks are then put on bicycles to a small river, where they are transshipped by canoe and re- loaded on bicycles. When the track gets too rough, the sacks are loaded on the backs of the refugees for the last stretch. The refugees and displaced are surviving by eating manioc leaves. Less than five tons of supplies have made it in to Shabunda. Given this logistical "cul de sac," we urgently recommend that the Zaire authorities, in consultation with UN officials, identify a more sustainable (and more secure) site for the Shabunda population and facilitate an immediate movement of the population by foot, before they weaken any further.

* Cholera is already present at Tingi Tingi, underscoring the high priority which should be given to bringing in emergency water pumps and chlorination means to use the existing available river water. Thus far, the cholera has been of a relatively less virulent strain, or mortality rates would already be even higher. The UN agencies require immediate assurances of funding to bring in the emergency water measures needed. Technical personnel are also needed to implement the measures at each site.

* Internally displaced Zairians (IDPs) and local villagers who are also struggling to survive should receive additional assistance. Some of this might be channeled in a way to strengthen local capacity. For example, a food for work program might be set up under which IDPs and affected villagers would assist in the repair of roads; such an approach would be cost-effective and could begin quickly.

* UNHCR, in conjunction with the governments of Zaire and Rwanda, should arrange for repatriation by air for vulnerables, including orphans and unaccompanied minors. Those at Shabunda are in especially poor condition, suffering from malnutrition, exhaustion and malaria.

* The concentrations in the Lubutu and Shabunda areas do not constitute the sum total of "lost" refugees in eastern Zaire, and focus must also be placed on other pockets of refugees. For example, up to 2,000 refugees are now returning each day to Cyangugu, Rwanda from the Bukavu area. Given that, unlike in the north (Goma area), a significant repatriation channel did not open up in South Kivu, it is logical to assume that at least tens of thousands more may be present in that area, especially west and south of Bukavu. Other missing refugees from the Uvira/Fizi areas may well still be further to the south. Efforts to locate them and assist a safe return (in conjunction with the rebels) should be taken by UN agencies, ICRC and others.

In sum, much more urgent and effective emergency assistance measures need to be put in place to enable minimum, life-sustaining assistance to get to the refugees and displaced in time. We call on the government of Zaire (and rebel leaders as necessary), donor governments and UN authorities to expedite the emergency humanitarian efforts along the lines described above. The situation is so complex and urgent that coordination within the UN must be tightened, preferably through the appointment of an emergency field coordinator with full authority to mobilize the UN agencies on the ground. The world wasn't much interested when hundreds of thousands of refugees were dispersed into the forest. Will it save them, now that many of the "lost" refugees have been found?

ENDS Report 17, January 27, 1997

For information, contact David Shorr (202) 828-0110. Refugees International, 2639 Conn. Ave, NW, Washington, DC 20008. www: http://www.refintl.org

Africa News


January 28, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (1/20 - 1/26)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Geneva - 16.01.97 Special Committee on Decolonization

In a message addressed to the "Special Committee of 24", the UN-Secretary- General underlines that is "a particular need to support the MINURSO in the execution of its mandate on the holding of a free and fair referendum in what is the largest Territory on the Special Committee's agenda".

17. - 19.01.97 ECOSY Congress

The third European Congress of Socialist Youth adopts in Strasbourg the following resolution, proposed by Juventude Socialista, Portugal: ECOSY, reaffirming its attitude supporting the legitimate right of the sahrawi people to self-determination and independence, denounces the difficulties to implement a political solution and calls on the international community, the UN, OUA and European Union to:

* create the optimal conditions for the realisation of a fair, democratic and transparent referendum on self-determination;

* to support every initiative to create conditions for the direct dialogue between the two parties of the conflict, Morocco and the Polisario Front;

* to spare no effort ensuring the full implementation of the UN-OUA Peace Plan; denounces the situation of isolation of the occupied territories;

* organise one campaign to permit free access of international human rights organisation personalities like the Nobel Peace Prize to the occupied Western Sahara. 

19. - 21.01.97 Revive the UN

The visit in Switzerland of the Sahrawi MINURSO coordinator intended to present to the government a demand for good offices for a mediation and the search of a place for further negociations with Morocco.The Swiss authorities declared to be willing to study this demand. In occasion of different declarations Bachir Mustafa Sayed precised the conditions of the last September meetings with Morocco.

He considers on the Moroccan side a real will of dialog does exist, which is confirmed by the involvment of the Crown Prince. The dialog should continue on the base of written proposals - a totally new approach. The Sahrawis keep some hope despite Morocco tries to extend indefinitely the cease-fire, attempts to neutralize the international pressures it is undergoing, and tries to put the Polisario Front to sleep, while making great diplomatic efforts to lessen the international recognition of SADR.

There was a new appointment for talks but it did not happen for lack of a mediator and a neutral place. The Sahrawi responsible declared that in a short-term the UN have to revive. Its new Secretary-General is willing to move forward. At the meeting mid-February with Mr. Kofi Annan, the Sahrawis will ask for the reinforcement of the MINURSO, which has to be removed of the Moroccan influence. The UN are involved by the Peace Plan, he added, and remain responsible of the matter. The Sahrawis are asking for supports in order to continue the negociations under fair conditions.

24.01.97 Regionalization

Following the adoption of the constitutional referendum of Sept. 13, 1996, the Moroccan Prime Minister transmits to the Parliament the draft bill on regionalization.

NEW PUBLICATIONS

Der "vergessene" Westsahara-Konflikt, Christen Anton, NZZ, CH-Z/rich, 23.01. 97, p. 5. Trdgt die Uno unter ihrem neuen Generalsekretdr Kofi Annan frischen Wind in die Westsahara ?, L/thi Walter, Der Bund, CH-Bern, 25.01.97, p. 5.

LANGUAGE: English
