490 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 88 on the Great Lakes (01/28)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1800 words


 

Nairobi - As fighting continues in eastern Zaire, ministers from six African states and the OAU are holding talks in Pretoria, South Africa, to prepare for a summit on the Great Lakes crisis. The talks - which began on Monday - follow a summit in Nairobi on December 16 1996 where Kenya, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Cameroon were mandated to spearhead peace efforts.

Kenya's Foreign Minister Stephen Musyoka chaired the meeting; others attending were South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, Zimbabwe's Stanley Mudenge, Cameroon's Deputy Foreign Minister Francis Nkwain, Tanzania's Foreign Minister Jakaya Kikwete, Congo's Destin Tatsa-Mboungou, and the Organisation of African Unity's assistant secretary general, Daniel Antonio. Reuters report that South African foreign ministry officials hope to set up a summit of the presidents of the so-called "peace quartet", which are those of South Africa, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Cameroon. The four presidents hope to enter into dialogue with leaders in Zaire, Burundi and Rwanda. 

* The "massive counter-offensive" threatened by the Zairean army appears to be severely hampered by the logistics of re-supply, report AFP. AFP say local sources link the slow-down of the government's counter-offensive to problems of resupplying troops with weapons and ammunition by air, as no ground corridor has been established. Observers also point to controversy regarding soldiers' salaries, as the end of the month approaches. Demoralised Zairean soldiers, who earn an average of one dollar a month, have not been paid in months and have already staged two rebellions in Kinshasa. Fourteen soldiers were sentenced to death in Kinshasa for cowardice last week (January 21).

* Rwandan Defence Minister and Vice-President Paul Kagame remarked today that while he was taking threats regarding the Zairean counter-offensive seriously, the Zairean government seemed to be "more talk than action". Kagame told journalists at Kigali airport that the ADFL rebels appeared to be winning. He was seeing off Benjamin Mkapa, President of Tanzania, following two days of talks on the Great Lakes region.

* Belgian Christian Taverniers, leader of the 280 white mercenaries reportedly spearheading Kinshasa's counter-offensive, has been quoted as calling for Kigali and Kinshasa to "reach a political solution before the hostilities really start". The Belgian daily Le Soir printed an interview with Taverniers on Monday, in which he suggested former Belgian Prime Minister Leo Tindemans as mediator. Taverniers claimed the white mercenaries were funded by Kuwait and consisted of "specialists" in bush and counter- guerrilla warfare; he said the force included Serbs and Croats but claimed there was no European power involved and that there were no Angolans or South Africans "in the game". The interview took an aggressive stance towards Rwanda, with Taverniers warning Rwandan Defence Minister Paul Kagame that Rwanda would not be attacked "if he withdraws his troops from Zaire". Taverniers was quoted by Le Soir as saying "even if there are Zaireans in the opposing forces, I consider that Rwanda and even Uganda are leading the dance" . Christian Taverniers is reported to be a friend of one of Africa's most notorious mercenaries, Bob Denard, who twice briefly took over the leadership of Comoros Island in the last decade.

* US-based Refugees International says that continued fighting in eastern Zaire prohibits mass repatriation of remaining refugees and complicates the delivery of even the most basic assistance. According to a bulletin issued by Refugees International yesterday (Monday January 27) there are at least 200, 000 refugees from Rwanda in Lubutu and Shabunda, eastern Zaire, "clinging tenuously to life", as well as unknown numbers of Zairean displaced persons. RI say those affected have been cut off from regular relief supplies of food and water and that declining health has led to deaths among the most vulnerable. Recommendations made by an RI assessment team include: immediate efforts by UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes Mohammed Sahnoun to negotiate a cease-fire; to avoid creation of permanent camps but supply minimum temporary assistance through an ad hoc structure created by relief agencies; expand access for relief fights; increase emergency assistance and equipment. RI documents the considerable obstacles in getting supplies into eastern Zaire, describing the poor condition of airstrips, the laborious transportation of sacks by bicycle and canoe, and the need for refugees to carry the sacks on their backs where vehicles fail to pass.

* A statement issued by UNHCR (24 January) stresses the problems of delivering aid to more than 200,000 refugees in Shabunda, Tingi-Tingi and Amisi. High Commissioner Sadako Ogata says that despite "best efforts" it is impossible to meet "even the life saving needs of the most vulnerable refugees". UNHCR says many refugees, especially children, have already died from malnutrition and disease. The statement underlines the fact that many refugees "remain under the control of the former Rwandan leadership, elements of which are armed". UNHCR states that seperation of refugees from armed elements "is even more difficult now than in the previous camps". The statement says that many of the refugees have indicated to UNHCR that they wish to repatriate to Rwanda, but are trapped by the conflict zone.

In the view of an unclassified cable from the US embassy in Rwanda, dated 21 January 1997, agencies should pull out (from Tingi-Tingi) and "stop feeding the killers, who will then run away to look for other sustenance leaving their hostages behind." The dispatch concludes "If we do not, we will be trading the children in Tingi-Tingi against the children who will be killed and orphaned in Rwanda". Having faced widespread accusation that aid to refugee camps between 1994-1996 in eastern Zaire was fundamental to sustaining armed groups and preventing repatriation, humanitarian organisations and donors feel sensitive about appearing to re-create similar situtions. Moreover, since the crisis of repatriation from eastern Zaire last year, the Rwandan government has stressed the need for available resources to go to re-integration.

UNICEF records deaths in Tingi-Tingi as a total of 27 on January 21 and a total of 21 on January 22. Out of these 48 deaths, 21 were under the age of five. 250 severely malnourished children are being fed in the therapeutic centre in Tingi-Tingi, and 2,300 children are receiving supplementary feeding.

* Burundian politicians opened a debate today to discuss the country's three year civil war; the debate was declared "national" but major parties, including all predominantly Hutu groups, boycotted the session. Rebels from the National Council for the Defence of Democracy (CNDD) were not invited to the talks, and have been told to first renounce violence. Burundian leader, Pierre Buyoya, opened the four-day meeting in Bujumbura, which is intended to be the first step in a national debate lasting until March. Buyoya has been told he must talk to rebels before regional sanctions are lifted - which he has not complied with, but not ruled out. Buyoya said that regional sanctions were "killing' chances for peace rather than encouraging it.

Spokesman for CNDD, Jerome Ndiho, claimed in a statement sent to Nairobi today from Brussels that CNDD's armed wing had killed 61 army troops in the past nine days, reports AFP. Ndiho dismissed claims by the government that its forces had seized large numbers of rebel weapons in an offensive in Kibira forest, northwest Burundi, a known rebel hideout.

* A UNICEF-led inter-agency assessment mission visited northeast Kenya last week to investigate the current drought situation and its effects on the population, assess current relief assistance efforts and determine the scope of a future UN response. The mission, which visited Garissa, Isiolo, Wajir and Mandera districts, included the UN Resident Coordinator and representatives of the Office of the President, USAID, WFP and UNDHA/IRIN.

The failure of successive rains in the northeast has inhibited the regeneration of vegetation and led to water shortages for both humans and livestock. Water is scarce in the aridland of the northeast, and pans and dams are swiftly drying up, while boreholes are coming under pressure because of overuse and the inability of communities to afford diesel and spare parts. The lack of vegetation and water has lead to worsening livestock health and a dramatic fall in livestock prices, eroding the purchasing power of pastoralist communities. Malnutrition is on the increase and there are growing concerns over the health of vulnerable groups.

The mission recommended an escalated relief programme to address the drought situation, including interventions in the food, water, health and livestock sectors. The team have also set forth recommendations to the Government of Kenya, including the lifting of the import tax on maize, road improvements before the onset of the next rainy season, and measures to subsidize communities' efforts to pay for the costs of food transport, health care and education during the crisis period. A full mission report will be made available to the donor community in the coming weeks.

Nairobi, 28 January 1997, 15:25 GMT (ENDS)

Africa News


January 28, 1997


Science and Health;
New Outbreak of Ebola in Gabon


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Geneva - Ebola haemorrhagic fever Gabon. As of 15 January 1997, 59 cases, including 44 deaths and 15 cases who have recovered, have occurred since the beginning of the Ebola outbreak in late July 1996 in the Booue area. 

There is no hospitalized case either in Booue or Libreville. The last case died on 8 January 1997. Libreville: 14 cases, including 10 deaths. Forty- eight contacts within the city are still being followed up.

The geographic distribution of the contacts were the areas of Okala, Owendo, Nzeng-Ayong, Gros Bouquet, Plaine Orety, Casepga and Melen hospital (5 healthy contacts, including 3 children admitted for closer follow up). Booue area, including Makokou: 44 cases, including 33 deaths.

Currently 54 contacts are being followed up in Makokou, Booue, Lolo I, Lolo II, Djidji, SHM sawmill, Lassio, Ndjole and Matora. Lambarene: 1 case who died. Four contacts are currently being followed up.

All contact subjects under follow-up are visited daily for temperature checks. Three quarters of them will be discharged from follow-up early next week as their follow-up period will have reached the maximum incubation period (i.e. 21 days). The epidemiological situation remains stable with no evidence of transmission in Libreville other than the episode which involved a Gabonese physician who flew to South Africa last October.

Next week, the team of Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) currently in Libreville will visit the Booue area. WHO Headquarters remains in daily contact with the Ministry of Health of Gabon and is also regularly kept informed of the situation through other channels including the French Cooperation in Libreville, MSF, and the Gabonese Red Cross.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


January 28, 1997


Business and Finance;
Currencies: Ghana Cedi Depreciates Further


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Ghanaian cedi continued its "creeping depreciation" this week, opening Monday at the average exchange rate of 1,753 to one U.S. dollar from an average of 1,746 to the greenback last week.

Dealers attribute the continued depreciation of the cedi to the scarcity of hard currency for the settlement of the country's huge import bills.

The cedi exchange at 353 to the dollar in 1991. 

Elsewhere, the CFA franc continued to fall against the dollar, exchanging Tuesday at the nominal rate of 557 to the greenback. The West African state of Guinea-Bissau became the 14th member of the CFA zone when it joined the pack of former French colonies on 1 January. The currency, which is supported by the French treasury, will begin circulating in May.

In Dakar on Tuesday the currency exchanged at 542 (buying) and 575 (selling) to one greenback. On the same day last week the bank's rates were 533 (buying) and 551 (selling) to the dollar.

The Following were the nominal exchange rates of African currencies against the U.S. dollar (current rates for such volatile currencies as the New Zaire and Angola's adjusted kwanza were not available):

493 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Guinea;
Guinea Offers To Mediate In Bakassi Dispute


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Guinea has offered to mediate in the dispute between Nigeria and Cameroon over ownership of the Bakassi Peninsula, the United Nations has said.

U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard, who made the announcement Monday, said that Cameroon and Nigeria had accepted Guinea's offer. 

Eckhard said that the Guinean foreign minister, Lamine Kamara, was in New York to consult with the U.N. assistant secretary-general for political affairs, Lansana Kouyate, over the issue.

Kamara is also expected to meet with U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to discuss ways of resolving the dispute, which has flared up repeatedly since 1994.

Togo has also been involved in past mediation efforts.

In 1996, during a visit of to Cameroon and Nigeria and to the disputed peninsula by a U.N. goodwill mission, the belligerents proposed measures aimed at improving relations between them.

These include immediate steps to reduce border military tension and the introduction of confidence-building steps involving cooperation in the economic and cultural fields.

A ruling on the ownership of the peninsula, thought to be rich in petroleum and fish, is pending at the International Court of Justice at The Hague, where it was referred for arbitration by Cameroon.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


494 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Business and Finance;
Southern African Trade On The Increase


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - Regional trade among the 12 states of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) has increased by almost 12. 5 percent since South Africa and Mauritius joined the organization, a reports by the community released recently says.

The report released in Gaborone, and published by the South African media, says that peace in Southern Africa and the introduction of trade liberalization measures have led to the notable increase in intra-regional trade.

The document, which is to be submitted next week to the SADC consultative conference in Windhoek, says the regional countries of Southern Africa are trading favorably in agricultural products, mining, food products, textiles, clothing, beverages, wood products and industrial chemicals. 

Identified obstacles to trade in the region are an inadequate production base, inadequate trade policies and market access, insufficient market skill, underdeveloped financial infrastructure, and inadequate trade statistics and information.

Another report to be submitted to the conference, and concentrating on trade and industry, says that low savings have hampered the level of investment in the region.

Average regional saving capacity is below 20 percent, the report says, because most SADC countries are underdeveloped and suffer negative real interest rates, high investment risks and low returns, scarce finance and an absence of secondary markets.

The report says that intra-regional investment was being further restricted by complicated exchange control regulations often unfamiliar in the commercial banking sector. It says the cross-border flow of labor in the SADC region is still legally restricted and in some countries there are considerable delays in the issue of work permits to foreign investors.

There is a need for the SADC states to improve their tax regimes considerably, the report adds, as they are cumbersome and generally lack transparency.

The states that make up SADC are Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


495 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Mozambique;
Mozambican, South African Police Cooperate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - South African and Mozambican policemen have recovered at least 100 cars in the central Beira and 50 others in Chimoio, suspected to have been stolen from South Africa.

A usually informed Maputo publication, Mediafax, reported Tuesday that the cars were seized in joint patrols which began at the weekend.

Mediafax, published by a cooperative of Mozambican journalists, quoted sources in the port city of Beira as saying that about 20 South African policemen were involved in the exercise. 

Neither the South African Embassy, nor the general command of the Mozambican Police, were prepared to give details about the operation.

But the unnamed Beira sources told the newspaper that the South Africans began working over the weekend in groups of two, each accompanied by one armed Mozambican policeman and two unarmed traffic police.

The joint police units stop any car which they suspect and check the engine number. They then radio a mobile communications unit to check whether or not the car is stolen.

If the engine number is on the list of stolen vehicles, the car is immediately seized and taken to parking lots set up for this operation.

Some drivers of stolen vehicles have been detained, although some have protested that they purchased the cars in good faith.

The police have also entered private garages without search warrants and are using master keys to open parked vehicles in the absence of their owners.

Officials at the South African Embassy in Maputo would say nothing other than that the operation is being undertaken simultaneously in four Southern African Development Community (SADC) states.

"We have to maintain secrecy if the operation is to be a success," the official said.

The general commander of the Mozambican Police, Pascoal Ronda, declined immediate comment.

South African policemen have, recently, also operated in neighbouring Zambia in an effort to stem the rising wave of drug trafficking.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


496 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria-Russia Steel Project Still On Course


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's five-billion-U.S.-dollar Ajaokuta steel project, being constructed by the Russian firm, TPE, is proceeding according plan, the country's Power and Steel Ministry said Tuesday.

"The bilateral relationship between Russia and Nigeria on (the) Ajaokuta project has indeed grown from strength to strength over the years from the design stage to its present state," said Ine Dappa, the ministry's spokesperson. 

This was in reaction to a recent report by a section of the Nigerian media, quoting officials of the ministry, to the effect that the project contract had been terminated over unpaid bills.

Dappa said a meeting of the ministry's officials and TPE "is scheduled to hold in Nigeria shortly."

She said Nigeria had settled "a substantial part of its debt on the project, " which is believed to have reached 98 percent completion.

Operational hitches had delayed the 1983 completion of the gigantic steel project, conceived in the 1960s to launch Nigeria into industrial age.

However, several units of the project, located in central Nigeria, have been completed. They are producing rods and other steel and foundry products.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


497 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Sports - Soccer;
Nigerian Football Assoc Names New Coaches


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian sports authorities have appointed Monday Sinclair as the new local Chief national soccer coach, replacing the sacked Shuaibu Amodu.

Announcing the changes on Monday, Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo said Sinclair, a Nigerian, who has handled several of the country's professional clubs, was taking over from the sacked Shuaibu Amodu.

Amodu lost his job on Monday because of his interviews to the media in which he complained about the pampering of foreign coaches by FA officials, who failed to provide the same financial resources local coaches assigned to handle national teams. 

But Nwobodo insisted that a foreign technical adviser would be hired within three weeks to prepare the national team for crucial World Cup qualification matches.

Four of Amodu's former assistants were also fired.

Sinclair, who was previously manager of Sharks of Port Harcourt, is to be assisted by James Peters, former coach of Nigeria's junior team.

Tunde Disu, former head of the FA's technical crew, returns as chief coach of the junior team, the Flying Eagles.

Nwobodo said the association retained Paul Hamilton and Fanny Amu as coaches for the under-21 and under-17 squads.

He also named former Nigerian internationals Emmanuel Okala, Best Ogedegbe and Muzambilu Aliyu as goalkeeper trainers for the three national teams.

Nwobodo also named Donatus Ohagwu as deputy to Sani Toro, the secretary- general of the Nigerian Football Association.

The changes came in the wake of poor performances by the national teams, which deflated the country's soccer pride, gained from the country's Olympic gold victory in 1996.

Soccer analysts in Lagos attributed Amodu's sacking to his war of words with soccer administrators over the plan to hire of a foreign technical adviser to replace Johannes Bonfrere of the Netherlands.

The Dutchman abruptly ended his contract with Nigeria shortly after leading the country's under-23 squad to win the Olympic soccer gold.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


498 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 28, 1997


Nigeria;
Task Force Established To Solve Lagos Fuel Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian authorities set up a task force Tuesday to help end a crippling fuel scarcity in Lagos, the nation's commercial capital.

It is headed by Maj. Gen. Timothy Shepidi, the chief of training and operations in the Defence Headquarters. 

The acting director of defence information, Col. Godwin Ugbo, told reporters in Lagos that members of the force had met with the petroleum resources minister, Dan Etete, and officials of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation on the crisis.

Ugvo said the week-long shortage, limited to Lagos, could ease within days.

The Lagos military administrator, Col. Mohammed Marwa, met with Etete Monday and expressed concern that the fuel shortage could undermine security in this city of some six million people.

The shortage has paralysed business, leaving motorists and commuters groaning.

Nigeria, an oil-producing country, experiences occasional fuel scarcity. These have been blamed partly on hoarding, smuggling and distribution or maintenance difficulties. At times, the country has had to import petrol to bridge the shortfall in local supply.

The current shortage is attributed to a payment disagreement between the Nigerian Ports Authority and the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, and between the corporation and oil marketers.


LOAD-DATE: January 30, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


499 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 29, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: EU-WFP to purchase grain from local markets


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The European Union (EU) and the World

Food Programme are now issuing bid notices to purchase close

to 900,000 quintals of grain for relief aid from local

markets, the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness

Commission(DPPC) said.

The DPPC has been lobbying with donors to respond to its

demand for relief aid to mitigate food shortage in some areas

through purchasing grain at reasonable price locally, it

said. 

The commission said, the increase in the supply of inputs

and the normal distribution of rainfall in the past two years

has enabled farmers boost production.

The EU has almost completed the purchase from local market

of over a million quintals of grain in line with its decision

last year, according to the commission.

The government, it said, is presently extending the

necessary assistance to donor organization in accordance to

their demand to buy par of the relief aid for neighbouring

countries from Ethiopian farmers.

It called on farmers to timely supply the grain for sale.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


500 of 607 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 29, 1997


Business and Finance;
Paris Club Provides Debt Relief for Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Paris Club of Creditor nations

have agreed on a 67 per cent debt relief for Ethiopia, the

National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) announced yesterday. 

A spokesman of the NBE told ENA that an Ethiopian

delegation comprising senior government officials has left to

Paris to negotiate on the debt relief.

In a statement the Paris Club issued in Paris yesterday

said the debt relief given to Ethiopia was the most generous

terms of debt reduction currently provided to the world's

poorest nations.

Further information on the debt relief will be available

following the return home of the delegation, according to the

spokesman.


LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
